text:
I wandered lonely as a cloud
That floats on high o'er vales and hills,
When all at once I saw a crowd,
A host, of golden daffodils;
Beside the lake, beneath the trees,
Fluttering and dancing in the breeze.
poem_title: I Wandered Lonely As A Cloud (Daffodils)
explanation: I walked by myself like a cloud that hovers over valleys and hills when suddenly I came across a group of golden daffodils swaying and moving in the wind by the lake and under the trees.

text:
Continuous as the stars that shine
And twinkle on the milky way,
They stretched in never-ending line
Along the margin of a bay:
Ten thousand saw I at a glance,
Tossing their heads in sprightly dance.
poem_title: I Wandered Lonely As A Cloud (Daffodils)
explanation: I saw a never-ending line of waves along the shore of a bay, as numerous as the stars that twinkle on the milky way. There were so many that I couldn't count them all, but they were all dancing joyfully and tossing their heads in unison.

text:
The waves beside them danced; but they
Out-did the sparkling waves in glee:
A poet could not but be gay,
In such a jocund company:
I gazed- and gazed- but little thought
What wealth the show to me had brought:
poem_title: I Wandered Lonely As A Cloud (Daffodils)
explanation: The waves danced beside them, but the couple was even more joyful. A poet couldn't help but feel happy in their lively presence. As the speaker watched them, they didn't realize at the time how much this experience would mean to them.

text:
For oft, when on my couch I lie
In vacant or in pensive mood,
They flash upon that inward eye
Which is the bliss of solitude;
And then my heart with pleasure fills,
And dances with the daffodils.
poem_title: I Wandered Lonely As A Cloud (Daffodils)
explanation: Sometimes, when I am lying on my couch in a state of relaxation or contemplation, memories of daffodils come to mind and fill me with joy. These memories bring a sense of blissful solitude to my heart and cause it to dance with happiness.

text:
I marvel how Nature could ever find space
For so many strange contrasts in one human face:
There's thought and no thought, and there's paleness and bloom
And bustle and sluggishness, pleasure and gloom.
explanation: It is amazing to me how Nature can fit so many opposing qualities into one human face. There can be both intelligence and vacancy, as well as both a lack of color and a bright radiance. There can be both energy and lethargy, as well as both happiness and sadness.

text:
There's weakness, and strength both redundant and vain;
Such strength as, if ever affliction and pain
Could pierce through a temper that's soft to disease,
Would be rational peace--a philosopher's ease.
explanation: Both weakness and strength are useless and meaningless. Even if one possesses great strength, it is of no use when faced with affliction and pain. The only true strength lies in developing a peaceful temperament that can withstand the hardships of life with ease, like that of a philosopher.

The person described exhibits an attitude of indifference towards both success and failure, and receives an excessive amount of attention. They experience pride without envy, and have a balance of both assertiveness and shyness.

text:
There's freedom, and sometimes a diffident stare
Of shame scarcely seeming to know that she's there,
There's virtue, the title it surely may claim,
Yet wants heaven knows what to be worthy the name.
explanation: Freedom and shame coexist, with the latter seeming unaware of the former's presence. Virtue is present but lacks certain qualities necessary to truly deserve the title.

text:
This picture from nature may seem to depart,
Yet the Man would at once run away with your heart;
And I for five centuries right gladly would be
Such an odd such a kind happy creature as he.
explanation: The image of this creature found in nature may appear strange, but it has the ability to capture one's heart. The speaker expresses their desire to be like this creature for the next five centuries due to its odd yet kind nature.

text:
She dwelt among the untrodden ways
Beside the springs of Dove,
Maid whom there were none to praise
And very few to love:
poem_title: She Dwelt Among The Untrodden Ways
explanation: This poem describes a woman who lived in a secluded place, near the springs of Dove. She was a maid who nobody praised or loved, except for a few.

text:
A violet by a mossy stone
Half hidden from the eye!
---Fair as a star, when only one
Is shining in the sky.
poem_title: She Dwelt Among The Untrodden Ways
explanation: A beautiful violet is growing by a mossy stone, but it is partially hidden from view. The violet is as lovely as a lone star shining in the sky.

text:
She lived unknown, and few could know
When Lucy ceased to be;
But she is in her grave, and, oh,
The difference to me!
poem_title: She Dwelt Among The Untrodden Ways
explanation: Lucy had lived her life in obscurity, and her passing went unnoticed by most. However, now that she has been laid to rest, her absence is deeply felt by the speaker.

text:
It was an April morning: fresh and clear
The Rivulet, delighting in its strength,
Ran with a young man's speed; and yet the voice
Of waters which the winter had supplied
Was softened down into a vernal tone.
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: The morning of April was refreshing and the Rivulet flowed swiftly like a young man. Despite being fed by winter waters, the sound of the stream was now gentler and more suitable for springtime.

text:
The spirit of enjoyment and desire,
And hopes and wishes, from all living things
Went circling, like a multitude of sounds.
The budding groves seemed eager to urge on
The steps of June; as if their various hues
Were only hindrances that stood between
Them and their object: but, meanwhile, prevailed
Such an entire contentment in the air
That every naked ash, and tardy tree
Yet leafless, showed as if the countenance
With which it looked on this delightful day
Were native to the summer.--Up the brook
I roamed in the confusion of my heart,
Alive to all things and forgetting all.
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: The joy and desire of all living things, along with their hopes and wishes, seemed to fill the air like a chorus of sounds. The groves were eager for June to arrive, as if their various colors were the only thing standing in the way of their desire. However, there was a sense of complete contentment in the atmosphere, causing even the naked ash and leafless trees to appear as though they belonged in the summer. Lost in the moment, I wandered along the brook, fully alive to everything and forgetting all else.

text:
At length I to a sudden turning came
In this continuous glen, where down a rock
The Stream, so ardent in its course before,
Sent forth such sallies of glad sound, that all
Which I till then had heard, appeared the voice
Of common pleasure: beast and bird, the lamb,
The shepherd's dog, the linnet and the thrush
Vied with this waterfall, and made a song,
Which, while I listened, seemed like the wild growth
Or like some natural produce of the air,
That could not cease to be. Green leaves were here;
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: I walked along the glen until I reached a sudden bend where a stream flowed down a rock, creating a joyful sound that was unlike anything I had heard before. It seemed to be the source of all the pleasure in the area, as the animals and birds, including lambs, dogs, linnets, and thrushes, sang along with it, creating a song that felt like it was a natural part of the environment. The sound was so captivating that it seemed like it was a wild and organic creation of the air that couldn't be stopped. The area was lush with green leaves and the experience was a tranquil and peaceful one.

text:
But 'twas the foliage of the rocks--the birch,
The yew, the holly, and the bright green thorn,
With hanging islands of resplendent furze:
And, on a summit, distant a short space,
By any who should look beyond the dell,
A single mountain-cottage might be seen.
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: The rocks were covered in a variety of foliage, including birch, yew, holly, and thorn. Islands of vibrant furze hung from the rocks. A mountain-cottage could be seen on a summit, but only if one looked beyond the dell and a short distance away.

text:
I gazed and gazed, and to myself I said,
'Our thoughts at least are ours; and this wild nook,
My EMMA, I will dedicate to thee.'
----Soon did the spot become my other home,
My dwelling, and my out-of-doors abode.
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: The speaker looked intently at a place and thought that even though everything in the world may not belong to them, their thoughts do. They decided to dedicate the spot to Emma. After spending some time there, it became a second home to the speaker, where they lived and spent time outside.

text:
And, of the Shepherds who have seen me there,
To whom I sometimes in our idle talk
Have told this fancy, two or three, perhaps,
Years after we are gone and in our graves,
When they have cause to speak of this wild place,
May call it by the name of EMMA'S DELL.
poem_title: It Was An April Morning: Fresh And Clear
explanation: Some of the Shepherds who have seen me in a certain place, which I have referred to as "Emma's Dell" in casual conversation, may remember it by that name in the future. This may happen years later when they have reason to mention the location.

poem_title: The World Is Too Much With Us; Late And Soon
explanation: The speaker laments that humanity is too consumed with materialism and disregards the beauty of nature. We waste our energy on acquiring possessions and overlook the natural world that belongs to us. Our hearts have been given away in exchange for a selfish and shallow existence. The sea, which reveals itself to the moon, is an example of the natural world that we fail to appreciate.

poem_title: The World Is Too Much With Us; Late And Soon
explanation: The winds are going to be howling constantly, and they are currently as still as flowers that are resting. We are not in harmony with anything, including this state of being. It doesn't affect us. I would prefer to be a Pagan who was raised in an outdated belief system rather than feeling out of tune with the world.

poem_title: The World Is Too Much With Us; Late And Soon
explanation: Standing on a beautiful meadow, I could have moments of joy and feel less lonely. I may see the mythical figure of Proteus emerging from the sea, or hear the sound of Triton's twisted horn.

text:
Calm is all nature as a resting wheel.
The kine are couched upon the dewy grass;
The horse alone, seen dimly as I pass,
Is cropping audibly his later meal:
Dark is the ground; a slumber seems to steal
O'er vale, and mountain, and the starless sky.
poem_title: Calm Is All Nature As A Resting Wheel
explanation: The atmosphere is tranquil as if everything in nature is at rest, with the cattle lying down on the damp grass, and the only sound is the audible chewing of the horse as I walk by. The ground is dark, and a feeling of sleepiness seems to cover the valleys, mountains, and the sky, which is devoid of stars.

text:
Now, in this blank of things, a harmony,
Home-felt, and home-created, comes to heal
That grief for which the senses still supply
Fresh food; for only then, when memory
Is hushed, am I at rest. My Friends! restrain
Those busy cares that would allay my pain;
Oh! leave me to myself, nor let me feel
The officious touch that makes me droop again.
poem_title: Calm Is All Nature As A Resting Wheel
explanation: In the midst of emptiness, a sense of comfort and peace arises from within, bringing solace to the sorrow that lingers on. Only when the mind is free from the burden of memories can one truly find rest. The speaker implores their friends to refrain from trying to ease their pain, as it only serves to prolong their suffering. Allow them to be alone and find their own way through the pain.

text:
Behold her, single in the field,
Yon solitary Highland Lass!
Reaping and singing by herself;
Stop here, or gently pass!
Alone she cuts and binds the grain,
And sings a melancholy strain;
O listen! for the Vale profound
Is overflowing with the sound.
explanation: Look at her, alone in the field, that Highland girl. She is harvesting and singing all by herself. You can either stop and watch, or simply pass by quietly. She works alone, cutting and bundling the grain while singing a sad tune. Listen closely, as her voice echoes through the deep valley, filling it with sound.

text:
No Nightingale did ever chaunt
More welcome notes to weary bands
Of travellers in some shady haunt,
Among Arabian sands:
A voice so thrilling ne'er was heard
In spring-time from the Cuckoo-bird,
Breaking the silence of the seas
Among the farthest Hebrides.
explanation: The Nightingale's song is the most soothing and pleasant sound for tired travelers resting in a cool spot amidst the sandy Arabian landscape. No other sound can rival its beauty, not even the sweet melody of the Cuckoo-bird heard during springtime, which breaks the stillness of the waves near the distant Hebrides.

text:
Will no one tell me what she sings?--
Perhaps the plaintive numbers flow
For old, unhappy, far-off things,
And battles long ago:
Or is it some more humble lay,
Familiar matter of to-day?
Some natural sorrow, loss, or pain,
That has been, and may be again?
explanation: The speaker seeks to know what the woman is singing about. He wonders if it's a sad song about past events, such as old battles or distant memories. Alternatively, it could be a simple song about current everyday topics. He ponders whether the song is about a common experience like heartbreak, grief, or pain that is relatable to many people and may be experienced again in the future.

text:
Whate'er the theme, the Maiden sang
As if her song could have no ending;
I saw her singing at her work,
And o'er the sickle bending;--
I listened, motionless and still;
And, as I mounted up the hill,
The music in my heart I bore,
Long after it was heard no more.
explanation: The Maiden sang about anything and everything, with an endless supply of songs. While working in the fields, she sang with her sickle in hand. I stood and listened, captivated by her music and carried the melody with me long after it faded away as I walked up the hill.

I am now in poverty because things have changed. Your love used to be like a fountain that flowed freely from my heart's door without any thought of running dry or my own needs. It simply flowed and gave without any concern for itself or me.

text:
What happy moments did I count!
Blest was I then all bliss above!
Now, for that consecrated fount
Of murmuring, sparkling, living love,
What have I? Shall I dare to tell?
A comfortless and hidden well.
explanation: I once counted many joyful moments and felt blessed beyond measure. However, now that I am without the sacred source of love that used to bring me happiness, what do I have left? Should I reveal that I am left with an empty and concealed well of sorrow and despair?

text:
A well of love- it may be deep-
I trust it is,- and never dry:
What matter? If the waters sleep
In silence and obscurity.
- Such change, and at the very door
Of my fond heart, hath made me poor.
explanation: The speaker believes that there is a deep well of love within them that will never dry up. However, even if the love remains dormant and hidden, it still exists. Despite this, a recent change at the door of their heart has made them feel poor and deprived.

text:
------The sky is overcast
With a continuous cloud of texture close,
Heavy and wan, all whitened by the Moon,
Which through that veil is indistinctly seen,
A dull, contracted circle, yielding light
So feebly spread, that not a shadow falls,
Chequering the ground--from rock, plant, tree, or tower.
explanation: The sky is covered with a thick, grey cloud that obscures the moon. The moon's light is weak and barely visible through the veil of clouds, creating a dull, featureless circle in the sky. The light is so weak that it doesn't cast any shadows on the ground, leaving everything from rocks and plants to trees and buildings unmarked.

text:
At length a pleasant instantaneous gleam
Startles the pensive traveller while he treads
His lonesome path, with unobserving eye
Bent earthwards; he looks up--the clouds are split
Asunder,--and above his head he sees
The clear Moon, and the glory of the heavens.
explanation: As the traveller walks along his solitary path with his head down, he suddenly witnesses a pleasant and brief flash of light that catches his attention. He looks up and is amazed to see the clouds parting to reveal the majestic Moon and the splendor of the sky above him.

text:
There, in a black-blue vault she sails along,
Followed by multitudes of stars, that, small
And sharp, and bright, along the dark abyss
Drive as she drives: how fast they wheel away,
Yet vanish not!--the wind is in the tree,
But they are silent;--still they roll along
Immeasurably distant; and the vault,
Built round by those white clouds, enormous clouds,
Still deepens its unfathomable depth.
explanation: In a black-blue sky, she sails with the stars following her. They are small, sharp, and bright, driving along with her in the dark abyss. They spin away quickly but don't disappear. The wind blows through the trees, but the stars remain silent, rolling along at a great distance. The huge clouds surrounding the sky deepen its unfathomable depth.

text:
At length the Vision closes; and the mind,
Not undisturbed by the delight it feels,
Which slowly settles into peaceful calm,
Is left to muse upon the solemn scene.
explanation: The Vision eventually ends and the mind is left with a sense of contentment that gradually subsides into a peaceful state. It is then able to reflect on the profound experience that has taken place.

text:
A narrow girdle of rough stones and crags,
A rude and natural causeway, interposed
Between the water and a winding slope
Of copse and thicket, leaves the eastern shore
Of Grasmere safe in its own privacy:
And there myself and two beloved Friends,
One calm September morning, ere the mist
Had altogether yielded to the sun,
Sauntered on this retired and difficult way.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: A strip of rugged stones and cliffs, forming a natural pathway, separates the water from a winding slope of trees and bushes, creating a sense of seclusion on the eastern shore of Grasmere. One peaceful September morning, before the mist had entirely cleared, I walked along this challenging and secluded path with two dear companions.

text:
----Ill suits the road with one in haste; but we
Played with our time; and, as we strolled along,
It was our occupation to observe
Such objects as the waves had tossed ashore--
Feather, or leaf, or weed, or withered bough,
Each on the other heaped, along the line
Of the dry wreck. And, in our vacant mood,
Not seldom did we stop to watch some tuft
Of dandelion seed or thistle's beard,
That skimmed the surface of the dead calm lake,
Suddenly halting now--a lifeless stand!
And starting off again with freak as sudden;
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: We didn't rush down the road, but instead took our time, enjoying our walk and observing the various objects that had been washed up on the shore by the waves. We saw feathers, leaves, weeds, and withered branches all piled on top of each other along the dry wreckage. Sometimes we even paused to watch dandelion seeds or thistle beards floating on the surface of the still lake, stopping suddenly and then starting up again with unpredictable movements. These moments of idleness allowed us to appreciate the beauty of nature and its unpredictable patterns.

text:
In all its sportive wanderings, all the while,
Making report of an invisible breeze
That was its wings, its chariot, and its horse,
Its playmate, rather say, its moving soul.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: As it roamed and played, a breeze that couldn't be seen propelled it forward like wings, a chariot, and a horse. This invisible force was more like a companion or the very essence of its movement.

text:
--And often, trifling with a privilege
Alike indulged to all, we paused, one now,
And now the other, to point out, perchance
To pluck, some flower or water-weed, too fair
Either to be divided from the place
On which it grew, or to be left alone
To its own beauty. Many such there are,
Fair ferns and flowers, and chiefly that tall fern,
So stately, of the queen Osmunda named;
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: We frequently took advantage of the freedom granted to us all and stopped to admire and possibly pick some beautiful flowers or water plants. We would pause, one after the other, unable to resist the allure of these plants that were too beautiful to be left alone or taken away from their natural surroundings. There were many such plants, including lovely ferns and flowers, but the most impressive was the tall and elegant fern known as Queen Osmunda.

text:
Plant lovelier, in its own retired abode
On Grasmere's beach, than Naiad by the side
Of Grecian brook, or Lady of the Mere,
Sole-sitting by the shores of old romance.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: The plant that grows in seclusion on Grasmere's shore is more beautiful than the Naiad (water nymph) next to a Greek stream or the Lady of the Lake from ancient legends who sits alone on the shore.

text:
--So fared we that bright morning: from the fields
Meanwhile, a noise was heard, the busy mirth
Of reapers, men and women, boys and girls.
Delighted much to listen to those sounds,
And feeding thus our fancies, we advanced
Along the indented shore; when suddenly,
Through a thin veil of glittering haze was seen
Before us, on a point of jutting land,
The tall and upright figure of a Man
Attired in peasant's garb, who stood alone,
Angling beside the margin of the lake.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: On a bright morning, we walked through the fields and heard the joyful noise of reapers, including men, women, boys, and girls. We were happy to listen to the sounds and continued walking along the curved shore. Suddenly, we saw a man standing alone on a jutting piece of land, dressed in peasant's clothing and fishing by the side of the lake, visible through a thin veil of shimmering mist.

text:
'Improvident and reckless,' we exclaimed,
'The Man must be, who thus can lose a day
Of the mid harvest, when the labourer's hire
Is ample, and some little might be stored
Wherewith to cheer him in the winter time.'
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: We expressed our disapproval of the Man's actions, calling him careless and irresponsible for wasting a day during the busiest time of the harvest season when the workers are paid well and could save some money for the winter months. We believed that he should have taken advantage of the opportunity to work and earn more to provide for himself during the colder season.

text:
Thus talking of that Peasant, we approached
Close to the spot where with his rod and line
He stood alone; whereat he turned his head
To greet us--and we saw a Mam worn down
By sickness, gaunt and lean, with sunken cheeks
And wasted limbs, his legs so long and lean
That for my single self I looked at them,
Forgetful of the body they sustained.--
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: As we spoke of the peasant, we neared the area where he was fishing with his rod and reel. The peasant acknowledged our presence and turned his head to greet us. We observed that he was a sickly man, thin and emaciated, with sunken cheeks and frail limbs. His legs were particularly long and thin, causing us to fixate on them and momentarily forget about the rest of his body.

text:
Too weak to labour in the harvest field,
The Man was using his best skill to gain
A pittance from the dead unfeeling lake
That knew not of his wants. I will not say
What thoughts immediately were ours, nor how
The happy idleness of that sweet morn,
With all its lovely images, was changed
To serious musing and to self-reproach.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: The Man was too feeble to work in the fields during harvest time and instead used his talents to try and earn some money from the lake, but it was unresponsive to his needs. The narrator refrains from sharing their thoughts on the matter, but acknowledges how the peaceful morning was disrupted by contemplation and feelings of guilt.

text:
Nor did we fail to see within ourselves
What need there is to be reserved in speech,
And temper all our thoughts with charity.
--Therefore, unwilling to forget that day,
My Friend, Myself, and She who then received
The same admonishment, have called the place
By a memorial name, uncouth indeed
As e'er by mariner was given to bay
Or foreland, on a new-discovered coast;
And POINT RASH-JUDGMENT is the name it bears.
poem_title: A Narrow Girdle Of Rough Stones And Crags
explanation: We understood the importance of being careful with our words and showing kindness in our thoughts. We didn't forget the lesson we learned that day and gave the place where it happened a name to remember it by. It might not be the most beautiful name, but it serves as a reminder to always strive to be better in our speech and actions. The place is now known as Point Rash-Judgment.

text:
A Whirl-Blast from behind the hill
Rushed o'er the wood with startling sound;
Then--all at once the air was still,
And showers of hailstones pattered round.
poem_title: A Whirl-Blast From Behind The Hill
explanation: A sudden and powerful gust of wind swept through the trees, coming from behind the hill and causing a startling noise. However, as quickly as it appeared, the wind suddenly stopped and the air was left completely still. This calm was soon replaced by a sudden downpour of hailstones that fell from the sky.

text:
Where leafless oaks towered high above,
I sat within an undergrove
Of tallest hollies, tall and green;
A fairer bower was never seen.
From year to year the spacious floor
With withered leaves is covered o'er,
And all the year the bower is green.
poem_title: A Whirl-Blast From Behind The Hill
explanation: I sat beneath a canopy of tall, green holly trees in an undergrove where towering, leafless oaks stood above. The bower was a beautiful sight, and it was always green, while the floor was covered in withered leaves throughout the year.

text:
But see! where'er the hailstones drop
The withered leaves all skip and hop;
There's not a breeze--no breath of air--
Yet here, and there, and everywhere
Along the floor, beneath the shade
By those embowering hollies made,
The leaves in myriads jump and spring,
As if with pipes and music rare
Some Robin Good-fellow were there,
And all those leaves, in festive glee,
Were dancing to the minstrelsy.
poem_title: A Whirl-Blast From Behind The Hill
explanation: The poem describes a scene where hailstones are falling and causing withered leaves to jump and dance, as if they were being moved by a playful spirit or a festive celebration. Despite there being no wind, the leaves are moving all around, creating a lively atmosphere as they bounce and sway. The imagery of Robin Good-fellow and music suggests a mischievous and joyful energy that is contagious and spreads throughout the forest.

text:
Strange fits of passion have I known:
And I will dare to tell,
But in the lover's ear alone,
What once to me befell.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: I have experienced inexplicable outbursts of emotions that I am willing to disclose, but only in the ears of a lover. Something happened to me in the past that I am hesitant to share with just anyone.

text:
When she I loved looked every day
Fresh as a rose in June,
I to her cottage bent my way,
Beneath an evening-moon.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: I used to visit the cottage of the woman I loved every evening when the moon was out. She always looked beautiful and vibrant, like a fresh rose in the month of June.

text:
Upon the moon I fixed my eye,
All over the wide lea;
With quickening pace my horse drew nigh
Those paths so dear to me.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: I focused my gaze on the moon as I traversed the vast meadow. My horse picked up speed as we approached the familiar trails that held special meaning to me.

text:
And now we reached the orchard-plot;
And, as we climbed the hill,
The sinking moon to Lucy's cot
Came near, and nearer still.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: We arrived at the apple orchard and as we ascended the hill, the moon appeared to move closer and closer to Lucy's house, which was situated nearby.

text:
In one of those sweet dreams I slept,
Kind Nature's gentlest boon!
And all the while my eye I kept
On the descending moon.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: I had a peaceful dream where I felt the gentle touch of nature's beauty. As I slumbered, I watched the moon slowly descend from the sky, mesmerized by its beauty.

text:
My horse moved on; hoof after hoof
He raised, and never stopped:
When down behind the cottage roof,
At once, the bright moon dropped.
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: As my horse continued to move forward, raising its hooves one after the other without pause, I noticed the sudden descent of the full moon behind the roof of a nearby cottage.

text:
What fond and wayward thoughts will slide
Into a Lover's head!
'O mercy!' to myself I cried,
'If Lucy hould be dead!'
poem_title: Strange Fits Of Passion Have I Known
explanation: The speaker expresses their wandering and sentimental thoughts as a lover, contemplating the possibility of their beloved, Lucy, being deceased. They exclaim their concern and distress at this idea, acknowledging the unpredictable nature of their own thoughts and emotions.

text:
FAREWELL, thou little Nook of mountain-ground,
Thou rocky corner in the lowest stair
Of that magnificent temple which doth bound
One side of our whole vale with grandeur rare;
Sweet garden-orchard, eminently fair,
The loveliest spot that man hath ever found,
Farewell!--we leave thee to Heaven's peaceful care,
Thee, and the Cottage which thou dost surround.
explanation: Goodbye to this small piece of mountain land, a rocky spot at the bottom of a grand temple that borders our valley. You are a beautiful garden and orchard, the most lovely place ever discovered by man. We leave you now in the peaceful care of heaven, along with the cottage that sits within your embrace.

text:
Our boat is safely anchored by the shore,
And there will safely ride when we are gone;
The flowering shrubs that deck our humble door
Will prosper, though untended and alone:
Fields, goods, and far-off chattels we have none:
These narrow bounds contain our private store
Of things earth makes, and sun doth shine upon;
Here are they in our sight--we have no more.
explanation: We have securely anchored our boat near the shore, where it will remain safe even after we depart. The blooming shrubs adorning our modest entrance will thrive without our attention. We possess no extensive lands, possessions, or possessions far away. Our possessions are confined to this small area of earth and the objects illuminated by the sun that we can see from our current position. This is all we have.

text:
Sunshine and shower be with you, bud and bell!
For two months now in vain we shall be sought:
We leave you here in solitude to dwell
With these our latest gifts of tender thought;
Thou, like the morning, in thy saffron coat,
Bright gowan, and marsh-marigold, farewell!
Whom from the borders of the Lake we brought,
And placed together near our rocky Well.
explanation: May you have both good and bad times, my friend! Unfortunately, we will not be able to see you for two months. We are leaving you alone with our last offerings of care and affection. You, like the morning, in your yellow clothing, must bid farewell to the bright yellow flowers we brought from the lake's edge and placed near our rocky well.

text:
We go for One to whom ye will be dear;
And she will prize this Bower, this Indian shed,
Our own contrivance, Building without peer!
--A gentle Maid, whose heart is lowly bred,
Whose pleasures are in wild fields gathered,
With joyousness, and with a thoughtful cheer,
Will come to you; to you herself will wed;
And love the blessed life that we lead here.
explanation: We invite you to come and meet a gentle and humble maiden who will value this beautiful Indian shed that we have built. She finds happiness in nature and will bring joy and thoughtfulness to your life. She will marry you and cherish the simple but wonderful life that we have created in this bower.

text:
Dear Spot! which we have watched with tender heed,
Bringing thee chosen plants and blossoms blown
Among the distant mountains, flower and weed,
Which thou hast taken to thee as thy own,
Making all kindness registered and known;
Thou for our sakes, though Nature's child indeed,
Fair in thyself and beautiful alone,
Hast taken gifts which thou dost little need.
explanation: The speaker addresses Spot, an animal they have watched closely and cared for by bringing it plants and flowers from faraway places. Despite being a creature of nature and already beautiful in its own right, Spot has accepted these gifts and shown gratitude towards its human caretakers. The speaker acknowledges that Spot did not necessarily need these presents, but took them anyway as a way to show appreciation for the kindness shown towards it.

text:
And O most constant, yet most fickle Place,
Thou hast thy wayward moods, as thou dost show
To them who look not daily on thy face;
Who, being loved, in love no bounds dost know,
And say'st, when we forsake thee, 'Let them go!'
Thou easy-hearted Thing, with thy wild race
Of weeds and flowers, till we return be slow,
And travel with the year at a soft pace.
explanation: This passage personifies a place as fickle yet constant, with varying moods that are only visible to those who don't see it every day. The place is loved boundlessly by some, but it remains easy-going and indifferent to their departure. The place is slow to change, with its wild yet beautiful flora taking their time to bloom and wilt with the passing of the year.

Assist us in recollecting the stories of the past, particularly of this cherished and adored springtime. Even though joy is fleeting, there should be something that remains to remind us of what has occurred. The steep rock's surface was covered with an abundance of primroses, and it glimmered at dusk like a star-filled sky. Additionally, a sparrow constructed a nest in the bush, and I even composed a song about it that will endure forever.

text:
O happy Garden! whose seclusion deep
Hath been so friendly to industrious hours;
And to soft slumbers, that did gently steep
Our spirits, carrying with them dreams of flowers,
And wild notes warbled among leafy bowers;
Two burning months let summer overleap,
And, coming back with Her who will be ours,
Into thy bosom we again shall creep.
explanation: The speaker expresses joy and gratitude towards a secluded garden that has been a peaceful haven for hard work and restful sleep. The garden has inspired pleasant dreams of flowers and birds singing among the trees. The speaker anticipates returning to the garden with someone special after the hot summer months have passed.

text:
A slumber did my spirit seal
I had no human fears:
She seemed a thing that could not feel
The touch of earthly years.
poem_title: A Slumber Did My Spirit Seal
explanation: My spirit was sealed with slumber, and I had no fears. The person I saw appeared to be incapable of feeling the passing of time on Earth.

poem_title: A Slumber Did My Spirit Seal
explanation: She is completely still and powerless, unable to sense or perceive anything. She is constantly moving with the rotation of the Earth, alongside other natural elements like rocks, stones, and trees.

Seeing a rainbow in the sky makes my heart leap with joy, just as it did when I was born and still does now that I am an adult. I hope to feel the same way even when I am old or, if not, to die. I believe that the child we once were shapes the person we become, and I wish for my life to be guided by a natural sense of reverence and love for the world around us.

text:
Art thou a Statist in the van
Of public conflicts trained and bred?
- First learn to love one living man;
'Then' may'st thou think upon the dead.
explanation: If you are someone who is involved in public conflicts and political affairs, you should first learn to love and appreciate the value of one living person before thinking about those who have died. This poem suggests that it is important to prioritize the living and their well-being before focusing on the past or those who have already passed away.

text:
A Lawyer art thou? - draw not nigh!
Go, carry to some fitter place
The keenness of that practised eye,
The hardness of that sallow face.
explanation: If you are a lawyer, do not approach me. Take your sharpness and your uninviting appearance elsewhere.

text:
Art thou a Man of purple cheer?
A rosy Man, right plump to see?
Approach; yet, Doctor, not too near,
This grave no cushion is for thee.
explanation: Are you a cheerful man dressed in purple? Are you a plump and rosy man? Approach, but not too close, doctor, as this grave is not meant for you to rest on.

text:
Or art thou one of gallant pride,
A Soldier and no man of chaff?
Welcome! - but lay thy sword aside,
And lean upon a peasant's staff.
explanation: Are you a proud and brave soldier or just a useless, insignificant person? If you are a soldier, then you are welcome here, but you must leave your sword behind and become more humble like a peasant.

text:
Physician art thou? one, all eyes,
Philosopher! a fingering slave,
One that would peep and botanise
Upon his mother's grave?
explanation:
Are you a doctor? Always watching, 
Philosopher! A slave to detail,
Someone who would investigate and study 
Even while standing by their mother's tomb?

text:
Wrapt closely in thy sensual fleece,
O turn aside,- and take, I pray,
That he below may rest in peace,
Thy ever-dwindling soul, away!
explanation: Covered in your seductive cloak, please turn away and take your soul, which is diminishing, with you so that the man below can finally rest in peace.

Perhaps a moralist has arrived on this land, by means unknown to us. He seems to be oblivious to his surroundings, having no sense of sight or hearing. He is his own universe, and worships only himself.

text:
One to whose smooth-rubbed soul can cling
Nor form, nor feeling, great or small;
A reasoning, self-sufficing thing,
An intellectual All-in-all!
explanation: This passage describes a person whose soul is so refined that it is not attached to any material or emotional aspects of life. They are a self-sufficient being, relying only on their own intellect and reasoning skills to navigate the world. Essentially, they are an all-encompassing intellectual entity.
Close the door and latch it tightly, retreat into your own thoughts and intellect, and don't waste a single moment near this useless dust. Be diligent with your time and don't let it slip away.

text:
But who is He, with modest looks,
And clad in homely russet brown?
He murmurs near the running brooks
A music sweeter than their own.
explanation: The speaker is pondering the identity of a person they see dressed plainly in brown and who appears unassuming. This person is often heard singing near streams and the speaker notes that their voice is even more beautiful than the natural sounds of the water.

text:
He is retired as noontide dew,
Or fountain in a noon-day grove;
And you must love him, ere to you
He will seem worthy of your love.
explanation: The subject of this poem is someone who is retired and compared to the dew that evaporates at midday or a fountain in a grove during noon. The poem suggests that before you can appreciate this person and see their worth, you must first love them.

text:
The outward shows of sky and earth,
Of hill and valley, he has viewed;
And impulses of deeper birth
Have come to him in solitude.
explanation: The speaker has observed the visible elements of nature, including the sky, earth, hills, and valleys. However, while being alone, the person has experienced more profound emotions or thoughts.

text:
In common things that round us lie
Some random truths he can impart,-
The harvest of a quiet eye
That broods and sleeps on his own heart.
explanation: There are truths to be found in everyday surroundings, according to the speaker. These truths are gained through introspection and reflection, as the speaker suggests that they come from "a quiet eye that broods and sleeps on his own heart." These truths are not necessarily profound or life-changing, but rather small insights that can be gleaned from observing the world around us. The speaker implies that these truths are accessible to anyone who takes the time to look for them.

text:
But he is weak; both Man and Boy,
Hath been an idler in the land;
Contented if he might enjoy
The things which others understand.
explanation: He is not strong, whether as a man or a boy, and has been lazy throughout his life. He is satisfied as long as he can have the same things that others have.
Come to me when you are strong and powerful, or when you are weak like a crashing wave. You can lay your body down fully or build your home on top of this burial ground.

text:
--------A Simple Child,
That lightly draws its breath,
And feels its life in every limb,
What should it know of death?
explanation: The innocence of a child is highlighted in this poem as it questions what a young, carefree mind could possibly understand about death. The child is described as drawing its breath with ease, fully immersed in the sensations of life, and unaware of the harsh realities that may come with it. The rhetorical question posed emphasizes the vast difference between the pure, untainted nature of a child and the harshness of the adult world. The poem suggests that the beauty of childhood lies in its simplicity and ignorance of the more complicated aspects of life.

text:
I met a little cottage Girl:
She was eight years old, she said;
Her hair was thick with many a curl
That clustered round her head.
explanation: I encountered a young girl who lived in a small cottage. She informed me that she was only eight years old. Her hair was voluminous and had multiple curls that encircled her head.

text:
She had a rustic, woodland air,
And she was wildly clad:
Her eyes were fair, and very fair;
--Her beauty made me glad.
explanation: She had a natural, outdoorsy vibe and her clothing was unconventional. Her eyes were particularly beautiful and her overall appearance brought me joy.

text:
"Sisters and brothers, little Maid,
How many may you be?"
"How many? Seven in all," she said
And wondering looked at me.
explanation: The speaker asks a young girl how many siblings she has, to which she replies that there are seven in total. The girl appears to be surprised by the question and looks at the speaker with curiosity.

text:
"And where are they? I pray you tell."
She answered, "Seven are we;
And two of us at Conway dwell,
And two are gone to sea.
explanation: The speaker asks where the people are and the person being asked responds that there are seven of them. Two of them live in Conway and two are currently at sea.

text:
"Two of us in the church-yard lie,
My sister and my brother;
And, in the church-yard cottage, I
Dwell near them with my mother."
explanation: In the churchyard, there are three graves belonging to the speaker's sister and brother, while the speaker and their mother live in a nearby cottage.

text:
"You say that two at Conway dwell,
And two are gone to sea,
Yet ye are seven!--I pray you tell,
Sweet Maid, how this may be."
explanation: The speaker is confused about the number of people in the household. They have been told that two people are living in Conway and two are at sea, but they still count seven people. The speaker asks the "sweet maid" to explain this discrepancy.

text:
Then did the little Maid reply,
"Seven boys and girls are we;
Two of us in the church-yard lie,
Beneath the church-yard tree."
explanation: The young girl answered that there were seven children in her family, but two of them had passed away and were buried under the tree in the churchyard.

text:
"You run about, my little Maid,
Your limbs they are alive;
If two are in the church-yard laid,
Then ye are only five."
explanation: Oh little girl, you run so fast and free, full of life and energy. Even if two of your loved ones have passed away and are resting in the churchyard, you and your family still make up a total of five.

text:
"Their graves are green, they may be seen,"
The little Maid replied,
"Twelve steps or more from my mother's door,
And they are side by side.
explanation: The young girl answered that the graves of those who have passed on are located just twelve steps away from her mother's door and can be easily spotted as they are situated next to each other and are covered in green.

text:
"My stockings there I often knit,
My kerchief there I hem;
And there upon the ground I sit,
And sing a song to them.
explanation: I frequently knit my stockings and hem my kerchief in that particular location. I take a seat on the ground and sing a song to accompany my work."

text:
"And often after sunset, Sir,
When it is light and fair,
I take my little porringer,
And eat my supper there.
explanation: Sometimes, Sir, I enjoy my dinner after the sun has set and the sky is still bright. I bring my small bowl and eat my meal in that tranquil spot.
The initial person to pass away was a woman named sister Jane. She was in agony while lying in her bed before God eased her suffering and she passed away."

text:
"So in the church-yard she was laid;
And, when the grass was dry,
Together round her grave we played,
My brother John and I.
explanation: She was buried in the church-yard and when the grass had dried, my brother John and I played around her grave.

text:
"And when the ground was white with snow,
And I could run and slide,
My brother John was forced to go,
And he lies by her side."
explanation: The speaker reminisces about a time when there was snow on the ground, and they could run and slide on it. However, their brother John was not able to join them because he had to go somewhere else. The speaker then reveals that John now lies beside someone, implying that he has since passed away.

text:
"How many are you, then," said I,
"If they two are in heaven?"
Quick was the little Maid's reply,
"O Master! we are seven."
explanation: The speaker asks the little girl how many siblings she has if two of them are in heaven. The girl promptly responds that she and her remaining siblings, totaling seven in all, are still alive.

text:
"But they are dead; those two are dead!
Their spirits are in heaven!"
'Twas throwing words away; for still
The little Maid would have her will,
And said, "Nay, we are seven!"
explanation: The speaker insists that two people are dead and their spirits are in heaven, but the little girl insists that they are still seven in their family, despite the deaths. The speaker's words are dismissed as the little girl holds firm in her belief that they are still part of the family.

The rooster is crowing, the stream is flowing, and the small birds are chirping while the lake sparkles. The green field is basking in the warm sun, while the oldest and youngest people are working alongside the strongest. The cattle are grazing and never lifting their heads, with forty of them eating together as if they were one.

The snow has melted away like a defeated army and is now struggling to survive on the top of the hill. The plowboy is happy and making noise. The mountains are filled with joy, the fountains are full of life, and small clouds are floating in the blue sky. The rain has passed, and the world is now filled with hope and joy.

text:
AMONG the dwellings framed by birds
In field or forest with nice care,
Is none that with the little Wren's
In snugness may compare.
explanation: The wren's dwelling is unparalleled in its coziness and attention to detail among all the homes built by birds in fields and forests.

text:
No door the tenement requires,
And seldom needs a laboured roof;
Yet is it to the fiercest sun
Impervious, and storm-proof.
explanation: The tenement does not have a door and rarely requires a complicated roof, but it is able to withstand the harshest sun and storms without being affected.

text:
So warm, so beautiful withal,
In perfect fitness for its aim,
That to the Kind by special grace
Their instinct surely came.
explanation: The object in question is not only physically attractive but also functions perfectly for its intended purpose. It is believed that the ability to recognize and appreciate its qualities was given to those who possess a certain innate ability or divine favor.

text:
And when for their abodes they seek
An opportune recess,
The hermit has no finer eye
For shadowy quietness.
explanation: When seeking a place to reside in peace and seclusion, the hermit possesses a keen sense of discernment for finding the perfect spot of serene solitude. Their ability to locate a shadowy and tranquil retreat is unmatched, as they possess an acute awareness of the stillness and peacefulness that is necessary for their way of life.

text:
These find, 'mid ivied abbey-walls,
A canopy in some still nook;
Others are pent-housed by a brae
That overhangs a brook.
explanation: Some people discover a secluded spot among the ivy-covered walls of an abbey, while others find shelter under a hill that juts out over a stream.

text:
There to the brooding bird her mate
Warbles by fits his low clear song;
And by the busy streamlet both
Are sung to all day long.
explanation: The male bird sings a clear, low song to his mate who is brooding. They both sing all day long by the stream.

text:
Or in sequestered lanes they build,
Where, till the flitting bird's return,
Her eggs within the nest repose,
Like relics in an urn.
explanation: They construct their nests in secluded pathways, where the eggs remain undisturbed until the bird's eventual return. The eggs are positioned within the nest as if they were precious artifacts resting within an urn.
Although having choices is beneficial, there are options that are superior to others. Even amongst beautiful things, there are some that are more stunning than the rest.

text:
This, one of those small builders proved
In a green covert, where, from out
The forehead of a pollard oak,
The leafy antlers sprout;
explanation: One of the small builders demonstrated their skills in a green area where antlers grew from a pollard oak.

text:
For She who planned the mossy lodge,
Mistrusting her evasive skill,
Had to a Primrose looked for aid
Her wishes to fulfill.
explanation: The woman who was designing a mossy shelter didn't trust her own abilities and sought the help of a Primrose to fulfill her desires.

text:
High on the trunk's projecting brow,
And fixed an infant's span above
The budding flowers, peeped forth the nest
The prettiest of the grove!
explanation: The nest, which was the most beautiful in the grove, was situated high on the projecting brow of a tree trunk, and was only a span away from the budding flowers. It was home to an unknown number of birds.

text:
The treasure proudly did I show
To some whose minds without disdain
Can turn to little things; but once
Looked up for it in vain:
explanation: I showed the treasure to those who have an appreciation for small things, but they were unable to find it when they looked for it.

text:
'Tis gone---a ruthless spoiler's prey,
Who heeds not beauty, love, or song,
'Tis gone! (so seemed it) and we grieved
Indignant at the wrong.
explanation: It has vanished, taken by a merciless thief who cares nothing for beauty, love, or music. It has disappeared and we feel sorrowful and angry at the injustice of it all.

text:
Just three days after, passing by
In clearer light the moss-built cell
I saw, espied its shaded mouth;
And felt that all was well.
explanation: Three days later, I passed by the moss-covered cell and saw it more clearly in the light. I noticed its shaded entrance and felt reassured that everything was okay.

text:
The Primrose for a veil had spread
The largest of her upright leaves;
And thus, for purposes benign,
A simple flower deceives.
explanation: The Primrose plant cleverly uses one of its largest leaves as a veil, tricking those who observe it into thinking that it is a flower. Despite this deception, the Primrose is harmless and serves a beneficial purpose in the natural world.

text:
Concealed from friends who might disturb
Thy quiet with no ill intent,
Secure from evil eyes and hands
On barbarous plunder bent,
explanation: You are hidden away from friends who might unintentionally disrupt your peace, and protected from those who seek to harm and steal from you.

text:
Rest, Mother-bird! and when thy young
Take flight, and thou art free to roam,
When withered is the guardian Flower,
And empty thy late home,
explanation: Take rest, dear mother bird. Enjoy your freedom as your young take flight and venture out on their own. When the flower that once protected your home withers away and your nest is empty, take comfort in the peace of rest.

text:
Think how ye prospered, thou and thine,
Amid the unviolated grove
Housed near the growing Primrose-tuft
In foresight, or in love.
explanation: Consider how well you and your loved ones have thrived, living among the untouched trees and plants, residing close to the blossoming Primrose flowers, whether it was due to your careful planning or your affection for nature.

text:
There is an Eminence,--of these our hills
The last that parleys with the setting sun;
We can behold it from our orchard-seat;
And, when at evening we pursue out walk
Along the public way, this Peak, so high
Above us, and so distant in its height,
Is visible; and often seems to send
Its own deep quiet to restore our hearts.
poem_title: There Is An Eminence,--Of These Our Hills
explanation: The hills have an Eminence, the final one that communicates with the setting sun. It can be seen from the orchard and when walking along the public path in the evening. Despite its height and distance, it appears to send a sense of peace to those who observe it, restoring their hearts with its deep quiet.

text:
The meteors make of it a favourite haunt:
The star of Jove, so beautiful and large
In the mid heavens, is never half so fair
As when he shines above it. 'Tis in truth
The loneliest place we have among the clouds.
poem_title: There Is An Eminence,--Of These Our Hills
explanation: The meteors love to frequent a certain spot in the sky where the planet Jupiter shines the brightest. Even though Jupiter is an impressive sight on its own, it appears even more magnificent when it is positioned above this specific location. This location is known to be the most isolated spot in the sky, away from other celestial bodies.

text:
And She who dwells with me, whom I have loved
With such communion, that no place on earth
Can ever be a solitude to me,
Hath to this lonely Summit given my Name.
poem_title: There Is An Eminence,--Of These Our Hills
explanation: The person who has been with me and whom I have loved so deeply that being alone is never lonely has given me the name of this desolate mountain peak.

text:
FANCY, who leads the pastimes of the glad,
Full oft is pleased a wayward dart to throw;
Sending sad shadows after things not sad,
Peopling the harmless fields with signs of woe:
Beneath her sway, a simple forest cry
Becomes an echo of man's misery.
Blithe ravens croak of death; and when the owl
Tries his two voices for a favourite strain--
'Tu-whit--Tu-whoo!' the unsuspecting fowl
Forebodes mishap or seems but to complain;
Fancy, intent to harass and annoy,
Can thus pervert the evidence of joy.
explanation: Fancy, the ruler of joy and entertainment, often enjoys causing mischief by creating a sense of sadness in harmless situations. She can make a simple forest sound like a cry of despair, and even the happy cawing of a raven can become a harbinger of death. The owl's hoot, meant to be a pleasant melody, can be twisted by Fancy into a foreboding warning or a meaningless lament. Fancy has the power to distort the evidence of happiness and bring distress where there should be none.

text:
Through border wilds where naked Indians stray,
Myriads of notes attest her subtle skill;
A feathered task-master cries, 'WORK AWAY!'
And, in thy iteration, 'WHIP POOR WILL!'
Is heard the spirit of a toil-worn slave,
Lashed out of life, not quiet in the grave.
explanation: In the wilderness along the border where indigenous people roam without clothing, the skilled musician's abilities are confirmed by numerous sounds. A bird that supervises the work commands the laborers to continue, and the refrain "whip poor Will" can be heard. The spirit of a slave who was overworked and died from beatings haunts the area.

The speaker marvels at the power of the woman, who could make even the melancholic songs of Philomel and the usually cheerful chirping of the Swallow express sorrow. However, the speaker notes that the lark remains immune to the woman's influence, as it continues to sing its joyous tune without being swayed by the woman's spell.

The daisy remains still on the wet grass, still bent from the previous evening, while a new star of dawn, referred to as 'He', rises and sparkles near a rose-colored cloud. 'He' is a shining gem and a singing bird, representing new hope and happiness.

text:
Hail, blest above all kinds!--Supremely skilled
Restless with fixed to balance, high with low,
Thou leav'st the halcyon free her hopes to build
On such forbearance as the deep may show;
Perpetual flight, unchecked by earthly ties,
Leav'st to the wandering bird of paradise.
explanation: Hail to the skillful and blessed one, who is above all kinds! With a fixed balance, you are restless and transcend high and low. You allow the halcyon bird to freely build its hopes on the forbearance of the deep. Your perpetual flight is unencumbered by earthly ties, leaving the wandering bird of paradise to roam freely.

The dove is both faithful and fast, but also possesses a unique balance that Nature has granted it. Despite its constant gaze downwards, it remains free and independent in the air. It is both humble and joyful, possessing a powerful ability to fly and sing tirelessly.

text:
To the last point of vision, and beyond,
Mount, daring warbler!--that love-prompted strain,
('Twixt thee and thine a never-failing bond)
Thrills not the less the bosom of the plain:
Yet might'st thou seem, proud privilege! to sing
All independent of the leafy spring.
explanation: Fly higher, fearless bird, until you can no longer see, and then keep going. Your song, inspired by love and creating an unbreakable bond between you and your mate, still manages to fill the hearts of those on the ground. Although you seem to sing without any dependence on the surrounding trees and foliage, it is a privilege that you have earned through your independence and bravery.

text:
How would it please old Ocean to partake,
With sailors longing for a breeze in vain,
The harmony thy notes most gladly make
Where earth resembles most his own domain!
Urania's self might welcome with pleased ear
These matins mounting towards her native sphere.
explanation: The author wonders how much the ocean would enjoy listening to the beautiful music created by the sailors who are yearning for wind to fill their sails. The author imagines that even the goddess Urania would be pleased to hear such lovely music reaching up towards her home in the heavens. The author marvels at how the earth and the ocean seem to blend together in perfect harmony, and how the sailors' music adds to this peaceful coexistence.

text:
Chanter by heaven attracted, whom no bars
To day-light known deter from that pursuit,
'Tis well that some sage instinct, when the stars
Come forth at evening, keeps Thee still and mute;
For not an eyelid could to sleep incline
Wert thou among them, singing as they shine!
explanation: Heavenly beings are drawn to your singing, and nothing can stop you from pursuing it during the day. However, it is fortunate that some natural instinct keeps you silent and still when the stars come out at night. If you were to sing among them, no one could fall asleep while listening to your beautiful voice.

text:
'Tis said, that some have died for love:
And here and there a churchyard grave is found
In the cold north's unhallowed ground,
Because the wretched man himself had slain,
His love was such a grievous pain.
And there is one whom I five years have known;
He dwells alone
Upon Helvellyn's side:
He loved--the pretty Barbara died;
And thus he makes his moan:
Three years had Barbara in her grave been laid
When thus his moan he made:
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: It is believed that some people have died due to the intensity of their love, as evidenced by the occasional graves found in un-sacred ground in the cold north. In some cases, the person themselves may have taken their own life due to the unbearable pain of their love. One man, whom I have known for five years, lives alone on the side of Helvellyn. He loved a woman named Barbara, who has been dead for three years, and he mourns her loss.

text:
'Oh, move, thou Cottage, from behind that oak!
Or let the aged tree uprooted lie,
That in some other way yon smoke
May mount into the sky!
The clouds pass on; they from the heavens depart.
I look--the sky is empty space;
I know not what I trace;
But when I cease to look, my hand is on my heart.
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker is asking for the cottage to be moved from behind the oak tree, or for the tree to be uprooted so that the smoke from the cottage can rise into the sky in a different direction. The clouds are passing on and disappearing into the empty sky, leaving the speaker uncertain about what they are seeing. When they stop looking, they feel a strong emotion that causes them to place their hand on their heart.

text:
'Oh! what a weight is in these shades! Ye leaves,
That murmur once so dear, when will it cease?
Your sound my heart of rest bereaves,
It robs my heart of peace.
Thou Thrush, that singest loud--and loud and free,
Into yon row of willows flit,
Upon that alder sit;
Or sing another song, or choose another tree.
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker is feeling weighed down by the surroundings, particularly the rustling leaves that used to bring comfort, but now only disrupt the peace. Even the thrush's song, which used to be enjoyed, now seems too loud and intrusive. The speaker longs for a respite from the noise and chaos of the world around them.

text:
'Roll back, sweet Rill! back to thy mountain-bounds,
And there for ever be thy waters chained!
For thou dost haunt the air with sounds
That cannot be sustained;
If still beneath that pine-tree's ragged bough
Headlong yon waterfall must come,
Oh let it then be dumb!
Be anything, sweet Rill, but that which thou art now.
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: The speaker is addressing a stream, telling it to stop its flow and return to its source in the mountains. The reason for this request is that the sound of the stream is too overpowering and cannot be sustained. The speaker suggests that if the waterfall must continue to flow, then it should do so quietly. The speaker is essentially asking the stream to be anything other than what it currently is, as its presence is too overwhelming.

text:
'Thou Eglantine, so bright with sunny showers,
Proud as a rainbow spanning half the vale,
Thou one fair shrub, oh! shed thy flowers,
And stir not in the gale.
For thus to see thee nodding in the air,
To see thy arch thus stretch and bend,
Thus rise and thus descend,--
Disturbs me till the sight is more than I can dear.'
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: Oh Eglantine, your beauty shines with the sun's rays and your pride matches that of a rainbow stretching across the valley. However, I implore you to not sway in the wind and to keep your flowers to yourself. Your movement in the air and the way you bend and rise causes me great discomfort and I cannot bear to watch it any longer.

text:
The Man who makes this feverish complaint
Is one of giant stature, who could dance
Equipped from head to foot in iron mail.
Ah gentle Love! if ever thought was thine
To store up kindred hours for me, thy face
Turn from me, gentle Love! nor let me walk
Within the sound of Emma's voice, nor know
Such happiness as I have known to-day.
poem_title: 'Tis Said, That Some Have Died For Love
explanation: A man of great size, wearing heavy armor, is expressing his distress to Love. He pleads that if Love has ever considered being kind to him, to turn away and spare him from the pain of hearing Emma's voice or experiencing the happiness he felt today.

text:
A poet! - He hath put his heart to school,
Nor dares to move unpropped upon the staff
Which art hath lodged within his hand- must laugh
By precept only, and shed tears by rule.
poem_title: A Poet! He Hath Put His Heart To School
explanation: The poet has dedicated himself to his craft, relying on the knowledge and skills he has acquired to guide him. He cannot risk expressing himself without the support of his learned techniques, and therefore must follow the rules of laughter and tears as they have been taught to him.

text:
Thy Art be Nature; the live current quaff,
And let the groveller sip his stagnant pool,
In fear that else, when Critics grave and cool
Have killed him, Scorn should write his epitaph.
poem_title: A Poet! He Hath Put His Heart To School
explanation: Nature is your art, drink from the lively stream and don't settle for the stagnant pool that others drink from. If you do, you risk being killed off by critical reviewers and being remembered only with disdain.

text:
How does the Meadow-flower its bloom unfold?
Because the lovely little flower is free
Down to its root, and, in that freedom, bold;
And so the grandeur of the Forest-tree
Comes not by casting in a formal mould,
But from its own divine vitality.
poem_title: A Poet! He Hath Put His Heart To School
explanation: The poem questions how the Meadow-flower blooms and suggests that it is due to its freedom, which allows it to grow bold and beautiful from the root. Similarly, the grandeur of the Forest-tree does not come from a set mold, but from its own natural vitality. The poem emphasizes the importance of freedom and individuality in nature's beauty and growth.

text:
Oft I had heard of Lucy Gray:
And, when I crossed the wild,
I chanced to see at break of day
The solitary child.
explanation: Lucy Gray was a name that had been mentioned to me many times before. When I was traveling through the wilderness, I happened to come across the young girl at dawn. She was by herself and seemed to be alone in the world.

text:
No mate, no comrade Lucy knew;
She dwelt on a wide moor,
- The sweetest thing that ever grew
Beside a human door!
explanation: Lucy lived alone on a vast moor, without a friend or companion. She was the most pleasant and delightful thing that could be found near any person's doorstep.

text:
You yet may spy the fawn at play,
The hare upon the green;
But the sweet face of Lucy Gray
Will never more be seen.
explanation: You may still catch sight of playful fawns and hares frolicking in the fields, but the beloved visage of Lucy Gray will never grace the earth again.

text:
'To-night will be a stormy night-
You to the town must go;
And take a lantern, Child, to light
Your mother through the snow.'
explanation: The night ahead is going to be filled with stormy weather, and you must make your way to the town. It is important that you bring a lantern with you to light your mother's way through the snow.

text:
'That, Father! will I gladly do:
'Tis scarcely afternoon-
The minster-clock has just struck two,
And yonder is the moon! '
explanation: "I am willing to do that, Father! It is only mid-afternoon and the clock at the church has just struck two. The moon is visible in the sky over there."

text:
At this the Father raised his hook,
And snapped a faggot-band;
He plied his work; - and Lucy took
The lantern in her hand.
explanation: The Father lifted his tool and broke a bundle of sticks. He continued his task while Lucy held a lantern.

text:
Not blither is the mountain roe:
With many a wanton stroke
Her feet disperse the powdery snow,
That rises up like smoke.
explanation: The mountain roe is full of energy and joy as she playfully moves around. Her feet kick up the snow, creating a cloud of powder that resembles smoke.

text:
The storm came on before its time:
She wandered up and down;
And many a hill did Lucy climb:
But never reached the town.
explanation: Lucy was caught in a storm that arrived earlier than expected. Despite her efforts to seek shelter, she wandered aimlessly, climbing hills in search of a town that was never reached.

text:
The wretched parents all that night
Went shouting far and wide;
But there was neither sound nor sight
To serve them for a guide.
explanation: Throughout the night, the distressed parents searched frantically, shouting and calling out in hopes of finding their lost child. However, their efforts proved to be futile as they were met with silence and darkness, leaving them without any indication of where to turn or where to look next.

text:
At day-break on a hill they stood
That overlooked the moor;
And thence they saw the bridge of wood,
A furlong from their door.
explanation: At dawn, they stood on a hill and looked out over the moor, from which they could see a wooden bridge only a short distance away from their home.

text:
They wept- and, turning homeward, cried,
'In heaven we all shall meet; '
- When in the snow the mother spied
The print of Lucy's feet.
explanation: As they cried and made their way back home, they believed that they would all reunite in heaven. However, the mother spotted Lucy's footprints in the snow, suggesting that she was still alive and had wandered off.
They followed the small footprints down the steep hill's edge, making their way through the broken hawthorn hedge and along the long stone wall.
They crossed an open field, following the same tracks without losing them until they finally arrived at a bridge.

text:
They followed from the snowy bank
Those footmarks, one by one,
Into the middle of the plank;
And further there were none!
explanation: The observers traced the footprints on the snowy bank step by step until they reached the middle of the plank, but no further.

text:
- Yet some maintain that to this day
She is a living child;
That you may see sweet Lucy Gray
Upon the lonesome wild.
explanation: However, there are those who believe that Lucy Gray is still alive and can be found wandering alone in the desolate wilderness. They claim that she remains a young girl, and that anyone can catch a glimpse of her if they search hard enough.

text:
O'er rough and smooth she trips along,
And never looks behind;
And sings a solitary song
That whistles in the wind.
explanation: She walks without care over any terrain, never glancing back, and hums a tune that echoes in the breeze.

text:
TELL me, ye Zephyrs! that unfold,
While fluttering o'er this gay Recess,
Pinions that fanned the teeming mould
Of Eden's blissful wilderness,
Did only softly-stealing hours
There close the peaceful lives of flowers?
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: The speaker is addressing the gentle breeze, asking if it witnessed the peaceful life of the flowers in the beautiful garden of Eden. The speaker wonders if the only thing that brought an end to the flowers' tranquil existence were simply the passing of time.

text:
Say, when the 'moving' creatures saw
All kinds commingled without fear,
Prevailed a like indulgent law
For the still growths that prosper here?
Did wanton fawn and kid forbear
The half-blown rose, the lily spare?
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: Did the animals who moved about witness a peaceful coexistence between different species without fear? Was there a similar leniency towards the still plants that thrived in the same environment? Did playful fawns and young goats refrain from damaging the budding roses and lilies?

text:
Or peeped they often from their beds
And prematurely disappeared,
Devoured like pleasure ere it spreads
A bosom to the sun endeared?
If such their harsh untimely doom,
It falls not 'here' on bud or bloom.
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: Do the flowers peek out of their buds and then quickly wither away before fully blooming? If that's the case, then it's not happening here - in this place, the flowers are allowed to fully bloom and enjoy the sun.

text:
All summer long the happy Eve
Of this fair Spot her flowers may bind,
Nor e'er, with ruffled fancy, grieve,
From the next glance she casts, to find
That love for little things by Fate
Is rendered vain as love for great.
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: Throughout the summer, Eve can happily gather flowers in this beautiful location without becoming upset if she discovers that her love for small things is just as futile as her love for larger things.

text:
Yet, where the guardian fence is wound,
So subtly are our eyes beguiled
We see not nor suspect a bound,
No more than in some forest wild;
The sight is free as air--or crost
Only by art in nature lost.
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: The presence of a fence can deceive our eyes and make us believe that there are no boundaries, just like in a dense forest. The view appears to be unrestricted, and only the absence of nature's art can obstruct it.

text:
And, though the jealous turf refuse
By random footsteps to be prest,
And feed on never-sullied dews,
'Ye', gentle breezes from the west,
With all the ministers of hope
Are tempted to this sunny slope!
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: The grass is too jealous to be stepped on by anyone and only feeds on pure dew. However, the gentle western breezes and their hopeful companions are enticed to this bright and sunny hillside despite the turf's reluctance.

poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: Many birds gather in this place, some living in cozy nests and others perched on tall stems that sway in greeting to visitors. Even the playful hare and leveret seem just as much a part of this environment as the birds.

text:
Apt emblem (for reproof of pride)
This delicate Enclosure shows
Of modest kindness, that would hide
The firm protection she bestows;
Of manners, like its viewless fence,
Ensuring peace to innocence.
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: This enclosure is a fitting symbol for rebuking pride. It represents the gentle and modest kindness that seeks to protect while remaining unseen. In the same way, it embodies the importance of good manners that provide a secure and peaceful environment for innocence.

text:
Thus spake the moral Muse--her wing
Abruptly spreading to depart,
She left that farewell offering,
Momento for some docile heart;
That may respect the good old age
When Fancy was Truth's willing Page;
And Truth would skim the flowery glade,
Though entering but as Fancy's Shade.
poem_title: A Flower Garden At Coleorton Hall, Leicestershire.
explanation: The moral Muse spoke and then abruptly left, leaving behind a parting gift for those with a receptive heart. This gift serves as a reminder of a time when imagination and truth were intertwined, and truth was able to explore the beauty of nature through the lens of imagination.

text:
EARTH has not anything to show more fair:
Dull would he be of soul who could pass by
A sight so touching in its majesty:
This City now doth like a garment wear
The beauty of the morning; silent, bare,
Ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples lie
Open unto the fields, and to the sky;
explanation: The beauty of the city in the morning is unmatched, with ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples all on display, open to the fields and sky. It would be a shame for anyone to pass by and not appreciate the majesty of it all.

text:
All bright and glittering in the smokeless air.
Never did sun more beautifully steep
In his first splendour valley, rock, or hill;
Ne'er saw I, never felt, a calm so deep!
The river glideth at his own sweet will:
Dear God! the very houses seem asleep;
And all that mighty heart is lying still!
explanation: The surroundings are bright and sparkling in the clear atmosphere. The sun has never shone so beautifully on the valley, rocks, and hills. The peace and stillness are unparalleled, and the river flows effortlessly. Even the buildings seem to be in slumber, and the entire bustling city lies silent.

text:
With ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like stars in heaven, and joyously it showed;
Some lying fast at anchor in the road,
Some veering up and down, one knew not why.
poem_title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled Far And Nigh
explanation: The sea was filled with numerous ships, scattered in different directions like stars in the sky, creating a joyful sight. Some were stationed in the harbor while others moved in unpredictable patterns. It was difficult to discern why some ships were swerving back and forth.

text:
A goodly vessel did I then espy
Come like a giant from a haven broad;
And lustily along the bay she strode,
Her tackling rich, and of apparel high.
poem_title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled Far And Nigh
explanation: I saw a large ship approaching from a wide harbor, appearing like a giant. It sailed strongly and confidently through the bay, with well-crafted rigging and impressive decorations.

text:
The ship was nought to me, nor I to her,
Yet I pursued her with a lover's look;
This ship to all the rest did I prefer:
When will she turn, and whither? She will brook
No tarrying; where she comes the winds must stir:
On went she, and due north her journey took.
poem_title: With Ships The Sea Was Sprinkled Far And Nigh
explanation: I didn't care about the ship, and it didn't care about me, but I still watched it with love in my eyes. Out of all the ships, this one was special to me. I wondered when it would change course and where it was headed. The ship wouldn't wait for anyone, wherever it went the winds would follow. It continued to sail north without delay.

text:
AMONG all lovely things my Love had been;
Had noted well the stars, all flowers that grew
About her home; but she had never seen
A glow-worm, never one, and this I knew.
poem_title: Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been
