explanation: My beloved had admired various beautiful things like stars and flowers around her house, but I realized that she had never laid eyes on a glow-worm before.

text:
While riding near her home one stormy night
A single glow-worm did I chance to espy;
I gave a fervent welcome to the sight,
And from my horse I leapt; great joy had I.
poem_title: Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been
explanation: One stormy night, as I was riding near my home, I happened to spot a single glow-worm. The sight filled me with great joy and I eagerly welcomed it. I even got off my horse to take a closer look at the tiny creature.

text:
Upon a leaf the glow-worm did I lay,
To bear it with me through the stormy night:
And, as before, it shone without dismay;
Albeit putting forth a fainter light.
poem_title: Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been
explanation: I placed a glow-worm on a leaf to accompany me through the stormy night, and despite emitting a dimmer light, it remained undaunted and continued to shine.

text:
When to the dwelling of my Love I came,
I went into the orchard quietly;
And left the glow-worm, blessing it by name,
Laid safely by itself, beneath a tree.
poem_title: Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been
explanation: Quietly, I made my way to the dwelling of my beloved and entered the orchard. There, I noticed a glow-worm and placed it safely beneath a tree, blessing it by name.

poem_title: Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been
explanation: The following day, I spent in anticipation, with a mixture of hope and fear. As night fell, a glow-worm shone brightly beneath a nearby tree. Excitedly, I led my beloved Lucy to the location, exclaiming "Look here!" The sight brought us both immense joy and happiness.
I am the mother of a five-year-old boy with a beautiful face and limbs that are perfectly formed. He loves me very much.

text:
One morn we strolled on our dry walk,
Or quiet home all full in view,
And held such intermitted talk
As we are wont to do.
explanation: We took a walk one morning and could see our home in the distance. During our walk, we had sporadic conversations as we usually do.

text:
My thoughts on former pleasures ran;
I thought of Kilve's delightful shore,
Our pleasant home when spring began,
A long, long year before.
explanation: I reminisced about the joys of the past, particularly the delightful shore of Kilve and our pleasant home during the start of spring, which seemed like a distant memory from a year ago.

text:
A day it was when I could bear
Some fond regrets to entertain;
With so much happiness to spare,
I could not feel a pain.
explanation: It was a day where I was capable of acknowledging some nostalgic feelings without being overwhelmed by them. I was so content that I was unable to feel any distress.

text:
The green earth echoed to the feet
Of lambs that bounded through the glade,
From shade to sunshine, and as fleet
From sunshine back to shade.
explanation: The grassy land reverberated with the footsteps of playful lambs leaping around the open space, shifting from the shelter of the trees to the warmth of the sun and returning to the shade as quickly.

text:
Birds warbled round me---and each trace
Of inward sadness had its charm;
Kilve, thought I, was a favoured place,
And so is Liswyn farm.
explanation: The birds sang beautifully around me and even my inner sadness seemed pleasant. I realized that Kilve and Liswyn farm were both special places.

text:
My boy beside me tripped, so slim
And graceful in his rustic dress!
And, as we talked, I questioned him,
In very idleness.
explanation: While walking with my son, he stumbled and I was struck by how elegant he looked in his simple clothing. As we conversed, I asked him questions out of mere curiosity.

text:
'Now tell me, had you rather be,'
I said. and took him by the arm,
'On Kilve's smooth shore, by the green sea,
Or here at Liswyn farm?'
explanation: I asked him which place he would prefer to be; on the smooth shore of Kilve, beside the green sea or at Liswyn farm, and took him by the arm.

text:
In careless mood he looked at me,
While still I held him by the arm,
And said, 'At Kilve I'd rather be
Than here at Liswyn farm.'
explanation: He looked at me carelessly while I grasped his arm and expressed his preference for being at Kilve rather than Liswyn farm.

text:
'Now, little Edward, say why so:
My little Edward, tell me why.'---
'I cannot tell, I do not know.'---
'Why, this is strange,' said I;
explanation: I asked little Edward why he was acting a certain way, but he replied that he did not know why he was doing so. I found this response to be strange and puzzling.

text:
'For, here are woods, hills smooth and warm:
There surely must one reason be
Why you would change sweet Liswyn farm
For Kilve by the green sea.'
explanation: The speaker points out the natural beauty of the woods and hills around them, wondering why anyone would want to leave the sweet Liswyn farm for Kilve by the green sea. There must be a compelling reason for such a move, but the speaker cannot fathom what it might be.

text:
At this, my boy hung down his head,
He blushed with shame, nor made reply;
And three times to the child I said,
'Why, :Edward, tell me why?'
explanation: The narrator's son became embarrassed and did not respond when asked a question. The narrator repeated the question three times, urging his son to provide an answer.

text:
His head he raised---there was in sight,
It caught his eye, he saw it plain---
Upon the house-top, glittering bright,
A broad and gilded vane.
explanation: He lifted his head and spotted a shiny object on the rooftop, which immediately caught his attention. The object was a large, gold-colored weathervane that sparkled in the sunlight.

text:
Then did the boy his tongue unlock,
And eased his mind with this reply:
'At Kilve there was no weather-cock;
And that's the reaon why.'
explanation: The boy finally spoke up and explained that there was no weather-cock in Kilve, which was the reason he couldn't answer the man's earlier question.

text:
O dearest, dearest boy! my heart
For better lore would seldom yearn,
Could I but teach the hundredth part
Of what from thee I learn.
explanation: My beloved boy, my heart longs for wisdom that could compare to what I learn from you. If only I could impart a fraction of the knowledge and understanding that you offer.

text:
I HEARD a thousand blended notes,
While in a grove I sate reclined,
In that sweet mood when pleasant thoughts
Bring sad thoughts to the mind.
explanation: As I lounged in a grove, my ears were filled with a harmonious blend of a thousand notes. This brought me to a bittersweet state of mind, where happy thoughts were mingled with sad ones.

text:
To her fair works did Nature link
The human soul that through me ran;
And much it grieved my heart to think
What man has made of man.
explanation: Nature connected the human soul to her beautiful creations, which flowed through me. However, it deeply saddened me to ponder upon the ways in which humans have corrupted each other through their actions.

text:
Through primrose tufts, in that green bower,
The periwinkle trailed its wreaths;
And 'tis my faith that every flower
Enjoys the air it breathes.
explanation: In the green haven, periwinkles trailed their wreaths amidst primrose tufts. The author believes that each flower relishes the air it inhales.

text:
The birds around me hopped and played,
Their thoughts I cannot measure:---
But the least motion which they made,
It seemed a thrill of pleasure.
explanation: The birds in my vicinity were frolicking and amusing themselves, and I cannot fathom their thoughts. However, their every movement appeared to elicit a sensation of joy.

text:
The budding twigs spread out their fan,
To catch the breezy air;
And I must think, do all I can,
That there was pleasure there.
explanation: The young branches of a tree extend themselves in a fan-like shape to capture the refreshing wind. Despite my efforts to resist the idea, I cannot help but believe that the tree experiences some form of delight in this moment.

text:
If this belief from heaven be sent,
If such be Nature's holy plan,
Have I not reason to lament
What man has made of man?
explanation: If this notion is divinely inspired and aligned with the sacred plan of nature, then is it not justifiable for me to grieve over the way humans have treated each other?

text:
I hate that Andrew Jones; he'll breed
His children up to waste and pillage.
I wish the press-gang or the drum
With its tantara sound would come,
And sweep him from the village!
explanation: The speaker expresses a strong dislike for Andrew Jones, believing that he will raise his children to be destructive and harmful. The speaker wishes for a group like the press-gang or the drum to come and remove Andrew from the village. The speaker's desire for Andrew's removal implies that they believe his presence is a negative influence on the community.

text:
I said not this, because he loves
Through the long day to swear and tipple;
But for the poor dear sake of one
To whom a foul deed he had done,
A friendless man, a travelling cripple!
explanation: I objected to the idea of inviting him because he has a habit of drinking and swearing all day long. However, my reason for objecting had nothing to do with his behavior. Rather, it was because he had wronged a helpless and lonely traveling cripple, and I couldn't bear the thought of him being around someone he had mistreated.

text:
For this poor crawling helpless wretch,
Some horseman who was passing by,
A penny on the ground had thrown;
But the poor cripple was alone
And could not stoop--no help was nigh.
explanation: A penniless and disabled person was crawling on the ground when a horseman threw a penny, but the person was unable to pick it up because they were alone and had no assistance.

text:
Inch-thick the dust lay on the ground
For it had long been droughty weather;
So with his staff the cripple wrought
Among the dust till he had brought
The half-pennies together.
explanation: The ground was covered in a thick layer of dust due to the prolonged period of drought. A crippled man used his staff to gather half-pennies that were scattered among the dust.

text:
It chanced that Andrew passed that way
Just at the time; and there he found
The cripple in the mid-day heat
Standing alone, and at his feet
He saw the penny on the ground.
explanation: Andrew happened to come across a cripple standing alone in the scorching mid-day heat. At the man's feet, he noticed a penny lying on the ground.

text:
He stopped and took the penny up:
And when the cripple nearer drew,
Quoth Andrew, "Under half-a-crown,
What a man finds is all his own,
And so, my Friend, good-day to you."
explanation: Andrew picked up a penny from the ground and when a beggar approached him, he stated that anything worth less than half-a-crown that one finds is their own. He then bid the beggar farewell.

text:
And 'hence' I said, that Andrew's boys
Will all be trained to waste and pillage;
And wished the press-gang, or the drum
With its tantara sound, would come
And sweep him from the village.
explanation: I stated that Andrew's sons will be taught to destroy and plunder, and I hoped that either the press-gang or the drum, with its loud call to arms, would come and take him away from the town.

The woman he saw was a beautiful and fleeting sight, appearing like a lovely vision that was there for only a moment. Her eyes were akin to twinkling stars, and her hair was as dark as the sky at dusk. She exuded an aura of springtime and new beginnings, with a carefree and lively spirit. She danced and moved with grace, like a happy apparition that could surprise and enchant anyone who saw her.

Upon closer inspection, I observed a woman who embodied both a spirit and a human. Her movements were effortless and unconstrained, reflective of her free-spirited nature. Her face exuded a gentle sweetness, with promises of hope and joy. She was not too perfect or unattainable for ordinary human beings, but rather someone relatable, who experienced the ups and downs of life, with moments of sadness, happiness, love, and affection.

The speaker observes the inner workings of a machine and sees it as a living being with thought and breath, capable of traveling between life and death. This being possesses strong reasoning, a calm temperament, endurance, foresight, strength, and skill. It is a perfect woman with a noble plan to warn, comfort, and command, yet still possesses a spirit that shines with an angelic light.

There is no clear boundary between sacred and profane ground, as the same turf and pathways connect them. The resting places of the dead, whether in gardens or family plots, blend together without distinction. The mingling of features and sounds create a peaceful atmosphere that is enhanced by the gentle breezes carrying the scent of flowers.

text:
And while those lofty poplars gently wave
Their tops, between them comes and goes a sky
Bright as the glimpses of eternity,
To saints accorded in their mortal hour.
explanation: The tall poplar trees sway gently, creating a space where the bright sky appears and disappears, like a glimpse of eternity that is given to saints during their lifetime.

text:
.   I thought of Thee, my partner and my guide,
As being past away.--Vain sympathies!
For, backward, Duddon! as I cast my eyes,
I see what was, and is, and will abide;
explanation: As I reflect on you, my companion and mentor, I fear you are no longer with me. But such thoughts are futile, as I look back and witness the enduring presence of the Duddon River. What was, still is, and always will be, providing a source of comfort and continuity amidst the passing of time.

The stream flows continuously and will continue to do so indefinitely. The physical appearance of things may endure, but their purpose will eventually expire. As individuals, no matter how courageous, powerful, or intelligent we may be, we will eventually disappear. However, if we are able to contribute something meaningful to the world that can continue to exist and have an impact, that is enough. As we approach death, we may find comfort in our love, hope, and faith, and realize that we possess greater potential than we ever imagined.

text:
.   Who is the happy Warrior? Who is he
That every man in arms should wish to be?
--It is the generous Spirit, who, when brought
Among the tasks of real life, hath wrought
Upon the plan that pleased his boyish thought:
Whose high endeavours are an inward light
That makes the path before him always bright;
explanation: The happy Warrior is someone that every man in arms would aspire to be like. It is a person with a generous spirit that has taken their childhood dreams and translated them into action in their adult life. Their high aspirations act as an inner light that illuminates their path, making it always clear and bright.
Someone who has a natural ability to recognize the value of knowledge and is eager to learn is committed to this pursuit. However, they don't stop there but also prioritize their moral development.

text:
Who, doomed to go in company with Pain,
And Fear, and Bloodshed, miserable train!
Turns his necessity to glorious gain;
In face of these doth exercise a power
Which is our human nature's highest dower:
Controls them and subdues, transmutes, bereaves
Of their bad influence, and their good receives:
By objects, which might force the soul to abate
Her feeling, rendered more compassionate;
explanation: There is someone who, despite being forced to endure Pain, Fear, and Bloodshed, manages to turn their struggles into something positive. They possess a unique power that allows them to control and overcome these negative emotions, ultimately transforming them into something good. This power is considered to be the greatest trait of human nature. The individual can even use their experiences to become more compassionate towards others who are going through similar struggles.

One can become placable because situations arise that require sacrifice. With greater self-awareness and purity, one becomes more skilled at enduring temptations and hardships. The more one is exposed to suffering and distress, the better equipped they become to handle it.

text:
Thence, also, more alive to tenderness.
--'Tis he whose law is reason; who depends
Upon that law as on the best of friends;
Whence, in a state where men are tempted still
To evil for a guard against worse ill,
And what in quality or act is best
Doth seldom on a right foundation rest,
He labours good on good to fix, and owes
To virtue every triumph that he knows:
--Who, if he rise to station of command,
Rises by open means; and there will stand
On honourable terms, or else retire,
And in himself possess his own desire;
explanation: The person referred to is someone who is sensitive and compassionate. They follow the law of reason and rely on it like a trusted friend. They live in a society where people often do bad things to protect themselves from worse outcomes, and where the best actions are not always based on solid principles. Despite this, they work hard to establish good on good and attribute their successes to their own virtue. They gain power through honest means and will only remain in a position of authority if it is honorable. If not, they will step down and be content with their own personal goals.

The person who understands their responsibilities and stays committed to them without any ulterior motives, such as pursuing wealth, status, or personal gain, is worthy of trust. This individual does not compromise their values or resort to deceitful tactics to achieve success.

text:
Whom they must follow; on whose head must fall,
Like showers of manna, if they come at all:
Whose powers shed round him in the common strife,
Or mild concerns of ordinary life,
A constant influence, a peculiar grace;
explanation: They must follow someone who is a source of guidance and inspiration. This person must possess qualities that are beneficial to all, whether it be in everyday situations or during times of conflict. Their presence should have a positive impact on those around them, and they should exude a unique charm and poise.

text:
But who, if he be called upon to face
Some awful moment to which Heaven has joined
Great issues, good or bad for human kind,
Is happy as a Lover; and attired
With sudden brightness, like a Man inspired;
explanation: When faced with a significant moment that holds the fate of humanity, there is no one happier than a person in love. They are filled with a sudden brightness and inspiration, like a divine force has taken over them.

text:
And, through the heat of conflict, keeps the law
In calmness made, and sees what he foresaw;
Or if an unexpected call succeed,
Come when it will, is equal to the need:
--He who, though thus endued as with a sense
And faculty for storm and turbulence,
Is yet a Soul whose master-bias leans
To homefelt pleasures and to gentle scenes;
explanation: This passage describes a person who is able to maintain calmness and uphold the law even in times of conflict. They are prepared for unexpected situations and are able to handle them with ease. Despite their ability to handle chaos, they still have a preference for peaceful and comforting environments.

text:
Sweet images! which, wheresoe'er he be,
Are at his heart; and such fidelity
It is his darling passion to approve;
More brave for this, that he hath much to love:--
'Tis, finally, the Man, who, lifted high,
Conspicuous object in a Nation's eye,
Or left unthought-of in obscurity,--
Who, with a toward or untoward lot,
Prosperous or adverse, to his wish or not--
Plays, in the many games of life, that one
Where what he most doth value must be won:
Whom neither shape or danger can dismay,
Nor thought of tender happiness betray;
explanation: The person who values sweet images and fidelity is a brave soul who has much to love. This person may be a prominent figure in society or unknown to the world, but they play the game of life where they must win what they value most. They are not easily discouraged by obstacles or danger, nor do they let thoughts of happiness distract them from their goals. This person's passion for loyalty and love is undeniable.

text:
Who, not content that former worth stand fast,
Looks forward, persevering to the last,
From well to better, daily self-surpast:
Who, whether praise of him must walk the earth
For ever, and to noble deeds give birth,
Or he must fall, to sleep without his fame,
And leave a dead unprofitable name--
Finds comfort in himself and in his cause;
explanation: The person who strives to surpass their previous achievements and continually improve, even if their efforts go unnoticed or unrewarded. They find solace in their own actions and beliefs, regardless of whether they receive recognition or are forgotten after their passing. Their motivation comes from within, and they are dedicated to their cause.

text:
And, while the mortal mist is gathering, draws
His breath in confidence of Heaven's applause:
This is the happy Warrior; this is he
That every man in arms should wish to be.
explanation: The confident warrior who draws his breath while the mortal mist is gathering is the one who should be admired and emulated by all men in arms. He is the happy warrior who seeks Heaven's approval.

text:
Nuns fret not at their convent's narrow room;
And hermits are contented with their cells;
And students with their pensive citadels;
Maids at the wheel, the weaver at his loom,
Sit blithe and happy; bees that soar for bloom,
High as the highest Peak of Furness-fells,
Will murmur by the hour in foxglove bells:
In truth the prison, unto which we doom
Ourselves, no prison is: and hence for me,
In sundry moods, 'twas pastime to be bound
Within the Sonnet's scanty plot of ground;
Pleased if some Souls (for such there needs must be)
Who have felt the weight of too much liberty,
Should find brief solace there, as I have found.
poem_title: Nuns Fret Not At Their Convent's Narrow Room
explanation: The speaker reflects on various individuals who are content with their limited living spaces, such as nuns in their convent, hermits in their cells, and students in their study halls. The speaker goes on to suggest that even beings such as bees who are confined to a small area are happy and content. The speaker then argues that the figurative "prisons" we create for ourselves are not truly limiting and can even be enjoyable, citing their own pleasure in the limitations of writing sonnets. The speaker hopes that others who have experienced the overwhelming nature of too much freedom can also find comfort in these limitations.

text:
GENIUS of Raphael! if thy wings
Might bear thee to this glen,
With faithful memory left of things
To pencil dear and pen,
Thou would'st forego the neighbouring Rhine,
And all his majesty--
A studious forehead to incline
O'er this poor family.
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: The speaker admires Raphael's artistic talent and wishes that he could come to the speaker's location and create a masterpiece of the scene. The speaker believes that Raphael would be more interested in capturing the essence of the simple family in the glen rather than the grandeur of the Rhine River nearby.

text:
The Mother--her thou must have seen,
In spirit, ere she came
To dwell these rifted rocks between,
Or found on earth a name;
An image, too, of that sweet Boy,
Thy inspirations give--
Of playfulness, and love, and joy,
Predestined here to live.
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: The speaker is referring to a mother and a boy who are both significant to them. They suggest that the mother is not just a physical entity that can be seen, but also a spiritual presence that was present before she came to live in the rocky landscape. They also mention the boy, who they describe as playful, loving, and joyful, and assert that their own inspirations have predestined him to live in this particular place.

text:
Downcast, or shooting glances far,
How beautiful his eyes,
That blend the nature of the star
With that of summer skies!
I speak as if of sense beguiled;
Uncounted months are gone,
Yet am I with the Jewish Child,
That exquisite Saint John.
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: The speaker is admiring the beauty of someone's eyes, describing them as a combination of starry and summery qualities. They feel as though they are under a spell, as if they are transported back in time to when they were with Saint John from the Bible. The language used is poetic and romantic, emphasizing the speaker's admiration for this person's eyes.

text:
I see the dark-brown curls, the brow,
The smooth transparent skin,
Refined, as with intent to show
The holiness within;
The grace of parting Infancy
By blushes yet untamed;
Age faithful to the mother's knee,
Nor of her arms ashamed.
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: The speaker describes a person with dark-brown curls, a smooth and transparent brow, and refined skin that seem to indicate an inner holiness. The person also possesses a graceful yet untamed quality that suggests youth and innocence, while also exhibiting a faithful devotion to their mother. The speaker admires this person's physical and emotional attributes, which seem to embody a sense of purity and virtue.

text:
Two lovely Sisters, still and sweet
As flowers, stand side by side;
Their soul-subduing looks might cheat
The Christian of his pride:
Such beauty hath the Eternal poured
Upon them not forlorn,
Though of a lineage once abhorred,
Nor yet redeemed from scorn.
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: There are two sisters who are standing together, still and sweet, like flowers. Their looks are able to subdue one's soul and even deceive a Christian of his pride. They possess such beauty that has been bestowed upon them by the Eternal, despite their lineage being once abhorred and not yet redeemed from scorn.

text:
Mysterious safeguard, that, in spite
Of poverty and wrong,
Doth here preserve a living light,
From Hebrew fountains sprung;
That gives this ragged group to cast
Around the dell a gleam
Of Palestine, of glory past,
And proud Jerusalem!
poem_title: A Jewish Family In A Small Valley Opposite St. Goar, Upon The Rhine
explanation: Despite poverty and injustice, there is a mysterious force that protects and preserves a living light that originated from Hebrew sources. This light allows a ragged group to shine a glimpse of the glory of Palestine's past and proud Jerusalem around the dell.

text:
IT is a beauteous evening, calm and free,
The holy time is quiet as a Nun
Breathless with adoration; the broad sun
Is sinking down in its tranquillity;
explanation: The evening is serene and peaceful, with the atmosphere like that of a nun in a state of awe. The sun is slowly descending into the horizon, creating a sense of stillness and calmness.

text:
The gentleness of heaven broods o'er the sea:
Listen! the mighty Being is awake,
And doth with his eternal motion make
A sound like thunder--everlastingly.
explanation: The peacefulness of the sky watches over the sea. The powerful being is awake, and its constant movement creates a thunderous sound that persists without end.

text:
Dear Child! dear Girl! that walkest with me here,
If thou appear untouch'd by solemn thought,
Thy nature is not therefore less divine:
Thou liest in Abraham's bosom all the year;
And worshipp'st at the Temple's inner shrine,
God being with thee when we know it not.
explanation: This poem is addressed to a young girl who walks with the speaker. The speaker assures the girl that even if she appears carefree and not contemplative, it does not diminish her divine nature. The speaker believes that the girl is constantly in the presence of God and is close to Abraham. Despite not being aware of it, God is always with her. The poem emphasizes the girl's inherent divinity and the sacredness of her being.

text:
"Why, William, on that old grey stone,
Thus for the length of half a day,
Why, William, sit you thus alone,
And dream your time away?
explanation: William is sitting alone on an old grey stone for half a day, lost in his thoughts. Someone approaches him and asks why he is sitting there and wasting his time daydreaming.

text:
"Where are your books?--that light bequeathed
To Beings else forlorn and blind!
Up! up! and drink the spirit breathed
From dead men to their kind.
explanation: Do you know where your books are? They hold knowledge and wisdom that can help those who are lost and unaware. Rise up and absorb the essence left behind by those who have passed, as it can be passed on to future generations.

text:
"You look round on your Mother Earth,
As if she for no purpose bore you;
As if you were her first-born birth,
And none had lived before you!"
explanation: It seems as though you are disregarding the history and existence of the world before you were born, looking at the earth as if it was created solely for your benefit. It is as if you believe you are the only important thing in the world and forget that others have come before and will come after you.

text:
One morning thus, by Esthwaite lake,
When life was sweet, I knew not why,
To me my good friend Matthew spake,
And thus I made reply:
explanation: I was enjoying a pleasant morning by Esthwaite lake, feeling content but unsure why. My friend Matthew spoke to me, and I responded to him.

Our eyes are always open and we are unable to control what we see. Our ears cannot be silenced, they always hear. Our bodies sense their surroundings whether we want them to or not, either in harmony or opposition.

text:
"Nor less I deem that there are Powers
Which of themselves our minds impress;
That we can feed this mind of ours
In a wise passiveness.
explanation: I believe that there are forces that influence our minds without our conscious effort, and that we are capable of nurturing our minds through a state of thoughtful inactivity.

text:
"Think you, 'mid all this mighty sum
Of things for ever speaking,
That nothing of itself will come,
But we must still be seeking?
explanation: Amidst the vastness of the universe and all the things that exist within it, do we truly believe that something new and significant will simply manifest without our active pursuit of it? We must not passively wait for opportunities or solutions to present themselves, but instead actively seek them out in order to progress and move forward.

text:
"--Then ask not wherefore, here, alone,
Conversing as I may,
I sit upon this old grey stone,
And dream my time away,"
explanation: "I am sitting here alone on this old grey stone, lost in thought and daydreaming. Don't ask me why I'm here or what I'm doing, I just need this time to myself."

text:
'MISERRIMUS,' and neither name nor date,
Prayer, text, or symbol, graven upon the stone;
Nought but that word assigned to the unknown,
That solitary word--to separate
From all, and cast a cloud around the fate
Of him who lies beneath. Most wretched one,
'Who' chose his epitaph?--Himself alone
Could thus have dared the grave to agitate,
And claim, among the dead, this awful crown;
poem_title: A Gravestone Upon The Floor In The Cloisters Of Worcester Cathedral
explanation: The word 'MISERRIMUS' is the only inscription on a grave, with no name, date, or symbol to provide any context. The word seems to be a deliberate choice by the deceased, as it sets them apart and shrouds their fate in mystery. The speaker wonders why someone would choose such a bleak epitaph for themselves, and suggests that only the deceased could have had the courage to do so. The word stands out among the other graves as a haunting reminder of the unknown person buried beneath.

text:
Nor doubt that He marked also for his own
Close to these cloistral steps a burial-place,
That every foot might fall with heavier tread,
Trampling upon his vileness. Stranger, pass
Softly!--To save the contrite, Jesus bled.
poem_title: A Gravestone Upon The Floor In The Cloisters Of Worcester Cathedral
explanation: There is no question that the burial place close to the cloistered steps was intended for the man who wrote the inscription. The purpose of this burial place was to remind people of his sins and wrongdoings, so that they would tread more heavily upon it as a sign of disrespect. However, the inscription also reminds us that Jesus bled to save those who are truly sorry for their sins. Therefore, as strangers pass by, they should do so quietly and with respect for the sacrifice that Jesus made for humanity.

Oh Milton! If only you were alive today, England would greatly benefit from your presence. The country is like a swamp, with still and stagnant waters. The virtues of English life, such as religion, military might, literature, family, and wealth, have all lost their true value and meaning. We have become selfish individuals, consumed by our own desires and neglecting the greater good of our society.

text:
Oh! raise us up, return to us again;
And give us manners, virtue, freedom, power.
Thy soul was like a Star, and dwelt apart;
Thou hadst a voice whose sound was like the sea:
Pure as the naked heavens, majestic, free,
So didst thou travel on life's common way,
In cheerful godliness; and yet thy heart
The lowliest duties on herself did lay.
explanation: Please bring us back and help us regain our manners, virtue, freedom, and power. Your soul was like a star that stood out from the rest, and your voice was as mighty as the sea. You were pure like the sky and moved through life with grace and godliness, never forgetting to fulfill even the humblest responsibilities.

text:
THE Danish Conqueror, on his royal chair,
Mustering a face of haughty sovereignty,
To aid a covert purpose, cried--'O ye
Approaching Waters of the deep, that share
With this green isle my fortunes, come not where
Your Master's throne is set.'--Deaf was the Sea;
poem_title: A Fact, And An Imagination, Or, Canute And Alfred, On The Seashore
explanation: The Danish Conqueror sat on his throne with a proud and commanding expression, and with a hidden agenda, he warned the approaching waters of the sea, which shared his fortunes with the green isle, not to come close to his throne. However, the sea ignored his warning, as it was deaf to his words.

text:
Her waves rolled on, respecting his decree
Less than they heed a breath of wanton air.
--Then Canute, rising from the invaded throne,
Said to his servile Courtiers,--'Poor the reach,
The undisguised extent, of mortal sway!
He only is a King, and he alone
Deserves the name (this truth the billows preach)
Whose everlasting laws, sea, earth, and heaven, obey.'
This just reproof the prosperous Dane
Drew, from the influx of the main,
For some whose rugged northern mouths would strain
At oriental flattery;
poem_title: A Fact, And An Imagination, Or, Canute And Alfred, On The Seashore
explanation: Canute, a powerful king, commanded the waves to stop rolling towards him, but as they continued to do so, he realized the limitations of mortal power. He rose from his throne and declared that only a king who could command the sea, earth, and heaven could truly deserve the title, as demonstrated by the waves' disregard for his orders. This rebuke was directed towards his courtiers who sought flattery and were willing to compromise their northern integrity for eastern praise. The episode highlights the importance of humility and the recognition of one's limitations in the face of nature's power.

text:
And Canute (fact more worthy to be known)
From that time forth did for his brows disown
The ostentatious symbol of a crown;
Esteeming earthly royalty
Contemptible as vain.
poem_title: A Fact, And An Imagination, Or, Canute And Alfred, On The Seashore
explanation: Canute, a historical figure, is known for rejecting the use of a crown as a symbol of his power. He considered earthly royalty to be worthless and did not want to be associated with it. Instead, he chose to focus on more meaningful actions that would benefit his people.

text:
Now hear what one of elder days,
Rich theme of England's fondest praise,
Her darling Alfred, 'might' have spoken;
To cheer the remnant of his host
When he was driven from coast to coast,
Distressed and harassed, but with mind unbroken:
'My faithful followers, lo! the tide is spent
That rose, and steadily advanced to fill
The shores and channels, working Nature's will
Among the mazy streams that backward went,
And in the sluggish pools where ships are pent:
And now, his task performed, the flood stands still,
At the green base of many an inland hill,
In placid beauty and sublime content!
Such the repose that sage and hero find;
poem_title: A Fact, And An Imagination, Or, Canute And Alfred, On The Seashore
explanation: In this passage, we hear the voice of Alfred, a revered figure in English history, who may have spoken to his followers during a time of great difficulty. He encourages them to see that the tide has turned and that they can find peace in the stillness that follows. Alfred speaks of the natural forces that have brought them to this moment and emphasizes the importance of finding rest and contentment amidst the chaos of battle. He reminds them that even great men such as himself find solace in quiet contemplation, and that they too can find strength in the stillness. This passage is a tribute to the resilience of the human spirit and the power of nature to bring us peace.

text:
Such measured rest the sedulous and good
Of humbler name; whose souls do, like the flood
Of Ocean, press right on; or gently wind,
Neither to be diverted nor withstood,
Until they reach the bounds by Heaven assigned.'
poem_title: A Fact, And An Imagination, Or, Canute And Alfred, On The Seashore
explanation: Those who are diligent and humble in nature find comfort in a steady pace towards their goals, much like the unwavering flow of the ocean. They are not easily discouraged or deterred, and will continue on their path until they have reached their predetermined destination.

text:
I heard a thousand blended notes
While in a grove I sat reclined,
In that sweet mood when pleasant thoughts
Bring sad thoughts to the mind.
explanation: As I sat in a grove, I heard a harmonious blend of a thousand musical notes. It was a bittersweet moment where happy thoughts brought about a tinge of sadness to my mind.

text:
To her fair works did Nature link
The human soul that through me ran;
And much it grieved my heart to think
What Man has made of Man.
explanation: Nature has connected the human soul to her beautiful creations, and it saddens me to think about the negative impact that humans have had on each other and the world around them.

text:
Through primrose tufts, in that sweet bower,
The periwinkle trailed its wreaths;
And 'tis my faith that every flower
Enjoys the air it breathes.
explanation: Amidst the primrose tufts, the periwinkle crept and wound its way, creating a beautiful wreath. The speaker believes that every flower, like the periwinkle, takes pleasure in the air it inhales.

text:
The birds around me hopped and played,
Their thoughts I cannot measure -
But the least motion which they made
It seemed a thrill of pleasure.
explanation: As I observed the birds around me, I noticed that they were hopping and playing with an indeterminate level of cognitive activity. However, every movement they made seemed to be accompanied by a sense of joy and excitement.

text:
The budding twigs spread out their fan
To catch the breezy air;
And I must think, do all I can,
That there was pleasure there.
explanation: The young twigs extend their branches to catch the gentle wind, and despite my efforts to resist the thought, I cannot help but believe that they are enjoying themselves.

text:
If this belief from heaven be sent,
If such be Nature's holy plan,
Have I not reason to lament
What Man has made of Man?
explanation: This statement questions the purpose of human existence and the actions that humans have taken. It suggests that if our beliefs and nature come from a divine source, then it is unfortunate that humans have not lived up to these standards. The author expresses regret at the state of humanity and the choices that have been made, implying that there is a higher standard that has been neglected.

text:
When Love was born of heavenly line,
What dire intrigues disturbed Cythera's joy!
Till Venus cried, 'A mother's heart is mine;
None but myself shall nurse my boy,'
explanation: When the deity of Love was born, there were many chaotic schemes that disrupted the happiness of Cythera. Venus, the goddess of love and beauty, was distraught and declared that she would be the only one to care for her son.

text:
But, infant as he was, the child
In that divine embrace enchanted lay;
And, by the beauty of the vase beguiled,
Forgot the beverage- and pined away.
explanation: The infant child was enchanted by the divine embrace and lay in it, forgetting about the beverage in the beautiful vase. However, he became entranced and wasted away due to the beauty of the vase.

text:
'And must my offspring languish in my sight? '
(Alive to all a mother's pain,
The Queen of Beauty thus her court addressed)
'No: Let the most discreet of all my train
Receive him to her breast:
Think all, he is the God of young delight.'
explanation: The Queen of Beauty spoke to her court, expressing her concern for her offspring who she did not want to see suffer. She requested that the most responsible member of her court take care of her child, as he is the God of young pleasure.

text:
Then TENDERNESS with CANDOUR joined,
And GAIETY the charming office sought;
Nor even DELICACY stayed behind:
But none of those fair Graces brought
explanation:
their court
To HUMILITY.

text:
Wherewith to nurse the child- and still he pined.
Some fond hearts to COMPLIANCE seemed inclined;
But she had surely spoiled the boy:
And sad experience forbade a thought
On the wild Goddess of VOLUPTUOUS JOY.
explanation: The child was not thriving despite attempts to care for him. Some people were willing to give in to the child's desires, but it was clear that he had been spoiled by someone. Previous negative experiences made it impossible to consider indulging in pleasure-seeking behavior.

text:
Long undecided lay th' important choice,
Till of the beauteous court, at length, a voice
Pronounced the name of HOPE:- The conscious child
Stretched forth his little arms, and smiled.
explanation: The decision was a difficult one and took a long time to make. Eventually, someone from the beautiful court spoke up and said the word "Hope." At that moment, the child who knew the answer all along reached out their arms and smiled.

text:
'Tis said ENJOYMENT (who averred
The charge belonged to her alone)
Jealous that HOPE had been preferred
Laid snares to make the babe her own.
explanation: It is rumored that ENJOYMENT, who claimed to be the only one responsible for bringing happiness, became jealous when HOPE was given credit. ENJOYMENT set traps to take possession of the infant HOPE.

text:
Of INNOCENCE the garb she took,
The blushing mien and downcast look;
And came her services to proffer:
And HOPE (what has not Hope believed!)
By that seducing air deceived,
Accepted of the offer.
explanation: She dressed herself in the guise of innocence, adopting a shy and modest demeanor as she presented her services. Hope, always willing to believe in the best of intentions, was beguiled by her charming appearance and accepted her offer without suspicion.

text:
It happened that, to sleep inclined,
Deluded HOPE: for one short hour
To that false INNOCENCE'S power
Her little charge consigned.
explanation: HOPE was feeling sleepy and decided to trust in the false sense of purity from INNOCENCE for a brief moment, leaving her responsibilities in the hands of INNOCENCE.

text:
The Goddess then her lap with sweetmeats filled
And gave, in handfuls gave, the treacherous store:
A wild delirium first the infant thrilled;
But soon upon her breast he sunk- to wake no more.
explanation: The Goddess gave the infant sweetmeats, filling her lap and giving handfuls of the treacherous store. The infant was thrilled at first, but soon fell into a deep sleep on the Goddess's breast and did not wake up again.

text:
I TRAVELL'D among unknown men,
In lands beyond the sea;
Nor, England! did I know till then
What love I bore to thee.
explanation: I journeyed to foreign lands and met unfamiliar people, but it wasn't until then that I realized how much I loved my home country, England.

text:
'Tis past, that melancholy dream!
Nor will I quit thy shore
A second time; for still I seem
To love thee more and more.
explanation: The sad dream is now over and I won't leave your side again as my love for you continues to grow stronger.

text:
Among thy mountains did I feel
The joy of my desire;
And she I cherish'd turn'd her wheel
Beside an English fire.
explanation: I experienced happiness in the mountains I love and the person I love was spinning wool by an English fire.

text:
Thy mornings showed, thy nights conceal'd,
The bowers where Lucy played;
And thine too is the last green field
That Lucy's eyes survey'd.
explanation: Lucy spent her days in the gardens that were visible during the daytime, while at night she hid away from view. The final landscape she laid her eyes on was the verdant field that now belongs to you.

text:
It is a beauteous evening, calm and free,
The holy time is quiet as a nun
Breathless with adoration; the broad sun
Is sinking down in its tranquility;
explanation: The evening is peaceful and serene, with a sense of holiness that is reminiscent of a nun in deep adoration. The sun sets slowly, casting a tranquil glow over the surroundings.

text:
The gentleness of heaven broods o'er the sea:
Listen! the mighty Being is awake,
And doth with his eternal motion make
A sound like thunder - everlastingly.
explanation: The calmness of the sky extends over the ocean. Pay attention! The powerful entity is alert and continuously creates a noise akin to thunder with its everlasting movement.

text:
Dear Child! dear Girl! that walkest with me here,
If thou appear untouched by solemn thought,
Thy nature is not therefore less divine:
Thou liest in Abraham's bosom all the year,
And worship'st at the Temple's inner shrine,
God being with thee when we know it not.
explanation: The speaker addresses a young girl, expressing that if she appears to not be deep in thought, this does not diminish her divine nature. The speaker believes that the girl is constantly in the presence of God, likening it to being in Abraham's bosom or worshipping in the inner sanctum of a temple. The speaker emphasizes that even if they are not aware of it, the girl is always in the company of the divine.

text:
The little hedgerow birds,
That peck along the roads, regard him not.
He travels on, and in his face, his step,
His gait, is one expression: every limb,
His look and bending figure, all bespeak
A man who does not move with pain, but moves
With thought.--He is insensibly subdued
To settled quiet: he is one by whom
All effort seems forgotten; one to whom
Long patience hath such mild composure given,
That patience now doth seem a thing of which
He hath no need. He is by nature led
To peace so perfect that the young behold
With envy, what the Old Man hardly feels.
explanation: The man walks along the road, ignored by the small birds in the hedges. His every movement and expression convey a sense of ease and thoughtfulness. He seems to move without effort or pain, and has become so accustomed to patience that it seems effortless to him. His peaceful demeanor is envied by the young, but for the old man, it is simply a natural state of being.

text:
SURPRISED by joy--impatient as the Wind
I turned to share the transport--O! with whom
But Thee, deep buried in the silent tomb,
That spot which no vicissitude can find?
Love, faithful love, recall'd thee to my mind--
But how could I forget thee? Through what power,
Even for the least division of an hour,
Have I been so beguiled as to be blind
To my most grievous loss?--That thought's return
Was the worst pang that sorrow ever bore,
Save one, one only, when I stood forlorn,
Knowing my heart's best treasure was no more;
That neither present time, nor years unborn
Could to my sight that heavenly face restore.
explanation: The speaker expresses their surprise at feeling joy but quickly becomes impatient to share it with someone. They realize that the person they wish to share it with is buried in a tomb and cannot be found. The speaker recalls their love for this person but wonders how they could have forgotten them even for a moment. The thought of their loss is painful, and the worst moment of sorrow was when they realized that they could never see their loved one's face again, no matter how much time passes.

text:
Wisdom and Spirit of the universe!
Thou Soul, that art the Eternity of thought!
And giv'st to forms and images a breath
And everlasting motion! not in vain,
By day or star-light, thus from my first dawn
Of childhood didst thou intertwine for me
The passions that build up our human soul;
explanation: The speaker addresses the universe's wisdom and spirit, which they see as the eternal essence of thought. They believe that this essence gives life and motion to all forms and images. The speaker reflects on how this essence has guided them since childhood, intertwining passions that shape the human soul.

text:
Not with the mean and vulgar works of Man;
But with high objects, with enduring things,
With life and nature; purifying thus
The elements of feeling and of thought,
And sanctifying by such discipline
Both pain and fear,--until we recognise
A grandeur in the beatings of the heart.
explanation: We should focus on noble and lasting things, such as life and nature, instead of the crude and offensive creations of humanity. This will cleanse our emotions and thoughts, and elevate our experiences of pain and fear to a higher level. Through this discipline, we will come to appreciate the greatness of our own hearts.

text:
Nor was this fellowship vouchsafed to me
With stinted kindness. In November days,
When vapours rolling down the valleys made
A lonely scene more lonesome; among woods
At noon; and 'mid the calm of summer nights,
When, by the margin of the trembling lake,
Beneath the gloomy hills, homeward I went
In solitude, such intercourse was mine:
Mine was it in the fields both day and night,
And by the waters, all the summer long.
explanation: I was not granted this companionship with any lack of kindness. During the dreary November days, when fog crept through the valleys, and even in the solitude of the woods at noon, or the stillness of summer nights when I journeyed home by the quivering lake beneath the dark hills, I had such companionship. It was with me in the fields day and night, and by the waters all throughout the summer.

text:
And in the frosty season, when the sun
Was set, and, visible for many a mile,
The cottage-windows through the twilight blazed,
I heeded not the summons: happy time
It was indeed for all of us; for me
It was a time of rapture! Clear and loud
The village-clock tolled six--I wheeled about,
Proud and exulting like an untired horse
That cares not for his home.--All shod with steel
We hissed along the polished ice, in games
Confederate, imitative of the chase
And woodland pleasures,--the resounding horn,
The pack loud-chiming, and the hunted hare.
explanation: During the winter season, as the sun set and the cottage windows emitted a warm glow in the twilight, I ignored any calls to return home. It was a joyous time for all of us, but for me it was particularly blissful. As the village clock rang six, I spun around with pride, feeling like an untiring horse that has no interest in returning home. With steel-clad feet, we glided along the smooth ice, playing games that mimicked the enjoyment of hunting in the woods, complete with the echoing horn, the pack of hounds bellowing loudly, and the thrill of chasing a hare.

text:
So through the darkness and the cold we flew,
And not a voice was idle: with the din
Smitten, the precipices rang aloud;
The leafless trees and every icy crag
Tinkled like iron; while far-distant hills
Into the tumult sent an alien sound
Of melancholy, not unnoticed while the stars,
Eastward, were sparkling clear, and in the west
The orange sky of evening died away.
explanation: We flew through the darkness and cold, and every voice was speaking. The noise echoed off the steep cliffs, and even the bare trees and icy rocks made a tinkling sound like iron. In the distance, the hills added to the commotion with a sad melody, which was not ignored even as the stars shone brightly in the east and the sun set in the west.

text:
Not seldom from the uproar I retired
Into a silent bay, or sportively
Glanced sideway, leaving the tumultuous throng,
To cut across the reflex of a star;
explanation: Sometimes when there was chaos around, I would seek solace in a quiet spot or playfully take a glance aside, distancing myself from the noisy crowd, to skim across the reflection of a star.

text:
Image, that, flying still before me, gleamed
Upon the glassy plain: and oftentimes,
When we had given our bodies to the wind,
And all the shadowy banks on either side
Came sweeping through the darkness, spinning still
The rapid line of motion, then at once
Have I, reclining back upon my heels,
Stopped short; yet still the solitary cliffs
Wheeled by me--even as if the earth had rolled
With visible motion her diurnal round!
Behind me did they stretch in solemn train,
Feebler and feebler, and I stood and watched
Till all was tranquil as a summer sea.
explanation: The speaker describes a flying image that he sees ahead of him while traveling on a plain. As they move forward, the shadows of the banks on either side pass by quickly, creating a sense of motion. The speaker is so taken by the experience that he stops and watches as the solitary cliffs behind him slowly fade away into the distance. He is left in peaceful stillness as if he were standing on a tranquil summer sea.

text:
The little hedgerow birds,
That peck along the road, regard him not.
He travels on, and in his face, his step,
His gait, is one expression; every limb,
His look and bending figure, all bespeak
A man who does not move with pain, but moves
With thought. -He is insensibly subdued
To settled quiet: he is one by whom
All effort seems forgotten; one to whom
Long patience hath such mild composure given
That patience now doth seem a thing of which
He hath no need. He is by nature led
To peace so perfect, that the young behold
With envy what the Old Man hardly feels.
explanation: The birds on the hedgerow pay no attention to the man walking along the road. His movements, posture, and facial expressions all indicate that he is not walking in pain, but rather with intention. He exudes a sense of settled calmness and effortless ease, as if patience has become second nature to him. The man seems so naturally at peace that even younger people envy his composure, which he hardly seems to notice himself.

text:
.  Most sweet it is with unuplifted eyes
To pace the ground, if path be there or none,
While a fair region round the traveller lies
Which he forbears again to look upon;
explanation: Walking with eyes cast down is a pleasant experience, whether there is a path or not. The traveler finds themselves surrounded by a beautiful area but chooses not to look up and admire it.

text:
Pleased rather with some soft ideal scene,
The work of Fancy, or some happy tone
Of meditation, slipping in between
The beauty coming and the beauty gone.
explanation: One finds more satisfaction in envisioning an idyllic setting created by imagination or a pleasant state of reflection that intervenes between the arrival and departure of beauty.

text:
If Thought and Love desert us, from that day
Let us break off all commerce with the Muse:
With Thought and Love companions of our way,
Whate'er the senses take or may refuse,
The Mind's internal heaven shall shed her dews
Of inspiration on the humblest lay.
explanation: If we lose the presence and influence of Thought and Love, then we should cease all connection with the Muse. Thought and Love are essential companions on our journey, regardless of what our senses may accept or reject. The Muse's inspiration derives from the internal heaven of the mind and enriches even the simplest of works.

text:
One who was suffering tumult in his soul,
Yet failed to seek the sure relief of prayer,
Went forth--his course surrendering to the care
Of the fierce wind, while mid-day lightnings prowl
Insidiously, untimely thunders growl;
explanation: A person who was distressed and troubled within themselves, but did not turn to prayer for comfort, ventured out into the world. They left their fate in the hands of the violent wind, while lightning struck during the day and thunder rumbled at inappropriate times.

text:
While trees, dim-seen, in frenzied numbers, tear
The lingering remnant of their yellow hair,
And shivering wolves, surprised with darkness, howl
As if the sun were not. He raised his eye
Soul-smitten; for, that instant, did appear
Large space ('mid dreadful clouds) of purest sky,
An azure disc--shield of Tranquillity;
Invisible, unlooked-for, minister
Of providential goodness ever nigh!
explanation: The trees are losing their leaves in large numbers and the wolves are howling in the dark. Despite this, the narrator sees a large patch of clear blue sky amidst the clouds, which brings him a sense of peace and hope. The sky represents a shield of tranquility that is always present, even in the midst of chaos and darkness. The narrator sees this as a sign of providential goodness that is always near.

text:
'Up, Timothy, up with your staff and away!
Not a soul in the village this morning will stay;
The hare has just started from Hamilton's grounds,
And Skiddaw is glad with the cry of the hounds.'
explanation: Timothy, it's time to wake up and grab your walking stick because everyone in the village has left. The hare has been spotted running across Hamilton's property and the sound of the hounds chasing after it can be heard from Skiddaw mountain.

text:
--Of coats and of jackets grey, scarlet, and green,
On the slopes of the pastures all colours were seen;
With their comely blue aprons, and caps white as snow,
The girls on the hills made a holiday show.
explanation: In the pastures, there were coats and jackets of various colors such as grey, scarlet, and green. The girls on the hills wore blue aprons and white caps that looked beautiful against the snowy backdrop. It was a festive scene that was pleasing to the eye.

Just six months ago, Timothy had a lush display of green box-wood sprigs in his funeral basin. However, tragedy struck when a coffin was carried through his doorstep, carrying his last remaining child.

text:
Now fast up the dell came the noise and the fray,
The horse and the horn, and the hark! hark away!
Old Timothy took up his staff, and he shut
With a leisurely motion the door of his hut.
explanation: There was a commotion coming up the valley with the sound of a horse and a horn. Old Timothy grabbed his staff and closed the door to his hut in a calm manner.

It is possible that he muttered to himself that he needed to take the key, as his beloved Ellen had passed away. However, he did not utter a single word about it to me and went hunting with a tear rolling down his face.

poem_title: She Was A Phantom Of Delight
explanation: When I first saw her, she was a delightful phantom, a beautiful apparition that was only meant to be admired for a brief moment. Her eyes were as fair as stars in the twilight sky, and her dark hair was reminiscent of the same. Her entire being seemed to be drawn from the cheerful dawn of May, and she moved with a dancing grace that was both gay and haunting. She had a way of startling and waylaying those who were lucky enough to catch a glimpse of her, and she left a lasting impression on those who did.

poem_title: She Was A Phantom Of Delight
explanation: Upon closer inspection, I observed a woman who appeared to be both a spirit and a human. She moved gracefully and effortlessly, with the freedom and innocence of a young woman. Her face was a combination of sweetness and promise, not too perfect to be unattainable for those of us bound by human nature. She was suited for the everyday experiences of life, including its occasional hardships, playful deceptions, compliments, criticism, love, affection, tears, and joy.

poem_title: She Was A Phantom Of Delight
explanation: I now observe the beating heart of the machine with a peaceful gaze. It is a living entity that contemplates existence between life and death. It possesses a steadfast purpose, a temperate will, the ability to endure, foresight, strength, and skill. It is a perfectly designed woman who is capable of inspiring warmth, comfort, and leadership. Although it is a commanding presence, it remains a bright, angelic spirit.

text:
A traveller on the skirt of Sarum's Plain
Pursued his vagrant way, with feet half bare;
Stooping his gait, but not as if to gain
Help from the staff he bore; for mien and air
Were hardy, though his cheek seemed worn with care
Both of the time to come, and time long fled:
Down fell in straggling locks his thin grey hair;
A coat he wore of military red
But faded, and stuck o'er with many a patch and shred.
explanation: A wanderer was walking on the edge of Sarum's Plain. He had bare feet and was slightly hunched, but did not rely on the staff he carried. He appeared tough despite his careworn face, showing concern for both the future and the past. His thin grey hair was unkempt, and he wore a faded military red coat that was patched and tattered.

text:
While thus he journeyed, step by step led on,
He saw and passed a stately inn, full sure
That welcome in such house for him was none.
No board inscribed the needy to allure
Hung there, no bush proclaimed to old and poor
And desolate, "Here you will find a friend!"
The pendent grapes glittered above the door;--
On he must pace, perchance 'till night descend,
Where'er the dreary roads their bare white lines extend.
explanation: As he continued on his journey, he came across an impressive inn but was convinced that it was not meant for him as there were no signs inviting the needy or the old and poor to seek refuge there. The only decoration was a cluster of grapes hanging above the door. He realized he had no choice but to keep moving forward, even if it meant traveling until nightfall along the desolate, barren roads.

text:
The gathering clouds grow red with stormy fire,
In streaks diverging wide and mounting high;
That inn he long had passed; the distant spire,
Which oft as he looked back had fixed his eye,
Was lost, though still he looked, in the blank sky.
Perplexed and comfortless he gazed around,
And scarce could any trace of man descry,
Save cornfields stretched and stretching without bound;
But where the sower dwelt was nowhere to be found.
explanation: The clouds were turning red with the impending storm, spreading out and reaching higher into the sky. The traveler had already passed the inn and the distant spire he had been using as a reference point was no longer visible. He looked around, feeling lost and alone as he couldn't see any signs of human life except for the endless fields of corn. He couldn't locate the residence of the sower, despite his efforts.

The speaker describes a desolate landscape devoid of any natural or man-made features that would bring comfort to his heart. He notes the absence of trees, meadows, or brooks, and instead sees only corn-stacks scattered throughout the area. Despite his hope that a laborer may be nearby, his attempts to call out for help go unanswered, and he is left to listen to the sounds of the wind rustling through the fields of unripe grain and thin grass on the unfurrowed plain.

text:
Long had he fancied each successive slope
Concealed some cottage, whither he might turn
And rest; but now along heaven's darkening cope
The crows rushed by in eddies, homeward borne.
Thus warned he sought some shepherd's spreading thorn
Or hovel from the storm to shield his head,
But sought in vain; for now, all wild, forlorn,
And vacant, a huge waste around him spread;
The wet cold ground, he feared, must be his only bed.
explanation: For a long time, he had hoped that every hill he climbed would lead to a cottage where he could rest, but as the sky grew darker, flocks of crows flew by on their way home. Realizing the warning, he searched for a shepherd's shelter or a small hut to protect himself from the storm, but his search was in vain. He was stranded in a desolate landscape, surrounded by nothing but emptiness and despair, and feared that he would have to sleep on the cold, wet ground.

text:
And be it so--for to the chill night shower
And the sharp wind his head he oft hath bared;
A Sailor he, who many a wretched hour
Hath told; for, landing after labour hard,
Full long endured in hope of just reward,
He to an armed fleet was forced away
By seamen, who perhaps themselves had shared
Like fate; was hurried off, a helpless prey,
'Gainst all that in 'his' heart, or theirs perhaps, said nay.
explanation: The speaker acknowledges that the sailor has experienced many hardships, including being forced onto an armed fleet by fellow seamen after enduring long hours of labor. The sailor has faced harsh weather and exposed himself to the elements in his line of work. Despite any reservations he or others may have had, he was taken as a helpless victim.

text:
For years the work of carnage did not cease,
And death's dire aspect daily he surveyed,
Death's minister; then came his glad release,
And hope returned, and pleasure fondly made
Her dwelling in his dreams. By Fancy's aid
The happy husband flies, his arms to throw
Round his wife's neck; the prize of victory laid
In her full lap, he sees such sweet tears flow
As if thenceforth nor pain nor trouble she could know.
explanation: For a long time, he witnessed death and destruction every day, serving as an instrument of death. Eventually, he was able to escape this grim fate and rediscover hope and joy. His imagination helped him envision a reunion with his beloved wife, embracing her with the spoils of his triumph. Overwhelmed with emotion, she shed tears of joy that seemed to promise a future free from suffering and hardship.

text:
Vain hope! for frand took all that he had earned.
The lion roars and gluts his tawny brood
Even in the desert's heart; but he, returned,
Bears not to those he loves their needful food.
His home approaching, but in such a mood
That from his sight his children might have run.
He met a traveller, robbed him, shed his blood;
And when the miserable work was done
He fled, a vagrant since, the murderer's fate to shun.
explanation: The speaker expresses disappointment in the vain hope that the protagonist, who had earned success, would be able to provide for his loved ones. Even in the heart of the desert, a lion can hunt and feed its family, but the protagonist returns empty-handed. He approaches his home in such a disturbed state that his children could have fled from him. He meets a traveller, robs and kills him, and flees as a vagrant to avoid punishment. The speaker thus points out the protagonist's fall from grace due to his greed and selfishness.

text:
From that day forth no place to him could be
So lonely, but that thence might come a pang
Brought from without to inward misery.
Now, as he plodded on, with sullen clang
A sound of chains along the desert rang;
He looked, and saw upon a gibbet high
A human body that in irons swang,
Uplifted by the tempest whirling by;
And, hovering, round it often did a raven fly.
explanation: After a certain day, he could not find any place lonely enough that would not cause him pain. He felt miserable inside due to external causes. While walking with a heavy heart, he heard the sound of chains in the deserted area. As he looked around, he saw a human body hanging on the gallows, swinging in the wind and bound in chains. A raven was often seen hovering around the body.

The scene was terrifying, and anyone who witnessed it in such a remote location would be filled with dread. The experience not only brought back all of the fears he had about other people, but it also conjured up a host of irrational and frightening thoughts. The stones rolled towards him as if they were trying to bury him alive, causing him to collapse and lose consciousness. When he regained his senses, he struggled to continue on his journey.

text:
As one whose brain habitual phrensy fires
Owes to the fit in which his soul hath tossed
Profounder quiet, when the fit retires,
Even so the dire phantasma which had crossed
His sense, in sudden vacancy quite lost,
Left his mind still as a deep evening stream.
Nor, if accosted now, in thought engrossed,
Moody, or inly troubled, would he seem
To traveller who might talk of any casual theme.
explanation: The person described in this passage experiences extreme fits of frenzy, but finds profound quiet after the fit subsides. The phantasm that previously plagued their mind has disappeared, leaving them in a state of stillness comparable to a deep evening stream. Even if someone were to approach them now, they would appear deep in thought rather than moody or troubled, and could carry on a conversation about any topic.

text:
Hurtle the clouds in deeper darkness piled,
Gone is the raven timely rest to seek;
He seemed the only creature in the wild
On whom the elements their rage might wreak;
Save that the bustard, of those regions bleak
Shy tenant, seeing by the uncertain light
A man there wandering, gave a mournful shriek,
And half upon the ground, with strange affright,
Forced hard against the wind a thick unwieldy flight.
explanation: The clouds darken and gather, leaving no place for the raven to find shelter. It seems as though the raven is the only living creature in this desolate place, bearing the brunt of the elements' fury. Only the bustard, a timid inhabitant of the barren land, catches sight of a man wandering in the uncertain light, prompting a mournful shriek and a clumsy attempt to flee against the wind.

text:
All, all was cheerless to the horizon's bound;
The weary eye--which, wheresoe'er it strays,
Marks nothing but the red sun's setting round,
Or on the earth strange lines, in former days
Left by gigantic arms--at length surveys
What seems an antique castle spreading wide;
Hoary and naked are its walls, and raise
Their brow sublime: in shelter there to bide
He turned, while rain poured down smoking on every side.
explanation: The view was bleak as far as the eye could see, with only the red sun setting and strange lines on the earth left by ancient beings to behold. Eventually, the weary eye catches sight of what appears to be an old castle, with weathered and bare walls that reach up high. Seeking refuge from the pouring rain, the narrator takes shelter within the castle's walls.

text:
Pile of Stone-henge! so proud to hint yet keep
Thy secrets, thou that lov'st to stand and hear
The Plain resounding to the whirlwind's sweep,
Inmate of lonesome Nature's endless year;
Even if thou saw'st the giant wicker rear
For sacrifice its throngs of living men,
Before thy face did ever wretch appear,
Who in his heart had groaned with deadlier pain
Than he who, tempest-driven, thy shelter now would gain.
explanation: Oh Stonehenge, you stand so tall and strong, with secrets hidden yet hinted at. You love to listen to the wind sweep over the plain, a part of Nature's endless existence. Even if you witnessed the sacrifice of living men in the giant wicker, no one has ever suffered as much as the person seeking shelter from the storm within your stones.

text:
Within that fabric of mysterious form,
Winds met in conflict, each by turns supreme;
And, from the perilous ground dislodged, through storm
And rain he wildered on, no moon to stream
From gulf of parting clouds one friendly beam,
Nor any friendly sound his footsteps led;
Once did the lightning's faint disastrous gleam
Disclose a naked guide-post's double head,
Sight which tho' lost at once a gleam of pleasure shed.
explanation: The speaker describes a mysterious and tumultuous environment where conflicting winds reign supreme. The protagonist is lost within this perilous terrain, buffeted by storms and rain with no guiding moon or friendly sounds. The only moment of relief comes from a flash of lightning, which briefly reveals a double-headed guidepost, bringing a glimmer of pleasure before disappearing again.

There were no signs swinging from the trees of the cottages to indicate his direction, and the darkness was all-encompassing, like the depths of the stormy ocean beneath a starless sky. There were no gypsies huddled around a fire made from furze or broom, nor were there any workers keeping watch over their bright red kilns. The sick were not represented by dimly lit rooms with flickering candles, and there was no line of light from a toll-gate to guide him through the desolate night.

text:
At length, though hid in clouds, the moon arose;
The downs were visible--and now revealed
A structure stands, which two bare slopes enclose.
It was a spot, where, ancient vows fulfilled,
Kind pious hands did to the Virgin build
A lonely Spital, the belated swain
From the night terrors of that waste to shield:
But there no human being could remain,
And now the walls are named the "Dead House" of the plain.
explanation: Eventually, the moon rose despite being obscured by clouds. It illuminated the downs and exposed a building that was enclosed by two bare slopes. This structure was built by kind and pious hands to serve as a lonely Spital where belated swains could seek refuge from the terrors of the night. However, nobody could stay there, and the walls are now known as the "Dead House" of the plain.

text:
Though he had little cause to love the abode
Of man, or covet sight of mortal face,
Yet when faint beams of light that ruin showed,
How glad he was at length to find some trace
Of human shelter in that dreary place.
Till to his flock the early shepherd goes,
Here shall much-needed sleep his frame embrace.
In a dry nook where fern the floor bestrows
He lays his stiffened limbs,--his eyes begin to close;
explanation: Despite not having a particular fondness for human dwellings or interactions, the speaker is relieved to stumble upon some form of human shelter amidst the ruins. It is a welcome respite, as the shepherd can now rest his weary body and catch up on the much-needed sleep that he has been deprived of. He finds a comfortable spot in a dry nook, surrounded by ferns, and begins to drift off into slumber.

text:
When hearing a deep sigh, that seemed to come
From one who mourned in sleep, he raised his head,
And saw a woman in the naked room
Outstretched, and turning on a restless bed:
The moon a wan dead light around her shed.
He waked her--spake in tone that would not fail,
He hoped, to calm her mind; but ill he sped,
For of that ruin she had heard a tale
Which now with freezing thoughts did all her powers assail;
explanation: The speaker heard a deep sigh and noticed a woman in a dark room on a restless bed. He woke her up and tried to soothe her, but it was clear that she was disturbed by a tragic story that had left her feeling frozen and powerless. The moon's light only added to the eerie feeling of the scene.

text:
Had heard of one who, forced from storms to shroud,
Felt the loose walls of this decayed Retreat
Rock to incessant neighings shrill and loud,
While his horse pawed the floor with furious heat;
Till on a stone, that sparkled to his feet,
Struck, and still struck again, the troubled horse:
The man half raised the stone with pain and sweat,
Half raised, for well his arm might lose its force
Disclosing the grim head of a late murdered corse.
explanation: Someone sought refuge in a crumbling building during a storm, but was disturbed by the constant neighing of a horse and its frantic pawing at the floor. Eventually, the horse struck a sparkling stone with such force that the man, struggling with pain and sweat, lifted it partially to reveal the grim sight of a recently murdered corpse.

The speaker tells a story about a solitary mansion that she had heard of. One night, she saw a figure with half-closed eyes illuminated by the moon's light and felt a chilling terror grip her. The figure spoke words of comfort to her, and she responded with a newfound courage. However, she wisely refrained from mentioning the discovery of a corpse, as she was unaware of the pain this topic would bring to the figure.

text:
But soon his voice and words of kind intent
Banished that dismal thought; and now the wind
In fainter howlings told its 'rage' was spent:
Meanwhile discourse ensued of various kind,
Which by degrees a confidence of mind
And mutual interest failed not to create.
And, to a natural sympathy resigned,
In that forsaken building where they sate
The Woman thus retraced her own untoward fate.
explanation: The man's comforting words and soothing voice dispelled the woman's gloomy thoughts, and the wind outside gradually quieted down. They engaged in conversation about various topics, which slowly but surely built a sense of trust and mutual understanding between them. As they sat in the abandoned building, the woman opened up about her unfortunate experiences and shared her personal story.

text:
"By Derwent's side my father dwelt--a man
Of virtuous life, by pious parents bred;
And I believe that, soon as I began
To lisp, he made me kneel beside my bed,
And in his hearing there my prayers I said:
And afterwards, by my good father taught,
I read, and loved the books in which I read;
For books in every neighbouring house I sought,
And nothing to my mind a sweeter pleasure brought.
explanation: My father lived by Derwent's side, he was a man of good character and was brought up by religious parents. From a young age, my father taught me to say my prayers by my bedside, and he encouraged me to read books. I loved reading and would look for books in every house nearby, finding nothing more enjoyable.

text:
"A little croft we owned--a plot of corn,
A garden stored with peas, and mint, and thyme,
And flowers for posies, oft on Sunday morn
Plucked while the church bells rang their earliest chime.
Can I forget our freaks at shearing time!
My hen's rich nest through long grass scarce espied;
The cowslip-gathering in June's dewy prime;
The swans that with white chests upreared in pride
Rushing and racing came to meet me at the water-side.
explanation: We had a small farm with a field of corn, a garden filled with peas, mint, thyme, and flowers we picked on Sunday mornings to make into bouquets while the church bells rang in the distance. I have fond memories of shearing time, when we would have fun together, and of finding my hen's hidden nest in the tall grass. In June, we would gather cowslips in the morning dew and watch with pride as the swans came rushing and racing to meet us at the water's edge, their white chests puffed out in display."

I have fond memories of the staff that supported my father's body as he grew older.
