This staff was always with him, whether he was sitting under the sweet sycamore tree listening to the buzz of bees or keeping warm by the winter fire. I also remember how I would dress up in my best clothes on market days, despite being in a hurry. Our faithful watchdog would always bark at strangers, but I would calm it down. And then there was the red-breasted bird that visited my window for years and pecked at the glass. All of these memories are dear to me and remind me of a simpler time."

text:
"The suns of twenty summers danced along,--
Too little marked how fast they rolled away:
But, through severe mischance and cruel wrong,
My father's substance fell into decay:
We toiled and struggled, hoping for a day
When Fortune might put on a kinder look;
But vain were wishes, efforts vain as they;
He from his old hereditary nook
Must part; the summons came;--our final leave we took.
explanation: For twenty years, time passed quickly without much notice. Unfortunately, my father's wealth declined due to unfortunate circumstances and mistreatment. We worked hard and hoped for a change of luck, but our efforts were in vain. Eventually, we had to leave our ancestral home due to financial difficulties.

text:
"It was indeed a miserable hour
When, from the last hill-top, my sire surveyed,
Peering above the trees, the steeple tower
That on his marriage day sweet music made!
Tilt then, he hoped his bones might there be laid
Close by my mother in their native bowers:
Bidding me trust in God, he stood and prayed;--
I could not pray:--through tears that fell in showers
Glimmered our dear-loved home, alas! no longer ours!
explanation: The speaker reflects on a dismal moment when their father looked upon the steeple tower of the church where he married the speaker's mother from atop a hill. The father had hoped to be buried there beside his wife in their homeland, and he encouraged the speaker to trust in God as he prayed. However, the speaker was too overcome with grief to join in prayer, and tears streamed down their face as they looked at their former home, which they had lost.

I had loved a young man for so long that I cannot pinpoint the exact moment when my love for him faded away. We spent our days singing carefree songs in the green mountains, like happy birds in May. As we grew older and tired of childish games, our bond only grew stronger. We discussed marriage and our future together, and I loved him like a brother. I knew that I could never find another person quite like him.

text:
"Two years were passed since to a distant town
He had repaired to ply a gainful trade:
What tears of bitter grief, till then unknown!
What tender vows, our last sad kiss delayed!
To him we turned:--we had no other aid:
Like one revived, upon his neck I wept;
And her whom he had loved in joy, he said,
He well could love in grief; his faith he kept;
And in a quiet home once more my father slept.
explanation: It had been two years since he left for a distant town to earn a living, causing us to shed tears of grief and delay our farewell. With no other help, we turned to him for support. Upon his return, I wept on his neck, and he promised to love my mother in her sorrow. He remained faithful and provided us with a peaceful home where my father could finally rest.

text:
"We lived in peace and comfort; and were blest
With daily bread, by constant toil supplied.
Three lovely babes had lain upon my breast;
And often, viewing their sweet smiles, I sighed,
And knew not why. My happy father died,
When threatened war reduced the children's meal:
Thrice happy! that for him the grave could hide
The empty loom, cold hearth, and silent wheel,
And tears that flowed for ills which patience might not heal.
explanation: The speaker describes a peaceful and comfortable life, where they worked hard to provide daily sustenance for their family. They had three children, and while looking at their smiles, the speaker felt an unexplainable sadness. When war approached, the family faced reduced meals, and the speaker's father passed away. The speaker reflects that it was fortunate for the father to have passed away before experiencing the struggles of an empty loom, cold hearth, and silent wheel, and the tears that came with it.

text:
"'Twas a hard change; an evil time was come;
We had no hope, and no relief could gain:
But soon, with proud parade, the noisy drum
Beat round to clear the streets of want and pain.
My husband's arms now only served to strain
Me and his children hungering in his view;
In such dismay my prayers and tears were vain:
To join those miserable men he flew,
And now to the sea-coast, with numbers more, we drew.
explanation: It was a difficult transition, as tough times had arrived and we had no hope or means of relief. However, soon enough, the sound of drums filled the streets with a show of force to eradicate hunger and suffering. Sadly, my husband's arms could only offer a desperate embrace for me and our starving children. Despite my prayers and tears, he joined the ranks of the destitute and we traveled to the sea-coast with many others.

text:
"There were we long neglected, and we bore
Much sorrow ere the fleet its anchor weighed;
Green fields before us, and our native shore,
We breathed a pestilential air, that made
Ravage for which no knell was heard. We prayed
For our departure; wished and wished--nor knew,
'Mid that long sickness and those hopes delayed,
That happier days we never more must view.
The parting signal streamed--at last the land withdrew.
explanation: We were left abandoned for a long time and we suffered greatly before the fleet finally set sail. Despite being surrounded by green fields and our homeland, we were forced to breathe in a deadly air that caused destruction without any warning. We prayed for our departure, yearning for better days, but we didn't realize that we would never see them again amidst the prolonged illness and delayed hopes. Eventually, the signal to leave came and we watched as the land disappeared, knowing that we were headed towards an uncertain future.

text:
"But the calm summer season now was past.
On as we drove, the equinoctial deep
Ran mountains high before the howling blast,
And many perished in the whirlwind's sweep.
We gazed with terror on their gloomy sleep,
Untaught that soon such anguish must ensue,
Our hopes such harvest of affliction reap,
That we the mercy of the waves should rue:
We reached the western world, a poor devoted crew.
explanation: The peaceful summer had come to an end and we continued on our journey through tumultuous seas. The equinox brought violent winds that caused many to perish. We looked on in fear at their tragic fate, unaware that we too would soon face similar hardships. Our hopes for a smooth journey were shattered as we faced affliction and misery. We arrived in the western world as a small and unfortunate group, destined for a difficult path ahead."

text:
"The pains and plagues that on our heads came down,
Disease and famine, agony and fear,
In wood or wilderness, in camp or town,
It would unman the firmest heart to hear.
All perished--all in one remorseless year,
Husband and children! one by one, by sword
And ravenous plague, all perished: every tear
Dried up, despairing, desolate, on board
A British ship I waked, as from a trance restored."
explanation: The suffering and hardships that we faced were unbearable. Disease, hunger, pain, and fear haunted us everywhere we went, whether in the wilderness, at camp, or in town. It was enough to break even the strongest of spirits. In a single year, everyone, including husbands and children, died from the sword or deadly diseases, leaving us with nothing but despair and loneliness. As I woke up on a British ship, it felt like I had just come out of a trance, realizing the devastation that had occurred.

text:
Here paused she of all present thought forlorn,
Nor voice nor sound, that moment's pain expressed,
Yet Nature, with excess of grief o'erborne,
From her full eyes their watery load released.
He too was mute; and, ere her weeping ceased,
He rose, and to the ruin's portal went,
And saw the dawn opening the silvery east
With rays of promise, north and southward sent;
And soon with crimson fire kindled the firmament.
explanation: She stopped and became lost in thought, feeling deeply saddened but unable to express her pain through words or sounds. Overwhelmed with grief, tears streamed down her face. The man remained silent and as her weeping continued, he got up and walked towards the entrance of the ruined building. He saw the promise of a new day as the dawn broke through the eastern sky, sending rays of light in all directions, eventually igniting the entire sky with a fiery crimson glow.

text:
"O come," he cried, "come, after weary night
Of such rough storm, this happy change to view."
So forth she came, and eastward looked; the sight
Over her brow like dawn of gladness threw;
Upon her cheek, to which its youthful hue
Seemed to return, dried the last lingering tear,
And from her grateful heart a fresh one drew:
The whilst her comrade to her pensive cheer
Tempered fit words of hope; and the lark warbled near.
explanation: He called out to her to come and see the happy change after a stormy night. She came and looked to the east, and the sight made her feel glad. Her cheek even seemed to regain its youthful color and she shed a fresh tear of gratitude. Her companion spoke words of hope and the lark sang nearby, bringing a sense of comfort to her sadness.

text:
They looked and saw a lengthening road, and wain
That rang down a bare slope not far remote:
The barrows glistered bright with drops of rain,
Whistled the waggoner with merry note,
The cock far off sounded his clarion throat;
But town, or farm, or hamlet, none they viewed,
Only were told there stood a lonely cot
A long mile thence. While thither they pursued
Their way, the Woman thus her mournful tale renewed.
explanation: As they gazed, they saw a road stretching into the distance and a wagon moving down a nearby slope. The rain made the mounds shine, and the driver whistled a tune while the distant rooster crowed. However, they did not see any towns or villages, only a solitary cottage a mile away. As they walked towards it, the woman began to recount her sorrowful story.

text:
"Peaceful as this immeasurable plain
Is now, by beams of dawning light imprest,
In the calm sunshine slept the glittering main;
The very ocean hath its hour of rest.
I too forgot the heavings of my breast.
How quiet 'round me ship and ocean were!
As quiet all within me. I was blest,
And looked, and fed upon the silent air
Until it seemed to bring a joy to my despair.
explanation: The vast plain before him was tranquil and serene, bathed in the first light of dawn. Even the vast ocean was still and calm, as if it too was taking a moment of respite. The speaker felt a sense of peace and forgot about the turmoil within himself. The stillness around him brought a sense of contentment and he found solace in the silence. The air was so quiet that it seemed to bring a sense of joy to his previously troubled spirit.

text:
"Ah! how unlike those late terrific sleeps,
And groans that rage of racking famine spoke;
The unburied dead that lay in festering heaps,
The breathing pestilence that rose like smoke,
The shriek that from the distant battle broke,
The mine's dire earthquake, and the pallid host
Driven by the bomb's incessant thunderstroke
To loathsome vaults, where heart-sick anguish tossed,
Hope died, and fear itself in agony was lost!
explanation: This passage describes the stark contrast between peaceful sleep and the horrors of war, famine, and disease. The speaker reflects on the terrors of death and decay, the stench of rotting corpses, the spread of illness, the sounds of battle, and the destructive power of bombs. In contrast, the speaker cherishes the tranquility and safety of restful sleep, free from the fear and pain that pervade the waking world. The passage highlights the immense suffering and loss that result from war and other disasters, and suggests that even the most basic human needs, such as sleep, can become a luxury in such dire circumstances.

text:
"Some mighty gulf of separation past,
I seemed transported to another world;
A thought resigned with pain, when from the mast
The impatient mariner the sail unfurled,
And, whistling, called the wind that hardly curled
The silent sea. From the sweet thoughts of home
And from all hope I was for ever hurled.
For me--farthest from earthly port to roam
Was best, could I but shun the spot where man might come.
explanation: After crossing a great distance, I felt like I had been transported to a different world. The sailor's impatience to set sail and the barely moving sea caused me pain and made me think of home. However, I found solace in being far away from any human interaction and preferred to stay far from any civilization.

The speaker had a strong desire to find a place to settle down and thought they had found it while traveling on the water. They expressed their intent to live there for the rest of their life, away from everything but heaven. However, their dream was shattered when the vessel reached its destination and they found themselves without a home. They were surrounded by many homes and people eating, but they were homeless and hungry.

text:
"No help I sought; in sorrow turned adrift,
Was hopeless, as if cast on some bare rock;
Nor morsel to my mouth that day did lift,
Nor raised my hand at any door to knock.
I lay where, with his drowsy mates, the cock
From the cross-timber of an out-house hung:
Dismally tolled, that night, the city clock!
At morn my sick heart hunger scarcely stung,
Nor to the beggar's language could I fit my tongue.
explanation: I didn't ask for help and was left feeling hopeless and alone, like I was stranded on a rock. I didn't eat anything that day and didn't try to seek help from anyone. I spent the night lying where a rooster was sleeping with its companions in an out-house, while the city clock ominously tolled. In the morning, I barely felt hunger and couldn't even speak like a beggar if I tried.

text:
"So passed a second day; and, when the third
Was come, I tried in vain the crowd's resort.
--In deep despair, by frightful wishes stirred,
Near the sea-side I reached a ruined fort;
There, pains which nature could no more support,
With blindness linked, did on my vitals fall;
And, after many interruptions short
Of hideous sense, I sank, nor step could crawl:
Unsought for was the help that did my life recall.
explanation: On the second day, the speaker attempted to seek out the crowd but failed. Despair and frightening thoughts led the speaker to a dilapidated fort near the sea, where they experienced intense physical and emotional pain, culminating in temporary blindness and a loss of mobility. Eventually, the speaker collapsed and was saved by unexpected help.

text:
"Borne to a hospital, I lay with brain
Drowsy and weak, and shattered memory;
I heard my neighbours in their beds complain
Of many things which never troubled me--
Of feet still bustling round with busy glee,
Of looks where common kindness had no part,
Of service done with cold formality,
Fretting the fever round the languid heart,
And groans which, as they said, might make a dead man start.
explanation: I was taken to a hospital where I lay with a drowsy and weak brain, and my memory was shattered. I could hear my neighbors in their beds complaining about things that never bothered me, like the sound of busy feet and looks lacking kindness. They spoke of service done with cold formality, which only added to the fever that surrounded their hearts. There were also groans so loud that they could wake the dead, or so they claimed.

text:
"These things just served to stir the slumbering sense,
Nor pain nor pity in my bosom raised.
With strength did memory return; and, thence
Dismissed, again on open day I gazed,
At houses, men, and common light, amazed.
The lanes I sought, and, as the sun retired,
Came where beneath the trees a faggot blazed,
The travellers saw me weep, my fate inquired,
And gave me food--and rest, more welcome, more desired.
explanation: The narrator reflects on how certain events have woken them up from a state of slumber, but these events did not evoke any emotions in them. However, their memory was restored and they were able to return to the open world. They wandered through the streets and ended up by a fire in the woods where they were seen crying by travellers who offered them food and a place to rest, which was greatly appreciated.

text:
"Rough potters seemed they, trading soberly
With panniered asses driven from door to door;
But life of happier sort set forth to me,
And other joys my fancy to allure--
The bag-pipe dinning on the midnight moor
In barn uplighted; and companions boon,
Well met from far with revelry secure
Among the forest glades, while jocund June
Rolled fast along the sky his warm and genial moon.
explanation: The potters appeared rough and serious as they went from house to house with their donkeys carrying their wares. However, my imagination was enticed by a livelier life and other pleasures. I was drawn to the sound of bagpipes playing on a moonlit moor in a brightly lit barn, and the joyous company of friends gathering from distant places to celebrate in the forest glades during the cheerful month of June.

text:
"But ill they suited me--those journeys dark
O'er moor and mountain, midnight theft to hatch!
To charm the surly house-dog's faithful bark,
Or hang on tip-toe at the lifted latch.
The gloomy lantern, and the dim blue match,
The black disguise, the warning whistle shrill,
And ear still busy on its nightly watch,
Were not for me, brought up in nothing ill:
Besides, on griefs so fresh my thoughts were brooding still.
explanation: The speaker expresses their unsuitability for engaging in covert and criminal activities during journeys over desolate terrains in the dark, such as stealing at midnight, silencing barking guard dogs, or sneaking past unlocked doors. They describe tools of the trade, such as lanterns, matches, disguises, and whistles, and claim that they were not meant for such a life, having been raised without any involvement in wrongdoing. Furthermore, the speaker has been preoccupied with recent grief and is still consumed by those thoughts.

text:
"What could I do, unaided and unblest?
My father! gone was every friend of thine:
And kindred of dead husband are at best
Small help; and, after marriage such as mine,
With little kindness would to me incline.
Nor was I then for toil or service fit;
My deep-drawn sighs no effort could confine;
In open air forgetful would I sit
Whole hours, with idle arms in moping sorrow knit.
explanation: The speaker laments their lack of aid and blessings, with their father and all of his friends gone. The speaker's husband's family is of little help and unkind, and the speaker is unfit for work or service. The speaker spends hours in sorrowful idleness, unable to contain their deep sighs and forgetful of their surroundings.

text:
"The roads I paced, I loitered through the fields;
Contentedly, yet sometimes self-accused.
Trusted my life to what chance bounty yields,
Now coldly given, now utterly refused.
The ground I for my bed have often used:
But what afflicts my peace with keenest ruth,
Is that I have my inner self abused,
Foregone the home delight of constant truth,
And clear and open soul, so prized in fearless youth.
explanation: The speaker reflects on their life, describing how they have wandered along roads and through fields, sometimes feeling content, but also self-accused. They have relied on chance for their livelihood, sometimes receiving it and sometimes being denied. They have even slept on the ground. However, what troubles them the most is that they have betrayed their own inner self, forfeiting the joy that comes with living a life of honesty and fearlessness. They now regret not valuing the clarity and openness of their youth.

text:
"Through tears the rising sun I oft have viewed,
Through tears have seen him towards that world descend
Where my poor heart lost all its fortitude:
Three years a wanderer now my course I bend--
Oh! tell me whither--for no earthly friend
Have I."--She ceased, and weeping turned away;
As if because her tale was at an end,
She wept; because she had no more to say
Of that perpetual weight which on her spirit lay.
explanation: The speaker has often watched the rising sun and the sun setting through tears. Her heart has lost all its strength since she lost her way and has been wandering for three years. She has no friends to turn to and asks for guidance on where to go. She stops speaking and weeps because she has shared all the pain that has been weighing heavily on her spirit.

text:
True sympathy the Sailor's looks expressed,
His looks--for pondering he was mute the while.
Of social Order's care for wretchedness,
Of Time's sure help to calm and reconcile,
Joy's second spring and Hope's long-treasured smile,
'Twas not for 'him' to speak--a man so tried,
Yet, to relieve her heart, in friendly style
Proverbial words of comfort he applied,
And not in vain, while they went pacing side by side.
explanation: The Sailor's silent expression conveyed genuine sympathy towards the woman, without uttering a word. He understood the importance of social order in dealing with distress, and how time could heal and bring peace. Although he himself had faced many trials, he offered words of comfort to alleviate her pain. As they walked together, their companionship proved to be a source of solace for the woman.

text:
Ere long, from heaps of turf, before their sight,
Together smoking in the sun's slant beam,
Rise various wreaths that into one unite
Which high and higher mounts with silver gleam:
Fair spectacle,---but instantly a scream
Thence bursting shrill did all remark prevent;
They paused, and heard a hoarser voice blaspheme,
And female cries. Their course they thither bent,
And met a man who foamed with anger vehement,
explanation: Before them, piles of earth created smoke in the sun's rays and combined to form a beautiful spectacle that gleamed with silver. However, their observation was interrupted by a loud scream that prevented them from appreciating the sight. They stopped to listen and heard a man's angry and profane voice, along with female cries. They headed towards the source of the disturbance and found a man who was frothing with intense anger.

text:
A woman stood with quivering lips and pale,
And, pointing to a little child that lay
Stretched on the ground, began a piteous tale;
How in a simple freak of thoughtless play
He had provoked his father, who straightway,
As if each blow were deadlier than the last,
Struck the poor innocent. Pallid with dismay
The Soldier's Widow heard and stood aghast;
And stern looks on the man her grey-haired Comrade cast.
explanation: The scene depicts a woman who is visibly upset, trembling and pale. She points to a child lying on the ground and tells a sorrowful story of how the child's father, in a fit of anger provoked by the child's innocent play, had struck him repeatedly. The soldier's widow who was also present was shocked and horrified by the tale, while her elderly comrade cast a stern look at the father.

The Sailor spoke with anger, forbidding any further actions in the name of manhood. The peasant responded with bitter insults and scornful questioning of the Sailor's intentions. The peasant even went so far as to predict the Sailor's eventual demise on the gallows. Despite the Sailor's inner turmoil, he remained outwardly calm and composed.

text:
Softly he stroked the child, who lay outstretched
With face to earth; and, as the boy turned round
His battered head, a groan the Sailor fetched
As if he saw--there and upon that ground--
Strange repetition of the deadly wound
He had himself inflicted. Through his brain
At once the griding iron passage found;
Deluge of tender thoughts then rushed amain,
Nor could his sunken eyes the starting tear restrain.
explanation: Gently, the Sailor caressed the child who lay motionless on the ground. When the boy turned his head, the Sailor let out a groan, as if he saw a reminder of the wound he had once inflicted upon someone. Memories of the pain he had caused flooded his mind, and he was overwhelmed with tender thoughts, causing tears to well up in his eyes.

text:
Within himself he said--What hearts have we!
The blessing this a father gives his child!
Yet happy thou, poor boy! compared with me,
Suffering not doing ill--fate far more mild.
The stranger's looks and tears of wrath beguiled
The father, and relenting thoughts awoke;
He kissed his son--so all was reconciled.
Then, with a voice which inward trouble broke
Ere to his lips it came, the Sailor them bespoke.
explanation: The speaker reflects on the kindness of a father's blessing to his child and compares his own suffering to the child's happiness. The father had initially been angry with his son but was moved by the stranger's tears and reconciled with him by giving him a kiss. The speaker, who is a sailor, speaks with a troubled voice as he contemplates the situation.

text:
"Bad is the world, and hard is the world's law
Even for the man who wears the warmest fleece;
Much need have ye that time more closely draw
The bond of nature, all unkindness cease,
And that among so few there still be peace:
Else can ye hope but with such numerous foes
Your pains shall ever with your years increase?"--
While from his heart the appropriate lesson flows,
A correspondent calm stole gently o'er his woes.
explanation: The world is a difficult and cruel place, even for those who have material comfort. Therefore, it is important to strengthen the bonds of humanity and put an end to all forms of unkindness. Without peace among ourselves, we will only face more difficulties and challenges as we grow older. These words of wisdom led the speaker to feel a sense of tranquility amidst their troubles.

text:
Forthwith the pair passed on; and down they look
Into a narrow valley's pleasant scene
Where wreaths of vapour tracked a winding brook,
That babbled on through groves and meadows green;
A low-roofed house peeped out the trees between;
The dripping groves resound with cheerful lays,
And melancholy lowings intervene
Of scattered herds, that in the meadow graze,
Some amid lingering shade, some touched by the sun's rays.
explanation: The couple continued on their journey and gazed down into a picturesque valley with a winding brook and green meadows. A small house could be seen peeking out from between the trees. The joyful sound of birds singing permeated the dripping groves, but the mood was occasionally interrupted by the melancholy lowing of scattered herds grazing in the meadow, some in the shade and some in the sun.

text:
They saw and heard, and, winding with the road,
Down a thick wood, they dropt into the vale;
Comfort, by prouder mansions unbestowed,
Their wearied frames, she hoped, would soon regale.
Erelong they reached that cottage in the dale:
It was a rustic inn;--the board was spread,
The milk-maid followed with her brimming pail,
And lustily the master carved the bread,
Kindly the housewife pressed, and they in comfort fed.
explanation: As they traveled down the winding road, they entered a thick wood and descended into a valley. They were relieved to find a humble cottage where they could rest and replenish their tired bodies. The cottage was a simple inn with a table set for them to enjoy a meal. The milkmaid arrived with a pail of fresh milk, and the innkeeper carved bread for them to eat. The kind-hearted host and hostess made sure they were comfortable and well-fed.

text:
Their breakfast done, the pair, though loth, must part;
Wanderers whose course no longer now agrees.
She rose and bade farewell! and, while her heart
Struggled with tears nor could its sorrow ease,
She left him there; for, clustering round his knees,
With his oak-staff the cottage children played;
And soon she reached a spot o'erhung with trees
And banks of ragged earth; beneath the shade
Across the pebbly road a little runnel strayed.
explanation: After finishing their breakfast, the two travelers knew they had to part ways despite their reluctance. They were no longer heading in the same direction. The woman got up and said goodbye, but her heart was heavy with sadness and she struggled to hold back her tears. The man stayed behind, playing with the children who had gathered around him with his sturdy oak-staff. The woman walked away, heading towards a shaded area where there were trees and rough banks of earth. A small stream flowed across the pebbly road, adding to the tranquility of the surroundings.

text:
A cart and horse beside the rivulet stood;
Chequering the canvas roof the sunbeams shone.
She saw the carman bend to scoop the flood
As the wain fronted her,--wherein lay one,
A pale-faced Woman, in disease far gone.
The carman wet her lips as well behoved;
Bed under her lean body there was none,
Though even to die near one she most had loved
She could not of herself those wasted limbs have moved.
explanation: Beside a stream, a horse and cart were parked, the sun shining through the checkered canvas roof. A woman approached and saw the carman bending down to scoop water out of the stream. In the wagon, a sickly woman lay, without a bed to rest on. The carman moistened the ill woman's lips as best he could. Despite being close to death and wanting to be near her loved ones, the sick woman could not move her frail body on her own.

text:
The Soldier's Widow learned with honest pain
And homefelt force of sympathy sincere,
Why thus that worn-out wretch must there sustain
The jolting road and morning air severe.
The wain pursued its way; and following near
In pure compassion she her steps retraced
Far as the cottage. "A sad sight is here,"
She cried aloud; and forth ran out in haste
The friends whom she had left but a few minutes past.
explanation: The Soldier's Widow felt genuine sympathy and pain when she saw the exhausted and frail old man being subjected to the harsh conditions of the bumpy road and early morning air. As she followed the wagon, she couldn't help but feel compassion towards the man's suffering. When she reached the cottage where he lived, she exclaimed in dismay at the sad sight and the friends who she had left only minutes ago came rushing out to see what was wrong.

The group rushed eagerly to the door as the woman, who was lying on her bare straw bed, half-raised her bony and deadly pale face. She looked at them with a distracted and confused expression and then collapsed back onto her bed with a feeble moan. The housewife fervently thanked God that she had a home to call her own and vowed that the woman would not be left to perish there without care.

text:
So in they bear her to the chimney seat,
And busily, though yet with fear, untie
Her garments, and, to warm her icy feet
And chafe her temples, careful hands apply.
Nature reviving, with a deep-drawn sigh
She strove, and not in vain, her head to rear;
Then said--"I thank you all; if I must die,
The God in heaven my prayers for you will hear;
Till now I did not think my end had been so near.
explanation: The group brings the woman to the chimney seat and cautiously remove her clothes to warm her cold feet and rub her temples. She takes a deep breath and manages to lift her head, expressing gratitude towards them all. She acknowledges that she didn't realize her end was so close and believes that if she must die, her prayers for them will be heard by God in heaven.

text:
"Barred every comfort labour could procure,
Suffering what no endurance could assuage,
I was compelled to seek my father's door,
Though loth to be a burthen on his age.
But sickness stopped me in an early stage
Of my sad journey; and within the wain
They placed me--there to end life's pilgrimage,
Unless beneath your roof I may remain;
For I shall never see my father's door again.
explanation: I was deprived of all comforts and endured unbearable suffering, forcing me to reluctantly seek refuge with my aging father. However, sickness overtook me during my journey and I was unable to go further. I was placed in a wagon with little hope of surviving unless I am allowed to stay under your roof. I know I will never make it to my father's door again."

text:
"My life, Heaven knows, hath long been burthensome;
But, if I have not meekly suffered, meek
May my end be! Soon will this voice be dumb:
Should child of mine e'er wander hither, speak
Of me, say that the worm is on my cheek.--
Torn from our hut, that stood beside the sea
Near Portland lighthouse in a lonesome creek,
My husband served in sad captivity
On shipboard, bound till peace or death should set him free.
explanation: The speaker reflects on the challenges they have faced in life, acknowledging that it has been burdensome. However, they express a willingness to accept their fate and hope to leave a humble legacy. They anticipate their impending death and hope that their children, if they ever return to the place of their suffering, will remember them with compassion. The speaker reveals that their husband was taken captive and forced to serve on a ship, leaving them alone in a hut near Portland lighthouse. They are left to endure their struggles and wait for his return or for death to release him from his bondage.

I was once a sailor's wife, but became a widow with the responsibility of taking care of my two young children. Despite the challenges, I had hope and prayed for daily sustenance, which was granted. However, tragedy struck when one of my children was violently killed and suspicion forced us to leave our home. We tried to find help but were unsuccessful, and had to separate as the boys and I could not survive together.

Rumors were spread that on a particular day, the speaker's husband was seen lurking around the area. However, he had disappeared and no one knew where he went. It was also claimed that he committed a crime in the nearby forest, close to their home. Despite these accusations, the speaker knew her husband was a kind and gentle man who would never harm anyone or anything. She believed that his love protected her from any harm that may come her way.

text:
Alas! the thing she told with labouring breath
The Sailor knew too well. That wickedness
His hand had wrought; and when, in the hour of death,
He saw his Wife's lips move his name to bless
With her last words, unable to suppress
His anguish, with his heart he ceased to strive;
And, weeping loud in this extreme distress,
He cried--"Do pity me! That thou shouldst live
I neither ask nor wish--forgive me, but forgive!"
explanation: The Sailor heard his dying wife utter his name with her last breath and knew that she was aware of the wickedness he had committed. Overwhelmed with guilt and anguish, he could no longer suppress his feelings and wept uncontrollably, pleading for forgiveness. He did not ask for her to spare his life but only for her mercy and understanding.

text:
To tell the change that Voice within her wrought
Nature by sign or sound made no essay;
A sudden joy surprised expiring thought,
And every mortal pang dissolved away.
Borne gently to a bed, in death she lay;
Yet still while over her the husband bent,
A look was in her face which seemed to say,
"Be blest; by sight of thee from heaven was sent
Peace to my parting soul, the fulness of content."
explanation: The poem describes a woman who is dying and her husband is by her side. She experiences a sudden joy that takes away her pain as she passes away. Her husband notices a look on her face that seems to convey a message of peace and contentment. The poem suggests that the woman's inner voice or spirit has brought about this positive change, and that nature has not played a role in it. The husband is comforted by the idea that his wife's soul has found peace and that he was able to play a role in it by being with her at the end.

text:
'She' slept in peace,--his pulses throbbed and stopped,
Breathless he gazed upon her face,--then took
Her hand in his, and raised it, but both dropped,
When on his own he cast a rueful look.
His ears were never silent; sleep forsook
His burning eyelids stretched and stiff as lead;
All night from time to time under him shook
The floor as he lay shuddering on his bed;
And oft he groaned aloud, "O God, that I were dead!"
explanation: The narrator describes a scene where 'she' is sleeping peacefully, while the protagonist is experiencing a range of emotions including a racing pulse, breathlessness, and a desire to touch her hand. However, when he attempts to do so, they both drop hands. He is unable to sleep and is constantly disturbed by the sound of the floor shaking beneath him. The protagonist is in great emotional distress, as evidenced by his stiff and burning eyelids, and frequent groans of wishing for death.

text:
The Soldier's Widow lingered in the cot,
And, when he rose, he thanked her pious care
Through which his Wife, to that kind shelter brought,
Died in his arms; and with those thanks a prayer
He breathed for her, and for that merciful pair.
The corse interred, not one hour heremained
Beneath their roof, but to the open air
A burthen, now with fortitude sustained,
He bore within a breast where dreadful quiet reigned.
explanation: The Soldier's Widow stayed in the small bed, and when the man got up, he expressed his gratitude for her kind care that allowed his wife to die in peace. He thanked her and prayed for her as well as the others who had been merciful to him. Once his wife was buried, he did not stay for even an hour under their roof, but carried the weight of his grief within him as he left into the world where he remained in a state of fearful stillness.

text:
Confirmed of purpose, fearlessly prepared
For act and suffering, to the city straight
He journeyed, and forthwith his crime declared:
"And from your doom," he added, "now I wait,
Nor let it linger long, the murderer's fate."
Not ineffectual was that piteous claim:
"O welcome sentence which will end though late,"
He said, "the pangs that to my conscience came
Out of that deed. My trust, Saviour! is in thy name!"
explanation: The man, certain of his mission, went to the city without fear, ready for the consequences of his actions. He confessed to his crime and awaited his punishment without delay. His plea was not in vain, as he hoped for a swift end to the guilt that plagued him. He trusted in the name of his savior to guide him through his fate.

text:
His fate was pitied. Him in iron case
(Reader, forgive the intolerable thought)
They hung not:--no one on 'his' form or face
Could gaze, as on a show by idlers sought;
No kindred sufferer, to his death-place brought
By lawless curiosity or chance,
When into storm the evening sky is wrought,
Upon his swinging corse an eye can glance,
And drop, as he once dropped, in miserable trance.
explanation: The speaker expresses pity for the subject's fate, who is imprisoned in an iron case. They are not hung, so no one can view them as entertainment. No one is brought to witness their death out of curiosity, and no one can catch a glimpse of their swinging body during a storm. The speaker imagines the subject's death as a miserable experience, one that the speaker cannot bear to think about.

text:
STRANGE fits of passion have I known:
And I will dare to tell,
But in the lover's ear alone,
What once to me befell.
explanation: I have experienced peculiar outbursts of intense emotion and I am willing to reveal what happened to me, but only to my beloved in private.

text:
When she I loved look'd every day
Fresh as a rose in June,
I to her cottage bent my way,
Beneath an evening moon.
explanation: Every day, my beloved appeared as beautiful as a rose in June. Under the moonlit sky, I would go to her cottage.

text:
Upon the moon I fix'd my eye,
All over the wide lea;
With quickening pace my horse drew nigh
Those paths so dear to me.
explanation: I looked up at the moon while riding my horse through the vast meadow, feeling a familiar sense of comfort and joy as I approached my beloved trails.

text:
And now we reach'd the orchard-plot;
And, as we climb'd the hill,
The sinking moon to Lucy's cot
Came near and nearer still.
explanation: We arrived at the orchard, and as we climbed up the hill, the moon began to approach Lucy's cottage and grew closer and closer.

text:
In one of those sweet dreams I slept,
Kind Nature's gentlest boon!
And all the while my eyes I kept
On the descending moon.
explanation: I had a pleasant dream where I slept peacefully, grateful for the kindness of nature. Throughout my slumber, I watched the moon slowly go down, enjoying the peaceful scene.

text:
My horse moved on; hoof after hoof
He raised, and never stopp'd:
When down behind the cottage roof,
At once, the bright moon dropp'd.
explanation: As the speaker's horse continued to move forward, with each step never stopping, they observed the moon suddenly drop down behind the roof of a nearby cottage.

text:
What fond and wayward thoughts will slide
Into a lover's head!
'O mercy!' to myself I cried,
'If Lucy should be dead!'
explanation: The thoughts that cross a lover's mind can be both fond and unpredictable, as demonstrated by the speaker's exclamation of concern about the possibility of Lucy's death. The speaker's emotional response conveys the depth of their feelings for Lucy and the fear that losing her would be too much to bear.

text:
I travelled among unknown men
In lands beyond the sea;
Nor, England! did I know till then
What love I bore to thee.
explanation: The speaker asserts that they have roamed among strangers in far-off lands across the sea. It wasn't until they left their home country, England, that they realized the depth of their love for it.

text:
'Tis past, that melancholy dream!
Nor will I quit thy shore
A second time; for still I seem
To love thee more and more.
explanation: That sad dream is over, and I vow to never leave you again. My love for you only grows stronger with each passing moment.

text:
Among thy mountains did I feel
The joy of my desire;
And she I cherished turned her wheel
Beside an English fire.
explanation: I experienced great happiness in the midst of the mountains, where my heart's desire was fulfilled. The woman that I loved was spinning wool next to a fire in England.

text:
Thy mornings showed, thy nights concealed,
The bowers where Lucy played;
And thine too is the last green field
That Lucy's eyes surveyed.
explanation: Lucy used to play in the gardens during the day and the night covered them. The last green field she ever saw was also yours.

text:
STAY near me---do not take thy flight!
A little longer stay in sight!
Much converse do I find I thee,
Historian of my infancy !
Float near me; do not yet depart!
Dead times revive in thee:
Thou bring'st, gay creature as thou art!
A solemn image to my heart,
My father's family!
explanation: Please stay with me, don't leave my sight just yet. You remind me of my childhood and bring back memories of my family. You are like a historian, preserving the past for me. Even though you are a joyful creature, you bring a solemn image to my heart, reminding me of my father's family. So, please stay close to me for a little while longer.

text:
Oh! pleasant, pleasant were the days,
The time, when, in our childish plays,
My sister Emmeline and I
Together chased the butterfly!
A very hunter did I rush
Upon the prey:---with leaps and spring
I followed on from brake to bush;
But she, God love her, feared to brush
The dust from off its wings.
explanation: The speaker fondly reminisces about the joyful moments of childhood spent chasing butterflies with their sister, Emmeline. The speaker describes themselves as a determined hunter, chasing the butterflies with enthusiasm, while Emmeline was more hesitant, afraid to harm the delicate creatures. These memories evoke a sense of nostalgia and a yearning for the innocence of youth.

text:
'Tis eight o'clock,--a clear March night,
The moon is up,--the sky is blue,
The owlet, in the moonlight air,
Shouts from nobody knows where;
He lengthens out his lonely shout,
Halloo! halloo! a long halloo!
explanation: It is currently 8 o'clock on a clear March night. The moon is visible and the sky is blue. An owl can be heard hooting in the moonlit air from an unknown location. Its lonely call echoes through the night, sounding like a long and drawn-out "halloo."

text:
--Why bustle thus about your door,
What means this bustle, Betty Foy?
Why are you in this mighty fret?
And why on horseback have you set
Him whom you love, your Idiot Boy?
explanation: Betty Foy is being questioned about the commotion outside her house, as she anxiously prepares to send her beloved Idiot Boy on horseback somewhere. The speaker is curious as to why she is so agitated and what could possibly be motivating her to send someone who is intellectually disabled on such a journey.
Almost no one is awake yet, so please lay him back down, Betty. He seems happy and is making sounds at you, but what use does he have for riding equipment like stirrups, saddles, or reins?

text:
But Betty's bent on her intent;
For her good neighbour, Susan Gale,
Old Susan, she who dwells alone,
Is sick, and makes a piteous moan
As if her very life would fail.
explanation: Betty is determined to help her neighbor, Susan Gale, who lives alone and is sick. Susan's condition is so severe that she is constantly moaning and appears to be on the brink of death. Despite the challenges, Betty is unwavering in her commitment to assist Susan.

text:
There's not a house within a mile,
No hand to help them in distress;
Old Susan lies a-bed in pain,
And sorely puzzled are the twain,
For what she ails they cannot guess.
explanation: Within a mile, there is no nearby home to assist them in their current state of distress. An elderly woman, Susan, is confined to her bed and is experiencing significant pain. The two individuals caring for her are at a loss for what could be causing her ailment.

Betty's husband is working as a woodman in a faraway valley and will be away for a week. This leaves Susan Gale in a difficult situation with no one to help her. She wonders what she should do and what might happen.

text:
And Betty from the lane has fetched
Her Pony, that is mild and good;
Whether he be in joy or pain,
Feeding at will along the lane,
Or bringing faggots from the wood.
explanation: Betty has gone to get her gentle and well-behaved pony from the lane. The pony is content grazing freely, or carrying bundles of firewood from the nearby woods, regardless of whether he is happy or experiencing discomfort.

text:
And he is all in travelling trim,--
And, by the moonlight, Betty Foy
Has on the well-girt saddle set
(The like was never heard of yet)
Him whom she loves, her Idiot Boy.
explanation: Betty Foy has prepared her beloved Idiot Boy for a journey, and he looks ready to go. She has even put a well-fitting saddle on him, which is something unusual for someone like him. The moonlight shines down on the pair as they prepare to embark on their adventure together.

text:
And he must post without delay
Across the bridge and through the dale,
And by the church, and o'er the down,
To bring a Doctor from the town,
Or she will die, old Susan Gale.
explanation: He needs to hurry and make a post about getting a Doctor from the town to come quickly and save old Susan Gale's life. He must cross the bridge, go through the dale, pass by the church, and travel over the down to get there as soon as possible. Delay could result in her death.

text:
There is no need of boot or spur,
There is no need of whip or wand;
For Johnny has his holly-bough,
And with a 'hurly-burly' now
He shakes the green bough in his hand.
explanation: Johnny doesn't require any equipment such as a boot, spur, whip or wand. He has a holly-bough which he shakes with a 'hurly-burly' motion, rendering any additional equipment unnecessary.

text:
And Betty o'er and o'er has told
The Boy, who is her best delight,
Both what to follow, what to shun,
What do, and what to leave undone,
How turn to left, and how to right.
explanation: Betty has repeatedly given advice to the Boy, who brings her great joy. She has instructed him on what actions to take and what actions to avoid, as well as which direction to turn.

text:
And Betty's most especial charge,
Was, 'Johnny! Johnny! mind that you
Come home again, nor stop at all,--
Come home again, whate'er befall,
My Johnny, do, I pray you do.'
explanation: Betty's main concern was to ensure that Johnny returned home safely without any delay. She repeatedly reminded him to come back home regardless of any obstacles he may encounter on his way. Betty's plea to Johnny was to prioritize his safe return as her most special request.

text:
To this did Johnny answer make,
Both with his head and with his hand,
And proudly shook the bridle too;
And then! his words were not a few,
Which Betty well could understand.
explanation: Johnny responded to Betty's statement by nodding his head and gesturing with his hand. He also confidently shook the bridle. He then proceeded to speak at length, conveying his message clearly to Betty.

text:
And now that Johnny is just going,
Though Betty's in a mighty flurry,
She gently pats the Pony's side,
On which her Idiot Boy must ride,
And seems no longer in a hurry.
explanation: Even though Johnny is leaving, Betty remains calm and comforts her son who is riding on a pony. She gently pats the pony's side and no longer seems anxious.

text:
But when the Pony moved his legs,
Oh! then for the poor Idiot Boy!
For joy he cannot hold the bridle,
For joy his head and heels are idle,
He's idle all for very joy.
explanation: The Idiot Boy experiences immense joy when the Pony moves his legs, to the point where he cannot control the bridle or use his head and heels. He is completely idle, consumed by his happiness.

text:
And while the Pony moves his legs,
In Johnny's left hand you may see
The green bough motionless and dead:
The Moon that shines above his head
Is not more still and mute than he.
explanation: As the Pony gallops, Johnny holds a lifeless green bough in his left hand. He remains completely still and silent beneath the shining moon above.

text:
His heart it was so full of glee,
That till full fifty yards were gone,
He quite forgot his holly whip,
And all his skill in horsemanship:
Oh! happy, happy, happy John.
explanation: John was filled with immense joy that he completely forgot about his holly whip and his expertise in horse riding, even after he had traveled fifty yards. He was overwhelmed with happiness, as reflected in his repeated exclamation of "Oh! happy, happy, happy John."

text:
And while the Mother, at the door,
Stands fixed, her face with joy o'erflows,
Proud of herself, and proud of him,
She sees him in his travelling trim,
How quietly her Johnny goes.
explanation: The mother is standing at the door, filled with happiness as she sees her son Johnny leaving in his travel outfit. She feels proud of herself and her son, admiring how calmly he is departing.

text:
The silence of her Idiot Boy,
What hopes it sends to Betty's heart!
He's at the guide-post--he turns right;
She watches till he's out of sight,
And Betty will not then depart.
explanation: Betty's heart is filled with hope as she watches her Idiot Boy standing still. He eventually turns right at the guide-post and disappears from her sight. Betty, however, remains there, refusing to leave.

text:
Burr, burr--now Johnny's lips they burr,
As loud as any mill, or near it;
Meek as a lamb the Pony moves,
And Johnny makes the noise he loves, 0
And Betty listens, glad to hear it.
explanation: Johnny's lips make a loud, buzzing noise like a mill, and the Pony moves calmly. Betty is happy to listen to Johnny's noise.

text:
Away she hies to Susan Gale:
Her Messenger's in merry tune;
The owlets hoot, the owlets curr,
And Johnny's lips they burr, burr, burr,
As on he goes beneath the moon.
explanation: She quickly goes to Susan Gale, and her messenger is in a joyful mood. The owls are hooting and Johnny's lips are making a buzzing sound as he walks under the moon.

text:
His steed and he right well agree;
For of this Pony there's a rumour,
That, should he lose his eyes and ears,
And should he live a thousand years,
He never will be out of humour.
explanation: The man and his horse have a great relationship, as there is a rumor about the horse that even if he were to lose his eyes and ears and live for a thousand years, he would never be in a bad mood.

text:
But then he is a horse that thinks!
And when he thinks, his pace is slack;
Now, though he knows poor Johnny well,
Yet, for his life, he cannot tell
What he has got upon his back.
explanation: The horse in question is particularly intelligent, capable of thought and cognition. However, when he begins to think, he slows down and becomes less efficient. Despite having a good relationship with his rider, Johnny, the horse is unable to identify what burden he is carrying on his back, adding a sense of mystery and intrigue to the situation.

text:
So through the moonlight lanes they go,
And far into the moonlight dale,
And by the church, and o'er the down,
To bring a Doctor from the town,
To comfort poor old Susan Gale.
explanation: They travel down moonlit paths and valleys, past the church and over the hills to fetch a doctor from the town to bring comfort to the elderly Susan Gale.

text:
And Betty, now at Susan's side,
Is in the middle of her story,
What speedy help her Boy will bring,
With many a most diverting thing,
Of Johnny's wit, and Johnny's glory.
explanation: Betty has joined Susan and is currently telling a story about how her son will quickly provide assistance. She includes entertaining anecdotes about Johnny's cleverness and accomplishments.

text:
And Betty, still at Susan's side,
By this time is not quite so flurried:
Demure with porringer and plate
She sits, as if in Susan's fate
Her life and soul were buried.
explanation: Betty remains with Susan and is no longer as agitated as before. She sits calmly with a bowl and plate, appearing as though her entire being is invested in Susan's well-being.

text:
But Betty, poor good woman! she,
You plainly in her face may read it,
Could lend out of that moment's store
Five years of happiness or more
To any that might need it.
explanation: Betty was a kind-hearted woman who wore her emotions on her face. She was so full of happiness that she would willingly give away five years' worth of it to anyone who needed it.

text:
But yet I guess that now and then
With Betty all was not so well;
And to the road she turns her ears,
And thence full many a sound she hears,
Which she to Susan will not tell.
explanation: Sometimes things weren't great between the speaker and Betty, and Betty would listen to the sounds of the road but not share them with Susan.
Susan is in distress and Betty reassures her that the man she is waiting for will return soon. Betty believes that he will arrive before eleven o'clock tonight.

Susan is in distress and expresses it audibly. The clock indicates that it is almost 11 o'clock. Betty, who is with Susan, predicts that someone must be coming soon, confident in her belief that the appearance of the moon in the sky is a reliable sign that the person will arrive.

text:
The clock is on the stroke of twelve,
And Johnny is not yet in sight:
--The Moon's in heaven, as Betty sees,
But Betty is not quite at ease;
And Susan has a dreadful night.
explanation: It is almost midnight and Johnny has not arrived yet. Betty can see the moon in the sky, but she is worried. Susan is having a terrible night.

text:
And Betty, half an hour ago,
On Johnny vile reflections cast:
'A little idle sauntering Thing!'
With other names, an endless string;
But now that time is gone and past.
explanation: Half an hour earlier, Betty had insulted Johnny with various derogatory names, including "idle sauntering thing." However, that moment has since passed.

text:
And Betty's drooping at the heart,
That happy time all past and gone,
'How can it be he is so late?
The Doctor, he has made him wait;
Susan! they'll both be here anon.'
explanation: Betty is feeling sad because the happy time has passed and wonders why the doctor is so late. She tells Susan that they will both arrive soon.

text:
And Susan's growing worse and worse,
And Betty's in a sad 'quandary';
And then there's nobody to say
If she must go, or she must stay!
--She's in a sad 'quandary'.
explanation: Susan's condition is deteriorating, and Betty is facing a difficult situation. There is no one to determine whether Susan should leave or remain in her current state. This has put Betty in a state of confusion and uncertainty.
It is one o'clock and the Doctor and his Guide are nowhere to be found on the moonlit road. There are no horses or people around and Betty is still with Susan.

Susan is starting to worry about the possibility of several unfortunate events happening to Johnny. She is afraid that he may drown or become lost and never be found, which would cause them both a lot of permanent regret.

text:
She prefaced half a hint of this
With, 'God forbid it should be true!'
At the first word that Susan said
Cried Betty, rising from the bed,
'Susan, I'd gladly stay with you.
explanation: Susan made a statement that Betty found concerning. Betty was so alarmed that she immediately offered to stay with Susan. However, Susan prefaced her statement with an expression of disbelief that it could be true.

text:
'I must be gone, I must away:
Consider, Johnny's but half-wise;
Susan, we must take care of him,
If he is hurt in life or limb'--
'Oh God forbid!' poor Susan cries.
explanation: "I need to leave, I have to go. Johnny doesn't have full understanding, so we must look out for him and protect him from harm. Susan is upset and hopes nothing bad will happen to Johnny."

text:
'What can I do?' says Betty, going,
'What can I do to ease your pain?
Good Susan tell me, and I'll stay;
I fear you're in a dreadful way,
But I shall soon be back again.'
explanation: Betty asks Susan how she can help relieve her pain and promises to stay with her until she feels better. She expresses concern about Susan's well-being and assures her that she will return soon after leaving.

text:
'Nay, Betty, go! good Betty, go!
There's nothing that can ease my pain,'
Then off she hies, but with a prayer
That God poor Susan's life would spare, 0
Till she comes back again.
explanation: Betty is urged to leave by someone in pain, who believes that nothing can alleviate their suffering. Betty departs, but not before requesting that God keeps Susan alive until she returns.

text:
So, through the moonlight lane she goes,
And far into the moonlight dale;
And how she ran, and how she walked,
And all that to herself she talked,
Would surely be a tedious tale.
explanation: She travels down the moonlit path and into the moonlit valley, her movements varying between running and walking. The thoughts she has to herself are too lengthy to recount in detail.

text:
In high and low, above, below,
In great and small, in round and square,
In tree and tower was Johnny seen,
In bush and brake, in black and green;
'Twas Johnny, Johnny, every where.
explanation: Johnny was visible in all places, whether it be high or low, above or below. He could be seen in all shapes and sizes, from great to small, round to square. Whether it was a tree, tower, bush or brake, black or green, Johnny's presence was apparent. He was everywhere, and people could not miss him.

text:
And while she crossed the bridge, there came
A thought with which her heart is sore--
Johnny perhaps his horse forsook,
To hunt the moon within the brook,
And never will be heard of more.
explanation: As she walked across the bridge, a troubling thought entered her mind: Johnny may have abandoned his horse to search for the reflection of the moon in the brook and may never return.

She is currently standing on top of a hill, with no one else around, surrounded by a vast landscape. There is no sign of Johnny or his horse in the fern or the gorse bushes. Additionally, there is no doctor or guide present.

text:
'O saints! what is become of him?
Perhaps he's climbed into an oak,
Where he will stay till he is dead;
Or, sadly he has been misled,
And joined the wandering gipsy-folk.
explanation: The speaker is inquiring about the whereabouts of an individual, wondering if they may have climbed into an oak tree and will remain there until death or if they have been deceived and joined a group of wandering gypsies.

The verse describes different scenarios of a person who may be in trouble or danger. The first scenario talks about a wicked pony carrying someone to a dark cave, which may imply the person is lost or trapped. The second scenario mentions a castle where the person is pursuing something, but among ghosts, which can be interpreted as a person being haunted or pursued by something. The third scenario talks about playing with a waterfall, which may suggest a person taking risks or being reckless. Overall, the verse paints a picture of someone facing various challenges and potentially putting themselves in harm's way.

text:
At poor old Susan then she railed,
While to the town she posts away;
'If Susan had not been so ill,
Alas! I should have had him still,
My Johnny, till my dying day.'
explanation: The speaker expresses her frustration towards Susan and blames her for losing Johnny. She expresses regret that if Susan had not been sick, she would have been able to keep Johnny forever. The speaker is heading to town, possibly to confront Johnny or Susan about the situation.

text:
Poor Betty, in this sad distemper,
The Doctor's self could hardly spare:
Unworthy things she talked, and wild;
Even he, of cattle the most mild,
The Pony had his share.
explanation: Betty was suffering from a serious illness and was talking incoherently. Even the doctor, who was known for his patience, found it difficult to deal with her. She spoke nonsensically and seemed to be delirious. Even the pony, who was usually calm around her, was not spared from her erratic behavior.

She has arrived in the town and quickly makes her way to the Doctor's door. The town is completely silent, with no sound to be heard anywhere. Despite the town being large and spacious, it feels as quiet as the sky above.

text:
And now she's at the Doctor's door,
She lifts the knocker, rap, rap, rap;
The Doctor at the casement shows
His glimmering eyes that peep and doze!
And one hand rubs his old night-cap.
explanation: She has arrived at the Doctor's door and knocks on it three times. The Doctor emerges from the window, rubbing his eyes and wearing his night-cap.

text:
'O Doctor! Doctor! where's my Johnny?'
'I'm here, what is't you want with me?'
'O Sir! you know I'm Betty Foy,
And I have lost my poor dear Boy,
You know him--him you often see;
explanation:
'Johnny, my son, where could he be?'
Betty Foy frantically seeks her son, Johnny, and calls out for a doctor's help. When the doctor responds, she explains that she has lost her son and pleads for his assistance. The doctor recognizes Betty and her son, as he has seen them before. Betty is distraught and desperate to find her child's whereabouts.

text:
'He's not so wise as some folks be:'
'The devil take his wisdom!' said
The Doctor, looking somewhat grim,
'What, Woman! should I know of him?'
And, grumbling, he went back to bed!
explanation: The Doctor was told that a man was not as wise as some others, to which he responded angrily and dismissed the comment. He was frustrated with the suggestion that he should know something about this man and grumpily went back to bed.

text:
'O woe is me! O woe is me!
Here will I die, here will I die;
I thought to find my lost one here,
But he is neither far nor near,
Oh! what a wretched Mother I!'
explanation: The speaker expresses deep sorrow and despair, lamenting their inability to find their lost loved one. They feel that they will die in this place, without any hope of reuniting with their missing person. The speaker's grief is palpable as they describe their desperate search, which has yielded no results. They refer to themselves as a wretched mother, perhaps indicating that the lost loved one is their child, and the pain of separation is particularly acute. Overall, the speaker's words convey a sense of hopelessness and anguish at the prospect of never being reunited with their loved one.

Betty is standing still and unsure of which direction to take. She is feeling distressed and would find some relief if she had the courage to knock once more. Unfortunately, the sound of the clock striking three only adds to her misery.

text:
Then up along the town she hies,
No wonder if her senses fail;
This piteous news so much it shocked her,
She quite forgot to send the Doctor,
To comfort poor old Susan Gale.
explanation: She quickly hurries through the town, and it's no surprise that she becomes disoriented. The news she received was so heartrending that she forgets to notify the Doctor to check on Susan Gale, who is in need of comfort.

text:
And now she's high upon the down,
And she can see a mile of road:
'O cruel! I'm almost threescore;
Such night as this was ne'er before,
There's not a single soul abroad.'
explanation: The woman is standing on a hill and can see a long stretch of road, feeling despair as she realizes she is almost sixty years old. She comments on the darkness of the night and the absence of any other people around, expressing sadness and possibly fear.

text:
She listens, but she cannot hear
The foot of horse, the voice of man;
The streams with softest sound are flowing,
The grass you almost hear it growing,
You hear it now, if e'er you can.
explanation: Despite her efforts to listen, she is unable to hear the sound of horses' hooves or people's voices. The streams flow quietly and the grass grows silently, almost imperceptibly. If there is any sound to be heard, it is only if one listens intently.

text:
The owlets through the long blue night
Are shouting to each other still:
Fond lovers! yet not quite hob nob,
They lengthen out the tremulous sob,
That echoes far from hill to hill.
explanation: The young owls are communicating with each other throughout the night, their cries carrying across the hills. They sound like affectionate partners, who are not quite on equal footing, as their cries are drawn out and trembling.

text:
Poor Betty now has lost all hope,
Her thoughts are bent on deadly sin,
A green-grown pond she just has past,
And from the brink she hurries fast,
Lest she should drown herself therein.
explanation: Betty is feeling hopeless and suicidal. She has just walked past a pond and is in a hurry to get away from it, fearing that she might drown herself in it.

She is sitting down and crying, with tears unlike any she has shed before. She is addressing her beloved pony, expressing her sadness over her "Idiot Boy" who has gone missing. She pleads with the pony to find him and promises to never burden the animal again.

text:
A thought is come into her head:
The Pony he is mild and good,
And we have always used him well;
Perhaps he's gone along the dell,
And carried Johnny to the wood.
explanation: She had a sudden idea that the Pony, who was always gentle and well-treated, might have wandered off towards the valley, possibly with Johnny on his back, towards the woods.

She suddenly stands up, as if she has wings. She doesn't consider the idea of committing a deadly sin anymore. Even if she were to come across fifty pounds, she wouldn't even think about drowning herself in it.

text:
O Reader! now that I might tell
What Johnny and his Horse are doing
What they've been doing all this time,
Oh could I put it into rhyme,
A most delightful tale pursuing!
explanation: Dear Reader, if only I could express in verse the entertaining story of Johnny and his horse, and what they have been up to all this while. It would be a delightful tale that would captivate your imagination.

text:
Perhaps, and no unlikely thought!
He with his Pony now doth roam
The cliffs and peaks so high that are,
To lay his hands upon a star,
And in his pocket bring it home.
explanation: It is not impossible that he, accompanied by his pony, is exploring the highest cliffs and peaks in order to touch and retrieve a star, which he intends to keep in his pocket.

text:
Perhaps he's turned himself about,
His face unto his horse's tail,
And, still and mute, in wonder lost,
All silent as a horseman-ghost,
He travels slowly down the vale.
explanation: He may have turned himself around and is now facing his horse's rear end. He is moving down the valley in complete silence, appearing to be lost in wonder as he travels like a ghostly horseman.

text:
And now, perhaps, is hunting sheep,
A fierce and dreadful hunter he;
Yon valley, now so trim and green,
In five months' time, should he be seen,
A desert wilderness will be!
explanation: The speaker suggests that a fierce hunter, who may be hunting sheep, is now present in the valley. The valley currently appears green and neat, but in five months' time, it will become a desolate wilderness due to the hunter's actions.

text:
Perhaps, with head and heels on fire,
And like the very soul of evil,
He's galloping away, away,
And so will gallop on for aye,
The bane of all that dread the devil!
explanation: He may be riding away with great speed, appearing as if he embodies evil itself. He will continue to gallop away indefinitely, causing fear for all those who fear the devil.

text:
I to the Muses have been bound
These fourteen years, by strong indentures:
O gentle Muses! let me tell
But half of what to him befell;
He surely met with strange adventures.
explanation: For fourteen years, I have been devoted to the Muses, bound by a strong commitment. Oh, kind Muses, allow me to recount only a portion of the unusual experiences he encountered, for they were truly remarkable.

text:
O gentle Muses! is this kind?
Why will ye thus my suit repel?
Why of your further aid bereave me?
And can ye thus unfriended leave me
Ye Muses! whom I love so well?
explanation: The speaker addresses the Muses and expresses disappointment at their lack of assistance. They question why the Muses have rejected their plea for help and feel abandoned by them. Despite their love for the Muses, the speaker is left feeling unsupported and frustrated.

text:
Who's yon, that, near the waterfall,
Which thunders down with headlong force,
Beneath the moon, yet shining fair,
As careless as if nothing were,
Sits upright on a feeding horse?
explanation: Who is that person sitting on a horse near the waterfall, which is flowing with great force under the bright moonlight? They seem completely unconcerned and relaxed while they sit there.

He appears to be letting his horse eat without restriction, without paying attention to the moon or stars, similar to what one may read in romantic stories. It is indeed Johnny, as the speaker exclaims.

text:
And that's the very Pony, too!
Where is she, where is Betty Foy?
She hardly can sustain her fears;
The roaring waterfall she hears,
And cannot find her Idiot Boy.
explanation: The speaker is asking about the whereabouts of Betty Foy and her son, known as the Idiot Boy. Betty Foy is afraid because she can hear the loud waterfall but cannot find her son. The speaker emphasizes that this is the very pony that they are looking for.

text:
Your Pony's worth his weight in gold:
Then calm your terrors, Betty Foy!
She's coming from among the trees,
And now all full in view she sees
Him whom she loves, her Idiot Boy.
explanation: Betty Foy need not worry as her beloved Pony is of great value. She spots him among the trees and sees her Idiot Boy, whom she loves, with him.

text:
And Betty sees the Pony too:
Why stand you thus, good Betty Foy?
It is no goblin, 'tis no ghost,
'Tis he whom you so long have lost,
He whom you love, your Idiot Boy.
explanation: Betty Foy also sees the Pony and questions why she is standing there. She reassures herself that it is not a goblin or ghost, but rather the Idiot Boy whom she has been missing and loves.

text:
She looks again--her arms are up--
She screams--she cannot move for joy;
She darts, as with a torrent's force,
She almost has o'erturned the Horse,
And fast she holds her Idiot Boy.
explanation: The woman takes another glance and raises her arms in excitement. Overwhelmed with happiness, she screams and is unable to move. She rushes forward with immense strength, almost toppling the horse, while tightly grasping onto her intellectually disabled son.

text:
And Johnny burrs, and laughs aloud;
Whether in cunning or in joy
I cannot tell; but while he laughs,
Betty a drunken pleasure quaffs
To hear again her Idiot Boy.
explanation: Johnny is giggling and making a burring sound, but it's unclear whether it's out of mischief or happiness. Betty, on the other hand, is drinking heavily due to her delight in listening to the silly antics of her silly son.

text:
And now she's at the Pony's tail,
And now is at the Pony's head,--
On that side now, and now on this;
And, almost stifled with her bliss,
A few sad tears does Betty shed.
explanation: Betty has reached the tail of the Pony and then moved to its head, switching sides continuously. Overwhelmed with happiness, she sheds a few tears of sadness.

The woman repeatedly kisses her beloved, who she refers to as her "Idiot Boy," and finds happiness both near him and far from him. However, she also experiences unease no matter where she goes. Her body is filled with exuberant joy.

text:
She pats the Pony, where or when
She knows not, happy Betty Foy!
The little Pony glad may be,
But he is milder far than she,
You hardly can perceive his joy.
explanation: Betty Foy is seen patting a pony without any indication of time or place. She appears to be happy while doing so. Although the pony seems content, it is much calmer than Betty, making it difficult to discern its level of joy.

text:
'Oh! Johnny, never mind the Doctor;
You've done your best, and that is all:'
She took the reins, when this was said,
And gently turned the Pony's head 0
From the loud waterfall.
explanation: "Don't worry about the doctor, Johnny. You did everything you could," she comforted him. She then took the reins and directed the pony away from the noisy waterfall.

text:
By this the stars were almost gone,
The moon was setting on the hill,
So pale you scarcely looked at her:
The little birds began to stir,
Though yet their tongues were still.
explanation: As the stars faded away and the moon descended over the hill, it appeared so faint that it was hardly noticeable. The birds started to move around, but they were still silent.

text:
The Pony, Betty, and her Boy,
Wind slowly through the woody dale;
And who is she, betimes abroad,
That hobbles up the steep rough road?
Who is it, but old Susan Gale?
explanation: Betty the pony and her young male companion are leisurely traveling through a forested valley when they come across an elderly woman struggling up a steep and rugged path. This woman, who appears to be a regular presence in the area, is none other than Susan Gale.

Susan was lost in deep thought for a long time, and she was filled with many terrifying worries about her messenger and nurse. As her mental state deteriorated, her physical condition began to improve.

She tossed and turned in bed, plagued by doubts and fears that surrounded her from all sides. She tirelessly debated every aspect of her situation, and despite the mental strain she was experiencing, her physical condition continued to improve.

text:
'Alas! what is become of them?
These fears can never be endured;
I'll to the wood.'--The word scarce said,
Did Susan rise up from her bed,
As if by magic cured.
explanation: Susan expresses her concern about the whereabouts of someone or something. She is unable to bear such fears and decides to go to the woods. As soon as she utters the words, she instantly gets up from her bed, as if she has been magically healed.
She travels up and down hills until she reaches the woods where she sees her friends and greets them joyfully. The meeting is a cheerful and delightful occasion, perhaps the happiest ever seen.

text:
The owls have hardly sung their last,
While our four travellers homeward wend;
The owls have hooted all night long,
And with the owls began my song,
And with the owls must end.
explanation: As four travelers make their way home, the night is filled with the sound of hooting owls. The speaker's song began with the owls' call and will end with it as well. Despite the owls' persistent singing throughout the night, the travelers continue on their journey, likely tired but determined to reach their destination.

text:
For while they all were travelling home,
Cried Betty, 'Tell us, Johnny, do,
Where all this long night you have been,
What you have heard, what you have seen:
And, Johnny, mind you tell us true.'
explanation: As they journeyed home, Betty implored Johnny to reveal his experiences of the night, including what he had seen and heard, emphasizing the importance of honesty in his recounting.
Johnny had been listening to the owls singing all night long. He had also spent a long time outside in the moonlight, from eight o'clock in the evening until five o'clock in the morning.

text:
And thus, to Betty's question, he
Made answer, like a traveller bold,
(His very words I give to you,)
'The cocks did crow to-whoo, to-whoo,
And the sun did shine so cold!'
--Thus answered Johnny in his glory,
And that was all his travel's story,
explanation: When Betty asked Johnny about his travels, he confidently replied with a poetic response, stating that the roosters crowed and the sun shone cold. This was the entirety of Johnny's travel story.

text:
I AM not One who much or oft delight
To season my fireside with personal talk.--
Of friends, who live within an easy walk,
Or neighbours, daily, weekly, in my sight:
And, for my chance-acquaintance, ladies bright,
Sons, mothers, maidens withering on the stalk,
These all wear out of me, like Forms, with chalk
Painted on rich men's floors, for one feast-night.
Better than such discourse doth silence long,
Long, barren silence, square with my desire;
To sit without emotion, hope, or aim,
In the loved presence of my cottage-fire,
And listen to the flapping of the flame,
Or kettle whispering its faint undersong.
explanation: I am not someone who enjoys talking about personal matters while sitting by the fire. I do not like to discuss my friends who are nearby or the people I casually meet. These people are like temporary shapes that fade away quickly, leaving no impression on me. I prefer the tranquility of silence, where I can sit aimlessly by my cottage fire and listen to the gentle sounds of the flames or the soft murmurs of the kettle.

text:
'Yet life,' you say, 'is life; we have seen and see,
And with a living pleasure we describe;
And fits of sprightly malice do but bribe
The languid mind into activity.
Sound sense, and love itself, and mirth and glee
Are fostered by the comment and the gibe.'
Even be it so; yet still among your tribe,
Our daily world's true Worldlings, rank not me!
Children are blest, and powerful; their world lies
More justly balanced; partly at their feet,
And part far from them: sweetest melodies
Are those that are by distance made more sweet;
Whose mind is but the mind of his own eyes,
He is a Slave; the meanest we can meet!
