explanation: The speaker acknowledges that life is to be experienced and enjoyed, and that sometimes even mischievous behavior can invigorate the mind. However, the speaker does not want to be considered part of the everyday world, where people are focused solely on themselves and their own perceptions. The speaker believes that children have a better understanding of the world around them, with a balance of what is within their control and what is not. The speaker also values the beauty of things that are distant and inaccessible, as they can evoke a greater sense of emotion. The speaker warns that anyone who only sees the world through their own eyes is a slave to their own limited perspective.

text:
Wings have we,--and as far as we can go,
We may find pleasure: wilderness and wood,
Blank ocean and mere sky, support that mood
Which with the lofty sanctifies the low.
Dreams, books, are each a world; and books, we know,
Are a substantial world, both pure and good:
Round these, with tendrils strong as flesh and blood,
Our pastime and our happiness will grow.
There find I personal themes, a plenteous store,
Matter wherein right voluble I am,
To which I listen with a ready ear;
Two shall be named, pre-eminently dear,--
The gentle Lady married to the Moor;
And heavenly Una with her milk-white Lamb,
explanation: We have wings and can find pleasure in exploring the wilderness, oceans, and sky. Our love for the grand and sublime elevates the ordinary. Dreams and books are like separate worlds that are both substantial and good. They become a source of happiness and personal themes that we can talk about with ease. Two themes that are particularly dear to me are the story of the gentle Lady married to the Moor and the heavenly Una with her milk-white Lamb.

text:
Nor can I not believe but that hereby
Great gains are mine; for thus I live remote
From evil-speaking; rancour, never sought,
Comes to me not; malignant truth, or lie.
Hence have I genial seasons, hence have I
Smooth passions, smooth discourse, and joyous thought:
And thus from day to day my little boat
Rocks in its harbour, lodging peaceably.
Blessings be with them--and eternal praise,
Who gave us nobler loves, and nobler cares--
The Poets, who on earth have made us heirs
Of truth and pure delight by heavenly lays!
Oh! might my name be numbered among theirs,
Then gladly would I end my mortal days.
explanation: Living a life free from gossip and animosity brings great benefits, as the speaker believes. By avoiding negativity, the speaker is able to enjoy peaceful thoughts and conversations, and experiences joy. The speaker credits poets for showing us how to love and care in a more noble way, and for sharing truth and pure delight through their work. The speaker admires these poets so much that they would be honored to be counted among them, and would find peace in knowing that their name was included among such great literary figures.

text:
STRANGE fits of passion have I known:
And I will dare to tell,
But in the lover's ear alone,
What once to me befell.
explanation: I have experienced peculiar outbursts of emotion, which I am willing to disclose only to someone who is in love, and only in private.

text:
When she I loved look'd every day
Fresh as a rose in June,
I to her cottage bent my way,
Beneath an evening moon.
explanation: Every day, when the woman I was in love with appeared, she looked as beautiful as a rose in June. Under the evening moon, I would make my way to her cottage.

text:
Upon the moon I fix'd my eye,
All over the wide lea;
With quickening pace my horse drew nigh
Those paths so dear to me.
explanation: I gazed at the moon while riding my horse across the open field. As we approached the familiar paths, my horse picked up speed, making me nostalgic for the past.

text:
And now we reach'd the orchard-plot;
And, as we climb'd the hill,
The sinking moon to Lucy's cot
Came near and nearer still.
explanation: We arrived at the orchard, and as we ascended the hill, we noticed the moon getting closer and closer to Lucy's house.

text:
In one of those sweet dreams I slept,
Kind Nature's gentlest boon!
And all the while my eyes I kept
On the descending moon.
explanation: I had a peaceful dream where I felt the kindness of nature. I watched the moon slowly descend as I slept.

text:
My horse moved on; hoof after hoof
He raised, and never stopp'd:
When down behind the cottage roof,
At once, the bright moon dropp'd.
explanation: As my horse continued to move forward, his hooves relentlessly pounding the ground, the bright moon suddenly disappeared behind the roof of a nearby cottage.

text:
What fond and wayward thoughts will slide
Into a lover's head!
'O mercy! ' to myself I cried,
'If Lucy should be dead! '
explanation: The musings of a lover can be unpredictable, as they often involve fond and whimsical thoughts. In this particular instance, the lover becomes concerned with the possibility of their beloved, Lucy, passing away. The thought of losing her causes them to exclaim "O mercy!" as they contemplate the idea. Such is the nature of love and its potential to evoke intense emotions and fears.

text:
HE dwelt among the untrodden ways
Beside the springs of Dove,
A Maid whom there were none to praise
And very few to love:
explanation: The person described in the poem lived in a secluded area next to the Dove springs. This person was a young woman who received little to no recognition or affection from others around her.

text:
A violet by a mossy stone
Half hidden from the eye!
Fair as a star, when only one
Is shining in the sky.
explanation: The speaker observes a violet flower growing next to a mossy stone, which is partially concealed from view. They compare the flower's beauty to that of a solitary star shining in the night sky.

text:
She lived unknown, and few could know
When Lucy ceased to be;
But she is in her grave, and oh,
The difference to me!
explanation: Lucy lived a life of obscurity, known by only a handful of people. Her passing went unnoticed, yet her death has affected the speaker deeply. Lucy now rests in her grave, and the speaker reflects on the significant impact her absence has had on their life.

text:
TRAVELL'D among unknown men,
In lands beyond the sea;
Nor, England! did I know till then
What love I bore to thee.
explanation: I have traveled to unfamiliar places and foreign lands across the sea, and it was only then that I came to realize the depth of my love for England.

text:
'Tis past, that melancholy dream!
Nor will I quit thy shore
A second time; for still I seem
To love thee more and more.
explanation: That sad dream is over, and I won't leave your side again because my love for you only grows stronger with time.

text:
Among the mountains did I feel
The joy of my desire;
And she I cherish'd turn'd her wheel
Beside an English fire.
explanation: I felt my heart's desire amidst the mountains, and the one I love was spinning her wheel by an English fire.

text:
Thy mornings show'd, thy nights conceal'd,
The bowers where Lucy play'd;
And thine too is the last green field
That Lucy's eyes survey'd.
explanation: Lucy played in the gardens during the day and disappeared into the night. The last thing she saw before she passed was a beautiful green field. That field now belongs to you.

For three years, she grew amidst sunshine and rain, until Nature decided that she was the most beautiful flower that had ever blossomed on earth. Nature claimed her for herself, intending to transform her into a lady of her own creation.

text:
'Myself will to my darling be
Both law and impulse; and with me
The girl, in rock and plain,
In earth and heaven, in glade and bower,
Shall feel an overseeing power
To kindle or restrain.
explanation: I will be both the law and motivation for my beloved, and together we will create an influence that will be felt by the girl in every aspect of nature. From rocks and plains to earth and sky, even in the midst of glades and bowers, she will sense a guiding force that can either ignite her passions or keep them in check.

text:
'She shall be sportive as the fawn
That wild with glee across the lawn
Or up the mountain springs;
And hers shall be the breathing balm,
And hers the silence and the calm
Of mute insensate things.
explanation: She will be playful like a fawn, full of joy as it frolics across a lawn or leaps up a mountain. She will embody the soothing qualities of nature, bringing a sense of peace and tranquility like that of inanimate objects.

text:
'The floating clouds their state shall lend
To her; for her the willow bend;
Nor shall she fail to see
Even in the motions of the storm
Grace that shall mould the maiden's form
By silent sympathy.
explanation: The girl will be surrounded by the beauty of nature, as the clouds and willow trees will provide her with their presence. She will not miss out on the gracefulness of the storm, which will shape her character through a connection that is not spoken but felt.

text:
'The stars of midnight shall be dear
To her; and she shall lean her ear
In many a secret place
Where rivulets dance their wayward round,
And beauty born of murmuring sound
Shall pass into her face.
explanation: She will cherish the stars that shine at midnight and listen intently to the secrets whispered in the many hidden places where streams meander and create enchanting sounds that add to her beauty.

text:
'And vital feelings of delight
Shall rear her form to stately height,
Her virgin bosom swell;
Such thoughts to Lucy I will give
While she and I together live
Here in this happy dell.'
explanation: The speaker promises to fill Lucy's mind with positive emotions and elevate her self-esteem. He envisions her growing into a confident and beautiful woman, with a proud and full chest. He plans to provide her with these feelings while they live together in a joyful place.

text:
Thus Nature spake -  The work was done -
How soon my Lucy's race was run!
She died, and left to me
This heath, this calm and quiet scene;
The memory of what has been,
And never more will be.
explanation: Nature spoke of the completion of Lucy's life and how quickly it had ended. Lucy had passed away and left behind a heath, a peaceful and serene environment, as well as memories of what had occurred and could never happen again.

text:
SLUMBER did my spirit seal;
I had no human fears:
She seem'd a thing that could not feel
The touch of earthly years.
explanation: My spirit was sealed in sleep, free from any human anxieties. She appeared to be an entity that was immune to the passage of time on earth.

She is devoid of movement, lacking any energy or power. Her senses of hearing and sight are absent. She is being carried along the daily rotation of the earth, surrounded by inanimate objects such as rocks, stones, and trees.

text:
SHE dwelt among the untrodden ways
Beside the springs of Dove,
A Maid whom there were none to praise
And very few to love:
explanation: The woman lived in a secluded area next to the Dove springs. No one saw her as deserving of praise, and only a small number of people loved her.

text:
A violet by a mossy stone
Half hidden from the eye!
Fair as a star, when only one
Is shining in the sky.
explanation: A violet grows near a mossy stone, not easily seen. Its beauty rivals that of a lone shining star in the nighttime sky.

text:
She lived unknown, and few could know
When Lucy ceased to be;
But she is in her grave, and oh,
The difference to me!
explanation: Lucy lived her life in obscurity, and her passing went unnoticed by many. However, now that she is buried, her absence is keenly felt by the speaker.

For three years she grew under the warmth of the sun and the nourishment of the rain, until Nature declared that he had never seen a more beautiful flower on earth. Thus, he decided to claim the child as his own and transform her into a lady.

text:
"Myself will to my darling be
Both law and impulse: and with me
The girl, in rock and plain,
In earth and heaven, in glade and bower,
Shall feel an overseeing power
To kindle or restrain.
explanation: I will be both the law and the driving force for my beloved, and together we will experience a guiding influence that will inspire or limit us in all places, whether it be among rocks and plains, in the heavens or on earth, or in forest clearings and gardens."

text:
'She shall be sportive as the fawn
That wild with glee across the lawn
Or up the mountain springs;
And hers shall be the breathing balm,
And hers the silence and the calm
Of mute insensate things.
explanation: She will be playful like a fawn bounding with joy across the grass or leaping up the mountain springs. She will have the soothing essence of nature and the tranquility of lifeless objects.

text:
'The floating clouds their state shall lend
To her; for her the willow bend;
Nor shall she fail to see
Even in the motions of the storm
Grace that shall mould the maiden's form
By silent sympathy.
explanation: The girl will receive inspiration and beauty from the clouds and willow trees. Even during storms, she will find grace and her form will be shaped through a deep connection with nature.

text:
'The stars of midnight shall be dear
To her; and she shall lean her ear
In many a secret place
Where rivulets dance their wayward round,
And beauty born of murmuring sound
Shall pass into her face.
explanation: She will cherish the stars that shine at midnight and listen intently in various secluded spots where streams flow freely and the beauty of their murmurs will reflect on her face.

text:
'And vital feelings of delight
Shall rear her form to stately height,
Her virgin bosom swell;
Such thoughts to Lucy I will give
While she and I together live
Here in this happy dell.'
explanation: I will bestow upon Lucy joyful emotions that will lift her up and make her feel proud. She will be filled with youthful enthusiasm and her confidence will grow. These feelings will be present as long as we are together in this serene and contented place.

text:
Thus Nature spake--The work was done--
How soon my Lucy's race was run!
She died, and left to me
This heath, this calm, and quiet scene;
The memory of what has been,
And never more will be.
explanation: Nature spoke and acknowledged that Lucy's life had come to an end. She had passed away and left behind a peaceful heath and quiet surroundings for the speaker to cherish. However, the speaker cannot help but feel sorrowful for what once was and what can never be again.

text:
We talked with open heart, and tongue
Affectionate and true,
A pair of friends, though I was young,
And Matthew seventy-two.
explanation: Despite the age difference between us, Matthew and I had a sincere and intimate conversation where we both spoke honestly and from the heart. We were genuine friends, even though I was much younger than him at the age of 72.

text:
We lay beneath a spreading oak,
Beside a mossy seat;
And from the turf a fountain broke,
And gurgled at our feet.
explanation: We rested under a large oak tree next to a seat covered in moss. A fountain sprouted up from the ground and made a gurgling sound as it flowed near us.

text:
"Now, Matthew!" said I, "let us match
This water's pleasant tune
With some old border-song, or catch
That suits a summer's noon;
explanation: I suggested to Matthew that we should accompany the pleasant tune of the water with an appropriate summer song or melody from the border region."

text:
"Or of the church-clock and the chimes
Sing here beneath the shade,
That half-mad thing of witty rhymes
Which you last April made!"
explanation: Sing to me of the church clock and its chimes, as they ring out beneath the shelter of the trees. Remember that clever poem you wrote for me last April, with its playful rhymes and whimsical tone.

text:
In silence Matthew lay, and eyed
The spring beneath the tree;
And thus the dear old Man replied,
The grey-haired man of glee:
explanation: Matthew lay in silence and watched the spring under the tree. The elderly man who was full of happiness responded to him.

text:
"No check, no stay, this Streamlet fears;
How merrily it goes!
'Twill murmur on a thousand years,
And flow as now it flows.
explanation: The Streamlet is afraid to stop flowing without a check in its path, and it continues on its merry way. It will continue to murmur and flow for a long time, perhaps even thousands of years, just as it does now.

text:
"And here, on this delightful day,
I cannot choose but think
How oft, a vigorous man, I lay
Beside this fountain's brink.
explanation: On this pleasant day, I cannot help but remember the times when I was a strong man and would often lie next to this fountain.

text:
"My eyes are dim with childish tears,
My heart is idly stirred,
For the same sound is in my ears
Which in those days I heard.
explanation: I am filled with nostalgia and sadness as my eyes are clouded with tears from my childhood memories. My heart is stirred with emotion as I hear the same sound that I once heard in those days gone by.

text:
"Thus fares it still in our decay:
And yet the wiser mind
Mourns less for what age takes away
Than what it leaves behind.
explanation: As we continue to age, this process of loss and decay persists. However, those who possess greater wisdom tend to be less sorrowful about the things that age takes away from them than they are about what it leaves behind.

text:
"The blackbird amid leafy trees,
The lark above the hill,
Let loose their carols when they please
Are quiet when they will.
explanation: The blackbird and lark have the freedom to sing whenever they want and stop when they desire. The blackbird sings among the leafy trees, while the lark sings above the hill. There is no restriction on when they can express themselves through their beautiful songs.

text:
"With Nature never do 'they' wage
A foolish strife; they see
A happy youth, and their old age
Is beautiful and free:
explanation: They do not engage in a pointless battle with nature but instead embrace it. They find joy in their youth and their old age is graceful and unrestrained.

text:
"But we are pressed by heavy laws;
And often, glad no more,
We wear a face of joy, because
We have been glad of yore.
explanation: The weight of societal regulations can weigh heavily on us, causing us to pretend to be happy even when we are not. We may put on a facade of joy because we have experienced happiness in the past, but in reality, we are struggling to maintain this facade.

text:
"If there be one who need bemoan
His kindred laid in earth,
The household hearts that were his own;
It is the man of mirth.
explanation: The person who has the most reason to grieve for the loss of their family members and loved ones is the one who always seemed to be the happiest and most carefree, according to this statement. The man or woman who was always joking and laughing, and who never seemed to let anything get them down, is the one who will feel the most acutely the absence of those who were closest to them. This is because they may have relied on their friends and family to keep them grounded and provide a sense of stability in their lives, and now they are left without that support. The speaker is suggesting that we should be mindful of this fact and offer our condolences and support to those who may be struggling to cope with the loss of their loved ones, even if they seem outwardly cheerful and upbeat.

text:
"My days, my Friend, are almost gone,
My life has been approved,
And many love me; but by none
Am I enough beloved."
explanation: I am nearing the end of my days, my friend, and I am content with the life I have lived. Many people have shown me love throughout my life, but I have yet to find someone who truly loves me enough.
The person who is complaining about me is also harming himself. I am living a carefree life and enjoying the beauty of the plains by singing my songs.

text:
"And, Matthew, for thy children dead
I'll be a son to thee!"
At this he grasped my hand, and said,
"Alas! that cannot be."
explanation: Matthew's friend offered to be a son to him after his children had passed away, but Matthew sadly declined, stating that it wasn't possible.
We stood up from the area near the fountain and smoothly made our way down the green path where the sheep roam. We then continued on through the forest.

text:
And, ere we came to Leonard's rock,
He sang those witty rhymes
About the crazy old church-clock,
And the bewildered chimes.
explanation: Before we reached Leonard's rock, he recited clever verses about the eccentric church-clock and its confused chimes.

text:
A SLUMBER did my spirit seal;
I had no human fears:
She seem'd a thing that could not feel
The touch of earthly years.
explanation: My spirit was in a deep sleep and I had no fears of human kind. She appeared to be something that was not affected by the passing of time on Earth.
She is completely still and powerless, unable to sense or perceive anything. She is constantly moving in the rotation of the earth, surrounded by natural objects such as rocks, stones, and trees.

O Duty, you are the strict enforcer of God's will. You guide and correct those who stray from the path of righteousness. You are the embodiment of justice and authority, crushing any fears that may arise. You provide a shield against temptation and alleviate the struggles of human weakness.

text:
There are who ask not if thine eye
Be on them; who, in love and truth,
Where no misgiving is, rely
Upon the genial sense of youth:
Glad hearts! without reproach or blot;
Who do thy work, and know it not:
O, if through confidence misplaced
They fail, thy saving arms, dread Power! around them cast.
explanation: Some people don't need constant validation or reassurance from others. They trust in the pure and innocent nature of youth and are content with doing their work without seeking recognition. These individuals have happy hearts and don't have any shame or wrongdoing to hide. However, if their confidence leads them astray, they hope that a higher power will protect and guide them.

text:
Serene will be our days and bright,
And happy will our nature be,
When love is an unerring light,
And joy its own security.
And they a blissful course may hold
Even now, who, not unwisely bold,
Live in the spirit of this creed;
Yet seek thy firm support, according to their need.
explanation: Our days will be calm and joyful, our nature content, if guided by the unerring light of love and the security of joy. Even those who live by this ideal can find happiness, but it is important to seek support when needed.

text:
I, loving freedom, and untried;
No sport of every random gust,
Yet being to myself a guide,
Too blindly have reposed my trust:
And oft, when in my heart was heard
Thy timely mandate, I deferr'd
The task, in smoother walks to stray;
But thee I now would serve more strictly, if I may.
explanation: I am inexperienced and value my freedom greatly. I have not been swayed by the whims of others, but have relied too heavily on my own judgement, leading me astray. Despite hearing your advice, I have sometimes neglected my responsibilities to wander aimlessly. However, I now wish to rededicate myself to serving you more diligently, if possible.

I am not asking for your guidance because of any turmoil within me, or due to any strong urge. It is simply that I am tired of this uncharted freedom. The unpredictability of my desires weighs heavily on me, and I yearn for a sense of permanence. I crave a restful repose that will remain unchanged.

text:
Yet not the less would I throughout
Still act according to the voice
Of my own wish; and feel past doubt
That my submissiveness was choice:
Not seeking in the school of pride
For 'precepts over dignified,'
Denial and restraint I prize
No farther than they breed a second Will more wise.
explanation: Despite this, I would still follow my own desires and believe that my obedience was voluntary. I do not seek guidance from arrogant teachings, instead, I value self-control only to the extent that it cultivates a more intelligent will.

The speaker addresses a stern, law-giving deity who paradoxically wears a kind and gentle expression. They observe that there is nothing as beautiful as the deity's smile, and note that even the flowers seem to rejoice in their presence. The deity is credited with keeping the stars in their rightful places and imbuing the heavens with enduring strength.

I am calling upon a great power for guidance, asking to be led and to end my weakness. I am seeking the spirit of selflessness and the ability to trust my own reasoning. I ask to live as a servant of truth, bound by its light.

text:
.  When first, descending from the moorlands,
I saw the Stream of Yarrow glide
Along a bare and open valley,
The Ettrick Shepherd was my guide.
When last along its banks I wandered,
Through groves that had begun to shed
Their golden leaves upon the pathways,
My steps the Border-minstrel led.
The mighty Minstrel breathes no longer,
'Mid mouldering ruins low he lies;
And death upon the braes of Yarrow,
Has closed the Shepherd-poet's eyes:
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: The speaker recalls two separate occasions when they walked along the banks of the Yarrow river, guided by the Ettrick Shepherd and the Border-minstrel. During the first walk, the valley was open and bare, while on the second, the trees had begun to shed their golden leaves. The speaker notes the passing of the Border-minstrel and the Shepherd-poet, both of whom had guided them along the river. The Shepherd-poet died on the braes of Yarrow, and the Border-minstrel has also passed away.

text:
Nor has the rolling year twice measured,
From sign to sign, its stedfast course,
Since every mortal power of Coleridge
Was frozen at its marvellous source;
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: Coleridge's creative ability has been stagnant for a year, and it seems unlikely that it will be revived anytime soon.

text:
The rapt One, of the godlike forehead,
The heaven-eyed creature sleeps in earth:
And Lamb, the frolic and the gentle,
Has vanished from his lonely hearth.
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: The divine being with an impressive forehead and heavenly eyes is now resting in the ground, while Lamb, the playful and kind-hearted individual, has disappeared from his solitary dwelling.

text:
Like clouds that rake the mountain-summits,
Or waves that own no curbing hand,
How fast has brother followed brother,
From sunshine to the sunless land!
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: The author compares the passing of time to clouds that sweep across mountaintops and waves that have no restraint. He reflects on how quickly one person has followed another from the brightness of life to the darkness of death.

text:
Yet I, whose lids from infant slumber
Were earlier raised, remain to hear
A timid voice, that asks in whispers,
"Who next will drop and disappear?"
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: As someone who has been awake since infancy, I am still present to hear a quiet voice asking anxiously who will be the next to vanish.

text:
Our haughty life is crowned with darkness,
Like London with its own black wreath,
On which with thee, O Crabbe! forth-looking,
I gazed from Hampstead's breezy heath.
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: Our arrogant existence is shrouded in gloom, reminiscent of London's dark aura, which I observed alongside Crabbe from the windy heath of Hampstead.

text:
As if but yesterday departed,
Thou too art gone before; but why,
O'er ripe fruit, seasonably gathered,
Should frail survivors heave a sigh?
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: It feels like you left just yesterday, but now you too are gone. However, why should we mourn when you were like ripe fruit, ready to be picked? We should not be sad for those who have passed on.

text:
Mourn rather for that holy Spirit,
Sweet as the spring, as ocean deep;
For Her who, ere her summer faded,
Has sunk into a breathless sleep.
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: Grieve instead for the loss of the Holy Spirit, who is as pleasant as spring and as profound as the ocean. We should lament the passing of the Spirit who, before her prime, has now passed away into an eternal slumber.

text:
No more of old romantic sorrows,
For slaughtered Youth or love-lorn Maid!
With sharper grief is Yarrow smitten,
And Ettrick mourns with her their Poet dead.
poem_title: Extempore Effusion Upon The Death Of James Hogg
explanation: The speaker declares that there will be no more lamenting for the romantic tragedies of the past, such as the death of a young lover or the heartbreak of a maiden. Instead, the towns of Yarrow and Ettrick are struck with a deeper sorrow as they mourn the death of their poet.

text:
Lulled by the sound of pastoral bells,
Rude Nature's Pilgrims did we go,
From the dread summit of the Queen
Of mountains, through a deep ravine,
Where, in her holy chapel, dwells
"Our Lady of the Snow."
explanation: We were enchanted by the tranquil ringing of the pastoral bells as we journeyed as humble travelers of Mother Nature, moving from the majestic peak of the highest mountain, across a narrow valley and into the sacred chapel of "Our Lady of the Snow."

The atmosphere was pleasant with a clear blue sky and mild air. The streams flowed freely and the bowers were lush green, as if the location had never experienced any harsh conditions. The genial spot appeared to always have a smiling face, embodying the pleasantness of summer hours.

We were happy and carefree, our hearts full of joy as we travelled along. Our only concern was the winding path we followed, and the occasional breeze that brought a hint of trouble. Winter was just a word, with no real impact on our journey.

text:
If foresight could have rent the veil
Of three short days--but hush--no more!
Calm is the grave, and calmer none
Than that to which thy cares are gone,
Thou Victim of the stormy gale;
Asleep on ZURICH'S shore!
explanation: If only we could have known what would happen three days ago, but let's not dwell on it anymore. The grave is peaceful, and there is no place more serene than where you now rest. You were a casualty of a tumultuous storm, but now you sleep calmly on the shore of Zurich.

text:
O GODDARD! what art thou?--a name--
A sunbeam followed by a shade!
Nor more, for aught that time supplies,
The great, the experienced, and the wise:
Too much from this frail earth we claim,
And therefore are betrayed.
explanation: The speaker addresses Goddard, questioning their true identity and describing them as a fleeting presence akin to a sunbeam followed by a shadow. The overall sentiment suggests that humanity often places too much importance on earthly things, leading to disappointment and betrayal.

text:
We met, while festive mirth ran wild,
Where, from a deep lake's mighty urn,
Forth slips, like an enfranchised slave,
A sea-green river, proud to lave,
With current swift and undefiled,
The towers of old LUCERNE.
explanation: We encountered each other amidst a lively celebration in Lucerne, where a powerful sea-green river flowed swiftly and purely from a deep lake, appearing as if it had been liberated from slavery. This river was proud to wash the ancient towers of Lucerne with its waters.

We said goodbye in a serious place, looking up at the never-ending sky. However, our minds were only focused on Earth and the simple things that bring us joy. We didn't feel any sadness or emotion as we parted ways.

text:
Fetch, sympathising Powers of air,
Fetch, ye that post o'er seas and lands,
Herbs, moistened by Virginian dew,
A most untimely grave to strew,
Whose turf may never know the care
Of 'kindred' human hands!
explanation: Oh, compassionate forces of the air, travel far and wide to gather herbs moistened by the dew of Virginia to sprinkle upon an early grave that will never receive the attention of loving human hands.

text:
Beloved by every gentle Muse
He left his Transatlantic home:
Europe, a realised romance,
Had opened on his eager glance;
What present bliss!--what golden views!
What stores for years to come!
explanation: The speaker describes a person who is loved by every gentle Muse and has left their home in America to explore Europe. The person is excited about the new experiences and opportunities that await them in Europe, feeling both present bliss and anticipation for what the future holds.

text:
Though lodged within no vigorous frame,
His soul her daily tasks renewed,
Blithe as the lark on sun-gilt wings
High poised--or as the wren that sings
In shady places, to proclaim
Her modest gratitude.
explanation: Despite not having a strong physical body, his spirit remained lively and he continued to complete his daily tasks with joy. He was as carefree as a lark soaring in the sun or a wren chirping in the shade to express its thankfulness.

Flattery is not the same as sincere praise, and the latter holds a special significance. Words spoken in truth become a lasting memorial, much like the sweet fragrance of flowers growing amidst the ruins of GOLDUA or the lingering rays of evening sun on the quiet peak of RIGHI.

text:
Lamented Youth! to thy cold clay
Fit obsequies the Stranger paid;
And piety shall guard the Stone
Which hath not left the spot unknown
Where the wild waves resigned their prey--
And 'that' which marks thy bed.
explanation: The stranger paid his respects to the deceased youth and the stone marking the grave will be guarded by piety. The location where the youth's body was found after being lost at sea will not be forgotten.

text:
And, when thy Mother weeps for Thee,
Lost Youth! a solitary Mother;
This tribute from a casual Friend
A not unwelcome aid may lend,
To feed the tender luxury,
The rising pang to smother.
explanation: If your mother grieves for you, lost youth, as a single mother, this tribute from a casual friend may provide some comfort in easing her pain. It can help to nourish the tender luxury and suppress the growing sorrow.

The wind was loud all night, accompanied by heavy rain that poured like a flood. However, the sun has now risen peacefully and brightly. The sweet sound of birds singing can be heard from the distant woods, as the stock dove coos over its own voice. The jay responds to the magpie's chatter, and the air is filled with the soothing sound of water.

Outdoor creatures bask in the sun's warmth, as the sky celebrates the start of a new day. The grass glistens with dew, while the hare frolics across the moors, leaving a trail of mist behind her as she runs. Her joyous playfulness is contagious, as she revels in the beauty of nature.

While wandering on the moor, I observed a hare frolicking with delight and the sound of the woods and far-off waters roaring filled my ears, but I was content and carefree, much like a young boy. The delightful season captured my attention, and I was able to forget about my past experiences and memories, as well as the superficial and melancholic ways of humanity.

Sometimes, when we experience extreme happiness, we may also experience a corresponding low. This happened to me one morning when I was overwhelmed with fears and unclear thoughts that brought me great sadness. Despite having previously experienced great joy, I found myself sinking into a state of dejection that I could not explain.

As the sky-lark sang and the hare played, the speaker was reminded of their own happiness and carefree life. They walked far from the world and its troubles, but acknowledged that one day they may face solitude, heartache, suffering, and financial struggles.

text:
My whole life I have lived in pleasant thought,
As if life's business were a summer mood;
As if all needful things would come unsought
To genial faith, still rich in genial good;
But how can He expect that others should
Build for him, sow for him, and at his call
Love him, who for himself will take no heed at all?
explanation: Throughout my life, I have lived with a positive outlook, believing that everything I need will come to me without much effort. However, it is unreasonable for me to expect others to do things for me when I am not willing to put in any effort myself. If I do not take responsibility for my own life and show love to others, I cannot expect the same in return.

text:
I thought of Chatterton, the marvellous Boy,
The sleepless Soul that perished in his pride;
Of Him who walked in glory and in joy
Following his plough, along the mountain-side:
By our own spirits are we deified:
We Poets in our youth begin in gladness;
But thereof come in the end despondency and madness.
explanation: As I reflected, my mind turned to the tale of Chatterton, the wondrous youth who met his demise due to his own vanity. I also thought of the man who walked the mountain slopes with his plow, basking in the splendor of his existence. It is through our own spirits that we become elevated, but as poets, we begin our journey with unbridled joy and enthusiasm, only to find ourselves consumed by despair and insanity in the end.

text:
Now, whether it were by peculiar grace,
A leading from above, a something given,
Yet it befell, that, in this lonely place,
When I with these untoward thoughts had striven,
Beside a pool bare to the eye of heaven
I saw a Man before me unawares:
The oldest man he seemed that ever wore grey hairs.
explanation: In this isolated location, I struggled with unsettling thoughts when suddenly, without warning, I came across an elderly man next to a pool that was exposed to the sky. It's possible that his presence was due to divine intervention or some other inexplicable force, but regardless, he appeared to be the oldest man I had ever seen with his long grey hair.

The sight of a massive boulder perched on the summit of a hill is a source of amazement to those who chance upon it. The mystery of how such a weighty object could have been transported to that location and from where it originated leaves observers with a feeling that the rock is somehow sentient. It is reminiscent of a sea creature emerging from the water to bask on a shoreline, as the boulder appears to be at rest on a natural shelf of sand or rock.

text:
Such seemed this Man, not all alive nor dead,
Nor all asleep--in his extreme old age:
His body was bent double, feet and head
Coming together in life's pilgrimage;
As if some dire constraint of pain, or rage
Of sickness felt by him in times long past,
A more than human weight upon his frame had cast.
explanation: This man appeared to be in a state between life and death and not entirely asleep, due to his advanced age. His body was hunched over, with his feet and head close together as if he had endured great pain or illness in the past, which had left a tremendous burden on his physical being.

text:
Himself he propped, limbs, body, and pale face,
Upon a long grey staff of shaven wood:
And, still as I drew near with gentle pace,
Upon the margin of that moorish flood
Motionless as a cloud the old Man stood,
That heareth not the loud winds when they call
And moveth all together, if it move at all.
explanation: The old man leaned on a long staff made of shaved wood, supporting his limbs, body, and pale face. As I approached him with a gentle pace near the marshy riverbank, he remained completely still like a cloud, unaffected by the loud winds that called out to him. He seemed to move only if everything around him moved at once.

text:
At length, himself unsettling, he the pond
Stirred with his staff, and fixedly did look
Upon the muddy water, which he conned,
As if he had been reading in a book:
And now a stranger's privilege I took;
And, drawing to his side, to him did say,
"This morning gives us promise of a glorious day."
explanation: He disturbed the pond with his staff and studied the muddy water intently as if he was reading a book. Intrigued by his actions, I approached him and commented on the promising day that lay ahead.

text:
A gentle answer did the old Man make,
In courteous speech which forth he slowly drew:
And him with further words I thus bespake,
"What occupation do you there pursue?
This is a lonesome place for one like you."
Ere he replied, a flash of mild surprise
Broke from the sable orbs of his yet-vivid eyes,
explanation: The old man responded politely and slowly to my question about his occupation in the isolated place we found ourselves. Before he could answer, I noticed a brief expression of surprise in his still-bright eyes.

text:
His words came feebly, from a feeble chest,
But each in solemn order followed each,
With something of a lofty utterance drest--
Choice word and measured phrase, above the reach
Of ordinary men; a stately speech;
Such as grave Livers do in Scotland use,
Religious men, who give to God and man their dues.
explanation: Despite his weak physical state, he spoke with a solemn and elevated tone, using carefully chosen words and phrases that surpassed the language of most ordinary people. His speech was dignified and reminiscent of the language used by serious and devout individuals in Scotland who give proper respect to both God and mankind.

text:
He told, that to these waters he had come
To gather leeches, being old and poor:
Employment hazardous and wearisome!
And he had many hardships to endure:
From pond to pond he roamed, from moor to moor;
Housing, with God's good help, by choice or chance,
And in this way he gained an honest maintenance.
explanation: The man explained that he came to the waters to collect leeches as a means of making a living, despite the dangers and exhaustion that came with the job. He traveled from pond to pond and moor to moor, often relying on chance for a place to stay. He credited God for helping him find shelter and allowing him to earn an honest living through his hard work.

The elderly man was still beside me, conversing in a soft voice that was difficult to decipher. It was as if his words were melding together, and I couldn't separate them. Additionally, the man's entire demeanor appeared dreamlike, as if he had been sent from a far-off location to provide me with the necessary encouragement and fortitude to face the challenges ahead.

The speaker's previous feelings of fear and hopelessness resurface, along with physical pain and suffering, as well as the knowledge of great poets who have also experienced misery and death. Seeking comfort, the speaker asks how the person they are speaking to manages to live and what actions they take.

He repeated his words with a smile and explained that he travels far and wide to collect leeches. While doing so, he stirs the waters of the pools where they reside with his feet. He used to find them easily, but they have been dwindling for a long time due to slow decay. Nonetheless, he continues to persevere and finds them wherever he can.

text:
While he was talking thus, the lonely place,
The old Man's shape, and speech--all troubled me:
In my mind's eye I seemed to see him pace
About the weary moors continually,
Wandering about alone and silently.
While I these thoughts within myself pursued,
He, having made a pause, the same discourse renewed.
explanation: As he spoke, I felt uneasy in the desolate surroundings and the appearance and words of the elderly man added to my discomfort. I envisioned him wandering aimlessly across the barren moors, lost in his thoughts and solitude. As I pondered these ideas, the man resumed his speech after a brief pause.

text:
And soon with this he other matter blended,
Cheerfully uttered, with demeanour kind,
But stately in the main; and when he ended,
I could have laughed myself to scorn to find
In that decrepit Man so firm a mind.
"God," said I, "be my help and stay secure;
I'll think of the Leech-gatherer on the lonely moor!"
explanation: The speaker reflects on a conversation with an old man who blended topics in a cheerful and kind manner, yet maintained a stately demeanor. Despite the man's physical weakness, the speaker was impressed by his strong mindset. The speaker then prays for God's help and security, and decides to remember the Leech-gatherer on the lonely moor as inspiration.

text:
Scorn not the Sonnet; Critic, you have frowned,
Mindless of its just honours; with this key
Shakspeare unlocked his heart; the melody
Of this small lute gave ease to Petrarch's wound;
explanation: Don't underestimate the Sonnet, critic, you have overlooked its true value. Shakespeare used this form of poetry to express his deepest emotions and Petrarch found comfort in its musicality during his time of distress.

text:
A thousand times this pipe did Tasso sound;
With it Camoens soothed an exile's grief;
The Sonnet glittered a gay myrtle leaf
Amid the cypress with which Dante crowned
His visionary brow: a glow-worm lamp,
It cheered mild Spenser, called from Faery-land
To struggle through dark ways; and when a damp
Fell round the path of Milton, in his hand
The Thing became a trumpet; whence he blew
Soul-animating strains--alas, too few!
explanation: This passage describes the power and versatility of poetry, as symbolized by different types of writing instruments. The pipe was used by Tasso and Camoens to express their emotions, while the Sonnet was used by Dante to elevate his thoughts. Spenser found comfort in the Sonnet during his struggles, and Milton used it as a trumpet to inspire others, though it is noted that he did not produce enough of these "soul-animating strains." The passage suggests that poetry has the ability to connect people across time and space, and to provide solace and inspiration in difficult circumstances.

text:
The dew was falling fast, the stars began to blink;
I heard a voice; it said, "Drink, pretty creature, drink!"
And, looking o'er the hedge, before me I espied
A snow-white mountain-lamb with a Maiden at its side.
explanation: The dew was coming down quickly and the stars were starting to twinkle. Suddenly, I heard a voice calling out to me saying, "Drink, pretty creature, drink!" As I looked over the hedge, I saw a pure white lamb accompanied by a young woman.

text:
Nor sheep nor kine were near; the lamb was all alone,
And by a slender cord was tethered to a stone;
With one knee on the grass did the little Maiden kneel,
While to that mountain-lamb she gave its evening meal.
explanation: The lamb was alone, with no sheep or cows nearby, and was tied to a stone with a thin rope. The little girl knelt on the grass and fed the lamb its dinner in the evening.

text:
The lamb, while from her hand he thus his supper took,
Seemed to feast with head and ears; and his tail with pleasure
"Drink, pretty creature, drink," she said in such a tone
That I almost received her heart into my own.
explanation: As the woman fed the lamb, it appeared to enjoy the meal with enthusiasm. She encouraged it to drink, and her tone of voice was so tender that it deeply touched the narrator, who felt a strong emotional connection to her.

text:
'Twas little Barbara Lewthwaite, a child of beauty rare!
I watched them with delight, they were a lovely pair.
Now with her empty can the Maiden turned away:
But ere ten yards were gone her footsteps did she stay.
explanation: Barbara Lewthwaite, a beautiful child, caught the speaker's eye and he was pleased by her presence. She turned away after disposing of her empty can, but stopped walking after only a few steps.

text:
Right towards the lamb she looked; and from a shady place
I unobserved could see the workings of her face:
If Nature to her tongue could measured numbers bring,
Thus, thought I, to her lamb that little Maid might sing:
explanation: I observed the girl as she looked towards the lamb, hidden in a shady spot where I could witness the emotions on her face. I imagined how sweet it would be if the girl could sing a song, perhaps in poetic verse, to her little lamb if only Nature had given her the gift of a melodic voice.

text:
"What ails thee, young One? what? Why pull so at thy cord?
Is it not well with thee? well both for bed and board?
Thy plot of grass is soft, and green as grass can be;
Rest, little young One, rest; what is't that aileth thee?
explanation: The speaker addresses a young one who seems to be struggling and asks why they are pulling at their cord. The speaker assures the young one that everything is well with them and that they have a soft and green plot of grass to rest on. The speaker encourages the young one to rest and wonders what could be causing them distress.

text:
"What is it thou wouldst seek? What is wanting to thy heart?
Thy limbs are they not strong? And beautiful thou art:
This grass is tender grass; these flowers they have no peers;
And that green corn all day is rustling in thy ears!
explanation: What is it that you desire? What is missing from your life? Your body seems healthy and attractive. The grass is soft and fragrant, the flowers are stunning, and the sound of rustling corn can be heard all day.

text:
"If the sun be shining hot, do but stretch thy woollen chain,
This beech is standing by, its covert thou canst gain;
For rain and mountain-storms! the like thou need'st not fear,
The rain and storm are things that scarcely can come here.
explanation: If the weather is hot and sunny, simply extend your woolen leash and seek shelter under the nearby beech tree. You don't need to worry about rain or mountain storms here, as they are unlikely to occur in this area.

text:
"Rest, little young One, rest; thou hast forgot the day
When my father found thee first in places far away;
Many flocks were on the hills, but thou wert owned by none,
And thy mother from thy side for evermore was gone.
explanation: Take a break, dear young one, you seem to have forgotten the time when my father discovered you in a distant location. At that time, many herds were grazing on the hills, but you did not belong to any of them. Your mother had disappeared, and you were all alone.

text:
"He took thee in his arms, and in pity brought thee home:
A blessed day for thee! then whither wouldst thou roam?
A faithful nurse thou hast; the dam that did thee yean
Upon the mountain-tops no kinder could have been.
explanation: He lifted you up and carried you home out of pity, which was a fortunate day for you. Where else would you have gone? You have a trustworthy caretaker, the mother sheep that gave birth to you on the mountain was just as loving."

text:
"Thou know'st that twice a day I have brought thee in this can
Fresh water from the brook, as clear as ever ran;
And twice in the day, when the ground is wet with dew,
I bring thee draughts of milk, warm milk it is and new.
explanation: I have been bringing you fresh water from the brook twice a day in this can. The water is clear and pure. Additionally, I bring you warm and new milk twice a day when the ground is wet with dew.

text:
"Thy limbs will shortly be twice as stout as they are now,
Then I'll yoke thee to my cart like a pony in the plough;
My playmate thou shalt be; and when the wind is cold
Our hearth shall be thy bed, our house shall be thy fold.
explanation: Soon, your body will be stronger and thicker, and I will use you to pull my cart like a pony tilling a field. You will be my companion, and when the weather is chilly, our home will be your sanctuary."

text:
"It will not, will not rest!--Poor creature, can it be
That 'tis thy mother's heart which is working so in thee?
Things that I know not of belike to thee are dear,
And dreams of things which thou canst neither see nor hear.
explanation: The poor creature refuses to rest, and it makes one wonder if it's the mother's heart that's causing such turmoil. Perhaps there are things that the creature holds dear, which are unknown to the speaker, or dreams of things that it cannot experience.

text:
"Alas, the mountain-tops that look so green and fair!
I've heard of fearful winds and darkness that come there;
The little brooks that seem all pastime and all play,
When they are angry, roar like lions for their prey.
explanation: The mountain-tops, though appearing lush and beautiful, hold dangers such as treacherous winds and darkness. Even the innocent-looking brooks can become ferocious, roaring like lions hunting for prey when they are angry."

text:
"Here thou need'st not dread the raven in the sky;
Night and day thou art safe,--our cottage is hard by.
Why bleat so after me? Why pull so at thy chain?
Sleep--and at break of day I will come to thee again!"
explanation: You don't have to fear the bird in the sky because our cottage is nearby, so you are always safe. Why are you crying out and tugging at your chain? Just go to sleep and I will return in the morning.

text:
--As homeward through the lane I went with lazy feet,
This song to myself did I oftentimes repeat;
And it seemed, as I retraced the ballad line by line,
That but half of it was hers, and one half of it was 'mine'.
explanation: While walking home, I lazily repeated a song to myself. As I went over the lyrics, I realized that only half of the song belonged to the person who originally sang it, while the other half felt like it was mine.

text:
Again, and once again, did I repeat the song;
"Nay," said I, "more than half to the damsel must belong,
For she looked with such a look and she spake with such a tone,
That I almost received her heart into my own."
explanation: I sang the same song over and over again, but I couldn't help it. The girl I sang it to had such a captivating look and spoke in such a beautiful tone that I felt like I was falling for her. I knew that more than half of the song must belong to her because of how she made me feel. It was almost as if she had given me her heart.

text:
There is a Yew-tree, pride of Lorton Vale,
Which to this day stands single, in the midst
Of its own darkness, as it stood of yore:
Not loathe to furnish weapons for the Bands
Of Umfraville or Percy ere they marched
To Scotland's heaths; or those that crossed the sea
And drew their sounding bows at Azincour,
Perhaps at earlier Crecy, or Poictiers.
explanation: There is a Yew-tree in Lorton Vale that remains standing alone in the midst of darkness. It has provided weapons for the Umfraville and Percy Bands and has been used by those who fought at Azincour, Crecy, and Poictiers.

text:
Of vast circumference and gloom profound
This solitary Tree! -a living thing
Produced too slowly ever to decay;
Of form and aspect too magnificent
To be destroyed. But worthier still of note
Are those fraternal Four of Borrowdale,
Joined in one solemn and capacious grove;
explanation: The Tree is a magnificent and solitary living thing that is too vast to be destroyed, producing at a slow pace that prevents decay. However, even more notable are the four fraternal trees of Borrowdale, standing together in a solemn and spacious grove.

text:
Huge trunks! -and each particular trunk a growth
Of intertwisted fibres serpentine
Up-coiling, and inveteratley convolved, -
Nor uninformed with Fantasy, and looks
That threaten the profane; -a pillared shade,
Upon whose grassless floor of red-brown hue,
By sheddings from the pining umbrage tinged
Perennially -beneath whose sable roof
Of boughs, as if for festal purpose decked
With unrejoicing berries -ghostly Shapes
May meet at noontide: Fear and trembling Hope,
Silence and Foresight, Death the Skeleton
And Time the Shadow; there to celebrate,
As in a natural temple scattered o'er
With altars undisturbed of mossy stone,
United worship; or in mute repose
To lie, and listen to the mountain flood
Murmuring from Glaramara's inmost caves.
explanation: The poem describes the massive trunks of trees, each one a complex tangle of serpentine fibers that seem almost alive with fantasy and threatening looks. The trees create a canopy of shade, their brown leaves covering the ground in a perpetual carpet. Underneath this sable roof, ghostly shapes may gather, including Fear, Hope, Silence, Foresight, Death, and Time. The trees create a natural temple, complete with mossy stone altars, where these forces can come together in worship and celebration or simply rest and listen to the sound of the nearby mountain stream.

text:
Fair Ellen Irwin, when she sate
Upon the braes of Kirtle,
Was lovely as a Grecian maid
Adorned with wreaths of myrtle;
Young Adam Bruce beside her lay,
And there did they beguile the day
With love and gentle speeches,
Beneath the budding beeches.
explanation: Ellen Irwin was a beautiful woman who was sitting on the hills of Kirtle. She looked as lovely as a Greek woman with a wreath of myrtle adorning her head. She was accompanied by Adam Bruce, who was lying beside her. The two of them spent the day talking and expressing their love for each other under the budding beeches.

text:
From many knights and many squires
The Bruce had been selected;
And Gordon, fairest of them all,
By Ellen was rejected.
Sad tidings to that noble Youth!
For it may be proclaimed with truth,
If Bruce hath loved sincerely,
That Gordon loves as dearly.
explanation: The Bruce had chosen many knights and squires, but Ellen had rejected the fairest of them all, Gordon. This was a great sadness for Gordon, as he loved Ellen deeply. However, if Bruce truly loved Ellen, it could be said that Gordon loved her just as much.

text:
But what are Gordon's form and face,
His shattered hopes and crosses,
To them, 'mid Kirtle's pleasant braes,
Reclined on flowers and mosses?
Alas that ever he was born!
The Gordon, couched behind a thorn,
Sees them and their caressing;
Beholds them blest and blessing.
explanation: The speaker questions the significance of Gordon's appearance and circumstances compared to the idyllic scene around him in Kirtle's braes. The Gordon, hidden behind a thorn, observes a couple enjoying each other's company and affection while surrounded by flowers and moss. The speaker laments Gordon's existence and the fact that he must witness the couple's happiness.

text:
Proud Gordon, maddened by the thoughts
That through his brain are travelling,
Rushed forth, and at the heart of Bruce
He launched a deadly javelin!
Fair Ellen saw it as it came,
And, starting up to meet the same,
Did with her body cover
The Youth, her chosen lover.
explanation: Gordon, filled with anger, hurled a spear at Bruce's heart while consumed by his thoughts. However, Ellen, who was watching the events unfold, quickly rose to shield her beloved from the projectile with her own body.

text:
And, falling into Bruce's arms,
Thus died the beauteous Ellen,
Thus, from the heart of her True-love,
The mortal spear repelling.
And Bruce, as soon as he had slain
The Gordon, sailed away to Spain;
And fought with rage incessant
Against the Moorish crescent.
explanation: Ellen, the beautiful woman, died in Bruce's arms while he defended her from the mortal spear. Once he had defeated the Gordon, Bruce left for Spain where he fiercely battled against the Moorish crescent.

text:
But many days, and many months,
And many years ensuing,
This wretched Knight did vainly seek
The death that he was wooing.
So, coming his last help to crave,
Heart-broken, upon Ellen's grave
His body he extended,
And there his sorrow ended.
explanation: The Knight spent several days, months, and even years attempting to achieve the death he sought, but his efforts were in vain. Eventually, he was left heartbroken and turned to Ellen's grave for his final salvation. He lay down on her grave, and his sorrow finally came to an end.

text:
Now ye, who willingly have heard
The tale I have been telling,
May in Kirkconnel churchyard view
The grave of lovely Ellen:
By Ellen's side the Bruce is laid;
And, for the stone upon his head,
May no rude hand deface it,
And its forlorn "Hie jacet"!
explanation: After listening to the story, those who are interested can visit Kirkconnel churchyard to see the grave of Ellen, who is buried next to Bruce. The speaker hopes that no one will deface the stone on Bruce's head or disturb the "Hie jacet" inscription.

The Nightingale is admired for having a passionate spirit as demonstrated by its fiery heart. Its powerful and intense singing pierces through the air with a tumultuous harmony that seems almost fierce. The bird sings with such fervor that it is as though it was blessed by the God of wine for Valentine's Day.

text:
A song in mockery and despite
Of shades, and dews, and silent night;
And steady bliss, and all the loves
Now sleeping in these peaceful groves.
explanation: This song is mocking the peaceful night, the calmness of the trees and the love that sleeps. Despite the beauty of the surroundings, the song is full of contempt and hatred.

Today, I heard a Stock-dove singing its story in a hidden place among the trees. Although its voice was muffled, the sound was carried by the wind. The bird didn't stop singing, repeatedly cooing its tune.
He courted her thoughtfully, singing of love with a gentle mix of seriousness and joy that seemed to never cease. His song spoke of commitment and deep happiness, and it was the perfect song for her.

text:
SMILE of the Moon!---for I so name
That silent greeting from above;
A gentle flash of light that came
From her whom drooping captives love;
Or art thou of still higher birth?
Thou that didst part the clouds of earth,
My torpor to reprove!
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker addresses the moon, referring to its gentle light as a "smile" and wonders if it is a message from a higher power. The light is a reminder to the speaker to shake off their lethargy and to be more active. The moon is likened to a compassionate captor who provides comfort to those who are feeling down. The speaker is moved by the moon's light and seems to feel that it has a profound effect on them.

text:
Bright boon of pitying Heaven!---alas,
I may not trust thy placid cheer!
Pondering that Time tonight will pass
The threshold of another year;
For years to me are sad and dull;
My very moments are too full
Of hopelessness and fear.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker in this poem laments the arrival of a new year, despite the idea of a "bright boon of pitying Heaven." The speaker cannot trust the idea of a peaceful or cheerful year, as they are constantly filled with sadness and fear. For years, life has been dreary and hopeless, and even the moments are too full of these negative emotions. The speaker seems to be struggling with a deep sense of despair and cannot find any solace in the idea of a new year.

text:
And yet, the soul-awakening gleam,
That struck perchance the farthest cone
Of Scotland's rocky wilds, did seem
To visit me, and me alone;
Me, unapproached by any friend,
Save those who to my sorrow lend
Tears due unto their own.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: Although I was alone and had no friends near me, I felt a spark of enlightenment that may have reached even the most distant parts of Scotland's rugged terrain. The only companions I had were those who shared in my grief and shed tears alongside me.

poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: Tonight, the bells of the church tower will ring out in celebration across the wide realms, welcoming the new year with a joyful peal. It is a tuneful offering for the welfare of millions who are happy and content in their slumber, but for me, it is a painful reminder of my wounds that refuse to heal, leaving me to watch and weep in sorrow.

text:
Born all too high, by wedlock raised
Still higherÑto be cast thus low!
Would that mine eyes had never gazed
On aught of more ambitious show
Than the sweet flowerets of the fields
---It is my royal state that yields
This bitterness of woe.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: I was born into a high position and raised even higher through marriage, but now I have fallen to a low state. I wish I had never seen anything more ambitious than the simple flowers in the fields. My royal status is the reason for my current sorrow.

text:
Yet how?---for I, if there be truth
In the world's voice, was passing fair;
And beauty, for confiding youth,
Those shocks of passion can prepare
That kill the bloom before its time;
And blanch, without the owner's crime,
The most resplendent hair.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The speaker wonders how they have lost their beauty at a young age, despite being considered attractive in their youth. The speaker notes that beauty can lead to intense emotions that can harm one's appearance prematurely. The speaker suggests that their hair has lost its shine without any fault of their own.

text:
Unblest distinction! showered on me
To bind a lingering life in chains:
All that could quit my grasp, or flee,
Is gone;---but not the subtle stains
Fixed in the spirit; for even here
Can I be proud that jealous fear
Of what I was remains.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: What a cursed fate bestowed upon me, trapping me in an endless existence. Everything I once held dear has slipped away, leaving only the indelible marks on my soul. Yet, amidst this despair, I can still find solace in the knowledge that the fear of what I once was remains.

text:
A Woman rules my prison's key;
A sister Queen, against the bent
O£ law and holiest sympathy,
Detains me, doubtful of the event;
Great God, who feel'st for my distress,
My thoughts are all that I possess,
O keep them innocent!
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The key to my prison is controlled by a woman who acts as a powerful queen, going against the laws and natural compassion. She keeps me detained, unsure of what the outcome will be. I pray to God to help me through this difficult time, as my only possession is my thoughts, which I hope to keep pure and innocent.

text:
Farewell desire of human aid,
Which abject mortals vainly court!
By friends deceived, by foes betrayed,
Of fears the prey, of hopes the sport;
Nought but the world-redeeming Cross
Is able to support my loss,
My burthen to support.
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The author bids farewell to the desire for human help, which is something that many people seek but ultimately find disappointing. They are often let down by friends and betrayed by enemies, and are left to be preyed upon by fear and teased by hope. The only thing that can truly support the author's burdensome losses is the world-redeeming Cross.

text:
Hark! the death-note of the year
Sounded by the castle-clock!
From her sunk eyes a stagnant tear
Stole forth, unsettled by the shock;
But oft the woods renewed their green,
Ere the tired head of Scotland's Queen
Reposed upon the block!
poem_title: Lament Of Mary Queen Of Scots
explanation: The year is ending and the castle clock is striking, announcing its death. The Queen of Scotland sheds a tear from her sunken eyes, disturbed by the sound. However, the woods will bloom anew before the Queen's tired head rests on the execution block.

text:
Oh! what's the matter? what's the matter?
What is't that ails young Harry Gill?
That evermore his teeth they chatter,
Chatter, chatter, chatter still!
Of waistcoats Harry has no lack,
Good duffle grey, and flannel fine;
He has a blanket on his back,
And coats enough to smother nine.
explanation: The speaker is curious about the reason why Harry Gill is constantly chattering his teeth. Despite having an abundance of clothes, including waistcoats, blankets, and coats, Harry cannot seem to shake the shivering.

text:
In March, December, and in July,
'Tis all the same with Harry Gill;
The neighbours tell, and tell you truly,
His teeth they chatter, chatter still.
At night, at morning, and at noon,
'Tis all the same with Harry Gill;
Beneath the sun, beneath the moon,
His teeth they chatter, chatter still!
explanation: Harry Gill is known for his incessant teeth chattering, which occurs in March, December, and July, as reported by his neighbors. This condition persists throughout the day and night, regardless of the weather or time of day.

Harry was a young and strong cattle driver, unmatched in his physical ability. He had a rosy complexion and a powerful voice. In contrast, Goody Blake was an elderly woman who lived in poverty. She was undernourished and barely had enough clothing to cover herself. Anyone who walked past her humble dwelling could see the dire circumstances she was living in.

text:
All day she spun in her poor dwelling:
And then her three hours' work at night,
Alas! 'twas hardly worth the telling,
It would not pay for candle-light.
Remote from sheltered village-green,
On a hill's northern side she dwelt,
Where from sea-blasts the hawthorns lean,
And hoary dews are slow to melt.
explanation: She spent her entire day spinning in her humble abode, and even though she worked for three hours at night, it was hardly worth mentioning as the money earned wouldn't be enough to cover the cost of the candle. She lived in a place far from the protected village-green, on the north side of a hill where the hawthorn trees leaned due to the strong sea-blasts, and the dew took a long time to disappear.

text:
By the same fire to boil their pottage,
Two poor old Dames, as I have known,
Will often live in one small cottage;
But she, poor Woman! housed alone.
'Twas well enough when summer came,
The long, warm, lightsome summer-day,
Then at her door the 'canty' Dame
Would sit, as any linnet, gay.
explanation: Two elderly women often share a small cottage and cook together over the same fire, but one of them lives alone. During the warm summer days, the cheerful woman would sit outside her door like a happy bird.

text:
But when the ice our streams did fetter,
Oh then how her old bones would shake!
You would have said, if you had met her,
'Twas a hard time for Goody Blake.
Her evenings then were dull and dead:
Sad case it was, as you may think,
For very cold to go to bed;
And then for cold not sleep a wink.
explanation: When the streams froze over with ice, Goody Blake's old bones would shake uncontrollably. Her evenings became dull and lifeless, as it was too cold to go to bed and she was unable to sleep due to the freezing temperatures. It was a sad and difficult time for Goody Blake.

text:
O joy for her! whene'er in winter
The winds at night had made a rout;
And scattered many a lusty splinter
And many a rotten bough about.
Yet never had she, well or sick,
As every man who knew her says,
A pile beforehand, turf or stick,
Enough to warm her for three days.
explanation: Despite the harsh winter winds that often scattered branches and debris throughout the night, the woman found joy in the chaos. However, those who knew her noted that she never had enough firewood or fuel to keep her warm for more than three days.

text:
Now, when the frost was past enduring,
And made her poor old bones to ache,
Could any thing be more alluring
Than an old hedge to Goody Blake?
And, now and then, it must be said,
When her old bones were cold and chill,
She left her fire, or left her bed,
To seek the hedge of Harry Gill.
explanation: As the frost became unbearable and caused Goody Blake's old bones to ache, she found comfort in the allure of an old hedge. Despite the occasional need to leave her warm bed or fireplace, she would seek solace in the hedge of Harry Gill.

text:
Now Harry he had long suspected
This trespass of old Goody Blake;
And vowed that she should be detected--
That he on her would vengeance take.
And oft from his warm fire he'd go,
And to the fields his road would take;
And there, at night, in frost and snow,
He watched to seize old Goody Blake.
explanation: Harry had a strong suspicion that Goody Blake had trespassed and was determined to catch her and seek revenge. He frequently left his warm fire to go to the fields, where he would wait in the cold and snow to catch her at night.

text:
And once, behind a rick of barley,
Thus looking out did Harry stand:
The moon was full and shining clearly,
And crisp with frost the stubble land.
--He hears a noise--he's all awake--
Again?--on tip-toe down the hill
He softly creeps--'tis Goody Blake;
She's at the hedge of Harry Gill!
explanation: Harry was standing behind a stack of barley when he noticed the full moon shining brightly and the land covered in frost. Suddenly, he heard a noise and became alert. He tiptoed down the hill and saw Goody Blake at the hedge of Harry Gill.

text:
Right glad was he when he beheld her:
Stick after stick did Goody pull:
He stood behind a bush of elder,
Till she had filled her apron full.
When with her load she turned about,
The by-way back again to take;
He started forward, with a shout,
And sprang upon poor Goody Blake.
explanation: He was very happy when he saw her. Goody kept pulling stick after stick and he watched from behind an elder bush until she had filled her apron. When she turned to head back, he shouted and jumped on her.

text:
And fiercely by the arm he took her,
And by the arm he held her fast,
And fiercely by the arm he shook her,
And cried, "I've caught you then at last!"--
Then Goody, who had nothing said,
Her bundle from her lap let fall;
And, kneeling on the sticks, she prayed
To God that is the judge of all.
explanation: He grabbed her arm tightly and shook her, exclaiming that he had finally caught her. Goody, who had been silent up until this point, dropped her bundle and fell to her knees on the sticks. She prayed to God, the ultimate judge.

text:
She prayed, her withered hand uprearing,
While Harry held her by the arm--
"God! who art never out of hearing,
O may he never more be warm!" 0
The cold, cold moon above her head,
Thus on her knees did Goody pray;
Young Harry heard what she had said:
And icy cold he turned away.
explanation: An elderly woman raised her withered hand in prayer while Harry supported her. She prayed to God, asking that someone she was referring to never feel warmth again. As she knelt, the chilly moon shone above her. Harry overheard her words and felt a coldness within him, causing him to turn away.

text:
He went complaining all the morrow
That he was cold and very chill:
His face was gloom, his heart was sorrow,
Alas! that day for Harry Gill!
That day he wore a riding-coat,
But not a whit the warmer he:
Another was on Thursday brought,
And ere the Sabbath he had three.
explanation: Harry Gill spent the whole next day complaining about how cold and chilly he was. He was very unhappy, and his face showed it. He wore a riding-coat that day, but it didn't seem to make him any warmer. He got another one on Thursday, but still he was cold. By the time the Sabbath came around, he had three riding-coats, but he was still complaining about the cold.

Despite being covered in blankets, Harry's teeth continued to chatter uncontrollably, reminiscent of a window shaking in the wind. His body was wasting away, and those who saw him knew that he would never be warm again, even if he lived for a long time. It was a futile effort to try and warm him up.

text:
No word to any man he utters,
A-bed or up, to young or old;
But ever to himself he mutters,
"Poor Harry Gill is very cold."
A-bed or up, by night or day;
His teeth they chatter, chatter still.
Now think, ye farmers all, I pray,
Of Goody Blake and Harry Gill!
explanation: The speaker of the poem keeps to himself the knowledge that Harry Gill is always cold, whether he is in bed or up, regardless of his age. The only thing he does is mutter to himself that Harry Gill is cold. Harry Gill's teeth still chatter even if he is in bed or out during the night or day. The speaker urges farmers to remember the story of Goody Blake and Harry Gill.

text:
At the corner of Wood Street, when daylight appears,
Hangs a Thrush that sings loud, it has sung for three years:
Poor Susan has passed by the spot, and has heard
In the silence of morning the song of the Bird.
explanation: On the corner of Wood Street, there is a Thrush that sings loudly at daylight for the past three years. Poor Susan has passed by and has heard the Bird's song in the quiet of the morning.

text:
Tis a note of enchantment; what ails her? She sees
A mountain ascending, a vision of trees;
Bright volumes of vapour through Lothbury glide,
And a river flows on through the vale of Cheapside.
explanation: There is a sense of magic in the air, but what is causing it? The woman sees a mountain rising up and a forest of trees. She notices clouds of mist floating through Lothbury, while a river flows through the valley of Cheapside.

text:
Green pastures she views in the midst of the dale,
Down which she so often has tripped with her pail;
And a single small cottage, a nest like a dove's,
The one only dwelling on earth that she loves.
explanation: She sees lush meadows in the valley where she has walked many times before with her bucket. There is only one small house, resembling a bird's nest, that she truly cherishes and is the only home she has ever loved.

text:
She looks, and her heart is in heaven: but they fade,
The mist and the river, the hill and the shade:
The stream will not flow, and the hill will not rise,
And the colours have all passed away from her eyes!
explanation: The sight before her fills her with joy, but it quickly disappears. The mist, river, hill, and shade all fade away. The stream stops flowing and the hill no longer rises. The colors that once brought her happiness have vanished from her sight.

text:
That is work of waste and ruin--
Do as Charles and I are doing!
Strawberry-blossoms, one and all,
We must spare them--here are many:
Look at it--the flower is small,
Small and low, though fair as any:
Do not touch it! summers two
I am older, Anne, than you.
explanation: Charles and I are sparing the strawberry blossoms, which are small but beautiful. Anne is being told not to touch them, as they are important and must be preserved. The speaker, who is older than Anne, believes that destroying the blossoms would be a waste and lead to ruin.

Sister Anne is asked to pull as many primroses as she can, while also being offered daisies, pansies, cuckoo-flowers, and daffodils to make a bed or bower with. She is encouraged to fill her lap and bosom with the flowers, but to spare the strawberry blossom.

text:
Primroses, the Spring may love them--
Summer knows but little of them:
Violets, a barren kind,
Withered on the ground must lie;
Daisies leave no fruit behind
When the pretty flowerets die;
Pluck them, and another year
As many will be blowing here.
explanation: Spring adores primroses, but they are not well-known in the summer. Violets are a fruitless plant that wither on the ground when they die, and daisies do not produce any fruit once their flowers fall off. However, if you pluck them, the next year will bring just as many blooming flowers.

text:
God has given a kindlier power
To the favoured strawberry-flower.
Hither soon as spring is fled
You and Charles and I will walk;
Lurking berries, ripe and red,
Then will hang on every stalk,
Each within its leafy bower;
And for that promise spare the flower!
explanation: The strawberry flower has been blessed by God with a gentle power. When spring has ended, the speaker and two others will go for a walk to find the ripe, red berries hidden among the leaves. The speaker urges them to spare the flower and enjoy the promise of the sweet fruit.

text:
FROM low to high doth dissolution climb,
And sink from high to low, along a scale
Of awful notes, whose concord shall not fail;
A musical but melancholy chime,
Which they can hear who meddle not with crime,
Nor avarice, nor over-anxious care.
