explanation: Peter decided to carry the drowned man on his back, even though it was a difficult task. He thought to himself that he would do it anyway, because it was what the man would want him to do. Peter felt sorry for the drowned man and wanted to help him in any way he could.

text:
With that resolve he boldly mounts
Upon the pleased and thankful Ass;
And then, without a moment's stay,
That earnest Creature turned away
Leaving the body on the grass. 0
explanation: With determination, he fearlessly hops onto the satisfied and grateful donkey, and without hesitation, the eager animal departs, abandoning the corpse on the ground.

text:
Intent upon his faithful watch,
The Beast four days and nights had past;
A sweeter meadow ne'er was seen,
And there the Ass four days had been,
Nor ever once did break his fast:
explanation: The Beast had been keeping a close watch for four days and nights, while the Ass had been in a beautiful meadow for the same duration without eating anything.

text:
Yet firm his step, and stout his heart;
The mead is crossed--the quarry's mouth
Is reached; but there the trusty guide
Into a thicket turns aside,
And deftly ambles towards the south.
explanation: The person walks with confidence and bravery, successfully crossing the meadow and arriving at the entrance of the quarry. However, their guide leads them into a thicket, skillfully heading towards the south.

text:
When hark a burst of doleful sound!
And Peter honestly might say,
The like came never to his ears,
Though he has been, full thirty years,
A rover--night and day!
explanation: Peter heard a sorrowful noise that he had never heard before in his thirty years of traveling.

text:
'Tis not a plover of the moors,
'Tis not a bittern of the fen;
Nor can it be a barking fox,
Nor night-bird chambered in the rocks,
Nor wild-cat in a woody glen!
explanation: It is not a bird found on the moors or in the fen, nor is it a fox that barks or a night-bird that lives in rocks, nor is it a wild-cat that resides in a wooded glen.

text:
The Ass is startled--and stops short
Right in the middle of the thicket;
And Peter, wont to whistle loud
Whether alone or in a crowd,
Is silent as a silent cricket.
explanation: The donkey suddenly becomes alarmed and halts in the midst of the bushes. Peter, who typically whistles loudly, whether he is alone or in a group, is now quiet as a cricket.

text:
What ails you now, my little Bess?
Well may you tremble and look grave!
This cry--that rings along the wood,
This cry--that floats adown the flood,
Comes from the entrance of a cave:
explanation: The speaker addresses someone named Bess, asking what is troubling her. He notes her trembling and serious expression. He hears a cry that echoes through the woods and along the river, originating from a nearby cave.

text:
I see a blooming Wood-boy there,
And if I had the power to say
How sorrowful the wanderer is,
Your heart would be as sad as his
Till you had kissed his tears away!
explanation: I observe a young boy emerging from the forest, full of life and vitality. However, if I could convey the depth of his sadness to you, your heart would be equally heavy. It is only through your comfort and compassion that his tears can be erased.

The person holds onto a branch of hawthorn that is filled with ripe and red berries. They then peer into a cave before returning back to the moonlight. It is unclear who this person is looking for, but it seems that they are searching for the silent dead.

text:
His father!--Him doth he require--
Him hath he sought with fruitless pains,
Among the rocks, behind the trees;
Now creeping on his hands and knees,
Now running o'er the open plains.
explanation: He is looking for his father and has been searching for him in vain. He has combed through the rocks, trees, and plains, crawling on his hands and knees or running, but has not found him.

text:
And hither is he come at last,
When he through such a day has gone,
By this dark cave to be distrest
Like a poor bird--her plundered nest
Hovering around with dolorous moan!
explanation: Finally, he has arrived at this dark cave after enduring a difficult day. He is distressed, like a bird whose nest has been plundered, and he circles around the cave with a sad moan.

text:
Of that intense and piercing cry
The listening Ass conjectures well;
Wild as it is, he there can read
Some intermingled notes that plead
With touches irresistible.
explanation: The Ass is able to interpret the intense and piercing cry he hears. Despite its wildness, he can discern some pleading notes that are impossible to ignore.

text:
But Peter--when he saw the Ass
Not only stop but turn, and change
The cherished tenor of his pace
That lamentable cry to chase--
It wrought in him conviction strange;
explanation: Peter was taken aback when he witnessed the sight of the Ass ceasing its movement, turning around and altering the tone of its mournful cry, which led to a sudden urge in Peter to follow it, instilling in him an unfamiliar sense of certainty.

text:
A faith that, for the dead man's sake
And this poor slave who loved him well,
Vengeance upon his head will fall,
Some visitation worse than all
Which ever till this night befell.
explanation: The speaker expresses their belief that the dead man's faith will cause harm to the person responsible for his death and the slave who loved him. They anticipate that a punishment worse than anything experienced before will befall the perpetrator.
As the Ass tries his best to reach his home, he struggles to climb the hilly terrain and his voice gradually fades, growing weaker until it eventually dies away completely.

text:
So with his freight the Creature turns
Into a gloomy grove of beech,
Along the shade with footsteps true
Descending slowly, till the two
The open moonlight reach.
explanation: The Creature walks into a dark grove of beech trees with his belongings. He walks carefully in the shade until he reaches an area illuminated by moonlight.

text:
And there, along the narrow dell,
A fair smooth pathway you discern,
A length of green and open road--
As if it from a fountain flowed--
Winding away between the fern.
explanation: You can see a beautiful and straight path in the narrow valley, surrounded by greenery and ferns. It seems to have come from a fountain and stretches out for a considerable distance.

text:
The rocks that tower on either side
Build up a wild fantastic scene;
Temples like those among the Hindoos,
And mosques, and spires, and abbey windows,
And castles all with ivy green!
explanation: The scenery is characterized by towering rocks on both sides, which form a wild and fantastic landscape. The view includes temples resembling those found in Hindu culture, as well as mosques, spires, and abbey windows. Additionally, there are castles covered in ivy, all contributing to the picturesque setting.

text:
And, while the Ass pursues his way,
Along this solitary dell,
As pensively his steps advance,
The mosques and spires change countenance
And look at Peter Bell!
explanation: As the donkey makes its way through the quiet valley, Peter Bell reflects on his surroundings. The mosques and spires in the distance seem to take on a new appearance and gaze back at him.

text:
That unintelligible cry
Hath left him high in preparation,--
Convinced that he, or soon or late,
This very night will meet his fate--
And so he sits in expectation!
explanation: The incomprehensible scream has put him on edge and made him feel ready for what may come. He is convinced that tonight he will either face his destiny or meet his demise. Therefore, he sits and waits in anticipation.

text:
The strenuous Animal hath clomb
With the green path; and now he wends
Where, shining like the smoothest sea,
In undisturbed immensity
A level plain extends. 0
explanation: The tired animal has climbed up the green path and is now walking on a level plain that stretches out as far as the eye can see, appearing like a smooth and undisturbed sea.

text:
But whence this faintly-rustling sound
By which the journeying pair are chased?
--A withered leaf is close behind,
Light plaything for the sportive wind
Upon that solitary waste.
explanation: The travelers hear a soft rustling sound as they journey forward, and they wonder what could be causing it. They soon realize that it is a withered leaf, being tossed about by the playful wind. The leaf follows them as they make their way across a desolate landscape, a reminder of the transience of life and the fleeting nature of existence.

text:
When Peter spied the moving thing,
It only doubled his distress;
"Where there is not a bush or tree,
The very leaves they follow me--
So huge hath been my wickedness!"
explanation: Peter felt even more distressed when he saw something moving. He believed that the leaves and the environment were following him wherever he went. This made him believe that his sins were so great that they had caused the world to turn against him.

text:
To a close lane they now are come,
Where, as before, the enduring Ass
Moves on without a moment's stop,
Nor once turns round his head to crop
A bramble-leaf or blade of grass.
explanation: They have arrived at a narrow lane where the patient donkey continues to walk steadily without any pause or deviation to eat a leaf or blade of grass, just as it did before.

text:
Between the hedges as they go,
The white dust sleeps upon the lane;
And Peter, ever and anon
Back-looking, sees, upon a stone,
Or in the dust, a crimson stain.
explanation: Peter walks down a lane covered in white dust and occasionally looks back to see a red stain on a stone or in the dust.

text:
A stain--as of a drop of blood
By moonlight made more faint and wan;
Ha! why these sinkings of despair?
He knows not how the blood comes there--
And Peter is a wicked man.
explanation: In the moonlight, a stain that looks like a drop of blood appears faint and pale. The speaker wonders why he feels so hopeless and sad. He doesn't know how the bloodstain got there, but he knows that Peter, who is a sinful person, might be involved.
He finally notices a bleeding wound on the head of the Ass that he had struck. He recognizes the blood and experiences a brief moment of happiness, but it quickly disappears.

text:
Of him whom sudden death had seized
He thought,--of thee, O faithful Ass!
And once again those ghastly pains,
Shoot to and fro through heart and reins,
And through his brain like lightning pass.
explanation: The sudden death of someone brought to mind thoughts of a loyal donkey. The pain of the loss caused physical and emotional agony, as if lightning was striking through his body and mind.

text:
I'VE heard of one, a gentle Soul,
Though given to sadness and to gloom,
And for the fact will vouch,--one night
It chanced that by a taper's light
This man was reading in his room;
explanation: There is a person known to be a kind-hearted individual, although they tend to feel melancholy and unhappy. This is confirmed by an incident where the person was reading in their room by candlelight one night.

text:
Bending, as you or I might bend
At night o'er any pious book,
When sudden blackness overspread
The snow-white page on which he read,
And made the good man round him look.
explanation: The poem describes a scene where a man is reading a religious book at night and suddenly the page goes black, causing the man to look around in confusion. The imagery of the white page turning black could symbolize a loss of clarity or understanding, or perhaps a moment of uncertainty or doubt. The use of the phrase "pious book" suggests that the man is deeply religious and may be seeking comfort or guidance from the text. The poem is written in a simple, straightforward style with a clear narrative structure.

text:
The chamber walls were dark all round,--
And to his book he turned again;
--The light had left the lonely taper,
And formed itself upon the paper
Into large letters--bright and plain!
explanation: The walls of the chamber were dark, and the person in the room turned back to his book. The light from the lone candle had left it and instead fell upon the paper in the form of large, bright letters.

text:
The godly book was in his hand--
And, on the page, more black than coal,
Appeared, set forth in strange array,
A 'word'--which to his dying day
Perplexed the good man's gentle soul.
explanation: The man was holding a religious book where he saw a word written in black that was darker than coal. The word was presented in an unusual manner, which puzzled the man and haunted him until his death.

text:
The ghostly word, thus plainly seen,
Did never from his lips depart;
But he hath said, poor gentle wight!
It brought full many a sin to light
Out of the bottom of his heart.
explanation: The word that haunted him was always present on his lips, revealing the many sins he kept hidden in his heart. Despite being a gentle soul, it seemed to bring forth the truth of his wrongdoings.

text:
Dread Spirits! to confound the meek
Why wander from your course so far,
Disordering colour, form, and stature!
--Let good men feel the soul of nature,
And see things as they are.
explanation: The speaker is addressing the "Dread Spirits," questioning why they are causing chaos and confusion. They are distorting the natural world by changing its color, shape, and size. The speaker urges that instead, people should strive to understand the essence of nature and observe things as they truly are.

text:
Yet, potent Spirits! well I know,
How ye, that play with soul and sense,
Are not unused to trouble friends
Of goodness, for most gracious ends--
And this I speak in reverence!
explanation: I understand that powerful spirits have the ability to manipulate both the mind and body and that they are not hesitant to cause trouble for those who hold true to their beliefs. However, I also acknowledge that these spirits have the potential to work towards benevolent purposes, and I speak of them with deep respect.

text:
But might I give advice to you,
Whom in my fear I love so well;
From men of pensive virtue go,
Dread Beings! and your empire show
On hearts like that of Peter Bell.
explanation: I have some advice for you, who I love so dearly because I am afraid. Stay away from men who are constantly sad and introspective because they are fearful of you and your power. Instead, show your influence on someone like Peter Bell, whose heart may be more open to your rule.

text:
Your presence often have I felt
In darkness and the stormy night;
And, with like force, if need there be,
Ye can put forth your agency
When earth is calm, and heaven is bright.
explanation: I have sensed your presence in both the darkness and the stormy night, and you can exert your power with equal strength in times of calmness and brightness.

text:
Then, coming from the wayward world,
That powerful world in which ye dwell,
Come, Spirits of the Mind! and try
To-night, beneath the moonlight sky,
What may be done with Peter Bell!
explanation: The speaker invites the Spirits of the Mind to come from the powerful and wayward world in which they dwell and attempt to do something with Peter Bell under the moonlit sky.

text:
--O, would that some more skilful voice
My further labour might prevent!
Kind Listeners, that around me sit,
I feel that I am all unfit
For such high argument.
explanation: I wish someone more skilled than I could take over my work so that I wouldn't have to continue. To those who are listening to me, I know that I am not capable enough to discuss such important topics.

I have enjoyed playing and dancing while narrating my story. I took my time before beginning and you all patiently waited for me. Please continue to show me kindness and generosity as I continue my story.

text:
Our Travellers, ye remember well,
Are thridding a sequestered lane;
And Peter many tricks is trying,
And many anodynes applying,
To ease his conscience of its pain. 0
explanation: The travelers are walking down a secluded path and Peter is attempting various methods to alleviate the guilt he feels.

text:
By this his heart is lighter far;
And, finding that he can account
So snugly for that crimson stain,
His evil spirit up again
Does like an empty bucket mount.
explanation: When he realizes he can easily explain the reason for the red stain, his heart becomes lighter. As a result, his negative spirit seems to disappear like an empty bucket being lifted.

text:
And Peter is a deep logician
Who hath no lack of wit mercurial;
"Blood drops--leaves rustle--yet," quoth he,
"This poor man never, but for me,
Could have had Christian burial.
explanation: Peter is a skilled logician with a sharp sense of humor. He remarks that although there are blood drops and rustling leaves, this man would never have received a Christian burial if it weren't for him.

It is clear that something sinister has occurred and the speaker admits that they may have been influenced by the devil to commit such an act. They express disbelief that they could have possibly thought that stealing an ass was worth it.

text:
So from his pocket Peter takes
His shining horn tobacco-box;
And, in a light and careless way,
As men who with their purpose play,
Upon the lid he knocks.
explanation: Peter retrieves his gleaming horn tobacco-box from his pocket and raps his fingers lightly on the lid, seemingly without much thought or intention, as if he were simply idly passing the time.

text:
Let them whose voice can stop the clouds,
Whose cunning eye can see the wind,
Tell to a curious world the cause
Why, making here a sudden pause,
The Ass turned round his head, and 'grinned'.
explanation: Those who possess the power to control nature, and those who have a keen sense of observation, should explain to the inquisitive world why the donkey suddenly halted and turned its head to display a wide grin.

text:
Appalling process! I have marked
The like on heath, in lonely wood;
And, verily, have seldom met
A spectacle more hideous--yet
It suited Peter's present mood.
explanation: The process was dreadful! I have witnessed similar occurrences on the heath and in remote woods, but this was particularly repulsive. However, it was fitting for Peter's current state of mind.

text:
And, grinning in his turn, his teeth
He in jocose defiance showed--
When, to upset his spiteful mirth,
A murmur, pent within the earth,
In the dead earth beneath the road
explanation: , interrupted his laughter. He showed his teeth with a wide grin, but his joy was short-lived when a murmuring sound from beneath the road disrupted his mischievous amusement.

text:
Rolled audibly! it swept along,
A muffled noise--a rumbling sound!--
'Twas by a troop of miners made,
Plying with gunpowder their trade,
Some twenty fathoms under ground.
explanation: The sound of a rumbling and muffled noise, which could be heard audibly, was created by a group of miners who were using gunpowder to carry out their work. The miners were situated about twenty fathoms underground.

text:
Small cause of dire effect! for, surely,
If ever mortal, King or Cotter,
Believed that earth was charged to quake
And yawn for his unworthy sake,
'Twas Peter Bell the Potter.
explanation: The poem describes how Peter Bell, a potter, believed that the earth would tremble and split open just for him. This is a small cause with a dire effect since the belief is unwarranted and self-centered. The speaker suggests that Peter Bell is not the only person to hold such an egocentric view, but he is the perfect example of it. The poem warns against arrogance and self-importance, highlighting the potential consequences of such attitudes.

In this passage, the speaker compares a person to an oak tree that remains standing even after being cut down to its center and to the weakest things that remain in place despite being frozen. The speaker marvels at the person's ability to endure and stand firm even under scrutiny, represented by the moon's gaze. The comparison to the oak tree and the frozen things suggests that the person's resilience is innate and unyielding.

text:
The Beast bestriding thus, he reached
A spot where, in a sheltering cove,
A little chapel stands alone,
With greenest ivy overgrown,
And tufted with an ivy grove;
explanation: The Beast strode onward until he arrived at a cove where a small chapel stood, surrounded by lush ivy and a grove of the same.

text:
Dying insensibly away
From human thoughts and purposes,
It seemed--wall, window, roof and tower--
To bow to some transforming power,
And blend with the surrounding trees.
explanation: The scene before the speaker appeared to be dying and losing its connection to human thoughts and intentions. The walls, windows, roofs, and towers appeared to be bowing to an unknown force and merging with the trees in the surrounding area.

text:
As ruinous a place it was,
Thought Peter, in the shire of Fife
That served my turn, when following still
From land to land a reckless will
I married my sixth wife!
explanation: Peter thought that the place in the shire of Fife where he married his sixth wife was disastrous. He had been wandering from one place to another with a careless attitude and ended up getting married again.

text:
The unheeding Ass moves slowly on,
And now is passing by an inn
Brim-full of a carousing crew,
That make, with curses not a few,
An uproar and a drunken din.
explanation: The donkey continues to move forward, paying no attention to its surroundings. It approaches an inn where a loud and rowdy group of people are drinking and causing a disturbance with their cursing and drunken behavior.

text:
I cannot well express the thoughts
Which Peter in those noises found;--
A stifling power compressed his frame,
While-as a swimming darkness came
Over that dull and dreary sound.
explanation: Peter was unable to articulate his feelings upon hearing certain noises that seemed to weigh heavily on him. He felt like a suffocating force was pressing down on him, and he was enveloped in a murky, disheartening sound that made him feel like he was swimming in darkness.

text:
For well did Peter know the sound;
The language of those drunken joys
To him, a jovial soul, I ween,
But a few hours ago, had been
A gladsome and a welcome noise.
explanation: Peter was familiar with the noise that he heard, as it was the language of people who were drunk and happy. He himself was a cheerful person and had enjoyed the noise just a few hours before.

text:
'Now', turned adrift into the past,
He finds no solace in his course;
Like planet-stricken men of yore,
He trembles, smitten to the core
By strong compunction and remorse.
explanation: The subject of the poem is experiencing feelings of regret and guilt, as he is unable to find comfort in his current path in life. He compares himself to individuals in history who were struck with despair, and is overwhelmed by his emotions. The use of vivid language, such as "planet-stricken" and "smitten to the core", adds to the intensity of the emotions being conveyed. Overall, the poem highlights the weight of remorse and the difficulty of moving forward when plagued by feelings of regret.

text:
But, more than all, his heart is stung
To think of one, almost a child;
A sweet and playful Highland girl,
As light and beauteous as a squirrel,
As beauteous and as wild!
explanation: His heart is pained when he thinks about the young Highland girl, who is almost like a child. She is playful and light, as beautiful and wild as a squirrel.

text:
Her dwelling was a lonely house,
A cottage in a heathy dell;
And she put on her gown of green,
And left her mother at sixteen,
And followed Peter Bell.
explanation: At the age of sixteen, she left her mother and went to live in a cottage located in a quiet valley. The house was isolated, leaving her feeling lonely. Despite this, she put on her green dress and decided to follow Peter Bell.

text:
But many good and pious thoughts
Had she; and, in the kirk to pray,
Two long Scotch miles, through rain or snow
To kirk she had been used to go,
Twice every Sabbath-day. 0
explanation: She had numerous noble and virtuous ideas and regularly attended church, even if it meant traveling through harsh weather conditions for two lengthy Scottish miles, twice every Sunday.

text:
And, when she followed Peter Bell,
It was to lead an honest life;
For he, with tongue not used to falter,
Had pledged his troth before the altar
To love her as his wedded wife.
explanation: She decided to follow Peter Bell because she wanted to live an honest life. Peter had promised to love her as his wife and she believed he wouldn't break his word.

The hope of a mother is uniquely hers, but in this instance, she became despondent and weak, akin to someone who had lost all hope. She looked to the Bible for inspiration and chose to name her unborn child Benoni, which translates to "child of sorrow."

text:
For she had learned how Peter lived,
And took it in most grievous part;
She to the very bone was worn,
And, ere that little child was born,
Died of a broken heart.
explanation: She had come to know about Peter's way of life, and it had deeply hurt her. She was completely worn out, and even before the birth of their child, she passed away due to a broken heart.

text:
And now the Spirits of the Mind
Are busy with poor Peter Bell;
Upon the rights of visual sense
Usurping, with a prevalence
More terrible than magic spell.
explanation: The Spirits of the Mind are currently preoccupied with Peter Bell, causing a disturbance in his visual perception. This disturbance is more powerful than any magic spell, as it takes over his ability to see properly.

text:
Close by a brake of flowering furze
(Above it shivering aspens play)
He sees an unsubstantial creature,
His very self in form and feature,
Not four yards from the broad highway:
explanation: Near a cluster of blooming gorse bushes, where the quivering aspen trees sway, a man notices a ghostly figure that resembles himself in appearance and form, standing only a few yards away from the busy road.

text:
And stretched beneath the furze he sees
The Highland girl--it is no other;
And hears her crying as she cried,
The very moment that she died,
"My mother! oh my mother!"
explanation: He sees the Highland girl lying under the furze and hears her utter the same words she did moments before her death, "My mother! oh my mother!"

text:
The sweat pours down from Peter's face,
So grievous is his heart's contrition;
With agony his eye-balls ache
While he beholds by the furze-brake
This miserable vision!
explanation: Peter's face is drenched in sweat as he feels deep remorse in his heart. He is in such agony that his eyes hurt as he gazes upon a pitiful sight near the bushes.

text:
Calm is the well-deserving brute,
'His' peace hath no offence betrayed;
But now, while down that slope he wends,
A voice to Peter's ear ascends,
Resounding from the woody glade:
explanation: The calm brute deserves its peace and has not caused any harm, but as it walks down a slope, Peter hears a voice coming from the nearby wooded area.

text:
The voice, though clamorous as a horn
Re-echoed by a naked rock,
Comes from that tabernacle--List!
Within, a fervent Methodist
Is preaching to no heedless flock!
explanation: A loud voice, reminiscent of a horn, echoes off a nearby rock. The source of the noise is a Methodist preacher who is delivering a passionate sermon to a congregation who is attentively listening.

text:
"Repent! repent!" he cries aloud,
"While yet ye may find mercy;--strive
To love the Lord with all your might;
Turn to him, seek him day and night,
And save your souls alive!
explanation: He urges people to repent and seek mercy from the Lord before it's too late. He advises them to love the Lord with all their strength, to constantly seek him, and save their souls.

text:
"Repent! repent! though ye have gone,
Through paths of wickedness and woe,
After the Babylonian harlot;
And, though your sins be red as scarlet,
They shall be white as snow!"
explanation: Turn away from your sinful ways, even if you have strayed far down the path of wickedness and suffering, following the Babylonian harlot. No matter how deep the stain of your sins, they will be cleansed and made as pure as snow if you repent.

text:
Even as he passed the door, these words
Did plainly come to Peter's ears;
And they such joyful tidings were,
The joy was more than he could bear!--
He melted into tears.
explanation: Peter heard joyful words as he passed by the door and they brought him so much happiness that he began to cry.

text:
Sweet tears of hope and tenderness!
And fast they fell, a plenteous shower!
His nerves, his sinews seemed to melt;
Through all his iron frame was felt
A gentle, a relaxing, power!
explanation: Tears streamed down his face in abundance, filled with optimism and affection. As they fell, he appeared to lose all tension and strength in his body, as if his muscles and tendons had liquified. The effect of this outpouring was a calming and gentle sensation, which spread throughout his entire being. It felt like a release, a letting go of all the troubles and stresses he had been holding on to.

He was frail in every aspect of his being, with a fragility that permeated throughout his entire body. Despite this, he possessed a gentle nature that was akin to that of a newborn baby, untainted by the sins and hardships of the world. His weakness did not breed bitterness or anger within him, but rather a docile and kind disposition.

text:
'Tis said, meek Beast! that, through Heaven's grace,
He not unmoved did notice now
The cross upon thy shoulder scored,
For lasting impress, by the Lord
To whom all human-kind shall bow;
explanation: It is said that the gentle creature, you, did not go unnoticed by the divine power above, for the burden of the cross marked upon your shoulder is a lasting symbol of the Lord to whom every human shall submit.

text:
Memorial of his touch--that day
When Jesus humbly deigned to ride,
Entering the proud Jerusalem,
By an immeasurable stream
Of shouting people deified!
explanation: This poem describes the day when Jesus rode into Jerusalem and was celebrated by the people who shouted and praised him. The author refers to this event as a "memorial of his touch" and emphasizes Jesus' humility despite the adoration of the crowd. The language of the poem suggests a sense of awe and wonder at the scene, with the use of words like "immeasurable stream" to describe the crowd's enthusiasm. Ultimately, the poem highlights the significance of this moment in Jesus' life and in the history of Christianity.

text:
Meanwhile the persevering Ass,
Turned towards a gate that hung in view
Across a shady lane; his chest
Against the yielding gate he pressed
And quietly passed through.
explanation: The determined donkey noticed a gate in the distance and headed towards it. As he approached, he pressed his chest against it and managed to slip through without making a sound.
He walks up the stony lane so quietly, almost like a ghost. He steps softly among the stones and pebbles, making no sound as if his hoofs were covered in felt.

text:
Along the lane the trusty Ass
Went twice two hundred yards or more,
And no one could have guessed his aim,--
Till to a lonely house he came,
And stopped beside the door.
explanation: The dependable donkey traveled down the lane for a distance of at least four hundred yards without any indication of his intentions. However, he eventually arrived at a solitary house and halted right next to its entrance, surprising the onlookers.

text:
Thought Peter, 'tis the poor man's home!
He listens--not a sound is heard
Save from the trickling household rill;
But, stepping o'er the cottage-sill,
Forthwith a little Girl appeared. 00
explanation: Peter observed that the cottage belonged to a poor man and was silent except for the sound of a small household stream. As he took a step over the threshold, a young girl suddenly appeared.

text:
She to the Meeting-house was bound
In hopes some tidings there to gather:
No glimpse it is, no doubtful gleam;
She saw--and uttered with a scream,
"My father! here's my father!"
explanation: She was heading towards the Meeting-house with the aim of gathering some news. Suddenly, she saw something that made her let out a scream. It was her father whom she had spotted, and she was overwhelmed with emotion.

text:
The very word was plainly heard,
Heard plainly by the wretched Mother--
Her joy was like a deep affright:
And forth she rushed into the light,
And saw it was another! 10
explanation: The mother heard a word that caused her great distress and confusion. Her initial joy was quickly replaced with fear as she rushed towards the source of the sound, only to realize that it was not what she had hoped for.

text:
And, instantly, upon the earth,
Beneath the full moon shining bright,
Close to the Ass's feet she fell;
At the same moment Peter Bell
Dismounts in most unhappy plight.
explanation: Under the bright full moon, the woman fell to the ground near the donkey's feet as soon as she arrived. At the same moment, Peter Bell dismounts from his ride in an unfortunate manner.

text:
As he beheld the Woman lie
Breathless and motionless, the mind
Of Peter sadly was confused;
But, though to such demands unused,
And helpless almost as the blind,
explanation: Peter was devastated as he witnessed the lifeless and still body of the Woman. He was overwhelmed with sadness and confusion, feeling helpless and lost like a blind person. Despite his inexperience in dealing with such situations, he had to gather his wits and figure out what to do next.

text:
He raised her up; and, while he held
Her body propped against his knee,
The Woman waked--and when she spied
The poor Ass standing by her side,
She moaned most bitterly.
explanation: He lifted her up and supported her body with his knee. The woman woke up and saw the donkey standing next to her, which caused her to cry out in distress.

text:
"Oh! God be praised--my heart's at ease--
For he is dead--I know it well!"
--At this she wept a bitter flood;
And, in the best way that he could,
His tale did Peter tell.
explanation: The speaker expresses gratitude to God and states that her heart is now at peace because the person she believes to be dead has indeed passed away. She then begins to cry heavily and Peter tries to console her by telling her the story in the best way he can.

Peter is visibly shaken and pale as he trembles while trying to speak. He struggles to articulate his thoughts, frequently pausing and turning his head away from his audience. It is clear that Peter is struggling to convey his message due to a myriad of reasons.

text:
At length she learned how he espied
The Ass in that small meadow-ground;
And that her Husband now lay dead,
Beside that luckless river's bed
In which he had been drowned.
explanation: Eventually, she found out how he had sighted the donkey in the tiny meadow and that her spouse was dead, lying next to the river where he had unfortunately drowned.

The Widow gives a sharp gaze towards the Beast, who is standing close to her. She recognizes that it is the same Ass that she knows and calls him by his name. Overcome with emotions, she repeatedly twists and turns her hands.

text:
"O wretched loss--untimely stroke!
If he had died upon his bed!
He knew not one forewarning pain;
He never will come home again--
Is dead, for ever dead!"
explanation: The loss is devastating and untimely, as if the person had died in their sleep, without any warning of pain. The fact that they will never return home again is a permanent and profound loss that will be felt forever.

Peter is standing next to a woman and is experiencing a growing sense of openness in his heart. His mind is filled with a sense of holiness and he is experiencing emotions towards humanity that he has never felt before.

text:
At length, by Peter's arm sustained,
The Woman rises from the ground--
"Oh, mercy! something must be done,
My little Rachel, you must run,--
Some willing neighbour must be found.
explanation: Peter helps the woman up from the ground and she exclaims that they need to find someone to help her daughter, Rachel. She asks for a willing neighbor to be found to assist them.

text:
"Make haste--my little Rachel--do,
The first you meet with--bid him come,
Ask him to lend his horse to-night,
And this good Man, whom Heaven requite,
Will help to bring the body home."
explanation: Hurry, Rachel, go find the first person you see and ask them to lend their horse for tonight. If they agree, may good fortune be bestowed upon them. We need their help to bring the body back home.

text:
Away goes Rachel weeping loud;--
An Infant, waked by her distress,
Makes in the house a piteous cry;
And Peter hears the Mother sigh,
"Seven are they, and all fatherless!"
explanation: Rachel leaves while crying loudly. Her distress wakes up a baby who then starts to cry. Peter hears Rachel sigh and say that she has seven children who are all without a father.

text:
And now is Peter taught to feel
That man's heart is a holy thing;
And Nature, through a world of death,
Breathes into him a second breath,
More searching than the breath of spring.
explanation: Peter has been taught the sanctity of man's heart and has gained a new perspective on life. He has been rejuvenated by the revitalizing powers of nature, which have given him a new lease on life. The breath of spring is not as potent as the life-giving breath of nature, which has given him a deeper understanding of the world around him.

text:
Upon a stone the Woman sits
In agony of silent grief--
From his own thoughts did Peter start;
He longs to press her to his heart,
From love that cannot find relief.
explanation: The Woman is sitting on a stone, visibly upset and distressed. Peter, who was lost in thought, suddenly notices her and feels a strong desire to comfort her with a warm embrace. Unfortunately, his love for her is unrequited, and he cannot alleviate her suffering.

text:
But roused, as if through every limb
Had past a sudden shock of dread,
The Mother o'er the threshold flies,
And up the cottage stairs she hies,
And on the pillow lays her burning head.
explanation: The mother's body trembled with fear as she quickly ran up the stairs of her cottage and placed her hot head on the pillow. It was as if a sudden jolt had gone through her entire body, making her feel anxious and uneasy.

text:
And Peter turns his steps aside
Into a shade of darksome trees,
Where he sits down, he knows not how,
With his hands pressed against his brow,
His elbows on his tremulous knees.
explanation: Peter diverts his path towards a group of trees that cast a deep shadow. He then sits down, not fully aware of how he got there, and places his hands on his forehead while his elbows rest on his shaky knees.

text:
There, self-involved, does Peter sit
Until no sign of life he makes,
As if his mind were sinking deep
Through years that have been long asleep
The trance is passed away--he wakes;
explanation: Peter sits there, completely absorbed in his own thoughts, until he becomes completely still and unresponsive, as if his mind is delving into a long-forgotten past. Eventually, he snaps out of his trance and wakes up.

text:
He lifts his head--and sees the Ass
Yet standing in the clear moonshine;
"When shall I be as good as thou?
Oh! would, poor beast, that I had now
A heart but half as good as thine!" 0
explanation: He raises his head and notices the donkey standing in the bright moonlight. He longs to be as virtuous as the animal and wishes he had a heart that was even half as good.

text:
But 'He'--who deviously hath sought
His Father through the lonesome woods,
Hath sought, proclaiming to the ear
Of night his grief and sorrowful fear--
He comes, escaped from fields and floods;--
explanation: He who has been searching for his father in the lonely woods, making his grief and fear known to the silent night, has finally escaped from the dangers of the surrounding fields and floods.

text:
With weary pace is drawing nigh;
He sees the Ass--and nothing living
Had ever such a fit of joy
As hath this little orphan Boy,
For he has no misgiving!
explanation: The tired boy is approaching his destination slowly, and he spots the donkey. The sight of the donkey fills him with immense joy, unlike anything he has ever experienced before. The boy is an orphan, and he has no worries or doubts about the future, making this moment of happiness all the more precious.

text:
Forth to the gentle Ass he springs,
And up about his neck he climbs;
In loving words he talks to him,
He kisses, kisses face and limb,--
He kisses him a thousand times!
explanation: The speaker in the poem jumps onto the back of a gentle donkey and embraces it with loving words, kisses, and caresses. The speaker expresses their affection for the donkey by kissing its face and limbs repeatedly, showing their love for the animal.

text:
This Peter sees, while in the shade
He stood beside the cottage-door;
And Peter Bell, the ruffian wild,
Sobs loud, he sobs even like a child,
"O God! I can endure no more!"
explanation: Peter, standing in the shade by the cottage-door, witnesses Peter Bell's emotional breakdown. The wild ruffian sobs uncontrollably, resembling a child, and declares that he cannot bear the pain any longer.
The story concludes abruptly as a neighbor arrives with his horse and Peter accompanies him to retrieve the dead body, which they successfully bring back before dawn with great caution.

text:
And many years did this poor Ass,
Whom once it was my luck to see
Cropping the shrubs of Leming-Lane,
Help by his labour to maintain
The Widow and her family.
explanation: For many years, I witnessed a destitute donkey grazing on the bushes of Leming-Lane, tirelessly toiling to provide for a widow and her household.

text:
And Peter Bell, who, till that night,
Had been the wildest of his clan,
Forsook his crimes, renounced his folly,
And, after ten months' melancholy,
Became a good and honest man.
explanation: Peter Bell, previously known as the most unruly member of his group, underwent a transformation after a particular evening. He abandoned all his unlawful activities and repented for his past mistakes, leading a gloomy life for ten months. Eventually, he emerged as a virtuous and sincere individual.

text:
WHEN I have borne in memory what has tamed
Great Nations, how ennobling thoughts depart
When men change swords for ledgers, and desert
The student's bower for gold, some fears unnamed
I had, my Country!--am I to be blamed?
Now, when I think of thee, and what thou art,
Verily, in the bottom of my heart,
Of those unfilial fears I am ashamed.
explanation: The poet reflects on how great nations have been subdued in the past and how noble thoughts are abandoned when people prioritize money over education. He confesses to having some unnamed fears for his country when he thought about this. However, upon reflection, he feels ashamed of these fears as he thinks of his country and what it represents to him.

text:
For dearly must we prize thee; we who find
In thee a bulwark for the cause of men;
And I by my affection was beguiled:
What wonder if a Poet now and then,
Among the many movements of his mind,
Felt for thee as a lover or a child!
explanation: We highly value you, as you are a defender of the rights of people. Due to my fondness for you, it's not surprising that I, as a poet, sometimes feel towards you with the intensity of a lover or a child, amidst the various thoughts that cross my mind.

text:
. I was thy neighbour once, thou rugged Pile!
Four summer weeks I dwelt in sight of thee:
I saw thee every day; and all the while
Thy Form was sleeping on a glassy sea.
So pure the sky, so quiet was the air!
So like, so very like, was day to day!
Whene'er I looked, thy Image still was there;
It trembled, but it never passed away.
How perfect was the calm! it seemed no sleep;
No mood, which season takes away, or brings:
I could have fancied that the mighty Deep
Was even the gentlest of all gentle things.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: I used to live near you, oh rugged mountain! For four weeks in the summer, I had a view of you. Every day, I witnessed your sleeping form on the still water. The sky was pure and the air was quiet, and each day was so similar to the last. Whenever I looked at you, your reflection was still there, trembling but never fading. The peacefulness was perfect, as if there was no time passing nor any changes in the weather. I could have even imagined that the vast ocean was the gentlest of all things.

text:
Ah!  then , if mine had been the Painter's hand,
To express what then I saw; and add the gleam,
The light that never was, on sea or land,
The consecration, and the Poet's dream;
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: The speaker expresses a desire to have the ability to paint what they witnessed, and to include the imaginary light that did not exist in reality. They also wish to capture the feeling of holiness and the imagination of a poet in their painting.

text:
I would have planted thee, thou hoary Pile
Amid a world how different from this!
Beside a sea that could not cease to smile;
On tranquil land, beneath a sky of bliss.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: If it were up to me, I would have planted this old building in a completely different world, one that is unlike the current world we live in. I would have placed it next to a sea that is always calm and happy, on peaceful land, and under a sky that is always perfect.

text:
Thou shouldst have seemed a treasure-house divine
Of peaceful years; a chronicle of heaven;--
Of all the sunbeams that did ever shine
The very sweetest had to thee been given.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: You were supposed to be a holy treasure, filled with years of peace and a record of heaven. Out of all the sunny moments that have ever existed, you were given the most delightful ones.

text:
A Picture had it been of lasting ease,
Elysian quiet, without toil or strife;
No motion but the moving tide, a breeze,
Or merely silent Nature's breathing life.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: The ideal picture would be one of tranquility and serenity, where there is no struggle or effort required. The only movement present would be the gentle ebb and flow of the tide or a light breeze, or even just the stillness of nature.

text:
Such, in the fond illusion of my heart,
Such Picture would I at that time have made:
And seen the soul of truth in every part,
A steadfast peace that might not be betrayed.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: At that time, I had an idealistic vision in my heart of a picture that would embody unwavering honesty and a sense of tranquility that could not be broken. I wished to see the truth in every corner of this image.

poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Things were once a certain way, but now they have changed. I am now under a new influence and things will never be the same. I have lost something valuable and it cannot be regained. This loss has caused me great pain, but it has also made me more compassionate and empathetic towards others.

text:
Not for a moment could I now behold
A smiling sea, and be what I have been:
The feeling of my loss will ne'er be old;
This, which I know, I speak with mind serene.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: I can no longer look at the sea with a happy heart, as I once did, because of the pain I feel inside. This feeling won't go away, but I accept it and speak of it calmly.

text:
Then, Beaumont, Friend! who would have been the Friend,
If he had lived, of Him whom I deplore,
This work of thine I blame not, but commend;
This sea in anger, and that dismal shore.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: The speaker addresses Beaumont, who would have been a dear friend to the person they mourn. The speaker praises Beaumont's work and does not blame him for it. They acknowledge the harsh sea and gloomy shore depicted in the work.

text:
O 'tis a passionate Work!--yet wise and well,
Well chosen is the spirit that is here;
That Hulk which labours in the deadly swell,
This rueful sky, this pageantry of fear!
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: This is a passionate work that is both wise and well-chosen. The poem describes a ship, or "hulk," laboring in the dangerous waves of the sea while the sky is ominous and foreboding. The language used creates a sense of fear and dread.

text:
And this huge Castle, standing here sublime,
I love to see the look with which it braves,
Cased in the unfeeling armour of old time,
The lightning, the fierce wind, the trampling waves.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: I adore this grand Castle, its appearance exudes bravery and strength as it stands tall and unyielding against the harsh elements of nature. Its ancient armor shields it from the lightning strikes, fierce winds, and pounding waves, showcasing its resilience and steadfastness.

text:
Farewell, farewell the heart that lives alone,
Housed in a dream, at distance from the Kind!
Such happiness, wherever it be known,
Is to be pitied; for 'tis surely blind.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Goodbye to the heart that chooses to be isolated, existing only in a dream, far away from others. This type of happiness, when found, is a sad thing because it is blind to the joys of human connection.

text:
But welcome fortitude, and patient cheer,
And frequent sights of what is to be borne!
Such sights, or worse, as are before me here.--
Not without hope we suffer and we mourn.
poem_title: Elegiac Stanzas Suggested By A Picture Of Peele Castle
explanation: Let us embrace resilience and a positive attitude, and seek out moments that remind us of the challenges we must face. Even if these challenges seem insurmountable, we must remain hopeful and endure.

The speaker is pleading to the gods to bring back her slain Lord. She has made vows in the hope that her sacrifice will inspire the gods to return him to her. She asks for celestial pity and implores Jove to restore him. The speaker's love gives her faith and she lifts her hands in supplication, her countenance brightening and her stature growing as she waits for the gods' decision.

text:
O terror! what hath she perceived?--O joy!
What doth she look on?--whom doth she behold?
Her Hero slain upon the beach of Troy?
His vital presence? his corporeal mould?
It is--if sense deceive her not--'tis He!
And a God leads him, wingèd Mercury!
explanation: The speaker is experiencing conflicting emotions of terror and joy. They question what the woman they are referring to has perceived and what she is looking at. It becomes clear that she is observing her lover, Hero, who has been killed on the beach of Troy. However, the woman sees his physical form and believes it to be him. She is being led by the god Mercury.

text:
Mild Hermes spake--and touched her with his wand
That calms all fear; "Such grace hath crowned thy prayer,
Laodamía! that at Jove's command
Thy husband walks the paths of upper air:
He comes to tarry with thee three hours' space;
Accept the gift, behold him face to face!"
explanation: Hermes spoke softly to Laodamia and eased her fears by touching her with his wand. He praised her prayer and informed her that Zeus had granted her request, allowing her deceased husband to visit her for three hours. Hermes urged her to accept this gift and to prepare to see her husband once again.

The Queen passionately sprang forward to embrace her Lord once again, attempting to achieve the ultimate connection. However, the ethereal form continually evaded her grasp, causing her to repeatedly reach out in desperation. The apparition would dissipate, only to reform and reappear directly within her line of vision.

text:
"Protesiláus, lo! thy guide is gone!
Confirm, I pray, the vision with thy voice:
This is our palace,--yonder is thy throne;
Speak, and the floor thou tread'st on will rejoice.
Not to appal me have the gods bestowed
This precious boon; and blest a sad abode."
explanation: Protesiláus is being informed that his guide has left him and he is being asked to confirm what he sees with his own voice. He is told that the place he is in is their palace and the throne is his. The speaker asks him to speak so that the floor he is standing on will rejoice. The speaker reassures Protesiláus that the gods did not give him this vision to frighten him, but to bless his sad abode.

Laodamia should not fear as the ghost before her is not there to frighten or deceive her. The ghost is a reward for her loyalty and her courage has also earned her great rewards. The gifts of Jove are not incomplete as he rewards those who are faithful and virtuous.

The Delphic oracle had prophesized that the first Greek to touch the shore of Troy would die, but the speaker, being a selfless leader, could not be deterred by this warning. He felt that the cause he was fighting for was more important than his own life and willingly sacrificed himself by jumping onto the sandy plain. Despite knowing the risk, he bravely faced his fate and was ultimately killed by Hector.

text:
"Supreme of Heroes--bravest, noblest, best!
Thy matchless courage I bewail no more,
Which then, when tens of thousands were deprest
By doubt, propelled thee to the fatal shore;
Thou found'st--and I forgive thee--here thou art--
A nobler counsellor than my poor heart.
explanation: You are the greatest hero, possessing unparalleled bravery, nobility, and excellence. I no longer mourn your unmatched courage that drove you to the fatal shore when thousands were filled with uncertainty. You discovered a superior advisor than my limited heart, and I forgive you for your actions.

text:
"But thou, though capable of sternest deed,
Wert kind as resolute, and good as brave;
And he, whose power restores thee, hath decreed
Thou should'st elude the malice of the grave:
Redundant are thy locks, thy lips as fair
As when their breath enriched Thessalian air.
explanation: Despite your ability to perform harsh actions, you possessed kindness to the same degree as your determination, and goodness to match your bravery. The one who has the authority to bring you back to life has decided that you should escape the cruelty of death. Your hair is abundant and your lips are still as beautiful as when they once enriched the air of Thessaly.

text:
"No spectre greets me,--no vain Shadow this;
Come, blooming Hero, place thee by my side!
Give, on this well-known couch, one nuptial kiss
To me, this day a second time thy bride!"
Jove frowned in heaven: the conscious Parcæ threw
Upon those roseate lips a Stygian hue.
explanation: There is no ghost or imaginary apparition that greets the speaker. Instead, they call upon their beloved, who they describe as a blooming hero, to join them on the familiar couch and give them a kiss as they marry for the second time. However, this request doesn't sit well with Jove, who becomes angry, and the Parcæ, who respond by causing the lover's lips to turn a dark color.

text:
"This visage tells thee that my doom is past:
Nor should the change be mourned, even if the joys
Of sense were able to return as fast
And surely as they vanish. Earth destroys
Those raptures duly---Erebus disdains:
Calm pleasures there abide--majestic pains.
explanation: My face shows that my fate is sealed, and there is no need to grieve over the loss of earthly pleasures that fade away as quickly as they come. The joys of the senses are inevitably destroyed by time, and even the underworld of Erebus looks down upon them. Instead, serene pleasures and grand pains can be found there."

text:
"Be taught, O faithful Consort, to control
Rebellious passion: for the Gods approve
The depth, and not the tumult, of the soul;
A fervent, not ungovernable love.
Thy transports moderate; and meekly mourn
When I depart, for brief is my sojourn--"
explanation: The speaker is advising their faithful partner to learn how to control their strong emotions, as the gods prefer a deep and passionate love that is still manageable. They suggest that their partner should try to moderate their intense feelings and show humble sadness when they depart, as their time together is fleeting.

text:
"Ah wherefore?--Did not Hercules by force
Wrest from the guardian monster of the tomb
Alcestis, a reanimated corse,
Given back to dwell on earth in vernal bloom?
Medea's spells dispersed the weight of years,
And Æson stood a youth 'mid youthful peers.
explanation: Why not? Hercules had once forcibly taken Alcestis, who had been brought back to life after death by the guardian of the tomb, and returned her to the world as a young woman. And Medea's magic had also reversed the effects of aging, allowing Æson to appear youthful again among his peers.

text:
"The Gods to us are merciful--and they
Yet further may relent: for mightier far
Than strength of nerve and sinew, or the sway
Of magic potent over sun and star,
Is love, though oft to agony distrest,
And though his favourite seat be feeble woman's breast.
explanation: The Gods are kind to humans and may continue to be so in the future. Love is more powerful than physical strength or magic and can cause great pain even though it often resides within the weak heart of a woman.

She tells him that she will follow wherever he goes, but he interrupts her and tells her to be quiet. When she looks at him, she feels better, as the pallor has disappeared from his face and he looks beautiful and graceful, with a hint of sadness mixed with happiness.

He spoke of a love that is felt by Spirits in worlds that are peaceful and balanced, with no worries or conflicts to resolve, and where the past is not mourned and the future is certain. He also spoke of the revival of heroic arts, pursued with a more refined sense of harmony.

text:
Of all that is most beauteous--imaged there
In happier beauty; more pellucid streams,
An ampler ether, a diviner air,
And fields invested with purpureal gleams;
Climes which the sun, who sheds the brightest day
Earth knows, is all unworthy to survey.
explanation: The author describes a place that is more beautiful than anything on earth. This place has clearer streams, a more divine atmosphere, and fields that shimmer with purple light. Even the sun, which lights up the earth, is not worthy enough to shine on this place.

text:
Yet there the Soul shall enter which hath earned
That privilege by virtue.--"Ill," said he,
"The end of man's existence I discerned,
Who from ignoble games and revelry
Could draw, when we had parted, vain delight,
While tears were thy best pastime, day and night;
explanation: The Soul that has earned the privilege shall enter there, according to the speaker. He states that he had a vision of the end of man's existence, where those who indulged in ignoble games and revelry found only empty pleasure after they parted. Meanwhile, the speaker's companion spent their time in tears, which was the best way to pass the time.

text:
"And while my youthful peers before my eyes
(Each hero following his peculiar bent)
Prepared themselves for glorious enterprise
By martial sports,--or, seated in the tent,
Chieftains and kings in council were detained;
What time the fleet at Aulis lay enchained.
explanation: As a young person, I observed my peers getting ready for heroic adventures through physical activities or by participating in discussions with leaders. Meanwhile, the fleet at Aulis was held captive and leaders were in meetings, preventing them from embarking on their own quests."

text:
"The wished-for wind was given:--I then revolved
The oracle, upon the silent sea;
And, if no worthier led the way, resolved
That, of a thousand vessels, mine should be
The foremost prow in pressing to the strand,--
Mine the first blood that tinged the Trojan sand.
explanation: I desired a strong wind and it came. I then consulted the oracle on the calm sea. If no one else was more deserving, I decided that my ship would be the first to land and my crew would spill the first blood on the Trojan sand out of a thousand vessels.

text:
"Yet bitter, oft-times bitter, was the pang
When of thy loss I thought, belovèd Wife!
On thee too fondly did my memory hang,
And on the joys we shared in mortal life,--
The paths which we had trod--these fountains, flowers:
My new-planned cities, and unfinished towers.
explanation: The speaker expresses the pain they felt thinking about the loss of their beloved wife. Memories of their shared joys and experiences in life, such as walking paths, admiring fountains and flowers, planning cities, and building towers, were too fondly held in their memory, causing a bitter pang.

text:
"But should suspense permit the Foe to cry,
'Behold they tremble!--haughty their array,
Yet of their numbers no one dares to die?'
In soul I swept the indignity away:
Old frailties then recurred:--but lofty thought,
In act embodied, my deliverance wrought.
explanation: The speaker is asking if they should allow the enemy to mock them for being afraid despite having a large army. However, they refuse to let this insult affect them and instead work to overcome their personal weaknesses. Through their determination and action, they are able to overcome their fears and achieve victory.

Although you are powerful in love, you lack reason and self-control. I advise you to seek our reunion in the afterlife through strength and courage. The unseen world has shown empathy towards you, and your emotions should be elevated and made more serious.

text:
"Learn, by a mortal yearning, to ascend--
Seeking a higher object. Love was given,
Encouraged, sanctioned, chiefly for that end;
For this the passion to excess was driven--
That self might be annulled: her bondage prove
The fetters of a dream opposed to love.--
explanation: Through a desire that is inherent in human nature, strive to rise to greater heights and pursue a noble goal. Love was bestowed upon us for this specific purpose, to encourage and permit us to pursue it. This is why the intensity of love can be overwhelming, as it drives us to surpass ourselves and abandon our ego. It is a test of our commitment to our goal, and our ability to let go of our selfish desires. In this way, love becomes a dreamlike state, where we are bound by the chains of our aspirations rather than our own personal interests.

text:
Aloud she shrieked! for Hermes re-appears!
Round the dear Shade she would have clung--'tis vain:
The hours are past--too brief had they been years;
And him no mortal effort can detain:
Swift, toward the realms that know not earthly day,
He through the portal takes his silent way,
And on the palace-floor a lifeless corse She lay.
explanation: The woman let out a loud scream as Hermes reappeared. She tried to cling onto the Shade, but it was too late as the hours had passed too quickly. No mortal could stop Hermes from leaving and he quickly made his way towards the other realm. The woman was left lifeless on the palace floor.

text:
Thus, all in vain exhorted and reproved,
She perished; and, as for a wilful crime,
By the just Gods whom no weak pity moved,
Was doomed to wear out her appointed time,
Apart from happy Ghosts, that gather flowers
Of blissful quiet 'mid unfading bowers.
explanation: Despite being urged and rebuked, she perished in vain. The just Gods, who were not moved by weak pity, deemed her to have committed a willful crime and sentenced her to serve her time alone, away from the happy spirits who enjoy the eternal serenity of unfading gardens.

text:
--Yet tears to human suffering are due;
And mortal hopes defeated and o'erthrown
Are mourned by man, and not by man alone,
As fondly he believes.--Upon the side
Of Hellespont (such faith was entertained)
A knot of spiry trees for ages grew
From out the tomb of him for whom she died;
And ever, when such stature they had gained
That Ilium's walls were subject to their view,
The trees' tall summits withered at the sight;
A constant interchange of growth and blight!
explanation: Human suffering deserves tears and when hopes are crushed, it is not just humans who mourn but others as well, although humans may believe otherwise. This belief was held by people who thought that a group of tall trees on the side of Hellespont grew out of the tomb of the person for whom someone died. As the trees grew tall enough to see the walls of Ilium, they would wither and die. This was a constant cycle of growth and decay.

text:
.   Tax not the royal Saint with vain expense,
With ill-matched aims the Architect who planned--
Albeit labouring for a scanty band
Of white-robed Scholars only--this immense
And glorious Work of fine intelligence!
Give all thou canst; high Heaven rejects the lore
Of nicely-calculated less or more;
poem_title: Inside Of King's College Chapel, Cambridge
explanation: Do not burden the noble scholar with unnecessary expenses, nor should the architect who designed this magnificent work be misguided in their intentions. Although they worked diligently for a small group of scholars, their creation is a grand display of intelligence. Give everything you can, as heaven does not acknowledge the value of precise calculations of excess or lack.

text:
So deemed the man who fashioned for the sense
These lofty pillars, spread that branching roof
Self-poised, and scooped into ten thousand cells,
Where light and shade repose, where music dwells
Lingering--and wandering on as loth to die;
Like thoughts whose very sweetness yieldeth proof
That they were born for immortality.
poem_title: Inside Of King's College Chapel, Cambridge
explanation: The man who created the impressive pillars and roof of this structure believed it to be a place of beauty and music, with light and shade in peaceful coexistence. The music lingers and wanders, reluctant to fade away, much like enduring thoughts that prove their own immortality through their sweetness.

text:
Rude is this Edifice, and Thou hast seen
Buildings, albeit rude, that have maintained
Proportions more harmonious, and approached
To closer fellowship with ideal grace.
poem_title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: This building is rude and lacks grace, unlike other buildings that may be considered rough but still maintain a sense of harmony and ideal proportions.

text:
But take it in good part:--alas! the poor
Vitruvius of our village had no help
From the great City; never, upon leaves
Of red Morocco folio, saw displayed,
In long succession, pre-existing ghosts
Of Beauties yet unborn--the rustic Lodge
Antique, and Cottage with verandah graced,
Nor lacking, for fit company, alcove,
Green-house, shell-grot, and moss-lined hermitage.
poem_title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: Unfortunately, the skilled builder of our small village did not receive any assistance from the city. He did not have access to the luxurious red Morocco folios that displayed the designs of beautiful buildings that were yet to be built. The builder did not have the opportunity to construct charming and ancient lodges, cottages with graceful verandahs, or delightful additions like alcoves, greenhouses, shell-grots, and moss-lined hermitages to accompany them.

text:
Thou see'st a homely Pile, yet to these walls
The heifer comes in the snow-storm, and here
The new-dropped lamb finds shelter from the wind.
And hither does one Poet sometimes row
His pinnace, a small vagrant barge, up-piled
With plenteous store of heath and withered fern,
(A lading which he with his sickle cuts,
Among the mountains) and beneath this roof
He makes his summer couch, and here at noon
Spreads out his limbs, while, yet unshorn, the Sheep,
Panting beneath the burthen of their wool,
Lie round him, even as if they were a part
Of his own Household: nor, while from his bed
He looks, through the open door-place, toward the lake
And to the stirring breezes, does he want
Creations lovely as the work of sleep--
Fair sights, and visions of romantic joy!
poem_title: Written With A Pencil Upon A Stone In The Wall Of The House, On The Island At Grasmere
explanation: Despite its humble appearance, this building provides shelter to animals in need, such as heifers during snowstorms and newly born lambs seeking protection from the wind. Occasionally, a poet will arrive in a small barge loaded with heath and fern gathered from the mountains. He will make his bed under the roof and rest during the day, surrounded by unshorn sheep who appear as if they are part of his family. From his bed, the poet can see the lake and feel the breeze, inspiring him with beautiful sights and dreams of romantic bliss.

text:
In distant countries have I been,
And yet I have not often seen
A healthy man, a man full grown,
Weep in the public roads, alone.
But such a one, on English ground,
And in the broad highway, I met;
Along the broad highway he came,
His cheeks with tears were wet:
Sturdy he seemed, though he was sad;
And in his arms a Lamb he had.
explanation: I have traveled to many far-off lands, but I have rarely witnessed a grown, healthy man crying alone in public. However, I did encounter such a sight on English soil, in the middle of a busy road. This man appeared strong, although clearly upset as tears streamed down his face. He held a lamb in his arms as he walked along the road.

text:
He saw me, and he turned aside,
As if he wished himself to hide:
And with his coat did then essay
To wipe those briny tears away.
I followed him, and said, 'My friend,
What ails you? wherefore weep you so?'
--'Shame on me, Sir! this lusty Lamb,
He makes my tears to flow.
To-day I fetched him from the rock;
He is the last of all my flock,
explanation: When he saw me, he looked away, trying to conceal himself from me, and then used his coat to wipe away his tears. I went after him and asked why he was crying. He responded with shame, saying that the young lamb was the cause of his tears. He had brought the lamb back from the rocky terrain, and it was the last remaining member of his flock.

As a young man, I made mistakes but still managed to buy an ewe and raise healthy sheep from her. Later on, I got married and became successful, having a full score of sheep and increasing my flock every year.

The speaker had a single ewe that helped them raise a fine flock of fifty sheep. The sheep grazed on the Quantock hills and prospered, leading to the speaker's own prosperity. However, now only one lamb remains from their stock, and the speaker has lost all care for their own survival, willing to succumb to poverty.

text:
'Six Children, Sir! had I to feed;
Hard labour in a time of need!
My pride was tamed, and in our grief
I of the Parish asked relief.
They said, I was a wealthy man;
My sheep upon the uplands fed,
And it was fit that thence I took
Whereof to buy us bread.
'Do this: how can we give to you,'
They cried, 'what to the poor is due?'
explanation: The speaker, a man with six children to feed, had to endure hard labor during a difficult time. He asked the Parish for help, but they refused, claiming he was a wealthy man due to his sheep on the uplands. The Parish believed he should sell some sheep to provide for his family. However, the speaker argued that he could not do this, as his sheep were his only source of income. The Parish questioned how they could give him aid when there were others who were poorer than him.

text:
'I sold a sheep, as they had said,
And bought my little children bread,
And they were healthy with their food
For me--it never did me good.
A woeful time it was for me,
To see the end of all my gains,
The pretty flock which I had reared
With all my care and pains,
To see it melt like snow away--
For me it was a woeful day.
explanation: The speaker sold a sheep as instructed and used the money to buy bread for their children who were healthy as a result. However, the speaker did not benefit from the sale and it was a sad time for them to see the end of their hard work in raising the flock as it disappeared quickly.

text:
'Another still! and still another!
A little lamb, and then its mother!
It was a vein that never stopped--
Like blood-drops from my heart they dropped.
'Till thirty were not left alive
They dwindled, dwindled, one by one
And I may say, that many a time
I wished they all were gone--
Reckless of what might come at last
Were but the bitter struggle past.
explanation: The speaker in the poem describes the continuous loss of their lambs until only thirty were left. Each loss felt like a drop of blood from their heart, but they eventually became indifferent and wished for all the lambs to be gone. The struggle of losing them was so bitter that they didn't care about the consequences that may follow.

I had a strong inclination towards evil deeds, and my thoughts were filled with wickedness. I suspected everyone I came across of having knowledge of my misdeeds. I couldn't find any peace or comfort, whether inside or outside. I went about my work in a state of restlessness and exhaustion. I had the urge to run away from home and seek refuge in the wilderness where wild animals roamed.

The speaker laments the loss of his beloved flock, which he valued as much as his own children. He confesses that as he accumulated more resources, he found himself loving his children less and less. He attributes his misfortune to divine punishment, and despite his prayers, he watched as his flock dwindled away week by week and day by day.

text:
'They dwindled, Sir, sad sight to see!
From ten to five, from five to three,
A lamb, a wether, and a ewe;--
And then at last from three to two;
And, of my fifty, yesterday
I had but only one:
And here it lies upon my arm,
Alas! and I have none;--
To-day I fetched it from the rock;
It is the last of all my flock.'
explanation: The speaker laments the loss of their flock, which has dwindled from ten to just one sheep. They express sadness at the sight of the decreasing numbers, with the last remaining sheep now lying on their arm. The sheep was retrieved from a rock, and the speaker mourns the fact that it is the last of their flock.

text:
Send this man to the mine, this to the battle,
Famish an aged beggar at your gates,
And let him die by inches- but for worlds
Lift not your hand against him- Live, live on,
As if this earth owned neither steel nor arsenic,
A rope, a river, or a standing pool.
explanation: The speaker is suggesting that instead of harming others, one should send them to work in a mine or to fight in a battle, or even let an elderly beggar starve to death. However, the speaker warns against physically harming others. They encourage individuals to live their lives as if they did not have access to weapons, poison, or other means of violence. Essentially, the speaker is promoting non-violence and peaceful coexistence.

text:
Live, if you dread the pains of hell, or think
Your corpse would quarrel with a stake- alas
Has misery then no friend?- if you would die
By license, call the dropsy and the stone
And let them end you- strange it is;
explanation: If you fear eternal damnation, or believe that your body would resist being staked, there are still other options. If you wish to die by choice, you can succumb to diseases such as dropsy or kidney stones. It's odd that there are those who would rather suffer in agony than choose a peaceful end.

text:
And most fantastic are the magic circles
Drawn round the thing called life- till we have learned
To prize it less, we ne'er shall learn to prize
The things worth living for.-
explanation: The magic circles around life are truly amazing, but we must learn to appreciate life less in order to appreciate the truly important things.

text:
If thou in the dear love of some one Friend
Hast been so happy that thou know'st what thoughts
Will sometimes in the happiness of love
Make the heart sink, then wilt thou reverence
This quiet spot; and, Stranger! not unmoved
Wilt thou behold this shapeless heap of stones,
The desolate ruins of St. Herbert's Cell.
poem_title: For The Spot Where The Hermitage Stood On St. Herbert's Island, Derwentwater.
explanation: If you have experienced the joy of being deeply loved by a dear friend, you may be familiar with the moments when love can also bring sadness. In those times, you will appreciate the tranquility of this place and understand the emotions that come with it. As a stranger, you will not be indifferent to the sight of the jumbled stones that remain of St. Herbert's Cell, a testament to the desolation it once housed.

text:
Here stood his threshold; here was spread the roof
That sheltered him, a self-secluded Man,
After long exercise in social cares
And offices humane, intent to adore
The Deity, with undistracted mind,
And meditate on everlasting things,
In utter solitude.--But he had left
A Fellow-labourer, whom the good Man loved
As his own soul. And, when with eye upraised
To heaven he knelt before the crucifix,
While o'er the lake the cataract of Lodore
Pealed to his orisons, and when he paced
Along the beach of this small isle and thought
Of his Companion, he would pray that both
(Now that their earthly duties were fulfilled)
Might die in the same moment. Nor in vain
So prayed he:--as our chronicles report,
Though here the Hermit numbered his last day
Far from St. Cuthbert his beloved Friend,
Those holy Men both died in the same hour.
poem_title: For The Spot Where The Hermitage Stood On St. Herbert's Island, Derwentwater.
explanation: The threshold of the self-secluded man, who had previously been heavily involved in social duties, was a place of solitude where he could focus on his adoration of the deity and contemplate eternal things. Although he had left his friend, a fellow laborer whom he deeply loved, behind, he prayed that they would both die at the same time after their earthly duties were fulfilled. His prayers were answered as both the man and his friend died at the same hour, despite the fact that the hermit had spent his final days apart from his beloved companion.

text:
MILTON! thou shouldst be living at this hour:
England hath need of thee: she is a fen
Of stagnant waters: altar, sword, and pen,
Fireside, the heroic wealth of hall and bower,
Have forfeited their ancient English dower
Of inward happiness. We are selfish men;
explanation: Oh Milton, if only you were alive today, England needs you. It is a country filled with stagnant waters, lacking in the heroic spirit of its past. The altar, sword, and pen, as well as the fireside and the wealth of its great halls and homes, have all lost their true English heritage of inner happiness. We have become selfish as a people.

text:
O raise us up, return to us again,
And give us manners, virtue, freedom, power!
Thy soul was like a Star, and dwelt apart;
Thou hadst a voice whose sound was like the sea:
Pure as the naked heavens, majestic, free,
So didst thou travel on life's common way,
In cheerful godliness; and yet thy heart
The lowliest duties on herself did lay.
explanation: Please come back to us and elevate us with your presence. Instill in us good behavior, moral principles, independence, and strength. Your spirit was exceptional, shining like a star and distinct from others. Your words were powerful, resonating like the waves of the sea.
