poem_title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: The speaker notes that they are alone without any siblings or friends nearby, but they can find comfort and happiness in the presence of their beloved. Despite the darkness around them, the speaker feels as content as they would in a bright and sunny room with green grass and flowers.

text:
Yet, God is my witness, thou small helpless Thing!
Thy life I would gladly sustain
Till summer come up from the south, and with crowds
Of thy brethren a march thou should'st sound through the clouds,
And back to the forests again!
poem_title: Written In Germany, On One Of The Coldest Days Of The Century
explanation: I swear to God that I would do anything to ensure your survival, little helpless creature. I will care for you until the warm summer months arrive, and you can join your fellow birds in a joyous flight through the sky and back to the safety of the forest.

text:
.  These times strike monied worldlings with dismay:
Even rich men, brave by nature, taint the air
With words of apprehension and despair:
While tens of thousands, thinking on the affray,
Men unto whom sufficient for the day
And minds not stinted or untilled are given,
Sound, healthy, children of the God of heaven,
Are cheerful as the rising sun in May.
explanation: The current situation is causing great concern and distress among wealthy individuals, who despite their brave and confident nature, cannot help but express their fears and worries. Meanwhile, there are tens of thousands of people who are content with having just enough to get by each day, possessing sound minds and healthy bodies, and are children of God. These individuals are as cheerful as the sun in May, and do not seem to be affected by the same concerns as the wealthy.

text:
What do we gather hence but firmer faith
That every gift of noble origin
Is breathed upon by Hope's perpetual breath;
That virtue and the faculties within
Are vital,--and that riches are akin
To fear, to change, to cowardice, and death?
explanation: The speaker suggests that the constant presence of hope is necessary for every noble gift to thrive. They argue that virtues and internal abilities are essential and that wealth is associated with fear, change, cowardice, and death. The overall message is the importance of hope in the pursuit of noble endeavors and the dangers of relying solely on material possessions.

poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker wishes for their body to die before they see another day. They had a dream about the northern lights and stars, which seemed to be in conflict in the sky. Although they witnessed this in their dream, the flashes of light still linger in their eyes while they are still alive. The speaker repeats their wish for their body to pass away before they experience another day.

poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker's fire has gone out, but it didn't suffer, and now the ashes are frozen. The speaker is still alive, but without the fire, they feel no joy or desire for the things that used to bring them pleasure. They used to wish to live for warmth, food, and fire, but now they're content to lay there alone, unafraid of death.

text:
Alas! ye might have dragged me on
Another day, a single one!
Too soon I yielded to despair;
Why did ye listen to my prayer
When ye were gone my limb were stronger;
And oh, how grievously I rue,
That, afterward, a little longer,
My friends, I did not follow you!
For strong and without pain I lay,
Dear friends, when ye were gone away.
poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker laments that their friends did not force them to keep going for just one more day, as they gave up too easily and feel regret for not continuing on. They reflect on how they felt stronger after their friends left and wish they had followed them, as they were in a good physical state without pain.

text:
My Child! they gave thee to another,
A woman who was not thy mother.
When from my arms my Babe they took,
On me how strangely did he look !
Through his whole body something ran,
A most strange working did I see;
---As if he strove to be a man,
That he might pull the sledge for me:
And then he stretched his arm, how wild!
Oh mercy! like a helpless child.
poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker is addressing their child who was given to another woman who is not their biological mother. The speaker vividly describes the moment their child was taken from their arms and the strange look in their eyes. The child's body seemed to be going through something intense, as if they were trying to become a grown man to help pull a sledge for the speaker. However, the child also exhibited vulnerability by stretching out their arm in a wild and helpless manner.

poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: The speaker expresses deep affection for someone they refer to as their "little joy" and "little pride." They reveal that they were close to death and would have passed away within two days. The speaker asks their loved ones not to mourn them because they feel that they would have died alongside their loved one. The speaker addresses the wind, wishing they could send a message through it to their friends who left too soon. The speaker laments not having the chance to say everything they wanted to say before their impending death.

poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: I will accompany you through the snow, even though you move with great weight and slowness. Despite my exhaustion and discomfort, I will return to see your tent once more. My fire is extinguished, and the water beside it has turned to snow. Tonight, a wolf has taken my food, leaving me isolated and hungry. Since I am forever alone, there is no reason for me to be afraid of death.

text:
Young as I am, my course is run,
I shall not see another sun;
I cannot lift my limb to know
If they have any life or no.
My poor forsaken child, if I
For once could have thee close to me,
With happy heart I then would die,
And my last thought would happy be;
But thou, dear Babe, art far away,
Nor shall I see another day.
poem_title: The Complaint Of A Forsaken Indian Woman
explanation: Despite my youth, my life has come to an end and I will not live to see another sunrise. I am too weak to move and cannot tell if my limbs have any sensation. If only I could hold my abandoned child close to me before I pass, my heart would be content and my final moments would be filled with joy. Unfortunately, my dear baby is too far away and I know that I will not live to witness another day.

text:
The sun has long been set,
The stars are out by twos and threes,
The little birds are piping yet
Among the bushes and the trees;
poem_title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: The sun has already disappeared below the horizon, leaving behind a sky filled with a few stars, which have appeared in pairs and threes. The small birds are still singing and making noise, hidden in the shrubs and trees.

text:
There's a cuckoo, and one or two thrushes,
And a far-off wind that rushes,
And a sound of water that gushes,
And the cuckoo's sovereign cry
Fills all the hollow of the sky.
poem_title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: The sky is filled with the sounds of nature, including a cuckoo and a couple of thrushes. The wind rushes in the distance and water gushes, creating a peaceful atmosphere. The cuckoo's distinctive call echoes throughout the sky, dominating the soundscape.

text:
Who would go `parading'
In London, `and masquerading',
On such a night of June
With that beautiful soft half-moon,
And all these innocent blisses?
On such a night as this is!
poem_title: The Sun Has Long Been Set
explanation: On a June night with a beautiful half-moon, who would want to parade and masquerade in London? This night is too innocent and blissful to engage in such activities.

text:
Up with me! up with me into the clouds!
For thy song, Lark, is strong;
Up with me, up with me into the clouds!
Singing, singing,
With clouds and sky about thee ringing,
Lift me, guide me till I find
That spot which seems so to thy mind!
explanation: Let's rise into the clouds together, Lark, because your song is powerful. Sing with me as we ascend and the clouds and sky surround us. Lead me to the place that you envision, and I will follow.

text:
I have walked through wildernesses dreary
And to-day my heart is weary;
Had I now the wings of a Faery,
Up to thee would I fly.
There is madness about thee, and joy divine
In that song of thine;
Lift me, guide me high and high
To thy banqueting-place in the sky.
explanation: I have traversed desolate landscapes and now feel exhausted. If I possessed the magical wings of a fairy, I would soar up to you. Your presence exudes both madness and heavenly bliss in your beautiful song. Please lift me up and guide me towards your celestial banquet hall in the sky.

text:
Joyous as morning
Thou art laughing and scorning;
Thou hast a nest for thy love and thy rest,
And, though little troubled with sloth,
Drunken Lark! thou would'st be loth
To be such a traveller as I.
Happy, happy Liver,
With a soul as strong as a mountain river
Pouring out praise to the Almighty Giver,
Joy and jollity be with us both!
explanation: The speaker admires the lark, who is joyful and carefree, with a comfortable home and a strong work ethic. The lark is contrasted with the speaker, who is envious of the lark's life and wishes they could be as content as the bird. The speaker praises the liver, which is also strong and joyful, and celebrates the beauty and generosity of the creator. The speaker wishes for joy and happiness to be shared between the lark and themselves.

text:
Alas! my journey, rugged and uneven,
Through prickly moors or dusty ways must wind;
But hearing thee, or others of thy kind,
As full of gladness and as free of heaven,
I, with my fate contented, will plod on,
And hope for higher raptures, when life's day is done.
explanation: My journey will be tough and uncertain, filled with obstacles and challenges, whether it be through harsh terrain or dusty paths. However, the sound of your voice, or others like you, fills me with joy and reminds me of the freedom of heaven. With this knowledge, I am content with my fate and will continue on, hopeful for even greater happiness in the afterlife.

text:
With how sad steps, O Moon, thou climb'st the sky,
"How silently, and with how wan a face!"
Where art thou? Thou so often seen on high
Running among the clouds a Wood-nymph's race!
Unhappy Nuns, whose common breath's a sigh
Which they would stifle, move at such a pace!
The northern Wind, to call thee to the chase,
Must blow to-night his bugle horn. Had I
The power of Merlin, Goddess! this should be:
And all the stars, fast as the clouds were riven,
Should sally forth, to keep thee company,
Hurrying and sparkling through the clear blue heaven.
But, Cynthia! should to thee the palm be given,
Queen both for beauty and for majesty.
poem_title: With How Sad Steps, O Moon, Thou Climb'st The Sky
explanation: The speaker addresses the moon, commenting on how sad and pale it looks as it rises in the sky. The moon is often seen racing through the clouds like a wood-nymph, but now it seems to be moving slowly and silently. The speaker imagines that unhappy nuns would move at the same pace, constantly sighing. The only way to make the moon move faster would be for the northern wind to blow its bugle horn. If the speaker had the power of Merlin, they would bring forth all the stars to keep the moon company, hurrying and sparkling through the clear blue sky. Ultimately, the speaker declares that the moon is the queen of beauty and majesty.

text:
.   A trouble, not of clouds, or weeping rain,
Nor of the setting sun's pathetic light
Engendered, hangs o'er Eildon's triple height:
Spirits of Power, assembled there, complain
For kindred Power departing from their sight;
poem_title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: The Eildon hills are shrouded in a sense of unease, not caused by natural phenomena, but by the departure of powerful spirits. These spirits have gathered at the triple peak to mourn the loss of one of their own.

text:
While Tweed, best pleased in chanting a blithe strain,
Saddens his voice again, and yet again.
Lift up your hearts, ye Mourners! for the might
Of the whole world's good wishes with him goes;
poem_title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: Tweed is singing a happy tune, but his voice repeatedly becomes sad. He encourages mourners to lift up their hearts because the entire world is sending their positive thoughts and wishes to the person they are grieving for.

text:
Blessings and prayers in nobler retinue
Than sceptred king or laurelled conqueror knows,
Follow this wondrous Potentate. Be true,
Ye winds of ocean, and the midland sea,
Wafting your Charge to soft Parthenope!
poem_title: On The Departure Of Sir Walter Scott From Abbotsford
explanation: The wondrous Potentate is followed by blessings and prayers that are more noble than those received by kings or conquerors. The winds of the ocean and midland sea are urged to be faithful in carrying this Potentate to the city of Parthenope.

Others find the peace they seek, even after enduring the heaviest storms. Even the guiltiest of minds are granted amnesty for their past. The speaker longs for their sentence to be reversed and only wishes to know the worst, feeling as if their heart will burst with the weight of uncertainty.

text:
O weary struggle! silent year
Tell seemingly no doubtful tale;
And yet they leave it short, and fear
And hopes are strong and will prevail.
My calmest faith escapes not pain;
And, feeling that the hope in vain,
I think that he will come again.
explanation: The struggle is exhausting and the passing year appears to offer no clear indication of what is to come. Despite this uncertainty, there is a sense of determination and optimism that prevails. Even in my most peaceful moments, I am still plagued by feelings of discomfort and doubt. However, I cannot help but hold onto the hope that he will return.

text:
ONCE did she hold the gorgeous East in fee;
And was the safeguard of the West: the worth
Of Venice did not fall below her birth,
Venice, the eldest Child of Liberty.
poem_title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: She was once in control of the East and protected the West. Venice was as valuable as her birthright and was the first child of liberty.

poem_title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: The City was pure and open, uncorrupted by deceit or violence. When she joined with another, it had to be the unending Sea.

text:
And what if she had seen those glories fade,
Those titles vanish, and that strength decay;
Yet shall some tribute of regret be paid
When her long life hath reach'd its final day:
Men are we, and must grieve when even the Shade
Of that which once was great is pass'd away.
poem_title: On The Extinction Of The Venetian Republic
explanation: What if the woman had witnessed her former glories, titles, and strength deteriorate over time? Despite this, when her life eventually comes to an end, some form of sorrow will be expressed. As humans, we naturally feel sadness when something that was once great is no longer present, even if it is just a shadow of its former self.

text:
While from the purpling east departs
The star that led the dawn,
Blithe Flora from her couch upstarts,
For May is on the lawn.
A quickening hope, a freshening glee,
Foreran the expected Power,
Whose first-drawn breath, from bush and tree,
Shakes off that pearly shower.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: As the star that guided the dawn disappears from the sky, Flora wakes up excitedly because May has arrived. There is a sense of renewed hope and happiness in the air, as the expected Power emerges and its breath causes a shower of dew to fall from the trees and bushes.

poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The beauty of nature is enhanced by the presence of a feminine force that brings balance to the seasons and adds radiance to the daytime. The sound of chirping birds and buzzing bees creates a joyful atmosphere, while the gentle hum of the breeze adds to the overall sense of contentment. This force is celebrated for its ability to inspire and uplift, bringing a sense of peace and harmony to all who experience it.

text:
Time was, blest Power! when youth and maids
At peep of dawn would rise,
And wander forth, in forest glades
Thy birth to solemnize.
Though mute the song---to grace the rite
Untouched the hawthorn bough,
Thy Spirit triumphs o'er the slight;
Man changes, but not Thou!
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: In the past, there was a time when young people woke up early in the morning to celebrate your birth by going into the forest. Even though they didn't sing or decorate the hawthorn branches, your presence was still felt and revered. While people change over time, you remain constant and powerful.

text:
Thy feathered Lieges bill and wings
In love's disport employ;
Warmed by thy influence, creeping things
Awake to silent joy:
Queen art thou still for each gay plant
Where the slim wild deer roves;
And served in depths where fishes haunt
Their own mysterious groves.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Your birds play with their bills and wings because of love, and even the creeping creatures that are usually silent awaken with joy because of your warmth. You are still the queen of every beautiful plant and are served in the depths where fishes have their own secret places.

text:
Cloud-piercing peak, and trackless heath,
Instinctive homage pay;
Nor wants the dim-lit cave a wreath
To honor thee, sweet May!
Where cities fanned by thy brisk airs
Behold a smokeless sky,
Their puniest flower-pot-nursling dares
To open a bright eye.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: The majestic mountains and vast plains pay tribute to the arrival of spring, as do the humblest of caves adorned with wreaths in your honor, beloved May. Even in the bustling cities, where the clear sky is a result of your refreshing winds, the tiniest of flowers dare to bloom under your guidance.

text:
And if, on this thy natal morn,
The pole, from which thy name
Hath not departed, stands forlorn
Of song and dance and game;
Still from the village-green a vow
Aspires to thee addrest,
Wherever peace is on the brow,
Or love within the breast.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: On your birthday, if the pole that bears your name is devoid of celebrations and merriment, there will still be a pledge made in your honor from the village-green. This vow will be directed towards you, wherever there is tranquility or love.

text:
Yes! where Love nestles thou canst teach
The soul to love the more;
Hearts also shall thy lessons reach
That never loved before.
Stript is the haughty one of pride,
The bashful freed from fear,
While rising, like the ocean-tide,
In flow the joyous year.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Love has the ability to teach and inspire the soul to love even more deeply. Its lessons are not limited to those who have experienced love before, as even the most guarded of hearts can be opened by its power. Pride is stripped away and fear is overcome as the joy of love flows like an ocean tide.

text:
Hush, feeble lyre! weak words refuse
The service to prolong!
To yon exulting thrush the Muse
Entrusts the imperfect song;
His voice shall chant, in accents clear,
Throughout the live-long day,
Till the first silver star appear,
The sovereignty of May.
poem_title: Ode, Composed On A May Morning
explanation: Be silent, weak instrument! Do not attempt to continue the inadequate song. Let the talented thrush take over and sing with clarity all day until the first star of the night appears, proclaiming the reign of May.

text:
.  With an incident in which he was concerned
In the sweet shire of Cardigan,
Not far from pleasant Ivor-hall,
An old Man dwells, a little man,--
'Tis said he once was tall.
For five-and-thirty years he lived
A running huntsman merry;
And still the centre of his cheek
Is red as a ripe cherry.
No man like him the horn could sound,
And hill and valley rang with glee
When Echo bandied, round and round
The halloo of Simon Lee.
In those proud days, he little cared
For husbandry or tillage;
To blither tasks did Simon rouse
The sleepers of the village.
explanation: The poem describes an old man named Simon Lee who lives in the shire of Cardigan. He was once a tall and merry huntsman who was known for his ability to sound the horn. However, he now lives a humble life and is no longer able to hunt due to his old age. Despite this, his cheeks remain rosy and he is remembered fondly by the villagers for his cheerful nature. In his younger days, Simon Lee was not interested in farming and instead preferred to wake up the villagers with his lively spirit.

text:
He all the country could outrun,
Could leave both man and horse behind;
And often, ere the chase was done,
He reeled, and was stone-blind.
And still there's something in the world
At which his heart rejoices;
For when the chiming hounds are out,
He dearly loves their voices!
explanation: He was able to outrun anybody and anything in the country, including horses. However, his love for the chase often caused him to become blind and dizzy. Despite this, he finds joy in the sound of the chiming hounds when they are out on a hunt.

text:
But, oh the heavy change!--bereft
Of health, strength, friends, and kindred, see!
Old Simon to the world is left
In liveried poverty.
His Master's dead--and no one now
Dwells in the Hall of Ivor;
Men, dogs, and horses, all are dead;
He is the sole survivor.
explanation: Simon has undergone a great transformation, losing his health, strength, friends, and family. He is now left alone in the world, living in poverty while wearing a liveried uniform. His master has passed away, and the once lively Hall of Ivor is now empty, with all its inhabitants - men, dogs, and horses - gone. Simon is the only one left, the sole survivor of a bygone era.

text:
And he is lean and he is sick;
His body, dwindled and awry,
Rests upon ankles swoln and thick;
His legs are thin and dry.
One prop he has, and only one,
His wife, an aged woman,
Lives with him, near the waterfall,
Upon the village Common.
explanation: He is thin and unwell, with a body that has become twisted and diminished. His ankles are bloated and his legs are gaunt and dehydrated. He relies on his wife, an elderly woman, as his sole support. The couple lives close to the waterfall on the village Common.

text:
Beside their moss-grown hut of clay,
Not twenty paces from the door,
A scrap of land they have, but they
Are poorest of the poor.
This scrap of land he from the heath
Enclosed when he was stronger;
But what to them avails the land
Which he can till no longer?
explanation: The couple living in the moss-covered clay hut only have a small plot of land located a short distance from their doorstep, yet they are considered to be the most impoverished individuals in the area. The man had previously enclosed the land from the nearby heath when he was in better physical condition, but now that he is unable to cultivate it, the land serves no practical purpose for them.

text:
Oft, working by her Husband's side,
Ruth does what Simon cannot do;
For she, with scanty cause for pride,
Is stouter of the two.
And, though you with your utmost skill
From labour could not wean them,
'Tis little, very little--all
That they can do between them.
explanation: Ruth works alongside her husband, Simon, and is often able to do tasks that he cannot. Despite having little reason to be proud, Ruth is stronger than Simon. However, even with their combined efforts, they are only able to accomplish very little and are unable to be weaned from their labor.

text:
Few months of life has he in store
As he to you will tell,
For still, the more he works, the more
Do his weak ankles swell.
My gentle Reader, I perceive,
How patiently you've waited,
And now I fear that you expect
Some tale will be related.
explanation: The speaker indicates that he has only a few months left to live, and he shares with the reader that despite his efforts, his weak ankles continue to swell. The speaker acknowledges the reader's patience and suggests that the reader may be anticipating a story.

text:
O Reader! had you in your mind
Such stores as silent thought can bring,
O gentle Reader! you would find
A tale in every thing.
What more I have to say is short,
And you must kindly take it:
It is no tale; but, should you think,
Perhaps a tale you'll make it.
explanation: Dear reader, if you were to contemplate the wealth of ideas that can be discovered through introspection, you would be amazed at the stories that abound in every aspect of life. I have little else to add, but I implore you to consider my words with an open mind. Although what I present is not a fully-formed tale, it may yet inspire you to create one of your own.

text:
One summer-day I chanced to see
This old Man doing all he could
To unearth the root of an old tree,
A stump of rotten wood.
The mattock tottered in his hand;
So vain was his endeavour,
That at the root of the old tree
He might have worked for ever.
explanation: On a summer day, I witnessed an old man trying to dig out the root of a decaying tree stump. He struggled with the mattock in his hand and despite his efforts, he was unable to uncover the root. His attempts were in vain and it seemed as though he could have worked at it forever without any success.

text:
"You're overtasked, good Simon Lee,
Give me your tool," to him I said;
And at the word right gladly he
Received my proffered aid.
I struck, and with a single blow
The tangled root I severed,
At which the poor old Man so long
And vainly had endeavoured.
explanation: The speaker, addressing Simon Lee, recognizes that the old man is overburdened with work and offers to help him by taking his tool. Simon Lee accepts the offer with gratitude. The speaker then uses the tool to quickly and easily sever a tangled root that Simon Lee had been struggling with for a long time. The old man is relieved and grateful, and the speaker moves on, having made a small but meaningful difference in Simon Lee's life.

text:
The tears into his eyes were brought,
And thanks and praises seemed to run
So fast out of his heart, I thought
They never would have done.
--I've heard of hearts unkind, kind deeds
With coldness still returning;
Alas! the gratitude of men
Hath oftener left me mourning.
explanation: The man was moved to tears and overflowing with thanks and praise, which seemed to pour out of his heart endlessly. The speaker reflects on the rarity of such genuine gratitude, having experienced more instances of unkindness and ingratitude in their own life. The poem highlights the power and beauty of expressing gratitude and the sadness that can come from not receiving it in return.

poem_title: Alas! What Boots The Long Laborious Quest
explanation: What is the point of working hard to achieve moral wisdom, going through all the ups and downs, or going through difficult tasks to improve ourselves and reach a state of peace where our rationality controls our emotions?

text:
What is it but a vain and curious skill,
If sapient Germany must lie deprest,
Beneath the brutal sword?-Her haughty Schools
Shall blush; and may not we with sorrow say-
A few strong instincts and a few plain rules,
Among the herdsmen of the Alps, have wrought
More for mankind at this unhappy day
Then all the pride of intellect and thought?
poem_title: Alas! What Boots The Long Laborious Quest
explanation: It is pointless and inquisitive to possess knowledge if Germany, a wise nation, must remain oppressed under the barbaric sword. Their proud schools will be ashamed, and sadly, we must admit that a few simple instincts and rules among the Alpine herdsmen have accomplished more for humanity than the arrogance of intellect and ideas.

text:
We talked with open heart, and tongue
Affectionate and true,
A pair of friends, though I was young,
And Matthew seventy-two.
explanation: Matthew and I had a heartfelt and open conversation, speaking honestly and affectionately to each other. Despite our age difference, we were good friends - I being young and Matthew being seventy-two.

text:
We lay beneath a spreading oak,
Beside a mossy seat;
And from the turf a fountain broke
And gurgled at our feet.
explanation: We rested beneath a wide oak tree, next to a seat covered in moss. A fountain sprang from the ground and made a gurgling sound at our feet.

text:
`Now, Matthew! ' said I, `let us match
This water's pleasant tune
With some old border-song, or catch
That suits a summer's noon;
explanation: I suggested to Matthew that we should find a song that complements the pleasant sound of the water. Perhaps an old border-song or a catchy tune that suits the ambiance of a summer's afternoon.

text:
`Or of the church-clock and the chimes
Sing here beneath the shade
That half-mad thing of witty rhymes
Which you last April made! '
explanation: Sing about the church-clock and its chimes while we sit in the shade. Recite the witty rhymes you made last April, the ones that were a bit crazy and full of clever wordplay.

text:
In silence Matthew lay, and eyed
The spring beneath the tree;
And thus the dear old man replied,
The grey-haired man of glee:
explanation: Matthew lay quietly and observed the spring flowing below the tree. Then, the joyful elderly man responded to something, bringing his grey hair to attention.

text:
`No check, no stay, this streamlet fears,
How merrily it goes!
'Twill murmur on a thousand years
And flow as now it flows.
explanation: The streamlet flows freely without any obstacles or hindrances. It moves along joyfully and will continue to do so for many years to come. The streamlet has a continuous murmur that will remain unchanged, just like the way it flows.

text:
`And here, on this delightful day,
I cannot choose but think
How oft, a vigorous man, I lay
Beside this fountain's brink.
explanation: On this beautiful day, I cannot help but remember the times when I, as a strong man, would often rest next to this fountain.

text:
`My eyes are dim with childish tears,
My heart is idly stirred,
For the same sound is in my ears
Which in those days I heard.
explanation: I am filled with emotion and my eyes are filled with tears from my childhood memories. My heart is stirred with a sense of nostalgia because I can hear the same sounds that I used to hear during those days.

text:
`Thus fares it still in our decay:
And yet the wiser mind
Mourns less for what Age takes away,
Than what it leaves behind.
explanation: Even as we age and deteriorate, the more intelligent and thoughtful among us realize that we should be more sorrowful for what remains after our youth and vitality are gone than for what has been lost.

text:
`The blackbird amid leafy trees,
The lark above the hill,
Let loose their carols when they please,
Are quiet when they will.
explanation: The blackbird and lark sing when they want to and are quiet when they choose to be. The blackbird perches on trees covered in leaves and the lark sings above the hill. Both birds sing beautiful melodies, but they do not follow a strict schedule or pattern. They sing freely and without restraint.

text:
`With Nature never do they wage
A foolish strife; they see
A happy youth, and their old age
Is beautiful and free:
explanation: They don't engage in foolish conflict with nature. Instead, they see a joyful youth and their old age as something beautiful and liberating.

text:
`But we are pressed by heavy laws;
And often, glad no more,
We wear a face of joy, because
We have been glad of yore.
explanation: We are burdened by strict laws that limit our ability to express joy freely. As a result, we often pretend to be happy when in reality we are not. We put on a facade of happiness because we have experienced joy in the past and want to hold onto those memories.

text:
`If there be one who need bemoan
His kindred laid in earth,
The household hearts that were his own, -
It is the man of mirth.
explanation: The person who is most likely to feel sorrow for the loss of loved ones is the one who is known for being lighthearted and enjoying life. They may have a hard time coping with the fact that their family members are no longer with them.

text:
`My days, my friend, are almost gone,
My life has been approved,
And many love me; but by none
Am I enough beloved.'
explanation: I am approaching the end of my days, my friend, and I feel content with my life's accomplishments. Despite being loved by many, I do not feel that anyone truly loves me enough.

text:
`Now both himself and me he wrongs,
The man who thus complains!
I live and sing my idle songs
Upon these happy plains:
explanation: He who complains is doing wrong to both himself and me. As I live and sing my carefree songs on these joyful meadows, he is consumed by his grievances.

text:
`And, Matthew, for thy children dead
I'll be a son to thee! '
At this he grasped my hand and said
`Alas! that cannot be.'
explanation: Matthew was grieving for his dead children when someone offered to be a son to him. Matthew sadly declined the offer, and the person grasped his hand in understanding.
We stood up from where we were sitting near the fountain and walked down the gentle slope of the grassy path. Then we smoothly made our way through the wood.

text:
And ere we came to Leonard's Rock
He sang those witty rhymes
About the crazy old church-clock,
And the bewildered chimes.
explanation: Before reaching Leonard's Rock, he entertained us with clever verses about the eccentric church-clock and its confused chimes.

text:
HIGH deeds, O Germans, are to come from you!
Thus in your books the record shall be found,
'A watchword was pronounced, a potent sound--
ARMINIUS!--all the people quaked like dew
Stirred by the breeze; they rose, a Nation, true,
True to herself--the mighty Germany,
She of the Danube and the Northern Sea,
She rose, and off at once the yoke she threw.
explanation: Germans, great accomplishments are expected of you! This is what your books will say; a powerful word was spoken - ARMINIUS! - and the people trembled like dew in the wind. They stood up as a united nation, true to themselves, the mighty Germany, stretching from the Danube to the Northern Sea. They rose up and threw off their oppressors' shackles.

text:
All power was given her in the dreadful trance;
Those new-born Kings she withered like a flame.'
--Woe to them all! but heaviest woe and shame
To that Bavarian who could first advance
His banner in accursed league with France,
First open traitor to the German name!
explanation: In a state of terror, she was granted complete authority; she destroyed the newly crowned kings with ease. The Bavarian leader who allied with France and betrayed Germany was particularly condemned. All of them are cursed and will suffer shame.

text:
'There is a Thorn--it looks so old,
In truth, you'd find it hard to say
How it could ever have been young,
It looks so old and grey.
Not higher than a two years' child
It stands erect, this aged Thorn;
No leaves it has, no prickly points;
It is a mass of knotted joints,
A wretched thing forlorn.
It stands erect, and like a stone
With lichens is it overgrown.
explanation: The poem describes an old, thorny-looking plant that appears to be ancient due to its aged and grey appearance. Despite its small size, it stands tall, but lacks leaves and thorns, instead being a mass of knotted joints. It is described as a pitiful and wretched thing, covered in lichens and resembling a stone.

text:
'Like rock or stone, it is o'ergrown,
With lichens to the very top,
And hung with heavy tufts of moss,
A melancholy crop:
Up from the earth these mosses creep,
And this poor Thorn they clasp it round
So close, you'd say that they are bent
With plain and manifest intent
To drag it to the ground;
And all have joined in one endeavour
To bury this poor Thorn for ever.
explanation: The Thorn is covered in lichens and moss that reach all the way to the top, making it appear bleak and mournful. The heavy tufts of moss are so abundant that they seem to be trying to pull the Thorn down towards the earth. The mosses have united with a sole purpose to completely bury the Thorn forever.

text:
'High on a mountain's highest ridge,
Where oft the stormy winter gale
Cuts like a scythe, while through the clouds
It sweeps from vale to vale;
Not five yards from the mountain path,
This Thorn you on your left espy;
And to the left, three yards beyond,
You see a little muddy pond
Of water--never dry
Though but of compass small, and bare
To thirsty suns and parching air.
explanation: On the highest peak of a mountain, where the harsh winter wind cuts like a blade and moves through the valleys, there stands a thorn bush just five yards from the path. To the left of the bush, three yards away, is a small muddy pond that never dries up despite its small size and exposure to the hot sun and dry air.

text:
'And, close beside this aged Thorn,
There is a fresh and lovely sight,
A beauteous heap, a hill of moss,
Just half a foot in height.
All lovely colours there you see,
All colours that were ever seen;
And mossy network too is there,
As if by hand of lady fair
The work had woven been;
And cups, the darlings of the eye,
So deep is their vermilion dye.
explanation: Next to the old thorn tree, there is a small but beautiful hill of moss, only half a foot tall but with a stunning array of colors. It looks as though it was woven by a skilled lady with its intricate network of moss. The cups on the moss hill are particularly striking with their deep, rich red color. It's a lovely sight to see.

text:
'Ah me! what lovely tints are there
Of olive green and scarlet bright,
In spikes, in branches, and in stars,
Green, red, and pearly white!
This heap of earth o'ergrown with moss,
Which close beside the Thorn you see,
So fresh in all its beauteous dyes,
Is like an infant's grave in size,
As like as like can be:
But never, never any where,
An infant's grave was half so fair.
explanation: The speaker is marveling at the beautiful colors of the surrounding plants and moss, specifically the olive green and bright scarlet shades. They compare the moss-covered heap of earth nearby to an infant's grave in size but note that it is far more beautiful than any actual burial site. The colors on the mossy mound are vibrant and stunning, making it a sight to behold.

text:
'Now would you see this aged Thorn,
This pond, and beauteous hill of moss,
You must take care and choose your time
The mountain when to cross.
For oft there sits between the heap
So like an infant's grave in size,
And that same pond of which I spoke,
A Woman in a scarlet cloak,
And to herself she cries,
'Oh misery! oh misery!
Oh woe is me! oh misery!'
explanation: If you want to see the old thorn tree, the pond, and the lovely mossy hill, you need to carefully choose when to cross the mountain. There is often a woman in a red cloak sitting near a small mound that looks like a baby's grave, and she cries out in distress, saying, "Oh misery! Oh woe is me! Oh misery!"

text:
'At all times of the day and night
This wretched Woman thither goes;
And she is known to every star,
And every wind that blows;
And there, beside the Thorn, she sits
When the blue daylight's in the skies,
And when the whirlwind's on the hill,
Or frosty air is keen and still,
And to herself she cries,
'Oh misery! oh misery!
Oh woe is me! oh misery!''
explanation: This sad and miserable woman can be found at any hour of the day or night always going to the same place. She is so well-known that even the stars and winds recognize her. She sits beside a thorn bush during the day and even during harsh weather conditions, crying out to herself in misery and woe.

text:
'Now wherefore, thus, by day and night,
In rain, in tempest, and in snow,
Thus to the dreary mountain-top
Does this poor Woman go?
And why sits she beside the Thorn
When the blue daylight's in the sky
Or when the whirlwind's on the hill,
Or frosty air is keen and still,
And wherefore does she cry?--
O wherefore? wherefore? tell me why
Does she repeat that doleful cry?'
explanation: Why does this woman persist in traveling to the desolate mountain top day and night, through all kinds of weather? And why does she sit by the thorn bush, crying out in agony whether it's sunny, windy, or frosty? The speaker is perplexed and wants to know the reason behind her sorrowful behavior.

text:
'I cannot tell; I wish I could;
For the true reason no one knows:
But would you gladly view the spot,
The spot to which she goes;
The hillock like an infant's grave,
The pond--and Thorn, so old and grey;
Pass by her door--'tis seldom shut--
And, if you see her in her hut--
Then to the spot away!
I never heard of such as dare
Approach the spot when she is there.'
explanation: The speaker expresses uncertainty about the reason why a woman visits a certain spot. They suggest that no one knows the true reason behind her visits. The woman's destination is described as a hillock resembling an infant's grave, a pond, and an old, grey thorn tree. The speaker advises passing by her door, which is seldom shut, and if one sees her in her hut, to go to the spot immediately. However, the speaker notes that they have never heard of anyone brave enough to approach the spot when the woman is there.

text:
'But wherefore to the mountain-top
Can this unhappy Woman go?
Whatever star is in the skies,
Whatever wind may blow?'
'Full twenty years are past and gone
Since she (her name is Martha Ray)
Gave with a maiden's true good-will
Her company to Stephen Hill;
And she was blithe and gay,
While friends and kindred all approved
Of him whom tenderly she loved.
explanation: The speaker questions why the unhappy woman, Martha Ray, would go to the mountain-top, regardless of the stars or wind. It has been 20 years since Martha gave her company to Stephen Hill, whom she loved and was approved of by her friends and family. Despite her happiness in the past, the speaker wonders what has caused her to become so unhappy that she would seek solace on the mountain-top.

text:
'And they had fixed the wedding day,
The morning that must wed them both;
But Stephen to another Maid
Had sworn another oath;
And, with this other Maid, to church
Unthinking Stephen went--
Poor Martha! on that woeful day
A pang of pitiless dismay
Into her soul was sent;
A fire was kindled in her breast,
Which might not burn itself to rest.
explanation: The wedding day was set for both of them, but Stephen had made a promise to another woman and went to church with her instead. Martha was devastated and felt a deep sense of despair. The pain she felt was so intense that it ignited a fire within her that couldn't be extinguished.

text:
'They say, full six months after this,
While yet the summer leaves were green,
She to the mountain-top would go,
And there was often seen.
What could she seek?--or wish to hide?
Her state to any eye was plain;
She was with child, and she was mad;
Yet often was she sober sad
From her exceeding pain.
O guilty Father--would that death
Had saved him from that breach of faith!
explanation: After six months, when the leaves were still green, she would often go to the mountain-top and be seen there. It was unclear what she was looking for or trying to hide, as her pregnancy and madness were obvious to anyone who saw her. Despite her pain, she would sometimes be sober and sad. The father was deemed guilty and it was wished that death had saved him from betraying her trust.

text:
Sad case for such a brain to hold
Communion with a stirring child!
Sad case, as you may think, for one
Who had a brain so wild!
Last Christmas-eve we talked of this,
And grey-haired Wilfred of the glen
Held that the unborn infant wrought
About its mother's heart, and brought
Her senses back again:
And, when at last her time drew near,
Her looks were calm, her senses clear.
explanation: It is a tragic situation for a brilliant mind to engage with an agitated child. It is indeed a sad case for someone who possesses such an untamed intellect. During the previous Christmas Eve, we discussed this matter, and Wilfred, an elderly man from the valley, suggested that an unborn infant influences its mother's heart and revives her senses. As her due date approached, the mother appeared composed, and her faculties were lucid.

I don't know much more than what I've already said, and I wish I did know more to tell you about what happened to this unfortunate child. No one knows for sure what happened to the child, and if Martha Ray gave birth to a child, whether alive or dead, it cannot be proven or confirmed. However, some people do recall that Martha Ray would often go up the mountain around this time.

text:
'And all that winter, when at night
The wind blew from the mountain-peak,
'Twas worth your while, though in the dark,
The churchyard path to seek:
For many a time and oft were heard
Cries coming from the mountain head:
Some plainly living voices were;
And others, I've heard many swear,
Were voices of the dead:
I cannot think, whate'er they say,
They had to do with Martha Ray.
explanation: During that winter, whenever the wind blew from the mountain peak, it was worth going down the churchyard path at night, even in the dark. Many people heard cries coming from the mountain head, some were believed to be living voices, while others were thought to be voices of the dead. Despite what people say, it is hard to believe that these voices had anything to do with Martha Ray.

text:
'But that she goes to this old Thorn,
The Thorn which I described to you,
And there sits in a scarlet cloak
I will be sworn is true.
For one day with my telescope,
To view the ocean wide and bright,
When to this country first I came,
Ere I had heard of Martha's name,
I climbed the mountain's height:--
A storm came on, and I could see
No object higher than my knee.
explanation: I am certain that she visits the old Thorn tree I previously told you about, and sits there wearing a scarlet cloak. I know this to be true as I once used my telescope to observe the vast ocean when I first arrived in this country and climbed the nearby mountain. During a storm, I could not see anything beyond my knee, but I saw her sitting there in her striking cloak.

text:
''Twas mist and rain, and storm and rain:
No screen, no fence could I discover;
And then the wind! in sooth, it was
A wind full ten times over.
I looked around, I thought I saw
A jutting crag,--and off I ran,
Head-foremost, through the driving rain,
The shelter of the crag to gain;
And, as I am a man,
Instead of jutting crag, I found
A Woman seated on the ground.
explanation: It was misty, rainy, and stormy weather with strong winds. I couldn't find any shelter or protection. I thought I saw a rocky cliff and hurried towards it to take cover from the rain. However, it turned out to be a woman sitting on the ground instead of a cliff.

text:
'I did not speak--I saw her face;
Her face!--it was enough for me;
I turned about and heard her cry,
'Oh misery! oh misery!'
And there she sits, until the moon
Through half the clear blue sky will go;
And, when the little breezes make
The waters of the pond to shake,
As all the country know,
She shudders, and you hear her cry,
'Oh misery! oh misery!''
explanation: The speaker remains silent upon seeing the woman's face, which is enough to evoke an emotional response. The woman cries out in misery and remains seated until the moon has traveled half the sky. When the wind causes ripples in the pond, the woman shudders and cries out again in misery.

text:
'But what's the Thorn? and what the pond?
And what the hill of moss to her?
And what the creeping breeze that comes
The little pond to stir?'
'I cannot tell; but some will say
She hanged her baby on the tree;
Some say she drowned it in the pond,
Which is a little step beyond:
But all and each agree,
The little Babe was buried there,
Beneath that hill of moss so fair.
explanation: The speaker questions the significance of the thorn, pond, hill of moss, and creeping breeze to a woman who is associated with a buried baby. There are various rumors about the woman's actions, with some claiming that she hanged the baby on a tree and others stating that she drowned it in the nearby pond. However, everyone agrees that the baby was buried under the hill of moss. The speaker does not know the truth behind the woman's story, but acknowledges that it remains a source of intrigue and speculation.

text:
'I've heard, the moss is spotted red
With drops of that poor infant's blood;
But kill a new-born infant thus,
I do not think she could!
Some say, if to the pond you go,
And fix on it a steady view,
The shadow of a babe you trace,
A baby and a baby's face,
And that it looks at you;
Whene'er you look on it, 'tis plain
The baby looks at you again.
explanation: There is a belief that the moss is stained red with the blood of an innocent child who was killed. However, it is hard to believe that someone could commit such a heinous act. Some people say that if you stare at a pond, you can see the reflection of a baby's face looking back at you. This image is said to follow your gaze and always look back at you whenever you look at it.

text:
'And some had sworn an oath that she
Should be to public justice brought;
And for the little infant's bones
With spades they would have sought.
But instantly the hill of moss
Before their eyes began to stir!
And, for full fifty yards around,
The grass--it shook upon the ground!
Yet all do still aver
The little Babe lies buried there,
Beneath that hill of moss so fair.
explanation: Some people had vowed to bring the woman to justice and were willing to dig up the ground to find the bones of the infant. However, as they were about to start digging, the moss-covered hill suddenly began to move and the grass around it shook for fifty yards. Despite the strange occurrence, people still believe that the baby's remains are buried under the beautiful hill of moss.

text:
'I cannot tell how this may be,
But plain it is the Thorn is bound
With heavy tufts of moss that strive
To drag it to the ground;
And this I know, full many a time,
When she was on the mountain high,
By day, and in the silent night,
When all the stars shone clear and bright,
That I have heard her cry,
'Oh misery! oh misery!
Oh woe is me! oh misery!''
explanation: The speaker observes that a thorn bush is surrounded by heavy tufts of moss that seem to be pulling it towards the ground. The speaker also notes that they have often heard someone, presumably a woman, crying out in misery when they were on the mountain during the day or night when the stars were visible.

text:
Behold her, single in the field,
Yon solitary Highland Lass!
Reaping and singing by herself;
Stop here, or gently pass!
Alone she cuts and binds the grain,
And sings a melancholy strain;
O listen! for the vale profound
Is overflowing with the sound.
explanation: Look at her, the only one in the field, that Highland girl! She's harvesting and singing all by herself. You can either stop and watch her, or just move on quietly. She's cutting and tying the grain on her own while singing a sad tune. Listen closely, because the valley is filled with the sound of her singing.

text:
No nightingale did ever chaunt
More welcome notes to weary bands
Of travellers in some shady haunt,
Among Arabian sands:
A voice so thrilling ne'er was heard
In spring-time from the cuckoo-bird
Breaking the silence of the seas
Among the farthest Hebrides.
explanation: The song of the nightingale is like a soothing balm to the tired and weary travelers seeking refuge in a shady spot amidst the Arabian sands. Never before has a voice been heard that can match the thrill and delight of the cuckoo-bird's call in the springtime, as it breaks the silence of the seas even in the remote Hebrides.

text:
Will no one tell me what she sings?
Perhaps the plaintive numbers flow
For old, unhappy, far-off things,
And battles long ago:
Or is it some more humble lay,
Familiar matter of today?
Some natural sorrow, loss, or pain,
That has been, and may be again!
explanation: The speaker is asking if anyone knows what the woman is singing about. It could be a sad song about things from the past, like old battles. Or maybe it's a simple song about something familiar from everyday life, like a common sadness or pain that people experience and will continue to experience. The speaker is curious and wants to know more.

The maiden sang tirelessly, regardless of the subject matter. She sang while working and even when leaning over her sickle. I listened attentively, taking the music with me as I climbed the hill, even though her song had already ended.

text:
CLOUDS, lingering yet, extend in solid bars
Through the grey west; and lo! these waters, steeled
By breezeless air to smoothest polish, yield
A vivid repetition of the stars;
poem_title: Composed By The Side Of Grasmere Lake 1806
explanation: The clouds are still present, forming solid bars in the grey western sky. The air is calm, creating a smooth surface on the water that reflects the stars with stunning clarity.

text:
Jove, Venus, and the ruddy crest of Mars
Amid his fellows beauteously revealed
At happy distance from earth's groaning field,
Where ruthless mortals wage incessant wars.
poem_title: Composed By The Side Of Grasmere Lake 1806
explanation: Jupiter, Venus, and Mars are visible in the sky, shining brightly and surrounded by other stars. They are far away from the troubled and war-torn world of Earth, where people fight without pause.

text:
Is it a mirror?--or the nether Sphere
Opening to view the abyss in which she feeds
Her own calm fires?--But list! a voice is near;
Great Pan himself low-whispering through the reeds,
'Be thankful, thou; for, if unholy deeds
Ravage the world, tranquillity is here!'
poem_title: Composed By The Side Of Grasmere Lake 1806
explanation: The speaker questions whether the reflection in front of them is a mirror or a portal to an underworld in which a female figure feeds her own calm fires. Suddenly, a voice is heard, which is revealed to be that of Great Pan whispering through the reeds. He advises the speaker to be thankful because even if the world is ravaged by unholy deeds, tranquillity can still be found in this place.

text:
WITHIN our happy castle there dwelt One
Whom without blame I may not overlook;
For never sun on living creature shone
Who more devout enjoyment with us took:
Here on his hours he hung as on a book,
On his own time here would he float away,
As doth a fly upon a summer brook;
But go tomorrow, or belike today,
Seek for him,---he is fled; and whither none can say.
explanation: In our joyful home lived someone who deserves recognition, as he took great pleasure in our company. He spent his time with us like it was precious, and cherished every moment. However, he has disappeared without a trace, and nobody knows where he has gone.

text:
Thus often would he leave our peaceful home,
And find elsewhere his business or delight;
Out of our Valley's limit did he roam:
Full many a time, upon a stormy night,
His voice came to us from the neighbouring height:
Oft could we see him driving full in view
At mid-day when the sun was shining bright;
What ill was on him, what he had to do,
A mighty wonder bred among our quiet crew.
explanation: He frequently departed from our tranquil abode to pursue his interests or work elsewhere, venturing beyond the borders of our Valley. On many occasions, we heard his voice echoing back to us from nearby peaks during stormy nights. Sometimes we even caught sight of him driving in plain sight on sunny afternoons. Our peaceful community was left wondering what troubles or tasks he faced, arousing great curiosity and amazement among us.

text:
Ah! piteous sight it was to see this Man
When he came back to us, a withered flower,---
Or like a sinful creature, pale and wan.
Down would he sit; and without strength or power
Look at the common grass from hour to hour:
And oftentimes, how long I fear to say,
Where apple-trees in blossom made a bower,
Retired in that sunshiny shade he lay;
And, like a naked Indian, slept himself away.
explanation: It was a pitiful sight to witness the man's return, resembling a withered or sinful being, pale and weak. He would sit down without any energy, gazing at the grass for hours on end. At times, he would seek refuge under the apple trees in full bloom, where he would lie down and sleep, similar to a bare Indian.

The departure of a man from their Valley always amazed the gentle tribe. This man was particularly happy during his stay, unlike any other living creature. Some speculated that he was a lover, while others had negative opinions of him. However, the man was devoted to verse, and his mind was a powerful force that pushed him forward like a storm.

A man with striking grey eyes and a pale face often strolled or rested by the brook or tree. His low-hanging lip and profound forehead gave him a thoughtful appearance. However, some believed that he did not belong in this place.

Heaven forbid! He had a legal right to be noisy and playful like a boy. He would toss his limbs about with joy, like tree branches in a strong wind. And even in his calmer moments, he always had something to keep himself occupied and banish boredom and frustration. He was eager to share his ideas and inventions with others, and many people sought him out for guidance. He was highly skilled and creative, and his contributions were not in vain.

text:
Expedients, too, of simplest sort he tried:
Long blades of grass, plucked round him as he lay,
Made, to his ear attentively applied,
A pipe on which the wind would deftly play;
Glasses he had, that little things display,
The beetle panoplied in gems and gold,
A mailed angel on a battle-day;
The mysteries that cups of flowers enfold,
And all the gorgeous sights which fairies do behold.
explanation: He experimented with basic methods, such as using long grass blades to make a pipe for the wind to play music on when held to his ear. He also had small glasses that revealed details of insects adorned with jewels and gold, as well as images of angels in armor on the battlefield. He explored the secrets hidden within flower cups and the breathtaking sights that fairies witness.

text:
He would entice that other Man to hear
His music, and to view his imagery:
And, sooth, these two were each to the other dear:
No livelier love in such a place could be:
There did they dwellÑfrom earthly labour free,
As happy spirits as were ever seen;
If but a bird, to keep them company,
Or butterfly sate down, they were, I ween,
As pleased as if the same had been a Maiden-queen.
explanation: The speaker describes a man who would lure another man to listen to his music and appreciate his art. The two men had a close and affectionate relationship, and they lived in a state of contentment, free from the struggles of everyday life. Even the presence of a bird or butterfly would bring them joy, as if it were a beautiful queen.

poem_title: Advance – Come Forth From Thy Tyrolean Ground
explanation: Oh, Liberty, emerge from your Tyrolean homeland, a strong-willed and untamed spirit. You are rightfully named the sweet nymph of the mountains, as you traverse through the vast range of the Alps, bouncing like an echo over the snow-capped peaks.

text:
Like Echo, when the hunter train at dawn
Have roused her from her sleep: and forest-lawn,
Cliffs, woods and caves, her viewless steps resound
And babble of her pastime!-On, dread Power!
With such invisible motion speed thy flight,
Through hanging clouds, from craggy height to height,
Through the green vales and through the herdsman's bower-
That all the Alps may gladden in thy might,
Here, there, and in all places at one hour.
poem_title: Advance – Come Forth From Thy Tyrolean Ground
explanation: The speaker compares a powerful entity to Echo, who is awakened by the sound of hunters in the morning and moves through the forest, cliffs, woods, and caves. The speaker urges this power to move with invisible speed, traversing the Alps and bringing joy to all places simultaneously.

text:
SIX thousand veterans practised in war's game,
Tried men, at Killicranky were arrayed
Against an equal host that wore the plaid,
Shepherds and herdsmen.--Like a whirlwind came
The Highlanders, the slaughter spread like flame;
explanation: In the battle of Killicranky, six thousand experienced veterans were pitted against an equally numbered force of Scottish shepherds and herdsmen. However, the Highlanders charged through like a whirlwind, causing widespread slaughter akin to a spreading flame.

text:
And Garry, thundering down his mountain-road,
Was stopped, and could not breathe beneath the load
Of the dead bodies.--'Twas a day of shame
For them whom precept and the pedantry
Of cold mechanic battle do enslave.
explanation: Garry was racing down a mountain road when he suddenly came to a halt. He was weighed down by the dead bodies of his comrades. It was a shameful day for those who followed strict rules and tactics in war, as they became enslaved to the cold, impersonal nature of battle.

text:
O for a single hour of that Dundee,
Who on that day the word of onset gave!
Like conquest would the Men of England see;
And her Foes find a like inglorious grave.
explanation: I wish for just one hour with the man from Dundee who gave the command to start the battle on that day. If he were here, the English would be victorious and their enemies would suffer the same shameful fate.

text:
---'T would be a wildish destiny,
If we, who thus together roam
In a strange land, and far from home,
Were in this place the guests of Chance:
Yet who would stop, or fear to advance,
Though home or shelter he had none,
With such a sky to lead him on?
explanation: It would be an unpredictable fate if we, who are wandering together in a foreign land far from our homes, were merely at the mercy of chance. However, despite lacking a home or shelter, who among us would hesitate to keep moving forward with such a beautiful sky guiding us?

The damp earth was chilly and dim, while the scene behind was foreboding. Moving towards the west felt like a divine fate. The greeting I received had a transcendental quality that made me feel empowered to journey through the radiant region.

text:
The voice was soft, and she who spake
Was walking by her native lake:
The salutation had to me
The very sound of courtesy:
Its power was felt; and while my eye
Was fixed upon the glowing sky,
The echo of the voice enwrought
A human sweetness with the thought
Of travelling through the world that lay
Before me in my endless way.
explanation: The speaker describes a moment when they heard a soft voice while walking by a lake. The greeting was polite and had a strong impact on them. As they gazed at the beautiful sky, the echo of the voice added a pleasant human touch to their thoughts of exploring the world ahead of them.

text:
The minstrels played their Christmas tune
To-night beneath my cottage-eaves;
While, smitten by a lofty moon,
The encircling laurels, thick with leaves,
Gave back a rich and dazzling sheen,
That overpowered their natural green.
explanation: The musicians performed a Christmas melody tonight near my house, and the surrounding laurel trees, which were covered in thick leaves, reflected a bright shine from the moon that overpowered their usual green color.

text:
Through hill and valley every breeze
Had sunk to rest with folded wings:
Keen was the air, but could not freeze,
Nor check, the music of the strings;
So stout and hardy were the band
That scraped the chords with strenuous hand.
explanation: The wind had calmed down and the weather was cold but not freezing. The music played on despite the conditions, with the musicians playing the strings with great effort and strength. The group was strong and determined to continue playing their music, even in the face of adversity.

text:
And who but listened?-till was paid
Respect to every inmate's claim,
The greeting given, the music played
In honour of each household name,
Duly pronounced with lusty call,
And 'Merry Christmas' wished to all.
explanation: Everyone present paid attention until each person was acknowledged and respected. The household names were celebrated with music and a hearty greeting, wishing everyone a Merry Christmas.

text:
SHOUT, for a mighty Victory is won!
On British ground the Invaders are laid low;
The breath of Heaven has drifted them like snow,
And left them lying in the silent sun,
Never to rise again!-the work is done.
explanation: Celebrate, for a great triumph has been achieved! The Invaders have been defeated on British soil and are now vanquished. The power of Heaven has blown them away like snow, leaving them motionless in the sun's warmth. Their defeat is permanent, and the task is complete.

text:
Come forth, ye old men, now in peaceful show
And greet your sons! drums beat and trumpets blow!
Make merry, wives! ye little children, stun
Your grandame's ears with pleasure of your noise!
Clap, infants, clap your hands! Divine must be
That triumph, when the very worst, the pain,
And even the prospect of our brethren slain,
Hath something in it which the heart enjoys:-
In glory will they sleep and endless sanctity.
explanation: Old men, come out and welcome your sons. Let the drums beat and trumpets blow in celebration. Wives should rejoice and children should make noise to please their grandmothers. Even infants should clap their hands. It is a divine triumph when the pain and death of our brothers brings joy to our hearts. They will rest in glory and eternal sanctity.

text:
BENEATH these fruit-tree boughs that shed
Their snow-white blossoms on my head,
With brightest sunshine round me spread
Of spring's unclouded weather,
In this sequestered nook how sweet
To sit upon my orchard-seat!
And birds and flowers once more to greet,
My last year's friends together.
explanation: Sitting in a secluded spot under fruit-tree branches that are shedding their white blossoms on my head, I am surrounded by the bright sunshine of spring's unclouded weather. It's a sweet pleasure to sit on my orchard-seat and be greeted by the birds and flowers, my friends from last year.

text:
One have I marked, the happiest guest
In all this covert of the blest:
Hail to Thee, far above the rest
In joy of voice and pinion!
Thou, Linnet! in thy green array,
Presiding Spirit here today,
Dost lead the revels of the May;
And this is thy dominion.
explanation: I have noticed one particular bird, the happiest guest in this paradise. Above all others, you, the Linnet, are the embodiment of joy with your beautiful voice and swift flight. Today, in your green feathers, you are the leader of the May festivities, and this space belongs to you.

text:
While bird, and butterflies, and flowers,
Make all one band of paramours,
Thou, ranging up and down the bowers,
Art sole in thy employment:
A Life, a Presence like the Air,
Scattering thy gladness without care,
Too blest with any one to pair;
Thyself thy own enjoyment.
explanation: The speaker is observing the natural world around them and notes that birds, butterflies, and flowers all seem to be in love with each other. However, the speaker also notices a solitary creature, possibly a bee or a hummingbird, flitting about the bushes all alone. The speaker describes this creature as having a joyful presence that seems to be effortlessly spread throughout its surroundings. The creature is too content with its own existence to need a partner or mate for companionship.

text:
Amid yon tuft of hazel trees,
That twinkle to the gusty breeze,
Behold him perched in ecstasies,
Yet seeming still to hover;
There! where the flutter of his wings
Upon his back and body flings
Shadows and sunny glimmerings,
That cover him all over.
explanation: Over there, among the clump of hazel trees that sway in the windy gusts, you can see him perched in a state of pure bliss, almost as if he's suspended in mid-air. It's where the beating of his wings throws patterns of light and dark across his body, creating a dazzling display that envelops him completely.

text:
My dazzled sight he oft deceives,
A Brother of the dancing leaves;
Then flits, and from the cottage eaves
Pours forth his song in gushes;
As if by that exulting strain
He mocked and treated with disdain
The voiceless Form he chose to feign,
While fluttering in the bushes.
explanation: He often tricks my eyes with his dancing leaf-like appearance, this bird who sings joyfully from the eaves of cottages before quickly flying away. It's as if he's mocking the silent form he pretends to be, all while fluttering playfully in nearby bushes.

text:
WE can endure that He should waste our lands,
Despoil our temples, and by sword and flame
Return us to the dust from which we came;
Such food a Tyrant's appetite demands:
And we can brook the thought that by his hands
Spain may be overpowered, and he possess,
For his delight, a solemn wilderness
Where all the brave lie dead. But, when of bands
Which he will break for us he dares to speak,
Of benefits, and of a future day
When our enlightened minds shall bless his sway;
'Then', the strained heart of fortitude proves weak;
Our groans, our blushes, our pale cheeks declare
That he has power to inflict what we lack strength to bear.
explanation: We are willing to endure the destruction of our lands and temples, and even our own deaths by the sword and flame, if that is what a tyrant desires. We can accept the idea that Spain may be conquered and turned into a lifeless wasteland where only the dead remain, all for the pleasure of the conqueror. However, if the tyrant speaks of breaking the chains that bind us and promises a better future under his rule, we falter. Our fortitude fails us, and we cannot bear the thought of the suffering that may come from his supposed benefits. Our groans, blushes, and pale cheeks reveal our weakness and lack of strength to endure his power.

text:
.   Oh! pleasant exercise of hope and joy!
For mighty were the auxiliars which then stood
Upon our side, we who were strong in love!
Bliss was it in that dawn to be alive,
But to be young was very heaven!--Oh! times,
In which the meagre, stale, forbidding ways
Of custom, law, and statute, took at once
The attraction of a country in romance!
When Reason seemed the most to assert her rights,
When most intent on making of herself
A prime Enchantress--to assist the work
Which then was going forward in her name!
Not favoured spots alone, but the whole earth,
The beauty wore of promise, that which sets
(As at some moment might not be unfelt
Among the bowers of paradise itself )
The budding rose above the rose full blown.
poem_title: The French Revolution As It Appeared To Enthusiasts
explanation: It was a delightful exercise filled with hope and joy, as we were supported by powerful allies who were also strong in love. It was a blissful experience to be alive during that dawn, and being young was like being in heaven. Those were the times when the dull and uninviting ways of tradition, law, and regulations suddenly became attractive like a romantic country. It was when Reason was most assertive of her authority, and when she was focused on becoming the primary Enchantress to help the progress that was being made in her name. The entire world, not just certain places, was adorned with the beauty of promise, which was like watching a budding rose surpass a fully bloomed one, an experience that could be compared to being in the gardens of paradise.

text:
What temper at the prospect did not wake
To happiness unthought of? The inert
Were roused, and lively natures rapt away!
They who had fed their childhood upon dreams,
The playfellows of fancy, who had made
All powers of swiftness, subtilty, and strength
Their ministers,--who in lordly wise had stirred
Among the grandest objects of the sense,
And dealt with whatsoever they found there
As if they had within some lurking right
To wield it;--they, too, who, of gentle mood,
Had watched all gentle motions, and to these
Had fitted their own thoughts, schemers more wild,
And in the region of their peaceful selves;--
Now was it that both found, the meek and lofty
Did both find, helpers to their heart's desire,
And stuff at hand, plastic as they could wish;
poem_title: The French Revolution As It Appeared To Enthusiasts
explanation: The mere thought of the possibilities that lay ahead awakened a sense of joy in all temperaments. Even those who were typically unenthusiastic about life were stirred into action, while those who had always lived in a world of imagination and fantasy, where they had wielded the powers of speed, agility, and strength, found themselves amidst the grandest objects of the physical world, treating them with a sense of ownership. Even the gentlest souls, who had always found solace in the peace of their own thoughts, now had access to a world of wild ideas and creativity that they could mold to their liking. In short, all found the perfect tools and helpers to bring their hearts' desires to fruition.

text:
Wcre called upon to exercise their skill,
Not in Utopia, subterranean fields,
Or some secreted island, Heaven knows where!
But in the very world, which is the world
Of all of us,--the place where in the end
We find our happiness, or not at all!
poem_title: The French Revolution As It Appeared To Enthusiasts
explanation: Individuals are being asked to utilize their talents and abilities in the real world, not in imaginary or isolated locations. This is the world we all share, where we ultimately discover our joy or lack thereof.

poem_title: Characteristics Of A Child Three Years Old
explanation: She is a loving and easy-to-handle girl, even though she can be a little wild. Her innocence gives her the privilege to make mischievous acts and playful jokes with her arch looks, laughing eyes, and sly tricks. She enjoys provoking mock-chastisement and playing with others, making them her partners in crime.

text:
And, as a faggot sparkles on the hearth,
Not less if unattended and alone
Than when both young and old sit gathered round
And take delight in its activity;
poem_title: Characteristics Of A Child Three Years Old
explanation: The brightness of a fire is not diminished when no one is around to enjoy it. Whether surrounded by people or left to burn alone, the flame still shines just as brightly and brings warmth and comfort to all those who come near. Just like a faggot on the hearth, its sparkle remains constant, regardless of who is there to witness it.

text:
Even so this happy Creature of herself
Is all-sufficient, solitude to her
Is blithe society, who fills the air
With gladness and involuntary songs.
poem_title: Characteristics Of A Child Three Years Old
explanation: Despite her happiness, this content creature is capable of enjoying her own company and finds joy in solitude. She does not require the presence of others to feel fulfilled and instead fills the air with her own songs and exudes a sense of bliss.

text:
Light are her sallies as the tripping fawn's
Forth-startled from the fern where she lay couched;
Unthought-of, unexpected, as the stir
Of the soft breeze ruffling the meadow-flowers,
Or from before it chasing wantonly
The many-coloured images imprest
Upon the bosom of a placid lake.
poem_title: Characteristics Of A Child Three Years Old
explanation: She moves with grace and agility, much like a young deer startled from its resting spot in the ferns. Her movements are effortless and unpredictable, much like the gentle breeze that ruffles the flowers in a meadow or playfully chases the reflections on the surface of a calm lake.

text:
YOUNG ENGLAND--what is then become of Old
Of dear Old England? Think they she is dead,
Dead to the very name? Presumption fed
On empty air! That name will keep its hold
In the true filial bosom's inmost fold
For ever.--The Spirit of Alfred, at the head
Of all who for her rights watched, toiled and bled,
Knows that this prophecy is not too bold.
poem_title: Young England--What Is Then Become Of Old
explanation: The speaker wonders what has happened to Old England and if it is now considered dead. They believe that the name of England will always hold a special place in the hearts of those who consider themselves true patriots. The Spirit of Alfred, who led the fight for England's rights, knows that the belief in Old England's endurance is not unfounded.

text:
What--how! shall she submit in will and deed
To Beardless Boys--an imitative race,
The 'servum pecus' of a Gallic breed?
Dear Mother! if thou 'must' thy steps retrace,
Go where at least meek Innocency dwells;
Let Babes and Sucklings be thy oracles.
poem_title: Young England--What Is Then Become Of Old
explanation: The speaker questions how a woman can submit to young, inexperienced men who are merely imitating the French. He refers to them as a "servum pecus" or a servile herd. The speaker addresses his mother and advises her to seek out innocent and pure individuals to guide her, such as babies and young children.

text:
Amid the smoke of cities did you pass
The time of early youth; and there you learned,
From years of quiet industry, to love
The living Beings by your own fireside,
With such a strong devotion, that your heart
Is slow to meet the sympathies of them
Who look upon the hills with tenderness,
And make dear friendships with the streams and groves.
explanation: As a young person, you spent your early years in urban areas where you developed a deep affection for the living creatures that surrounded you at home. Through years of hard work and dedication, you learned to value the companionship of those closest to you, which has made it difficult for you to bond with others who hold a deep love for nature and its elements.

text:
Yet we, who are transgressors in this kind,
Dwelling retired in our simplicity
Among the woods and fields, we love you well,
Joanna! and I guess, since you have been
So distant from us now for two long years,
That you will gladly listen to discourse,
However trivial, if you thence be taught
That they, with whom you once were happy, talk
Familiarly of you and of old times.
explanation: Although we are sinners living a simple life in the countryside, we still hold a great fondness for Joanna. It has been two years since we last saw her, but we believe she would be happy to hear from us and engage in conversations, no matter how mundane they may seem. We wish to speak of old times and remind her that she is still remembered and loved by those she once shared happy moments with.

text:
While I was seated, now some ten days past,
Beneath those lofty firs, that overtop
Their ancient neighbour, the old steeple-tower,
The Vicar from his gloomy house hard by
Came forth to greet me; and when he had asked,
"How fares Joanna, that wild-hearted Maid!
And when will she return to us?" he paused;
explanation: Ten days ago, I was sitting under tall fir trees next to the old steeple-tower when the Vicar came out of his dark house nearby to greet me. He asked about Joanna, a wild-hearted girl, and when she would come back to the village.

text:
And, after short exchange of village news,
