explanation: This book is unsophisticated and lacks beauty or eloquence. Why would it dare to present itself to my Lady? However, it must have a sense of her kindness since her actions constantly prove her to be the best person alive.

text:
Alas, poor Book! for thy unworthiness,
To show to her some pleasant meanings writ
In winning words, since through her gentiless,
Thee she accepts as for her service fit!
Oh! it repents me I have neither wit
Nor leisure unto thee more worth to give;
For of all good she is the best alive.
poem_title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Oh dear Book, I am sorry that you are not deserving enough to convey pleasant ideas to her through your enchanting words. She accepts you as a useful tool, but I regret that I am unable to provide you with more valuable content due to my lack of wit and time. She is the best person alive, and I wish I could offer her more through you.

text:
Beseech her meekly with all lowliness,
Though I be far from her I reverence,
To think upon my truth and stedfastness,
And to abridge my sorrow's violence,
Caused by the wish, as knows your sapience,
She of her liking proof to me would give;
For of all good she is the best alive.
poem_title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: Humbly plead with her, even though I am distant, to consider my loyalty and reduce the intensity of my sadness caused by hoping she would demonstrate her affection for me. You understand that if she would show me her fondness, it would bring me great joy, and she is the finest person I know.

text:
Pleasure's Aurora, Day of gladsomeness!
Luna by night, with heavenly influence
Illumined! root of beauty and goodnesse,
Write, and allay, by your beneficence,
My sighs breathed forth in silence,-comfort give!
Since of all good, you are the best alive.
poem_title: From The Cuckoo And The Nightingale
explanation: This verse is an ode to the pleasures of life, and the beauty and goodness that come with them. It invokes the celestial bodies of the sun and moon as symbols of these pleasures, and asks for comfort and solace in times of sorrow. The author acknowledges that these pleasures are the best things in life, and thanks them for their continued presence.

text:
O BLITHE New-comer! I have heard,
I hear thee and rejoice.
O Cuckoo! Shall I call thee Bird,
Or but a wandering Voice?
explanation: Oh joyful newcomer, I have heard your call and it brings me great delight. Oh Cuckoo, should I refer to you as a bird or simply a wandering voice?

text:
While I am lying on the grass
Thy twofold shout I hear,
From hill to hill it seems to pass,
At once far off, and near.
explanation: As I lay on the grass, I could hear your shout echoing through the hills, seeming to come from both far away and close by at the same time.

text:
Though babbling only to the Vale,
Of Sunshine and of flowers,
Thou bringest unto me a tale
Of visionary hours.
explanation: Although you only speak to the valley about the beauty of the sun and flowers, you bring me a story of magical moments.

text:
Thrice welcome, darling of the Spring!
Even yet thou art to me
No bird, but an invisible thing,
A voice, a mystery;
explanation: Oh how delightful it is to welcome you, beloved symbol of the season of Spring! However, to me, you are not just a bird, but an intangible entity, a voice, an enigma that is yet to be fully understood.

text:
The same whom in my school-boy days
I listened to; that Cry
Which made me look a thousand ways
In bush, and tree, and sky.
explanation: In my childhood, I listened to the same cry that made me look around in wonder at the world around me. It was a cry that drew my attention to every bush, tree, and sky.
I searched for you many times, wandering through the woods and fields, but you remained elusive, a desire and a passion that I yearned for but never found.

text:
And I can listen to thee yet;
Can lie upon the plain
And listen, till I do beget
That golden time again.
explanation: I can still listen to you and lie down on the ground to listen until I am able to experience that wonderful time again.

text:
O blessed Bird! the earth we pace
Again appears to be
An unsubstantial, faery place;
That is fit home for Thee!
explanation: Oh lucky bird! As we walk on this earth, it seems once again like a magical and dreamlike realm, a perfect habitat for you.

text:
WHAT need of clamorous bells, or ribands gay,
These humble nuptials to proclaim or grace?
Angels of love, look down upon the place;
Shed on the chosen vale a sun-bright day!
Yet no proud gladness would the Bride display
Even for such promise:--serious is her face,
Modest her mien; and she, whose thoughts keep pace
With gentleness, in that becoming way
Will thank you. Faultless does the Maid appear;
poem_title: Composed On The Eve Of The Marriage Of A Friend In The Vale Of Grasmere
explanation: Why use loud bells or fancy decorations to celebrate this simple wedding? Let the angels of love bless this humble spot with a bright day. The bride is not boastful or showy, but serious and modest. She expresses gratitude in a gentle manner, true to her kind nature. The maid looks perfect, faultless in her appearance.

text:
No disproportion in her soul, no strife:
But, when the closer view of wedded life
Hath shown that nothing human can be clear
From frailty, for that insight may the Wife
To her indulgent Lord become more dear.
poem_title: Composed On The Eve Of The Marriage Of A Friend In The Vale Of Grasmere
explanation: The woman's soul is free of imbalance and conflict, but as she experiences the realities of marriage and the imperfections of humanity, she may develop a deeper appreciation and affection for her husband's leniency and understanding.

text:
'Begone, thou fond presumptuous Elf,'
Exclaimed an angry Voice,
'Nor dare to thrust thy foolish self
Between me and my choice!'
A small Cascade fresh swoln with snows
Thus threatened a poor Briar-rose,
That, all bespattered with his foam,
And dancing high and dancing low,
Was living, as a child might know,
In an unhappy home.
explanation: An angry voice commanded a presumptuous elf to leave and not interfere with their decisions. The elf was dancing around a small cascade that had swollen with snow, and was threatening a poor briar-rose that was covered in foam. The rose was living in an unhappy home and the elf was warned to leave it alone.

text:
'Dost thou presume my course to block?
Off, off! or, puny Thing!
I'll hurl thee headlong with the rock
To which thy fibres cling.'
The Flood was tyrannous and strong;
The patient Briar suffered long,
Nor did he utter groan or sigh,
Hoping the danger would be past;
But, seeing no relief, at last,
He ventured to reply.
explanation: The speaker warns someone not to get in their way or they will be thrown off a rock. The flood is powerful and oppressive while the briar is patient and endures the danger silently. Eventually, the briar speaks up when there seems to be no end to the danger in sight.

text:
'Ah!' said the Briar, 'blame me not;
Why should we dwell in strife?
We who in this sequestered spot
Once lived a happy life!
You stirred me on my rocky bed--
What pleasure through my veins you spread
The summer long, from day to day,
My leaves you freshened and bedewed;
Nor was it common gratitude
That did your cares repay.
explanation: The Briar expressed its discontent with the conflict, asking not to be blamed. The Briar and the speaker had previously lived a happy life in their secluded area. The speaker had previously provided care to the Briar, and in return, the Briar had been revitalized. The Briar emphasizes that it was not merely out of gratitude that it benefited from the speaker's care.

text:
'When spring came on with bud and bell,
Among these rocks did I
Before you hang my wreaths to tell
That gentle days were nigh!
And in the sultry summer hours,
I sheltered you with leaves and flowers;
And in my leaves--now shed and gone,
The linnet lodged, and for us two
Chanted his pretty songs, when you
Had little voice or none.
explanation: I hung my wreaths among the rocks to signal the arrival of spring and the approach of gentle days. During the hot summer, I provided shelter with leaves and flowers, while the linnet nested in my foliage and sang sweet songs for us when you were unable to. Despite my leaves now being gone, I have memories of the times we shared together.

text:
'But now proud thoughts are in your breast--
What grief is mine you see,
Ah! would you think, even yet how blest
Together we might be!
Though of both leaf and flower bereft,
Some ornaments to me are left--
Rich store of scarlet hips is mine,
With which I, in my humble way,
Would deck you many a winter day,
A happy Eglantine!'
explanation: The speaker expresses their sadness over the proud thoughts of their loved one, as they believe they could still be happy together. Despite being stripped of their leaves and flowers, the speaker still possesses scarlet hips that they would use to decorate their loved one throughout the winter. The speaker refers to themselves as a happy Eglantine.

The speaker cannot recount any further words spoken by the person they were with. A loud and fast-moving stream in a rocky valley drowned out any other sounds. The briar shook and the speaker is afraid that these were the last words they will hear from their companion.

text:
HERE, on our native soil, we breathe once more.
The cock that crows, the smoke that curls, that sound
Of bells; those boys who in yon meadow-ground
In white-sleeved shirts are playing; and the roar
Of the waves breaking on the chalky shore;--
All, all are English. Oft have I looked round
With joy in Kent's green vales; but never found
Myself so satisfied in heart before.
poem_title: Composed In The Valley Near Dover, On The Day Of Landing
explanation: Being back on home turf, we feel a sense of relief. The sounds of familiar things such as the cockerel's crow, the smoke rising from chimneys, the bells ringing, and the boys playing in the meadow in their white shirts, all signify that we are back in England. Even the sound of the waves crashing against the chalky shore is a reminder of our homeland. We have often admired the beauty of Kent's green fields, but this time the feeling of contentment in our hearts is stronger than ever before.

text:
Europe is yet in bonds; but let that pass,
Thought for another moment. Thou art free,
My Country! and 'tis joy enough and pride
For one hour's perfect bliss, to tread the grass
Of England once again, and hear and see,
With such a dear Companion at my side.
poem_title: Composed In The Valley Near Dover, On The Day Of Landing
explanation: Although Europe is currently constrained, the speaker urges the reader to momentarily ignore this fact. The speaker then declares that their country, England, is free and this brings them immense joy and pride. They express their happiness at being able to walk on the grass of England once again and to hear and see everything with their beloved companion by their side.

text:
BENEATH yon eastern ridge, the craggy bound,
Rugged and high, of Charnwood's forest ground
Stand yet, but, Stranger! hidden from thy view,
The ivied Ruins of forlorn GRACE DIEU;
poem_title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: On the eastern ridge lies the rocky boundary of Charnwood's forest ground, with the hidden ruins of Grace Dieu, covered in ivy, remaining unseen by the stranger's eye.

text:
Erst a religious House, which day and night
With hymns resounded, and the chanted rite:
And when those rites had ceased, the Spot gave birth
To honourable Men of various worth:
There, on the margin of a streamlet wild,
Did Francis Beaumont sport, an eager child;
poem_title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: The location was once a religious institution where hymns were sung and rituals were performed around the clock. After the religious activities ceased, the area became a breeding ground for individuals of different backgrounds and social statuses. Francis Beaumont, as a young boy, played along the banks of a wild stream in this area.

text:
There, under shadow of the neighbouring rocks,
Sang youthful tales of shepherds and their flocks;
Unconscious prelude to heroic themes,
Heart-breaking tears, and melancholy dreams
Of slighted love, and scorn, and jealous rage,
With which his genius shook the buskined stage.
poem_title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: The speaker describes a young man singing stories of shepherds and their flocks in the shadow of nearby rocks. These stories are a precursor to more intense themes of heartbreak, jealousy, and tragedy that the young man's talent will eventually bring to the stage.

text:
Communities are lost, and Empires die,
And things of holy use unhallowed lie;
They perish;--but the Intellect can raise,
From airy words alone, a Pile that ne'er decays.
poem_title: Inscriptions For A Seat In The Groves Of Coleorton
explanation: Communities and Empires crumble, and sacred objects are desecrated, leading to their destruction. However, the power of the human mind can create a lasting monument through the use of language and ideas that withstand the test of time. Such structures built in the mind can never be destroyed and serve as a testament to the strength of human intellect.

text:
Yet are they here the same unbroken knot
Of human Beings, in the self-same spot!
Men, women, children, yea the frame
Of the whole spectacle the same!
Only their fire seems bolder, yielding light,
Now deep and red, the colouring of night;
That on their Gipsy-faces falls,
Their bed of straw and blanket-walls.
explanation: The group of human beings remains unbroken and in the same location, including men, women, and children. The only noticeable difference is their fire, which appears bolder and gives off a deeper red light, coloring the night. This light falls on their faces and their makeshift bed of straw and blanket walls.

text:
--Twelve hours, twelve bounteous hours are gone, while I
Have been a traveller under open sky,
Much witnessing of change and cheer,
Yet as I left I find them here!
The weary Sun betook himself to rest;--
Then issued Vesper from the fulgent west,
Outshining like a visible God
The glorious path in which he trod.
explanation: I have spent twelve hours travelling under the open sky, witnessing many changes and cheerful moments. However, as I leave, I realize that these moments are still present. The tired sun has set and Vesper has emerged from the bright west, shining like a god and illuminating the path he walks on.

text:
And now, ascending, after one dark hour
And one night's diminution of her power,
Behold the mighty Moon! this way
She looks as if at them--but they
Regard not her:--oh better wrong and strife
(By nature transient) than this torpid life;
explanation: After a dark hour and a night of reduced power, the Moon now rises in all her magnificence. She appears to be looking down on the world, but the people below pay her no attention. The speaker suggests that it is better to experience wrong and conflict, which are only temporary, than to live a stagnant and uneventful life.

text:
Life which the very stars reprove
As on their silent tasks they move!
Yet, witness all that stirs in heaven or earth!
In scorn I speak not;--they are what their birth
And breeding suffer them to be;
Wild outcasts of society!
explanation: Life is being criticized by the stars as they carry out their duties in silence. Everything that moves in either heaven or earth bears witness to this fact. However, I do not say this in contempt; they are simply a product of their upbringing and circumstances. They are like social outcasts, wild and untamed.

text:
WE had a female Passenger who came
From Calais with us, spotless in array,--
A white-robed Negro, like a lady gay,
Yet downcast as a woman fearing blame;
explanation: On our journey from Calais, we were accompanied by a female passenger who was immaculately dressed. She was a black woman dressed in white, appearing as a happy lady, but her demeanor suggested that she was afraid of being judged.

text:
Meek, destitute, as seemed, of hope or aim
She sate, from notice turning not away,
But on all proffered intercourse did lay
A weight of languid speech, or to the same
No sign of answer made by word or face:
Yet still her eyes retained their tropic fire,
That, burning independent of the mind,
Joined with the lustre of her rich attire
To mock the Outcast.--O ye Heavens, be kind!
And feel, thou Earth, for this afflicted Race!
explanation: The woman appeared meek and destitute, lacking hope or purpose. She sat without turning away from any offered interaction, but responded with a heavy, lethargic speech or no response at all. Despite this, her eyes still burned with a fierce passion, independent of her mind, and shone brightly with the richness of her clothing. The speaker calls upon the heavens and the earth to have compassion and kindness towards this suffering group of people.

text:
CALM is all nature as a resting wheel.
The kine are couched upon the dewy grass;
The horse alone, seen dimly as I pass,
Is cropping audibly his later meal:
Dark is the ground; a slumber seems to steal
O'er vale, and mountain, and the starless sky.
explanation: Everything in nature is peaceful and still, like a wheel that has stopped moving. Cows are resting on the damp grass, while the only sound audible is the horse munching on his food. The ground is dark and a sense of sleepiness seems to have taken over the valleys, mountains and even the sky, which is devoid of stars.

text:
Now, in this blank of things, a harmony,
Home-felt, and home-created, comes to heal
That grief for which the senses still supply
Fresh food; for only then, when memory
Is hushed, am I at rest. My Friends! restrain
Those busy cares that would allay my pain;
Oh! leave me to myself, nor let me feel
The officious touch that makes me droop again.
explanation: In the midst of emptiness, a sense of comfort and peace emerges, born from the familiarity and warmth of home. This serves as a remedy for the lingering pain that is continually fueled by the senses, only subsiding when memory is silenced. The speaker implores their friends to refrain from attempting to ease their suffering through busy distractions or unwanted physical contact, as it only serves to exacerbate their distress.

text:
THERE 's not a nook within this solemn Pass,
But were an apt confessional for one
Taught by his summer spent, his autumn gone,
That Life is but a tale of morning grass
Wither'd at eve. From scenes of art which chase
That thought away, turn, and with watchful eyes
Feed it 'mid Nature's old felicities,
Rocks, rivers, and smooth lakes more clear than glass
Untouch'd, unbreathed upon. Thrice happy quest,
If from a golden perch of aspen spray
(October's workmanship to rival May)
The pensive warbler of the ruddy breast
That moral sweeten by a heaven-taught lay,
Lulling the year, with all its cares, to rest!
explanation: The speaker reflects on the transience of life, seeing in the natural world an unwavering truth. They suggest that art can distract from this reality, but the natural world brings clarity. The speaker longs to find peace in nature, particularly in the beauty of rocks, rivers, and clear lakes. They hope to hear the song of a bird, which could provide a moral lesson and ease the burdens of the passing year. The poem emphasizes the importance of finding solace and truth in the natural world, particularly as a respite from the distractions of modern life.

text:
WHILE flowing rivers yield a blameless sport,
Shall live the name of Walton: Sage benign!
Whose pen, the mysteries of the rod and line
Unfolding, did not fruitlessly exhort
To reverend watching of each still report
That Nature utters from her rural shrine.
poem_title: Written Upon A Blank Leaf In
explanation: The name of Walton will forever be associated with the peaceful and blameless activity of fishing in flowing rivers. He was a wise and kind scholar who shared his knowledge of fishing through his writing, encouraging others to pay attention to the quiet secrets of nature that can be heard from the countryside. His teachings were not in vain, as many have taken up his philosophy and enjoyed the tranquility of fishing.

text:
Meek, nobly versed in simple discipline,
He found the longest summer day too short,
To his loved pastime given by sedgy Lee,
Or down the tempting maze of Shawford brook--
Fairer than life itself, in this sweet Book,
The cowslip-bank and shady willow-tree;
And the fresh meads--where flowed, from every nook
Of his full bosom, gladsome Piety!
poem_title: Written Upon A Blank Leaf In
explanation: The subject of the poem is a humble and virtuous man who finds great joy in spending time outdoors, particularly at the Sedgy Lee and Shawford brook. He cherishes the natural beauty of the cowslip-bank, willow trees, and meadows, and his heart overflows with happiness and piety. The longest summer day is not enough for him to fully indulge in his beloved pastime.

text:
IF Nature, for a favourite child,
In thee hath tempered so her clay,
That every hour thy heart runs wild,
Yet never once doth go astray,
explanation: Nature has crafted the speaker in a way that causes their heart to be constantly passionate and energetic, yet they never lose their way. This implies that the speaker is able to maintain a sense of direction and purpose despite their wild nature.

text:
Read o'er these lines; and then review
This tablet, that thus humbly rears
In such diversity of hue
Its history of two hundred years.
explanation: Take a look at these words and then examine this humble tablet that displays its two hundred year history in a variety of colors.

text:
--When through this little wreck of fame,
Cipher and syllable! thine eye
Has travelled down to Matthew's name,
Pause with no common sympathy.
explanation: As you read through the remains of what was once a celebrated reputation, take a moment to stop and feel a deep connection when you come across the name Matthew. Don't just skim over it with disinterest, but truly take a moment to empathize with the person behind the name.

text:
And, if a sleeping tear should wake,
Then be it neither checked nor stayed:
For Matthew a request I make
Which for himself he had not made.
explanation: If a tear falls from my eyes while I sleep, don't stop it from falling. This is my request to Matthew, something I wouldn't have asked for myself.

text:
Poor Matthew, all his frolics o'er,
Is silent as a standing pool;
Far from the chimney's merry roar,
And murmur of the village school.
explanation: Matthew is no longer happy and carefree; he is now quiet and still, like a stagnant pool. He is far away from the warmth and liveliness of the fireplace, as well as the sounds of children learning in the village school.

text:
The sighs which Matthew heaved were sighs
Of one tired out with fun and madness;
The tears which came to Matthew's eyes
Were tears of light, the dew of gladness.
explanation: Matthew was exhausted from all the fun and craziness he had experienced, as shown by the sighs he let out. However, the tears that welled up in his eyes were not tears of sadness, but rather tears of joy and happiness, like the gentle dew that forms in the morning.

text:
Yet, sometimes, when the secret cup
Of still and serious thought went round,
It seemed as if he drank it up--
He felt with spirit so profound.
explanation: Sometimes, during moments of introspection, it appeared that the speaker fully immersed himself in his thoughts. He felt deeply connected to his inner being and experienced a heightened sense of spirituality.

text:
--Thou soul of God's best earthly mould!
Thou happy Soul! and can it be
That these two words of glittering gold
Are all that must remain of thee?
explanation: Oh, soul formed in God's image, how fortunate you are! Is it true that only these two words of gold are all that is left of you?

text:
YES! thou art fair, yet be not moved
To scorn the declaration,
That sometimes I in thee have loved
My fancy's own creation.
poem_title: Yes! Thou Art Fair, Yet Be Not Moved
explanation: Although you are beautiful, please do not dismiss the fact that I have on occasion fallen in love with the image of you that my imagination has created.

text:
Imagination needs must stir;
Dear Maid, this truth believe,
Minds that have nothing to confer
Find little to perceive.
poem_title: Yes! Thou Art Fair, Yet Be Not Moved
explanation: Believe it or not, imagination must be active in order for one to perceive things. Those who have empty minds end up with little to perceive.

text:
Be pleased that nature made thee fit
To feed my heart's devotion,
By laws to which all Forms submit
In sky, air, earth, and ocean.
poem_title: Yes! Thou Art Fair, Yet Be Not Moved
explanation: Nature has made you suitable to satisfy the love that resides in my heart, through the laws that all forms obey in the various elements of the world such as the sky, air, earth, and ocean.

text:
SAY, what is Honour?--'Tis the finest sense
Of 'justice' which the human mind can frame,
Intent each lurking frailty to disclaim,
And guard the way of life from all offence
Suffered or done. When lawless violence
Invades a Realm, so pressed that in the scale
Of perilous war her weightiest armies fail,
Honour is hopeful elevation,--whence
Glory, and triumph. Yet with politic skill
Endangered States may yield to terms unjust;
poem_title: Say, What Is Honour?--‘tis The Finest Sense
explanation: Honour can be defined as the strongest belief in justice that a person can conceive of in order to reject any hidden weaknesses, and to protect the path of life from any harm or wrongdoing. It is a hopeful elevation that is gained when lawless violence invades a kingdom and its armies fail. It leads to glory and triumph. However, endangered states might compromise their value of honour and yield to unjust terms with political skill.

text:
Stoop their proud heads, but not unto the dust--
A Foe's most favourite purpose to fulfil:
Happy occasions oft by self-mistrust
Are forfeited; but infamy doth kill.
poem_title: Say, What Is Honour?--‘tis The Finest Sense
explanation: Do not let your enemies bring you down completely, but also don't become too proud. Often times, people miss out on good opportunities because they doubt themselves, but at the same time, being remembered for infamy can be just as damaging.

poem_title: Call Not The Royal Swede Unfortunate
explanation: Do not consider the Swedish monarch unlucky, as he never submitted to Fortune, ignored fear, resisted temptation, and lost his royal title and position by his own decision, not by chance. He remains alive, cherished by his own soul.

text:
And hence, wherever virtue is revered,
He sits a more exalted Potentate,
Throned in the hearts of men. Should Heaven ordain
That this great Servant of a righteous cause
Must still have sad or vexing thoughts to endure,
Yet may a sympathising spirit pause,
Admonished by these truths, and quench all pain
In thankful joy and gratulation pure.
poem_title: Call Not The Royal Swede Unfortunate
explanation: Wherever virtue is respected, it holds a higher position and is revered by people. This great servant of a righteous cause may still experience sadness or distress, but those who sympathize with these truths are reminded to overcome any pain with grateful joy and pure celebration.

text:
Is there a power that can sustain and cheer
The captive chieftain, by a tyrant's doom,
Forced to descend into his destined tomb--
A dungeon dark! where he must waste the year,
And lie cut off from all his heart holds dear;
poem_title: Is There A Power That Can Sustain And Cheer
explanation: Is there a force that can provide comfort and encouragement to a captive leader, who has been sentenced to spend time in a dark prison cell, away from all that he loves?

text:
What time his injured country is a stage
Whereon deliberate Valour and the rage
Of righteous Vengeance side by side appear,
Filling from morn to night the heroic scene
With deeds of hope and everlasting praise:--
Say can he think of this with mind serene
And silent fetters? Yes, if visions bright
Shine on his soul, reflected from the days
When he himself was tried in open light.
poem_title: Is There A Power That Can Sustain And Cheer
explanation: When a person sees their country suffering, with brave and vengeful people fighting for justice, it can be difficult to remain calm while being restrained. However, if the person remembers their own past experiences of facing trials and tribulations, they can find peace and hope in their memories. Despite being held captive, they can still reflect on the heroic acts of their fellow countrymen and women and find solace in the knowledge that their country is not alone in the fight for freedom and justice.

text:
METHOUGHT I saw the footsteps of a throne
Which mists and vapours from mine eyes did shroud--
Nor view of who might sit thereon allowed;
But all the steps and ground about were strown
With sights the ruefullest that flesh and bone
Ever put on; a miserable crowd,
Sick, hale, old, young, who cried before that cloud,
'Thou art our king, O Death! to thee we groan.'
poem_title: Methought I Saw The Footsteps Of A Throne
explanation: I had a vision of a throne, but it was hidden from my sight by mist and vapor. I couldn't see who was sitting on it, but all around it were people in the most pitiful state, of all ages and conditions, sick and healthy, old and young. They were crying out to Death, saying that he was their king and that they groaned under his rule.

text:
Those steps I clomb; the mists before me gave
Smooth way; and I beheld the face of one
Sleeping alone within a mossy cave,
With her face up to heaven; that seemed to have
Pleasing remembrance of a thought foregone;
A lovely Beauty in a summer grave!
poem_title: Methought I Saw The Footsteps Of A Throne
explanation: I climbed the steps and the mist cleared before me, revealing a mossy cave where I saw a woman sleeping with her face turned towards the sky. It appeared as though she was remembering something from the past, and she was a beautiful sight to behold, even though she lay in what seemed like a summer grave.

text:
THE embowering rose, the acacia, and the pine,
Will not unwillingly their place resign;
If but the Cedar thrive that near them stands,
Planted by Beaumont's and by 's hands.
poem_title: Inscriptions In The Ground Of Coleorton, The Seat Of Sir George Beaumont, Bart., Leicestershire
explanation: The rose, acacia, and pine trees will gladly make way for the cedar tree if it thrives. This cedar tree was planted by Beaumont and Fletcher.

text:
One wooed the silent Art with studious pains:
These groves have heard the Other's pensive strains;
Devoted thus, their spirits did unite
By interchange of knowledge and delight.
poem_title: Inscriptions In The Ground Of Coleorton, The Seat Of Sir George Beaumont, Bart., Leicestershire
explanation: One person worked hard to master the art of silence, while the other expressed themselves through thoughtful music. Despite their different approaches, they shared a deep connection through their mutual passion and the exchange of ideas and enjoyment.

text:
May Nature's kindliest powers sustain the Tree,
And Love protect it from all injury!
And when its potent branches, wide out-thrown,
Darken the brow of this memorial Stone,
Here may some Painter sit in future days,
Some future Poet meditate his lays;
poem_title: Inscriptions In The Ground Of Coleorton, The Seat Of Sir George Beaumont, Bart., Leicestershire
explanation: May the Tree be nurtured by the gentle forces of nature, and shielded from harm by the power of love. As its branches grow and spread, casting shadows upon the nearby memorial Stone, may artists and writers be inspired by its beauty and find solace in its presence. For generations to come, may this Tree remain a symbol of life and hope, a testament to the enduring power of nature to inspire and uplift the human spirit.

text:
Not mindless of that distant age renowned
When Inspiration hovered o'er this ground,
The haunt of him who sang how spear and shield
In civil conflict met on Bosworth-field;
And of that famous Youth, full soon removed
From earth, perhaps by Shakspeare's self approved,
Fletcher's Associate, Jonson's Friend beloved.
poem_title: Inscriptions In The Ground Of Coleorton, The Seat Of Sir George Beaumont, Bart., Leicestershire
explanation: This passage acknowledges the historical significance of the location where Shakespeare once wrote, and the great works that have been produced there. Specifically, it references the famous play about the Battle of Bosworth Field and the talented writers who worked alongside Shakespeare, including John Fletcher and Ben Jonson. The passage suggests that this location may have been a source of inspiration for these writers and their masterpieces.

text:
JONES! as from Calais southward you and I
Went pacing side by side, this public Way
Streamed with the pomp of a too-credulous day,
When faith was pledged to new-born Liberty:
A homeless sound of joy was in the sky:
From hour to hour the antiquated Earth
Beat like the heart of Man: songs, garlands, mirth,
Banners, and happy faces, far and nigh!
And now, sole register that these things were,
Two solitary greetings have I heard,
'Good-morrow, Citizen!' a hollow word,
As if a dead man spake it! Yet despair
Touches me not, though pensive as a bird
Whose vernal coverts winter hath laid bare.
poem_title: Composed Near Calais, On The Road Leading To Ardres, August 7, 1802
explanation: While walking from Calais towards the south, the speaker (Jones) and his companion witnessed the enthusiastic celebration of Liberty, which was marked by a display of banners, songs, and joyous faces. However, the speaker now reflects on the change in mood, where these celebrations have dwindled, and the only remnants of the past are the two hollow greetings he received. Despite the sense of sadness that prevails, the speaker does not succumb to despair, and instead, he remains reflective and somber, like a bird whose once lush environment has been stripped bare by winter.

text:
FROM the dark chambers of dejection freed,
Spurning the unprofitable yoke of care,
Rise, GILLIES, rise; the gales of youth shall bear
Thy genius forward like a winged steed.
poem_title: From The Dark Chambers Of Dejection Freed
explanation: Gillies is urged to break free from his depressing state and reject the burden of worry that holds him down. Instead, he should rise up and allow the winds of youth to carry his creativity forward like a flying horse.

text:
Though bold Bellerophon (so Jove decreed
In wrath) fell headlong from the fields of air,
Yet a rich guerdon waits on minds that dare,
If aught be in them of immortal seed,
And reason govern that audacious flight
Which heavenward they direct.--Then droop not thou,
Erroneously renewing a sad vow
In the low dell 'mid Roslin's faded grove:
A cheerful life is what the Muses love,
A soaring spirit is their prime delight.
poem_title: From The Dark Chambers Of Dejection Freed
explanation: Bellerophon, though courageous, fell from the sky due to the wrath of Jove. However, those who possess a spark of immortality and the ability to reason in their daring pursuits will reap rich rewards. Therefore, do not despair and renew a sad vow in the Roslin grove. The Muses prefer a cheerful life and a soaring spirit.

text:
AND is it among rude untutored Dales,
There, and there only, that the heart is true?
And, rising to repel or to subdue,
Is it by rocks and woods that man prevails?
Ah no! though Nature's dread protection fails,
There is a bulwark in the soul. This knew
Iberian Burghers when the sword they drew
In Zaragoza, naked to the gales
Of fiercely-breathing war. The truth was felt
By Palafox, and many a brave compeer,
Like him of noble birth and noble mind;
By ladies, meek-eyed women without fear;
And wanderers of the street, to whom is dealt
The bread which without industry they find.
poem_title: And Is It Among Rude Untutored Dales
explanation: Is it only in the wild and uneducated countryside that people have true hearts? Do people only triumph over challenges when faced with rocks and forests? No, the soul itself can be a fortress. The Burghers of Iberia knew this when they fought in Zaragoza, exposed to the harsh winds of war. This truth was also evident to Palafox and other brave individuals, including noble women and even homeless wanderers who survive on the charity of others. Nature may not always protect us, but the strength within ourselves can prevail.

text:
IS it a reed that's shaken by the wind,
Or what is it that ye go forth to see?
Lords, lawyers, statesmen, squires of low degree,
Men known, and men unknown, sick, lame, and blind,
Post forward all, like creatures of one kind,
With first-fruit offerings crowd to bend the knee
In France, before the new-born Majesty.
'Tis ever thus. Ye men of prostrate mind,
A seemly reverence may be paid to power;
But that's a loyal virtue, never sown
In haste, nor springing with a transient shower:
When truth, when sense, when liberty were flown,
What hardship had it been to wait an hour?
Shame on you, feeble Heads, to slavery prone!
explanation: Are you going to see a reed blowing in the wind or something else? People of all ranks, including lords, lawyers, statesmen, and poor people with disabilities, rush forward to offer their first fruits and pay homage to the new French monarch. This is always the case - people with a submissive attitude tend to show respect to those in power, but true loyalty cannot be rushed or forced. Loyalty is a virtue that takes time to cultivate and requires a deep understanding of truth, reason, and liberty. It is shameful that so many people are willing to submit to slavery without a fight.

text:
Why art thou silent! Is thy love a plant
Of such weak fibre that the treacherous air
Of absence withers what was once so fair?
Is there no debt to pay, no boon to grant?
explanation: Why are you not speaking? Is your love so fragile that the mere absence of the other person causes it to wither away? Is there no obligation to fulfill or gift to bestow?

text:
Yet have my thoughts for thee been vigilant,
Bound to thy service with unceasing care--
The mind's least generous wish a mendicant
For nought but what thy happiness could spare.
explanation: My thoughts have been constantly focused on you, and I have been dedicated to ensuring your happiness. Even the most selfish desires of my mind have been humble, only seeking what would benefit you.

text:
Speak!--though this soft warm heart, once free to hold
A thousand tender pleasures, thine and mine,
Be left more desolate, more dreary cold
Than a forsaken bird's-nest fill'd with snow
'Mid its own bush of leafless eglantine--
Speak, that my torturing doubts their end may know!
explanation: Please speak to me, even though my heart, which used to hold countless joys for both of us, now feels empty and cold like a bird's nest filled with snow in the midst of a leafless bush. I need to hear your voice so that I can finally put my doubts and fears to rest.

text:
GRATEFUL is Sleep, my life in stone bound fast;
More grateful still: while wrong and shame shall last,
On me can Time no happier state bestow
Than to be left unconscious of the woe.
poem_title: Michael Angelo In Reply To The Passage Upon His Staute Of Sleeping Night
explanation: Sleep is a source of gratitude for me, as it provides me with a respite from the hardships of life. However, even more grateful than the gift of sleep is the ability to remain unaware of the pain and suffering caused by wrongdoing and shame. No other state of being could bring me greater happiness than to be unconscious of such sorrow.

text:
Ah then, lest you awaken me, speak low.
Grateful is Sleep, more grateful still to be
Of marble; for while shameless wrong and woe
Prevail, 'tis best to neither hear nor see.
poem_title: Michael Angelo In Reply To The Passage Upon His Staute Of Sleeping Night
explanation: If you don't want to disturb my sleep, please speak quietly. Sleep is grateful, and even more so when it feels like it's made of marble. When there is so much shameless wrongdoing and suffering in the world, it's better to not hear or see anything at all.

text:
Then wake me not, I pray you. Hush, speak low.
Come, gentle Sleep, Death's image tho' thou art,
Come share my couch, nor speedily depart;
How sweet thus living without life to lie,
Thus without death how sweet it is to die.
poem_title: Michael Angelo In Reply To The Passage Upon His Staute Of Sleeping Night
explanation: Please don't wake me up, speak quietly. Sleep, even though you resemble death, come and stay with me on my bed. Don't leave quickly. It's pleasant to live like this, without really living, and it's pleasant to die like this, without actually dying.

text:
EMPERORS and Kings, how oft have temples rung
With impious thanksgiving, the Almighty's scorn!
How oft above their altars have been hung
Trophies that led the good and wise to mourn
Triumphant wrong, battle of battle born,
And sorrow that to fruitless sorrow clung!
Now, from Heaven-sanctioned victory, Peace is sprung;
poem_title: Emperors And Kings, How Oft Have Temples Rung
explanation: Throughout history, rulers such as emperors and kings have celebrated their victories in temples with thanksgiving, despite their actions being deemed impious by the Almighty. Trophies of their conquests have been displayed above altars, causing pain and grief for the virtuous and intelligent. These triumphs only led to more suffering and despair. However, with the help of divine intervention, peace has been achieved through victorious battles.

text:
In this firm hour Salvation lifts her horn.
Glory to arms! But, conscious that the nerve
Of popular reason, long mistrusted, freed
Your thrones, ye Powers, from duty fear to swerve!
Be just, be grateful; nor, the oppressor's creed
Reviving, heavier chastisement deserve
Than ever forced unpitied hearts to bleed.
poem_title: Emperors And Kings, How Oft Have Temples Rung
explanation: Salvation is here, and we should celebrate our armed forces. However, we must remember that the people's opinions have played a significant role in freeing us from our duties as rulers. Therefore, we should be fair and thankful, and not allow the oppressive beliefs of the past to resurface. If we fail to do so, we will face a punishment more severe than any that have caused heartbreak and suffering in the past.

text:
FESTIVALS have I seen that were not names:
This is young Buonaparte's natal day,
And his is henceforth an established sway-
Consul for life. With worship France proclaims
Her approbation, and with pomps and games.
explanation: I have witnessed celebrations that lacked a name, but today marks the birth of young Buonaparte and his position as Consul for life is now firmly established. France shows its adoration by declaring its approval and hosting grand festivities.

text:
Heaven grant that other Cities may be gay!
Calais is not: and I have bent my way
To the sea-coast, noting that each man frames
His business as he likes. Far other show
My youth here witnessed, in a prouder time;
explanation: I hope other cities are more lively than Calais. I have traveled to the coast and observed that everyone is going about their own business. When I was young, things were different in Calais and it was a more impressive place.

text:
The senselessness of joy was then sublime!
Happy is he, who, caring not for Pope,
Consul, or King, can sound himself to know
The destiny of Man, and live in hope.
explanation: The beauty of pure happiness is indescribable. One who is content with their own self-worth, regardless of societal hierarchies and politics, is truly fortunate. They have the ability to understand the purpose of humanity and maintain a positive outlook on life.

text:
LOOK now on that Adventurer who hath paid
His vows to Fortune; who, in cruel slight
Of virtuous hope, of liberty, and right,
Hath followed wheresoe'er a way was made
By the blind Goddess,--ruthless, undismayed;
poem_title: Look Now On That Adventurer Who Hath Paid
explanation: Take a moment to observe the adventurer who has devoted himself to the goddess of Fortune, disregarding the values of virtue, freedom, and justice. He has relentlessly pursued any path that she has presented him with, showing no mercy or fear in his actions.

text:
And so hath gained at length a prosperous height,
Round which the elements of worldly might
Beneath his haughty feet, like clouds, are laid.
O joyless power that stands by lawless force!
Curses are 'his' dire portion, scorn, and hate,
Internal darkness and unquiet breath;
And, if old judgments keep their sacred course,
Him from that height shall Heaven precipitate
By violent and ignominious death.
poem_title: Look Now On That Adventurer Who Hath Paid
explanation: The person described has achieved a great deal of success and power, so much so that even powerful worldly forces are beneath them. However, this power has been attained through force rather than lawful means, leading to curses, scorn, hate, and internal turmoil. According to old judgments, this individual will ultimately be brought down from their height of power through a violent and shameful death.

text:
It is not to be thought of that the Flood
Of British freedom, which, to the open sea
Of the world's praise, from dark antiquity
Hath flowed, 'with pomp of waters, unwithstood,'
Roused though it be full often to a mood
Which spurns the check of salutary bands,
That this most famous Stream in bogs and sands
Should perish; and to evil and to good
Be lost for ever. In our halls is hung
Armoury of the invincible Knights of old:
We must be free or die, who speak the tongue
That Shakespeare spake; the faith and morals hold
Which Milton held.-In every thing we are sprung
Of Earth's first blood, have titles manifold.
explanation: The speaker expresses that it is unimaginable for the flood of British freedom, which has flowed since ancient times and gained worldwide recognition, to be lost or forgotten. Although it may sometimes rebel against authority, this famous stream should not be allowed to perish. The speaker draws inspiration from the armoury of the invincible Knights of old that hangs in their halls. They believe that they must remain free or die, as they speak the same language as Shakespeare and hold the same values as Milton. The speaker emphasizes that they are descended from the first humans on Earth and have many titles to their name.

text:
[In the vale of Grasmere, by the side of an old highway
leading to Ambleside, is a gate, which, from time out of
mind, has been called the Wishing-gate, from a belief that
wishes formed or indulged there have a favorable issue.]
explanation: There is a gate in the valley of Grasmere that has been known as the Wishing-gate for a long time. It is located beside an old road that leads to Ambleside. People believe that wishes made or thought of at this gate will come true.

In a perpetually verdant land, HOPE reigns supreme. All abilities that serve the optimistic Queen are self-assured and joyful, and any clouds that may obstruct her path are quickly dispelled. Whenever she focuses her attention on a particular objective, happiness follows closely behind, and the power of imagination makes the journey there an effortless one.

text:
Not such the land of Wishes---there
Dwell fruitless day-dreams, lawless prayer,
And thoughts with things at strife;
Yet how forlorn, should ye depart
Ye superstitions of the heart,
How poor, were human life!
explanation: The land of Wishes is not what it seems - it is a place of unfulfilled dreams, misguided beliefs, and conflicting thoughts. However, if we were to rid ourselves of these superstitions that reside within our hearts, our lives would be lacking and incomplete.

text:
When magic lore abjured its might,
Ye did not forfeit one dear right,
One tender claim abate;
Witness this symbol of your sway,
Surnving near the public way,
The rustic Wishing-gate!
explanation: Despite the loss of the power of magic, you have not lost anything dear or important. This is evidenced by the survival of the Wishing-gate, a symbol of your control and influence that remains standing near the road.
Don't ask if the fairy folk brought good fortune to this place before they left. Don't wonder if a warrior cast a powerful spell here in his quest for glory, or if a saint died here.

text:
Enough that all arouud is fair,
Composed with Nature's finest care,
And in her fondest love---
Peace to embosom and content---
To overawe the turbulent,
The selfish to reprove.
explanation: The surroundings are beautiful, crafted by Nature's loving touch, providing peace and satisfaction. It has the power to calm those who are unruly and correct those who are selfish.

text:
Yea! even the Stranger from afar,
Reclining on this moss-grown bar,
Unknowing, and unknown,
The infection of the ground partakes,
Longing for his Beloved---who maker
All happiness her own.
explanation: Even those who are strangers and far from home can find comfort in the peaceful and mossy surroundings. They may not know anyone or anything about this place, but they too can be affected by its beauty and tranquility. Perhaps they long for a loved one who brings them happiness, just like the way this place brings peace to anyone who visits.

text:
Then why should conscious Spirits fear
The mystic stirrings that are here,
The ancient faith disclaim?
The local Genius ne'er befriends
Desires whose course in folly ends,
Whose just reward is shame.
explanation: There is no reason for self-aware beings to be intimidated by the mysterious movements of the universe or to deny the existence of ancient beliefs. The protective spirit of a certain place does not support reckless desires that lead to foolishness and ultimately dishonor.

text:
Smile if thou wilt, but not in scorn,
If some, by ceaseless pains outworn,
Here crave an easier lot;
If some have thirsted to renew
A broken vow, or bind a true,
With firmer, holier knot.
explanation: Don't mock those who seek a better life after being exhausted by constant struggles. Don't judge those who want to make amends for a broken promise or strengthen a true relationship. Instead, show compassion and understanding towards their efforts.

text:
And not in vain, when thoughts are cast
Upon the irrevocable past,
Some Penitent sincere
May for a worthier future sigh,
While trickles from his downcast eye
No unavailing tear.
explanation: Reflecting on the past can be meaningful if it inspires sincere remorse and a desire for a better future. This can lead to positive change and growth, even if accompanied by tears.

text:
The Worldling, pining to be freed
From turmoil, who would turn or speed
The current of his fate,
Might stop before this favored scene,
At Nature's call, nor blush to lean
Upon the Wishing-gate.
explanation: The person, who is consumed by a desire to escape the chaos in their life and change their destiny, may find solace in this particular location. They may pause and listen to the natural surroundings and not feel ashamed to rely on this spot as a source of hope and comfort.

text:
The Sage, who feels how blind, how weak
Is man, though loth such help to seek,
Yet, passing, here might pause,
And thirst for insight to allay
Misgiving, while the crimson day
In quietness withdraws;
explanation: The wise person, who understands the limitations of humanity and may be hesitant to seek assistance, could stop here and desire knowledge to alleviate any doubts as the day comes to a peaceful end.

text:
Or when the church-clock's knell profound
To Time's first step across the bound
Of midnight makes reply;
Time pressing on with starry crest,
To filial sleep upon the breast
Of dread eternity.
explanation: When the deep sound of the church clock marks the beginning of a new day, Time marches forward with the stars shining above, carrying us towards our eternal rest.

poem_title: It Is No Spirit Who From Heaven Hath Flown
explanation: The figure descending from the heavens is not a spiritual being or a traveler seeking to explore the skies. It is actually Hesperus, identifiable by his shining crown, who serves as the first indication that the sun has set. Despite the brightness of the day, clouds are still present and moving overhead.

text:
A few are near him still--and now the sky,
He hath it to himself--'tis all his own.
O most ambitious Star! an inquest wrought
Within me when I recognised thy light;
poem_title: It Is No Spirit Who From Heaven Hath Flown
explanation: There are a few people near him, but now he has the sky to himself. The speaker addresses a star, calling it the most ambitious. The speaker had an emotional reaction when they recognized the star's light.

text:
A moment I was startled at the sight:
And, while I gazed, there came to me a thought
That I might step beyond my natural race
As thou seem'st now to do; might one day trace
Some ground not mine; and, strong her strength above,
My Soul, an Apparition in the place,
Tread there with steps that no one shall reprove!
poem_title: It Is No Spirit Who From Heaven Hath Flown
explanation: As I was taken aback by what I saw, a thought occurred to me that perhaps I too could surpass my own limitations like the figure before me. I could explore uncharted territories and my soul could transcend its usual boundaries, becoming a specter that could move freely without judgement.

text:
ENGLAND! the time is come when thou should'st wean
Thy heart from its emasculating food;
The truth should now be better understood;
Old things have been unsettled; we have seen
Fair seed-time, better harvest might have been
But for thy trespasses; and, at this day,
If for Greece, Egypt, India, Africa,
Aught good were destined, thou would'st step between.
poem_title: England! The Time Is Come When Thou Should’st Wean
explanation: England, it is time for you to stop relying on things that weaken you. You need to understand the truth and let go of old habits. We have had opportunities for growth, but your mistakes have held us back. Today, if there were good things destined for other countries, you would get in the way. It's time to change your ways and allow progress to happen.

text:
England! all nations in this charge agree:
But worse, more ignorant in love and hate,
Far--far more abject, is thine Enemy:
Therefore the wise pray for thee, though the freight
Of thy offences be a heavy weight:
Oh grief that Earth's best hopes rest all with Thee!
poem_title: England! The Time Is Come When Thou Should’st Wean
explanation: England is universally acknowledged as being in a dire state. However, its enemy is even worse, lacking knowledge in both love and hate and being more submissive. Despite the heavy burden of England's wrongdoings, the wise still pray for its redemption. It is a great sorrow that the future of the world depends on England's actions.

Quickly rotate the quiet wheel! The hour of rest has arrived with the night, bringing relief to tired hands as if by magic. The damp night covers the earth, so turn the wheel quickly and continuously!

text:
Now, beneath the starry sky,
Couch the widely-scattered sheep;--
Ply the pleasant labour, ply!
For the spindle, while they sleep,
Runs with speed more smooth and fine,
Gathering up a trustier line.
explanation: The sheep are scattered and resting under the starry sky. It is a good time to spin wool into thread as the spindle runs smoothly and efficiently while they sleep, resulting in a reliable line. So, the spinner should take advantage of this peaceful moment and continue their work.

text:
Short-lived likings may be bred
By a glance from fickle eyes;
But true love is like the thread
Which the kindly wool supplies,
When the flocks are all at rest
Sleeping on the mountain's breast.
explanation: Temporary infatuations can be sparked by a fleeting look from someone with a changeable disposition. However, genuine love is comparable to the strong and steady thread produced from wool gathered from contented flocks resting peacefully on the mountain.

text:
HOW sweet it is, when mother Fancy rocks
The wayward brain, to saunter through a wood!
An old place, full of many a lovely brood,
Tall trees, green arbours, and ground-flowers in flocks;
poem_title: How Sweet It Is, When Mother Fancy Rocks
explanation: It is delightful to let one's imagination wander through a forest when it is stimulated by fanciful thoughts. The forest is an ancient place that is abundant with a variety of beautiful creatures such as towering trees, lush green bushes, and clusters of wildflowers.

text:
And wild rose tip-toe upon hawthorn stocks,
Like a bold Girl, who plays her agile pranks
At Wakes and Fairs with wandering Mountebanks,--
When she stands cresting the Clown's head, and mocks
The crowd beneath her. Verily I think,
Such place to me is sometimes like a dream
Or map of the whole world: thoughts, link by link,
Enter through ears and eyesight, with such gleam
Of all things, that at last in fear I shrink,
And leap at once from the delicious stream.
poem_title: How Sweet It Is, When Mother Fancy Rocks
explanation: The wild roses delicately balance on the hawthorn branches, resembling a confident girl who enjoys teasing and performing with traveling performers at festivals and fairs. This scene feels almost like a surreal dream or a representation of the entire world, as thoughts and sensations flood the mind through the senses, overwhelming to the point of fear and causing a sudden withdrawal from the immersive experience.

text:
I GRIEVED for Buonaparte, with a vain
And an unthinking grief! The tenderest mood
Of that Man's mind--what can it be? what food
Fed his first hopes? what knowledge could 'he' gain?
'Tis not in battles that from youth we train
The Governor who must be wise and good,
And temper with the sternness of the brain
Thoughts motherly, and meek as womanhood.
explanation: The speaker expresses their sorrow for Napoleon Bonaparte, but acknowledges that their grief is unfounded and thoughtless. They question what kind of person Napoleon was, what inspired his hopes and what he learned. The speaker believes that being a wise and good leader cannot be achieved solely through battles and military training, but requires a balance of strength and tenderness, similar to the qualities of a mother.

text:
Wisdom doth live with children round her knees:
Books, leisure, perfect freedom, and the talk
Man holds with week-day man in the hourly walk
Of the mind's business: these are the degrees
By which true Sway doth mount; this is the stalk
True Power doth grow on; and her rights are these.
explanation: Children are often found in the company of wisdom, surrounded by books, free time, unrestricted freedom, and meaningful discussions with other people. These are the building blocks that lead to true influence and authority, and they are the foundation upon which true power is established. These are the inalienable rights of those who possess true power.

text:
HERE pause: the poet claims at least this praise,
That virtuous Liberty hath been the scope
Of his pure song, which did not shrink from hope
In the worst moment of these evil days;
poem_title: Here Pause: The Poet Claims At Least This Praise
explanation: The poet takes a moment to reflect and claims that his poetry has always aimed to celebrate virtuous Liberty. He has not lost hope even in the darkest moments of the evil times.

text:
From hope, the paramount 'duty' that Heaven lays,
For its own honour, on man's suffering heart.
Never may from our souls one truth depart--
That an accursed thing it is to gaze
On prosperous tyrants with a dazzled eye;
poem_title: Here Pause: The Poet Claims At Least This Praise
explanation: It is the duty of man's suffering heart, bestowed upon him by Heaven, to hold onto hope. We must never forget that it is a cursed act to admire successful oppressors with a blinded mind.

text:
Nor--touched with due abhorrence of 'their' guilt
For whose dire ends tears flow, and blood is spilt,
And justice labours in extremity--
Forget thy weakness, upon which is built,
O wretched man, the throne of tyranny!
poem_title: Here Pause: The Poet Claims At Least This Praise
explanation: Do not forget the guilt of those whose actions bring about tears and bloodshed, causing justice to struggle. However, do not overlook your own weakness, as it is the foundation upon which tyrants build their thrones.

text:
YES! hope may with my strong desire keep pace,
And I be undeluded, unbetrayed;
For if of our affections none finds grace
In sight of Heaven, then, wherefore hath God made
The world which we inhabit? Better plea
Love cannot have, than that in loving thee
Glory to that eternal Peace is paid,
Who such divinity to thee imparts
As hallows and makes pure all gentle hearts.
poem_title: From The Italian Of Michael Angelo
explanation: I am hopeful that my strong desire will align with what is meant for me, and that I won't be led astray. If none of our feelings are accepted by God, then why did He create this world? My love for you is the best argument that there is a divine force that sanctifies and purifies all kind hearts. Through loving you, I am giving glory to that eternal peace that has imbued you with such divinity.

text:
His hope is treacherous only whose love dies
With beauty, which is varying every hour;
But, in chaste hearts uninfluenced by the power
Of outward change, there blooms a deathless flower,
That breathes on earth the air of paradise.
poem_title: From The Italian Of Michael Angelo
explanation: The speaker suggests that hope can be deceptive if it is dependent on external beauty, which is constantly changing. However, there is a pure and enduring love that resides in chaste hearts that is not affected by the fluctuations of the world. This love is like a timeless flower that brings a heavenly essence to the earthly realm.

text:
HAIL Twilight, sovereign of one peaceful hour!
Not dull art Thou as undiscerning Night;
But studious only to remove from sight
Day's mutable distinctions.--Ancient Power!
Thus did the waters gleam, the mountains lower,
To the rude Briton, when, in wolf-skin vest
Here roving wild, he laid him down to rest
On the bare rock, or through a leafy bower
Looked ere his eyes were closed. By him was seen
The self-same Vision which we now behold;
poem_title: Hail, Twilight, Sovereign Of One Peaceful Hour
explanation: Oh Twilight, you rule over a peaceful hour, and you are not boring like the unobservant Night. Your only aim is to hide the changes of the day. You have been around since ancient times, and the early Britons saw the same things that we see now when they looked upon the waters and mountains in the fading light. They too found comfort in your presence as they settled down to rest in the wild.

text:
At thy meek bidding, shadowy Power! brought forth
These mighty barriers, and the gulf between;
The flood, the stars,--a spectacle as old
As the beginning of the heavens and earth!
poem_title: Hail, Twilight, Sovereign Of One Peaceful Hour
explanation: By your humble command, mysterious force, the great obstacles and chasm were created, separating the water from the stars, a sight that has existed since the very dawn of time.

text:
WHILE not a leaf seems faded; while the fields,
With ripening harvest prodigally fair,
In brightest sunshine bask; this nipping air,
Sent from some distant clime where Winter wields
His icy scimitar, a foretaste yields
Of bitter change, and bids the flowers beware;
explanation: Although the leaves on the trees are still green and the crops are flourishing in the sunshine, a chill in the air warns of an impending winter. The cold wind comes from a far-off place where winter reigns with its icy grip, giving a glimpse of the harsh weather to come and cautioning the flowers to prepare for the frost.

text:
And whispers to the silent birds, 'Prepare
Against the threatening foe your trustiest shields.'
For me, who under kindlier laws belong
To Nature's tuneful quire, this rustling dry
Through leaves yet green, and yon crystalline sky,
Announce a season potent to renew,
'Mid frost and snow, the instinctive joys of song,
And nobler cares than listless summer knew.
explanation: The speaker in the poem urges the birds to prepare for battle against an unknown enemy, speaking softly so as not to disturb their peaceful surroundings. The speaker reflects on their own place in nature's choir and finds inspiration in the rustling of dry leaves and the clear sky. They believe that the coming season, despite the cold and snow, will bring a renewed sense of joy and purpose, allowing for the expression of more meaningful songs and thoughts than those of the lazy summer months.

text:
Now that all hearts are glad, all faces bright,
Our aged Sovereign sits, to the ebb and flow
Of states and kingdoms, to their joy or woe,
Insensible. He sits deprived of sight,
And lamentably wrapt in twofold night,
Whom no weak hopes deceived; whose mind ensued,
Through perilous war, with regal fortitude,
Peace that should claim respect from lawless Might.
explanation: The aged monarch, seated amidst the joy and happiness of his subjects, remains unaffected by the ups and downs of other nations and their fortunes. He is blind and lives in a state of darkness, but he is not deluded by false hopes. He bravely led his kingdom through treacherous wars and now desires peace that is respected by all, even those who would use force to achieve their goals.

text:
Dread King of Kings, vouchsafe a ray divine
To his forlorn condition! let thy grace
Upon his inner soul in mercy shine;
Permit his heart to kindle, and to embrace
(Though it were only for a moment's space)
The triumphs of this hour; for they are THINE!
explanation: Oh great and powerful ruler, please grant a glimmer of hope to this desperate soul. Let your mercy shine upon him and allow his heart to feel the joy and success of this moment, even if it is just temporary. All of this belongs to you, the ultimate authority.

text:
"Her divine skill taught me this,
That from every thing I saw
I could some instruction draw,
And raise pleasure to the height
Through the meanest objects sight.
By the murmur of a spring,
Or the least bough's rustelling;
By a Daisy whose leaves spread
Shut when Titan goes to bed;
Or a shady bush or tree;
She could more infuse in me
Than all Nature's beauties can
In some other wiser man.'
G. Wither. * His muse.
explanation: The speaker in the poem explains that he was taught a divine skill by someone who showed him how to find instruction and pleasure in even the most ordinary things. He learned to appreciate the sound of a spring or the rustling of a branch, and even a simple daisy closing at night. This person was able to imbue in him a greater appreciation for nature than some other, wiser men.

text:
IN youth from rock to rock I went,
From hill to hill in discontent
Of pleasure high and turbulent,
Most pleased when most uneasy;
But now my own delights I make,--
My thirst at every rill can slake,
And gladly Nature's love partake,
Of Thee, sweet Daisy!
explanation: When I was young, I used to wander around from rock to rock and hill to hill, feeling unsatisfied and restless even in moments of pleasure. I was most content when I was uneasy. However, now that I am older, I find joy in simpler pleasures, such as drinking from a stream and appreciating nature's beauty, particularly the sweet daisy.

Winter adorns himself with a garland that barely covers his few grey hairs, while Spring brings gentle breezes to clear the clouds so that the sun may shine upon you. You have the rightful ownership of the vast fields of Summer, and even the gloomy Autumn finds delight in your crimson head when you are drenched with rain.

text:
In shoals and bands, a morrice train,
Thou greet'st the traveller in the lane;
Pleased at his greeting thee again;
Yet nothing daunted,
Nor grieved if thou be set at nought:
And oft alone in nooks remote
We meet thee, like a pleasant thought,
When such are wanted.
explanation: You greet travelers in groups and clusters, dancing along the lane. You are happy to receive their greetings in return, but you are not discouraged nor saddened if you are ignored. Sometimes, you can be found alone in far-off corners like a comforting idea when one needs it.

text:
Be violets in their secret mews
The flowers the wanton Zephyrs choose;
Proud be the rose, with rains and dews
Her head impearling,
Thou liv'st with less ambitious aim,
Yet hast not gone without thy fame;
Thou art indeed by many a claim
The Poet's darling.
explanation: Be like violets hidden away in a secret place, the flowers that the playful Zephyrs select. The rose should be proud with droplets of rain and dew adorning her head. You, on the other hand, live with less grandiose aspirations yet have gained recognition. You are indeed beloved by many poets.

text:
If to a rock from rains he fly,
Or, some bright day of April sky,
Imprisoned by hot sunshine lie
Near the green holly,
And wearily at length should fare;
He needs but look about, and there
Thou art!--a friend at hand, to scare
His melancholy.
explanation: If someone finds themselves seeking refuge from the rain by a rock, or basking in the hot sunshine next to a holly tree, and eventually becomes weary, they only need to glance around to find a friend nearby, ready to chase away their melancholy.

I have spent countless moments surrounded by nature, whether it be a rocky terrain or a peaceful garden, before resting for just an hour. During these moments, I have felt the influence of your sweetness, which has provided me with various emotions: a sense of understanding, a lasting love, a fleeting happiness, a memory that had once disappeared, a fanciful idea that may or may not be true, or a creative thought that had wandered away.

text:
If stately passions in me burn,
And one chance look to Thee should turn,
I drink out of an humbler urn
A lowlier pleasure;
The homely sympathy that heeds
The common life, our nature breeds;
A wisdom fitted to the needs
Of hearts at leisure.
explanation: If I have strong emotions and happen to catch your gaze, I find joy in simpler things. I appreciate the everyday connections we share and the understanding that comes from experiencing life together. This wisdom is best suited for those who have time to slow down and appreciate the small things.

text:
Fresh-smitten by the morning ray,
When thou art up, alert and gay,
Then, cheerful Flower! my spirits play
With kindred gladness:
And when, at dusk, by dews opprest
Thou sink'st, the image of thy rest
Hath often eased my pensive breast
Of careful sadness.
explanation: When the morning sun shines on you and you are lively and happy, it lifts my spirits and I feel the same joy. And in the evening, when the dew makes you tired and you rest, your peaceful image has often helped me feel less sad and worried.

text:
And all day long I number yet,
All seasons through, another debt,
Which I, wherever thou art met,
To thee am owing;
An instinct call it, a blind sense;
A happy, genial influence,
Coming one knows not how, nor whence,
Nor whither going.
explanation: Throughout every day and every season, I feel a constant obligation towards you, wherever we may cross paths. It's an unexplainable instinct or feeling, a positive force that inexplicably appears and disappears without explanation. I can't quite pinpoint how or why it happens, but I know that I owe it all to you.

text:
Child of the Year! that round dost run
Thy pleasant course,--when day's begun
As ready to salute the sun
As lark or leveret,
Thy long-lost praise thou shalt regain;
Nor be less dear to future men
Than in old time;--thou not in vain
Art Nature's favourite.
explanation: Oh Child of the Year! You run your daily course with such joy and eagerness, greeting the sun like the lark or the leveret. Your praises, which were once lost, will be regained and you will remain dear to future generations, just as you were in the past. Nature has always favored you, and that will never be in vain.

text:
DARK and more dark the shades of evening fell;
The wished-for point was reached--but at an hour
When little could be gained from that rich dower
Of prospect, whereof many thousands tell.
poem_title: Composed After A Journey Across The Hambleton Hills, Yorkshire
explanation: As the evening grew darker, the desired location was finally reached, but unfortunately it was too late to enjoy the beautiful view that many have raved about in the past.

text:
Yet did the glowing west with marvellous power
Salute us; there stood Indian citadel,
Temple of Greece, and minster with its tower
Substantially expressed--a place for bell
Or clock to toll from! Many a tempting isle,
With groves that never were imagined, lay
'Mid seas how steadfast! objects all for the eye
Of silent rapture; but we felt the while
We should forget them; they are of the sky,
And from our earthly memory fade away.
poem_title: Composed After A Journey Across The Hambleton Hills, Yorkshire
explanation: We were greeted by the breathtaking beauty of the west, as Indian citadels, Greek temples, and towering churches stood before us. Even the islands we saw were so mesmerizing with their unimaginable groves, but we knew that these sights would eventually fade from our memory, belonging only to the sky.

text:
AN age hath been when Earth was proud
Of lustre too intense
To be sustained; and Mortals bowed
The front in self-defence.
Who 'then', if Dian's crescent gleamed,
Or Cupid's sparkling arrow streamed
While on the wing the Urchin played,
Could fearlessly approach the shade?
--Enough for one soft vernal day,
If I, a bard of ebbing time,
And nurtured in a fickle clime,
May haunt this horned bay;
Whose amorous water multiplies
The flitting halcyon's vivid dyes;
And smooths her liquid breast--to show
These swan-like specks of mountain snow,
White as the pair that slid along the plains
Of heaven, when Venus held the reins!
explanation: There was a time when the earth was so dazzlingly bright that mortals had to shield their eyes. During this era, even the sight of the moon or Cupid's arrow would cause people to cower in fear. However, for the poet who now lingers in a bay surrounded by mountains, it is enough to have one gentle spring day to reflect on the past. The bay's waters are clear and the colors of the halcyon bird are reflected in it. The poet is reminded of the swan-like snow covered peaks that Venus once traveled with her chariot.

text:
In youth we love the darksome lawn
Brushed by the owlet's wing;
Then, Twilight is preferred to Dawn,
And Autumn to the Spring.
Sad fancies do we then affect,
In luxury of disrespect
To our own prodigal excess
Of too familiar happiness.
Lycoris (if such name befit
Thee, thee my life's celestial sign!)
When Nature marks the year's decline,
Be ours to welcome it;
Pleased with the harvest hope that runs
Before the path of milder suns;
Pleased while the sylvan world displays
Its ripeness to the feeding gaze;
Pleased when the sullen winds resound the knell
Of the resplendent miracle.
explanation: When we are young, we enjoy being in dark places that are touched by the wings of owls. We prefer twilight to dawn and autumn to spring. We have a tendency to be sad and disrespectful towards the excess of happiness we have. Lycoris, who represents the celestial sign of our lives, reminds us to welcome the decline of the year with pleasure for the harvest that comes before the milder suns. We take pleasure in the ripeness of the sylvan world and the feeding gaze it offers. We are happy to hear the sullen winds resound the knell of the resplendent miracle.

text:
But something whispers to my heart
That, as we downward tend,
Lycoris! life requires an 'art'
To which our souls must bend;
A skill--to balance and supply;
And, ere the flowing fount be dry,
As soon it must, a sense to sip,
Or drink, with no fastidious lip.
Then welcome, above all, the Guest
Whose smiles, diffused o'er land and sea,
Seem to recall the Deity
Of youth into the breast:
May pensive Autumn ne'er present
A claim to her disparagement!
While blossoms and the budding spray
Inspire us in our own decay;
Still, as we nearer draw to life's dark goal,
Be hopeful Spring the favourite of the Soul!
explanation: The author reflects on the need for art in life, represented by the metaphor of a flower, Lycoris. Life requires a skill to balance and supply, to enjoy the present and not be wasteful. The author welcomes the Guest, who brings smiles and a reminder of the youthfulness of the soul. The author hopes that autumn, representing the approaching end of life, will not diminish the value of the Guest. The blossoms and budding sprays of spring inspire us even as we age, and the author hopes that the soul will always favor hopeful spring as we approach life's end.

text:
Now we are tired of boisterous joy,
Have romped enough, my little Boy!
Jane hangs her head upon my breast,
And you shall bring your stool and rest;
This corner is your own.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: We have had enough of loud excitement and play, my little boy. Jane is tired and leans her head on my chest, while I offer you a stool to rest on in this designated corner for you.

text:
There! take your seat, and let me see
That you can listen quietly:
And, as I promised, I will tell
That strange adventure which befell
A poor blind Highland Boy.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Sit down and listen attentively as I tell you the story of a peculiar incident that happened to a blind boy from the Highlands.

text:
A 'Highland' Boy!-why call him so?
Because, my Darlings, ye must know
That, under hills which rise like towers,
Far higher hills than these of ours!
He from his birth had lived.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The reason why he is called a 'Highland' boy is because he was born and raised in the mountains, in an area with much higher hills than the ones we are accustomed to.

text:
He ne'er had seen one earthly sight
The sun, the day; the stars, the night;
Or tree, or butterfly, or flower,
Or fish in stream, or bird in bower,
Or woman, man, or child.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He had never witnessed anything of this world; no sun or stars, no trees, butterflies, flowers, fish, birds, or even human beings.

text:
And yet he neither drooped nor pined,
Nor had a melancholy mind;
For God took pity on the Boy,
And was his friend; and gave him joy
Of which we nothing know.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Despite his difficult circumstances, the boy did not become sad or depressed. This was most likely because God showed him mercy and kindness, and brought happiness into his life that we cannot fully understand or comprehend.

text:
His Mother, too, no doubt, above
Her other children him did love:
For, was she here, or was she there,
She thought of him with constant care,
And more than mother's love.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: It is evident that the protagonist's mother had a special affection for him compared to her other children. Whether she was present or absent, she always worried about him, showing a love that surpassed that of a typical mother.

text:
And proud she was of heart, when, clad
In crimson stockings, tartan plaid,
And bonnet with a feather gay,
To Kirk he on the Sabbath day
