Went hand in hand with her.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: She felt immense pride in her heart as she walked hand in hand with her partner to the church on a Sunday. She was dressed in crimson stockings, a tartan plaid, and a bonnet adorned with a lively feather.

text:
A dog too, had he; not for need,
But one to play with and to feed;
Which would have led him, if bereft
Of company or friends, and left
Without a better guide.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He owned a dog simply for companionship and care, not out of necessity. The dog would have been a source of comfort and guidance for him if he were ever alone without other friends or companions.

text:
And then the bagpipes he could blow-
And thus from house to house would go;
And all were pleased to hear and see,
For none made sweeter melody
Than did the poor blind Boy.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The poor blind boy would play his bagpipes and go from house to house. People were happy to hear and see him because he played the sweetest melodies.

text:
Yet he had many a restless dream;
Both when he heard the eagles scream,
And when he heard the torrents roar,
And heard the water beat the shore
Near which their cottage stood.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He had numerous uneasy dreams, whether it was the screeching of the eagles or the roaring of the torrents that disturbed his sleep. Even the sound of the water hitting the shore close to their cottage would cause him to have restless nights.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Their cottage was located next to a vast and unfamiliar lake, unlike our humble abode next to a serene body of water. This lake was enormous and unpredictable, with constant fluctuations in its temperament and currents that caused it to be constantly active.

text:
For to this lake, by night and day,
The great Sea-water finds its way
Through long, long windings of the hills
And drinks up all the pretty rills
And rivers large and strong:
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The lake is fed by the sea through a winding path among hills, which collects all the small and large rivers and streams. This process occurs both day and night.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The subject, which is not specified, quickly retraces its steps along the same path it took before, with the same purpose or task. This behavior has been happening since the beginning of the Earth and will continue indefinitely for as long as the planet exists.

text:
And, with the coming of the tide,
Come boats and ships that safely ride
Between the woods and lofty rocks;
And to the shepherds with their flocks
Bring tales of distant lands.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: As the tide arrives, boats and ships navigate through the woods and rocks, offering a safe passage. The shepherds with their flocks listen to the travelers' stories of far-off lands.

text:
And of those tales, whate'er they were,
The blind Boy always had his share;
Whether of mighty towns, or vales
With warmer suns and softer gales,
Or wonders of the Deep.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The blind boy was always included in the different stories and tales shared, regardless of the topic. The stories ranged from epic cities to peaceful valleys with gentle winds, and even to fascinating accounts of the ocean's depths.

text:
Yet more it pleased him, more it stirred,
When from the water-side he heard
The shouting, and the jolly cheers;
The bustle of the mariners
In stillness or in storm.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He found himself increasingly delighted and excited as he listened to the loud cheers and commotion of the sailors on the water's edge, whether they were working in calm conditions or facing a fierce storm.

text:
But what do his desires avail?
For He must never handle sail;
Nor mount the mast, nor row, nor float
Ill sailor's ship, or fisher's boat,
Upon the rocking waves.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: His desires are of no use since he cannot fulfill them. He is forbidden to handle any sail, climb the mast, row a boat, or even float on the sea as he is deemed an unlucky sailor or fisherman. He is prohibited from experiencing the thrill of the rocking waves.

text:
His Mother often thought, and said,
What sin would be upon her head
If she should suffer this: 'My Son,
Whate'er you do, leave this undone;
The danger is so great.'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The mother of the son expressed concern over the possibility of her son experiencing a great danger. She believed that if this were to happen, she would be at fault for not preventing it. She advised her son to avoid any situation that could lead to harm, emphasizing the severity of the potential consequences.

text:
Thus lived he by Loch Leven's side
Still sounding with the sounding tide,
And heard the billows leap and dance,
Without a shadow of mischance,
Till he was ten years old.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He resided alongside Loch Leven where he lived peacefully and listened to the rhythmic sounds of the waves without any trouble for ten years of his life.

text:
When one day (and now mark me well,
Ye soon shall know how this befell)
He in a vessel of his own,
On the swift flood is hurrying down,
Down to the mighty Sea.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: This passage describes how someone is traveling down a river in their own boat and will soon reach the sea. The speaker assures the listener that they will soon learn more about what happens next.

text:
In such a vessel never more
May human creature leave the shore!
If this or that way he should stir,
Woe to the poor blind Mariner!
For death will be his doom.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: No one should ever leave the shore in such a vessel as it will lead to death. If someone tries to move in any direction, they will be doomed, especially a blind mariner.

text:
But say what bears him?-Ye have seen
The Indian's bow, his arrows keen,
Rare beasts, and birds with plumage bright;
Gifts which, for wonder or delight,
Are brought in ships from far.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: What is the source of his strength? Have you ever witnessed the Indian's bow and his sharp arrows, along with exotic creatures and brightly feathered birds that are brought on ships from distant lands? These are the marvelous and delightful gifts that he possesses.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The seafaring men had given gifts to the inhabitants of the glen's haven, and each hut had possibly received its own. The Boy was familiar with and valued all of the gifts.

text:
The rarest was a Turtle-shell
Which he, poor Child, had studied well;
A shell of ample size, and light
As the pearly car of Amphitrite,
That sportive dolphins drew.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The child had studied well the rarest of all, a turtle shell. This shell was not only large, but also light like the pearly car of Amphitrite, which was drawn by dolphins.

text:
And, as a Coracle that braves
On Vaga's breast the fretful waves,
This shell upon the deep would swim,
And gaily lift its fearless brim
Above the tossing surge.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The shell is compared to a coracle, which is a small boat that navigates through rough waters, specifically on the Vaga river. The shell is depicted as being able to float on the open sea and withstand the turbulence of the waves. It is described as being brave and fearless, as it cheerfully rises above the tossing surge.

text:
And this the little blind Boy knew:
And he a story strange yet true
Had heard, how in a shell like this
An English Boy, O thought of bliss!
Had stoutly launched from shore;
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The little blind boy was aware of a peculiar but legitimate story about an English boy who had launched a shell from the shore, which brought him immense joy.

text:
Launched from the margin of a bay
Among the Indian isles, where lay
His father's ship, and had sailed far-
To join that gallant ship of war,
In his delightful shell.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He departed from the shore of a bay located in the Indian islands where his father's ship was anchored. He had traveled quite a distance to meet the warship and was now sailing in his comfortable boat.

text:
Our Highland Boy oft visited
The house that held this prize; and, led
By choice or chance, did thither come
One day when no one was at home,
And found the door unbarred.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The Highland Boy frequently visited the house that contained something valuable. One day, he arrived when nobody was present, and he discovered that the door was unlocked.

text:
While there he sate, alone and blind,
That story flashed upon his mind;-
A bold thought roused him, and he took
The shell from out its secret nook,
And bore it on his head.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Sitting by himself, unable to see, the protagonist suddenly remembered a story. This memory inspired him to take action; he retrieved a shell from a hidden location and placed it on his head.

text:
He launched his vessel,-and in pride
Of spirit, from Loch Leven's side,
Stepped into it-his thoughts all free
As the light breezes that with glee
Sang through the adventurer's hair.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: With a sense of pride, the adventurer launched his vessel from the side of Loch Leven. He stepped into it and felt his thoughts become as free as the light breezes that playfully sang through his hair.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He stood for a while and then sat down, feeling the movement of the tide. As the tide retreated further and further from the shore, he became more pleased and was eventually pulled in by the suction of the water.

text:
And there he is in face of Heaven.
How rapidly the Child is driven!
The fourth part of a mile, I ween,
He thus had gone, ere he was seen
By any human eye.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He stood before the sky, and the child moved quickly. He had covered a distance of almost a quarter of a mile before he was seen by anyone.

text:
But when he was first seen, oh me
What shrieking and what misery!
For many saw; among the rest
His Mother, she who loved him best,
She saw her poor blind Boy.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Upon his first sighting, there was great distress and wailing. His mother, who held the strongest affection for him, was also present and witnessed her son's unfortunate blindness.

text:
But for the child, the sightless Boy,
It is the triumph of his joy!
The bravest traveller in balloon,
Mounting as if to reach the moon,
Was never half so blessed.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The sightless boy experiences an immense feeling of joy at the sight of a hot air balloon. To him, it is a triumphant moment that surpasses the bravery of any balloon traveler who has attempted to reach the moon. The boy's happiness is immeasurable.

text:
And let him, let him go his way,
Alone, and innocent, and gay!
For, if good Angels love to wait
On the forlorn unfortunate,
This Child will take no harm.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Allow him to continue on his path, without any companions, yet full of joy and purity. If benevolent celestial beings favor keeping company with those who are lonely and unlucky, then this youngster will remain unscathed.

text:
But now the passionate lament,
Which from the crowd on shore was sent,
The cries which broke from old and young
In Gaelic, or the English tongue,
Are stifled-all is still.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The intense mourning of the crowd on the shore, expressed in both Gaelic and English, has now ceased and everything is quiet.

text:
And quickly with a silent crew
A boat is ready to pursue;
And from the shore their course they take,
And swiftly down the running lake
They follow the blind Boy.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: Without delay, a boat manned by a quiet crew is prepared to follow the blind Boy. They set off from the shore and speedily navigate down the lake, keeping pace with the Boy.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: They slow down their pace, reminiscent of a fowler pursuing a young duck with a delicate touch on Grasmere's calm surface.

text:
Or as the wily sailors crept
To seize (while on the Deep it slept)
The hapless creature which did dwell
Erewhile within the dancing shell,
They steal upon their prey.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The cunning sailors quietly approached and caught the helpless creature that had been living in a shell while it was resting in the sea. They snuck up on it and took it by surprise.

text:
With sound the least that can be made,
They follow, more and more afraid,
More cautious as they draw more near;
But in his darkness he can hear,
And guesses their intent.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The approaching individuals are getting more and more scared as they make minimal noise while coming closer. The person in the dark is attentive and can hear them, making assumptions about their purpose.

text:
'Lei-gha-Lei-gha'-he then cried out,
'Lei-gha-Lei-gha'-with eager shout;
Thus did he cry, and thus did pray,
And what he meant was, 'Keep away,
And leave me to myself!'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: He shouted out "Lei-gha-Lei-gha" with enthusiasm, meaning "Keep away and leave me alone". He cried out and prayed fervently with this phrase, emphasizing his desire for solitude and space.

text:
Alas! and when he felt their hands--
You've often heard of magic wands,
That with a motion overthrow
A palace of the proudest show,
Or melt it into air:
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The speaker expresses surprise and dismay as he describes a situation where "their" hands are felt. He refers to the existence of magic wands that can destroy even the grandest of palaces with a mere wave.

text:
So all his dreams-that inward light
With which his soul had shone so bright-
All vanished;-'twas a heartfelt cross
To him, a heavy, bitter loss,
As he had ever known.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: All of his hopes and aspirations, which had illuminated his soul so brilliantly, disappeared. It was a devastating blow to him, a significant and bitter loss, unlike any other he had experienced.

text:
But hark! a gratulating voice,
With which the very hills rejoice:
'Tis from the crowd, who tremblingly
Have watched the event, and now can see
That he is safe at last.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: A voice of celebration echoes through the hills, as a crowd who had been anxiously watching a certain event can finally breathe a sigh of relief. They are overjoyed to see that the person in question has made it through unscathed.

text:
And then, when he was brought to land,
Full sure they were a happy band,
Which, gathering round, did on the banks
Of that great Water give God thanks,
And welcomed the poor Child.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: After being brought to shore, the group was undoubtedly joyful as they gathered around the banks of the large body of water and expressed their gratitude to God. They also warmly received the young child.

text:
And in the general joy of heart
The blind Boy's little dog took part;
He leapt about, and oft did kiss
His master's hands in sign of bliss,
With sound like lamentation.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The blind boy's dog joined in the happiness by jumping around and kissing his master's hands as a sign of joy, but the sound he made was similar to that of sorrow.

text:
But most of all, his Mother dear,
She who had fainted with her fear,
Rejoiced when waking she espies
The Child; when she can trust her eyes,
And touches the blind Boy.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The most significant person who felt relieved upon seeing the child was his mother, who had fainted out of fear. She was overjoyed when she regained consciousness and saw her son. She felt relieved when she could touch the blind child and confirm that he was indeed alive.

text:
She led him home, and wept amain,
When he was in the house again:
Tears flowed in torrents from her eyes;
She kissed him-how could she chastise?
She was too happy far.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: She took him home and cried uncontrollably when he was back in the house. Tears streamed down her face as she kissed him, unable to scold him because she was too overjoyed.

text:
Thus, after he had fondly braved
The perilous Deep, the Boy was saved;
And, though his fancies had been wild,
Yet he was pleased and reconciled
To live in peace on shore.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: The boy had courageously faced the dangers of the sea and was ultimately rescued. Despite his wild imagination, he was content to live peacefully on land.

text:
And in the lonely Highland dell
Still do they keep the Turtle-shell
And long the story will repeat
Of the blind Boy's adventurous feat,
And how he was preserved.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803
explanation: In the remote valley of the Scottish Highlands, the locals continue to safeguard the Turtle-shell, which holds a tale of the brave and daring journey of a blind boy. The story of his survival is one that will be retold for generations to come.

text:
INTREPID sons of Albion! not by you
Is life despised; ah no, the spacious earth
Ne'er saw a race who held, by right of birth,
So many objects to which love is due:
Ye slight not life--to God and Nature true;
poem_title: Occasioned By The Battle Of Waterloo February 1816
explanation: Brave Englishmen! You do not hold life in contempt. In fact, there has never been a group of people who have so many things to love and cherish as you do. You are true to God and nature, and you understand the value of life.

text:
But death, becoming death, is dearer far,
When duty bids you bleed in open war:
Hence hath your prowess quelled that impious crew.
Heroes!--for instant sacrifice prepared;
Yet filled with ardour and on triumph bent
'Mid direst shocks of mortal accident--
To you who fell, and you whom slaughter spared
To guard the fallen, and consummate the event,
Your Country rears this sacred Monument!
poem_title: Occasioned By The Battle Of Waterloo February 1816
explanation: Dying in battle for one's duty is considered more valuable than simply dying. The speaker praises the bravery of the heroes who defeated the impious enemies. These heroes were willing to make the ultimate sacrifice in the face of mortal danger as they fought with great enthusiasm to achieve victory. To those who lost their lives and those who survived to protect the fallen and complete the mission, the country honors them with this sacred monument.

text:
TOO frail to keep the lofty vow
That must have followed when his brow
Was wreathed--'The Vision' tells us how--
With holly spray,
He faltered, drifted to and fro,
And passed away.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: The subject of the poem was too weak to keep a promise he made when he was once crowned with holly. His weakness caused him to falter and eventually pass away. This is revealed in a poem called "The Vision."

text:
Well might such thoughts, dear Sister, throng
Our minds when, lingering all too long,
Over the grave of Burns we hung
In social grief--
Indulged as if it were a wrong
To seek relief.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Dear Sister, it's understandable that we are consumed by such thoughts as we spend too much time at Burns' grave, mourning together as if it's wrong to try and find solace.

text:
But, leaving each unquiet theme
Where gentlest judgments may misdeem,
And prompt to welcome every gleam
Of good and fair,
Let us beside this limpid Stream
Breathe hopeful air.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Let's put aside any controversial topics that could be misunderstood and focus on the positive things in life. Let's enjoy the beauty of this clear stream and take in the fresh air with optimism.

text:
Enough of sorrow, wreck, and blight;
Think rather of those moments bright
When to the consciousness of right
His course was true,
When Wisdom prospered in his sight
And virtue grew.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Stop dwelling on sadness, destruction, and decay. Instead, focus on the joyful moments when he followed the path of righteousness, when wisdom shone through and virtue flourished.

text:
Yes, freely let our hearts expand,
Freely as in youth's season bland,
When side by side, his Book in hand,
We wont to stray,
Our pleasure varying at command
Of each sweet Lay.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Let us allow our hearts to open up without restraint, similar to the way we did in our youth. Back then, we used to walk together, carrying his Book, and amble along as we pleased, enjoying the various sweet melodies that came our way.

text:
How oft inspired must he have trod
These pathways, yon far-stretching road!
There lurks his home; in that Abode,
With mirth elate,
Or in his nobly-pensive mood,
The Rustic sate.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: He must have walked these paths and the long road countless times, feeling inspired. His home is hidden in the distance, and there he would sit with the villagers, either full of joy or lost in deep thought.

text:
Proud thoughts that Image overawes,
Before it humbly let us pause,
And ask of Nature, from what cause
And by what rules
She trained her Burns to win applause
That shames the Schools.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Let us halt our proud thoughts and reflect on the image that overwhelms us. We should inquire of Nature how she trained poets like Burns to achieve such acclaim that outshines the education system.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: The influence of the writer is felt everywhere, from the busiest streets to the loneliest glens. His pen has the power to affect people's lives even in the harshest winter conditions, and even when bees are busy in their hives. His words resonate deeply within the hearts of people, and his impact endures.

text:
What need of fields in some far clime
Where Heroes, Sages, Bards sublime,
And all that fetched the flowing rhyme
From genuine springs,
Shall dwell together till old Time
Folds up his wings?
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Why bother with faraway fields when great figures like heroes, wise individuals, and talented poets who drew inspiration from genuine sources will be living together until the end of time?

text:
Sweet Mercy! to the gates of Heaven
This Minstrel lead, his sins forgiven;
The rueful conflict, the heart riven
With vain endeavour,
And memory of Earth's bitter leaven,
Effaced for ever.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: This passage is a prayer for mercy and forgiveness. The speaker asks that the minstrel, who is likely a musician or poet, be led to the gates of heaven with his sins forgiven. The speaker describes the minstrel's past struggles and pain, which were caused by his efforts to succeed in life, and hopes that these memories will be erased forever. Overall, the passage expresses a desire for spiritual redemption and release from earthly troubles.

text:
But why to Him confine the prayer,
When kindred thoughts and yearnings bear
On the frail heart the purest share
With all that live?--
The best of what we do and are,
Just God, forgive!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland,
explanation: Why limit prayer to only God when our hearts are filled with love and compassion for all living beings? Our best intentions and actions should be forgiven by God, who understands our innate desire to connect with all forms of life.

text:
LONG time his pulse hath ceased to beat
But benefits, his gift, we trace--
Expressed in every eye we meet
Round this dear Vale, his native place.
poem_title: By The Side Of The Grave Some Years After
explanation: Although he has been dead for a while, we continue to see the positive impact he had on the community he grew up in. We can see his generosity in the way people look at each other and interact with one another.

text:
To stately Hall and Cottage rude
Flowed from his life what still they hold,
Light pleasures, every day, renewed;
And blessings half a century old.
poem_title: By The Side Of The Grave Some Years After
explanation: For many years, the simple joys of life flowed from him and continued to enrich both the grand Hall and humble Cottage. These blessings, which have endured for fifty years, came in the form of small yet delightful pleasures that were renewed each day.

text:
Oh true of heart, of spirit gay,
Thy faults, where not already gone
From memory, prolong their stay
For charity's sweet sake alone.
poem_title: By The Side Of The Grave Some Years After
explanation: You, who are sincerely honest and joyful in your spirit, hold onto your faults in your memory for the sake of kindness and compassion towards others.

text:
Such solace find we for our loss;
And what beyond this thought we crave
Comes in the promise from the Cross,
Shining upon thy happy grave.
poem_title: By The Side Of The Grave Some Years After
explanation: We find comfort in our grief and the promise of the Cross brings us hope. It shines upon your resting place, bringing you happiness beyond this life.

text:
A ROMAN Master stands on Grecian ground,
And to the people at the Isthmian Games
Assembled, He, by a herald's voice, proclaims
THE LIBERTY OF GREECE:--the words rebound
Until all voices in one voice are drowned;
poem_title: On A Celebrated Event In Ancient History
explanation: A Roman leader is present in Greece, and he speaks to the crowd gathered at the Isthmian Games, announcing the freedom of Greece through a herald's voice. The proclamation echoes throughout the audience until a united voice is heard.

text:
Glad acclamation by which air was rent!
And birds, high-flying in the element,
Dropped to the earth, astonished at the sound!
Yet were the thoughtful grieved; and still that voice
Haunts, with sad echoes, musing Fancy's ear:
Ah! that a 'Conqueror's' words should be so dear:
Ah! that a 'boon' could shed such rapturous joys!
A gift of that which is not to be given
By all the blended powers of Earth and Heaven.
poem_title: On A Celebrated Event In Ancient History
explanation: The sound of victorious cheering was so loud that it tore through the air, causing even the high-flying birds to drop down in surprise. However, some were not completely joyful and the melancholic echoes of the cheering lingered in their minds. They lamented that the words of a conqueror could bring such happiness and that a gift, which cannot be obtained by any means, could bring such ecstasy.

text:
HAIL, Zaragoza! If with unwet eye
We can approach, thy sorrow to behold,
Yet is the heart not pitiless nor cold;
Such spectacle demands not tear or sigh.
These desolate remains are trophies high
Of more than martial courage in the breast
Of peaceful civic virtue: they attest
Thy matchless worth to all posterity.
poem_title: Hail, Zaragoza! If With Unwet Eye
explanation: The speaker addresses the city of Zaragoza, expressing admiration for its resilience in the face of destruction. The speaker notes that, though they can witness the city's devastation without shedding tears, their heart is not without feeling. The ruins of Zaragoza are celebrated as a testament to the courage and virtue of its people, not just in war but in times of peace as well. The speaker honors Zaragoza's legacy and recognizes the city's significance for future generations.

text:
Blood flowed before thy sight without remorse;
Disease consumed thy vitals; War upheaved
The ground beneath thee with volcanic force:
Dread trials! yet encountered and sustained
Till not a wreck of help or hope remained,
And law was from necessity received.
poem_title: Hail, Zaragoza! If With Unwet Eye
explanation: You witnessed bloodshed without feeling any guilt, diseases attacked your body and war destroyed everything around you with great force. These were terrifying challenges that you faced and endured until you were left with nothing, no help or hope. It was only out of necessity that you turned to the law.

text:
AVAUNT all specious pliancy of mind
In men of low degree, all smooth pretence!
I better like a blunt indifference,
And self-respecting slowness, disinclined
To win me at first sight: and be there joined
Patience and temperance with this high reserve,
Honour that knows the path and will not swerve;
poem_title: Avaunt All Specious Pliancy Of Mind
explanation: Reject all false flexibility and smooth talk from those of lower status. I prefer straightforwardness and a sense of self-worth, rather than someone who tries to win me over too easily. This should be combined with patience and self-control, as well as a strong sense of honor and integrity. One who knows their path and remains steadfast on it.

text:
Affections, which, if put to proof, are kind;
And piety towards God. Such men of old
Were England's native growth; and, throughout Spain
(Thanks to high God) forests of such remain:
Then for that Country let our hopes be bold;
For matched with these shall policy prove vain,
Her arts, her strength, her iron, and her gold.
poem_title: Avaunt All Specious Pliancy Of Mind
explanation: England and Spain have historically been home to men who possess genuine affections and piety towards God. Although many of these men are no longer present in England, there are still many in Spain. Therefore, we should have hope for Spain's future because these virtues are more important than political policies, military strength, or wealth.

text:
NUNS fret not at their convent's narrow room,
And hermits are contented with their cells,
And students with their pensive citadels;
Maids at the wheel, the weaver at his loom,
Sit blithe and happy; bees that soar for bloom,
High as the highest peak of Furness fells,
Will murmur by the hour in foxglove bells:
In truth the prison unto which we doom
Ourselves no prison is: and hence for me,
In sundry moods, 'twas pastime to be bound
Within the Sonnet's scanty plot of ground;
Pleased if some souls (for such there needs must be)
Who have felt the weight of too much liberty,
Should find brief solace there, as I have found.
explanation: The speaker is suggesting that despite being confined to certain places, such as nuns in a convent, hermits in their cells, students in their study rooms, and weavers at their looms, they are content and happy with their surroundings. Even bees flying high in search of flowers find joy in the small space within foxglove flowers. The speaker then argues that the limitations we put on ourselves are not necessarily a prison, but rather a place of comfort and security. The speaker finds pleasure in the limitations of the sonnet form, and hopes that others who have struggled with too much freedom may also find solace in its structure.

text:
WHO weeps for strangers? Many wept
For George and Sarah Green;
Wept for that pair's unhappy fate,
Whose grave may here be seen.
explanation: It is uncommon for people to cry for strangers, but there were many who did so for George and Sarah Green. The couple had an unfortunate fate, and their grave can be found here.

text:
By night, upon these stormy fells,
Did wife and husband roam;
Six little ones at home had left,
And could not find that home.
explanation: The husband and wife were wandering through the stormy fells at night, searching for their home, while their six young children were left behind and unable to be found.

text:
For 'any' dwelling-place of man
As vainly did they seek.
He perish'd; and a voice was heard--
The widow's lonely shriek.
explanation: They searched in vain for any place where humans could live, but the man had already died. The only sound that could be heard was the anguished cry of the widow left behind.

text:
Not many steps, and she was left
A body without life--
A few short steps were the chain that bound
The husband to the wife.
explanation: With just a few steps, the wife's lifeless body lay before the husband. The simple act of walking became the link that connected the husband to his wife's death.

text:
Now do those sternly-featured hills
Look gently on this grave;
And quiet now are the depths of air,
As a sea without a wave.
explanation: The hills that were once severe in appearance now seem to look kindly upon the grave, and the air is still and peaceful, like a calm sea without any waves.

text:
But deeper lies the heart of peace
In quiet more profound;
The heart of quietness is here
Within this churchyard bound.
explanation: The true essence of peace lies beyond the surface level and can be found within the stillness that exists in this churchyard. A deep sense of tranquility can be felt here, where the heart of quietness resides.

text:
And from all agony of mind
It keeps them safe, and far
From fear and grief, and from all need
Of sun or guiding star.
explanation: This protects them from mental suffering, ensuring they are secure and distant from any anxiety, sorrow, and the requirement of any form of direction or guidance.

text:
O darkness of the grave! how deep,
After that living night--
That last and dreary living one
Of sorrow and affright?
explanation: How profound is the darkness of the grave, after experiencing the final and terrifying night of sorrow and fear in life.

text:
O sacred marriage-bed of death,
That keeps them side by side
In bond of peace, in bond of love,
That may not be untied!
explanation: The marriage bed of death is sacred and keeps the couple together in peace and love, unable to be separated.

text:
'WHO but hails the sight with pleasure
When the wings of genius rise,
Their ability to measure
With great enterprise;
But in man was ne'er such daring
As yon Hawk exhibits, pairing
His brave spirit with the war in
The stormy skies!
poem_title: Hint From The Mountains For Certain Political Pretenders
explanation: There is no denying the impressive sight of a genius soaring with great ambition. However, even the most daring of humans cannot compare to the bravery displayed by the hawk as it pairs its fearless spirit with the tumultuous skies in times of war.

text:
'Mark him, how his power he uses,
Lays it by, at will resumes!
Mark, ere for his haunt he chooses
Clouds and utter glooms!
There, he wheels in downward mazes;
Sunward now his flight he raises,
Catches fire, as seems, and blazes
With uninjured plumes!'--
poem_title: Hint From The Mountains For Certain Political Pretenders
explanation: Observe how the subject is able to control and utilize his power at will, putting it aside and then resuming it as desired. Take note of his potential choice for a dwelling place, which may be shrouded in dark clouds and utter darkness. Watch as he spirals downward before soaring back up towards the sun, appearing to catch fire and blaze with unharmed feathers.

poem_title: Hint From The Mountains For Certain Political Pretenders
explanation: Dear stranger, don't mistake the sight you see as a display of bravery. It's not a courageous bird braving the storm to find food. It's a mere imitation, like the false bravado seen in times of political unrest when people are elevated from their usual positions, akin to the insignificant tuft of fern you see.

text:
'Such it is; the aspiring creature
Soaring on undaunted wing,
(So you fancied) is by nature
A dull helpless thing,
Dry and withered, light and yellow;--
'That' to be the tempest's fellow!
Wait--and you shall see how hollow
Its endeavouring!'
poem_title: Hint From The Mountains For Certain Political Pretenders
explanation: The speaker asserts that the creature that appears to be soaring fearlessly is actually a weak and unimpressive being. They describe it as dry, withered, and light-colored, and claim that it is no match for the power of a storm. The speaker advises the listener to wait and witness the creature's failure in its attempt to withstand the tempest.

poem_title: Lines Written On A Blank Leaf In A Copy Of The Author’s Poem
explanation: I hesitantly brought this incomplete poem to the public's attention, but I have one reason to be pleased. The pious and knowledgeable MURFITT read and appreciated it, and his spirit influenced my thinking.

text:
He conned the new-born Lay with grateful heart--
Foreboding not how soon he must depart;
Unweeting that to him the joy was given
Which good men take with them from earth to heaven.
poem_title: Lines Written On A Blank Leaf In A Copy Of The Author’s Poem
explanation: He deceived the newly born Lay, who was full of gratitude, without realizing that he would soon have to leave. He did not know that the joy he gave her was the kind that good people take with them to heaven.

text:
DEAR Reliques! from a pit of vilest mould
Uprisen--to lodge among ancestral kings;
And to inflict shame's salutary stings
On the remorseless hearts of men grown old
In a blind worship; men perversely bold
Even to this hour,--yet, some shall now forsake
Their monstrous Idol if the dead e'er spake,
To warn the living; if truth were ever told
By aught redeemed out of the hollow grave:
O murdered Prince! meek, loyal, pious, brave!
The power of retribution once was given:
But 'tis a rueful thought that willow bands
So often tie the thunder-wielding hands
Of Justice sent to earth from highest Heaven!
poem_title: Feelings Of A French Royalist, On The Disinterment Of The Remains Of The Duke D’enghien
explanation: The speaker, addressing the "Reliques," laments the state of the world where people blindly worship idols and disregard the truth. The speaker hopes that the dead, such as the "murdered Prince," can speak and warn the living to abandon their misguided ways. The speaker reflects on the potential for retribution, but laments the fact that justice is often tied up and unable to act. Ultimately, the poem is a call for people to seek truth and reject false idols.

text:
I DROPPED my pen; and listened to the Wind
That sang of trees uptorn and vessels tost--
A midnight harmony; and wholly lost
To the general sense of men by chains confined
Of business, care, or pleasure; or resigned
To timely sleep. Thought I, the impassioned strain,
Which, without aid of numbers, I sustain,
Like acceptation from the World will find.
poem_title: Composed At The Same Time And On The Same Occasion
explanation: As I dropped my pen, I became entranced by the sound of the Wind, singing of trees being uprooted and ships being tossed about. This midnight melody allowed me to escape from the everyday concerns of people who are bound by work, worries, or leisure, or who have surrendered to the necessity of rest. I thought to myself that the emotional intensity of the song, which I am able to express without the help of formal poetry, would be appreciated by the World.

text:
Yet some with apprehensive ear shall drink
A dirge devoutly breathed o'er sorrows past;
And to the attendant promise will give heed--
The prophecy,--like that of this wild blast,
Which, while it makes the heart with sadness shrink,
Tells also of bright calms that shall succeed.
poem_title: Composed At The Same Time And On The Same Occasion
explanation: Some individuals will listen to a mournful song about their past sorrows with fear, but they will also pay attention to the promise of a better future. This prophecy is similar to the wild wind that brings sadness, but also predicts the arrival of peaceful calm.

Our ancestors entrusted us with their land and we will pass it on to our children or die trying. This is our fundamental belief and our sense of devotion. Both God and nature confirm the fairness of this ideal. Whatever we aspire to accomplish with weapons, we have no choice but to pursue it. Even the gaze of a newborn reminds us of this obligation.

text:
In the wife's smile; and in the placid sky;
And, at our feet, amid the silent dust
Of them that were before us.--Sing aloud
Old songs, the precious music of the heart!
Give, herds and flocks, your voices to the wind!
While we go forth, a self-devoted crowd,
With weapons grasped in fearless hands, to assert
Our virtue, and to vindicate mankind.
explanation: The wife's smile and the calm sky bring a sense of peace while standing among the graves of those who came before. The heart's cherished songs should be sung loudly and the animals should add their voices to the wind. The group goes forward fearlessly with weapons in hand to defend their virtue and fight for the betterment of humanity.

text:
By Moscow self-devoted to a blaze
Of dreadful sacrifice, by Russian blood
Lavished in fight with desperate hardihood;
The unfeeling Elements no claim shall raise
To rob our Human-nature of just praise
For what she did and suffered. Pledges sure
Of a deliverance absolute and pure
She gave, if Faith might tread the beaten ways
Of Providence. But now did the Most High
Exalt his still small voice;-to quell that Host
Gathered his power, a manifest ally;
He, whose heaped waves confounded the proud boast
Of Pharaoh, said to Famine, Snow, and Frost,
Finish the strife by deadliest victory!'
poem_title: By Moscow Self-Devoted To A Blaze
explanation: This passage speaks of Moscow's sacrifice during a brutal fight, where Russian blood was shed with great courage. The elements cannot take away from the human nature of those who fought and suffered in the conflict. The people of Moscow gave assurance of a complete and pure deliverance if they had faith in providence. However, the Most High intervened and commanded the elements of Famine, Snow, and Frost to defeat the enemy. The poem compares this to the biblical story of God's power over Pharaoh's army, using the same elements to bring about victory.

text:
OF mortal parents is the Hero born
By whom the undaunted Tyrolese are led?
Or is it Tell's great Spirit, from the dead
Returned to animate an age forlorn?
He comes like Phoebus through the gates of morn
When dreary darkness is discomfited,
Yet mark his modest state! upon his head,
That simple crest, a heron's plume, is worn.
explanation: Is the Hero born from mortal parents the leader of the undaunted Tyrolese? Or is it the spirit of Tell, returned from the dead to inspire a hopeless age? He arrives like Phoebus when darkness is defeated, but his appearance is humble with only a heron's plume on his head.

text:
O Liberty! they stagger at the shock
From van to rear--and with one mind would flee,
But half their host is buried:--rock on rock
Descends:--beneath this godlike Warrior, see!
Hills, torrents, woods, embodied to bemock
The Tyrant, and confound his cruelty.
explanation: The people are horrified by the destruction and chaos caused by the war. They want to flee but have lost many of their comrades who are buried in the rubble. They witness the destruction caused by the godlike warrior who embodies the natural elements such as hills, torrents, and woods to defy the tyrant and his cruelty.

text:
YE Storms, resound the praises of your King!
And ye mild Seasons--in a sunny clime,
Midway on some high hill, while father Time
Looks on delighted--meet in festal ring,
And loud and long of Winter's triumph sing!
Sing ye, with blossoms crowned, and fruits, and flowers,
Of Winter's breath surcharged with sleety showers,
And the dire flapping of his hoary wing!
Knit the blithe dance upon the soft green grass;
explanation: Celebrate the power of Winter, O storms and gentle seasons alike! From a sunny hilltop, under the watchful eye of Father Time, come together in joyous celebration and sing of Winter's victories. Let the flowers, fruits, and blossoms be your instruments as you sing of Winter's icy breath and the sound of his aged wings flapping. Dance merrily on the soft grass, and let the praises of your King be heard far and wide.

text:
With feet, hands, eyes, looks, lips, report your gain;
Whisper it to the billows of the main,
And to the aerial zephyrs as they pass,
That old decrepit Winter--'He' hath slain
That Host, which rendered all your bounties vain!
explanation: Use all your senses to share your victory; tell the ocean waves and the passing winds that you have defeated the old and weak Winter and his army that had previously rendered your efforts futile.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: In the past, tired of the world, men sought solitude in desolate places such as barren heaths, bleak moors, and quaking fens, as well as deep glens and trackless forests with tall trees. They withdrew to these places for penance and prayer, and made do with whatever accommodations they found or built new ones in order to better praise God.

text:
High lodged the 'Warrior', like a bird of prey;
Or where broad waters round him lay:
But this wild Ruin is no ghost
Of his devices--buried, lost!
Within this little lonely isle
There stood a consecrated Pile;
Where tapers burned, and mass was sung,
For them whose timid Spirits clung
To mortal succour, though the tomb
Had fixed, for ever fixed, their doom!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: The 'Warrior' was perched up high like a bird of prey, looking over the surrounding waters. However, the current state of ruin is not a result of his actions, but rather a separate occurrence. On a small, isolated island, there was once a sacred building where candles were lit and masses were held for those who sought comfort in mortal aid, despite the fact that their fate had already been sealed by death.

text:
Upon those servants of another world
When madding Power her bolts had hurled,
Their habitation shook;--it fell,
And perished, save one narrow cell;
Whither, at length, a Wretch retired
Who neither grovelled nor aspired:
He, struggling in the net of pride,
The future scorned, the past defied;
Still tempering, from the unguilty forge
Of vain conceit, an iron scourge!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: When a powerful force struck the otherworldly servants, their home trembled and collapsed, except for a single small cell. Eventually, a person who neither humbled themselves nor aimed for greatness sought refuge in the cell. This individual wrestled with the trap of arrogance, disregarded the future, and challenged the past. They continued to shape a harsh tool from the innocent flames of self-importance.

text:
Proud Remnant was he of a fearless Race,
Who stood and flourished face to face
With their perennial hills;--but Crime,
Hastening the stern decrees of Time,
Brought low a Power, which from its home
Burst, when repose grew wearisome;
And, taking impulse from the sword,
And, mocking its own plighted word,
Had found, in ravage widely dealt,
Its warfare's bourn, its travel's belt!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: The speaker describes the Proud Remnant as a member of a courageous and prosperous community that lived in harmony with their natural surroundings. However, their downfall was brought about by crime, which led to the destruction of their once-great power. The community was forced to leave their home after becoming restless, and they used violence to achieve their goals, even breaking promises they had made. In the end, the community was known for their widespread destruction, which became the defining characteristic of their travels and warfare.

text:
All, all were dispossessed, save him whose smile
Shot lightning through this lonely Isle!
No right had he but what he made
To this small spot, his leafy shade;
But the ground lay within that ring
To which he only dared to cling;
Renouncing here, as worse than dead,
The craven few who bowed the head
Beneath the change; who heard a claim
How loud! yet lived in peace with shame.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: Everyone was forced to leave the island except for the one person whose smile was so powerful it seemed to bring the lightning down. He had no real claim to the land except for the small area where he had made his home. He stayed within his small ring of territory and chose to abandon those who had given in to the demands of the invaders, even though their claim was loud and strong. These people lived in peace but also in shame.

text:
From year to year this shaggy Mortal went
(So seemed it) down a strange descent:
Till they, who saw his outward frame,
Fixed on him an unhallowed name;
Him, free from all malicious taint,
And guiding, like the Patmos Saint,
A pen unwearied--to indite,
In his lone Isle, the dreams of night;
Impassioned dreams, that strove to span
The faded glories of his Clan!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: Year after year, this unkempt man descended into an unfamiliar place, which caused people to label him as wicked. However, he was actually an innocent man who wrote tirelessly like Saint John of Patmos. He wrote about his passionate dreams on his isolated island, attempting to revive the lost splendor of his family.

text:
Suns that through blood their western harbour sought,
And stars that in their courses fought;
Towers rent, winds combating with woods,
Lands deluged by unbridled floods;
And beast and bird that from the spell
Of sleep took import terrible;--
These types mysterious (if the show
Of battle and the routed foe
Had failed) would furnish an array
Of matter for the dawning day!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: The poem describes various chaotic and violent events, such as sunsets stained with blood, stars appearing to fight each other, towers breaking apart, winds causing trees to collide, floods swamping the land, and animals awoken from their sleep displaying frightening behavior. The author suggests that if these events were not enough to capture the attention of the reader, they could be used as inspiration for the beginning of a story.

text:
How disappeared He?--ask the newt and toad,
Inheritors of his abode;
The otter crouching undisturbed,
In her dank cleft;--but be thou curbed,
O froward Fancy! 'mid a scene
Of aspect winning and serene;
For those offensive creatures shun
The inquisition of the sun!
And in this region flowers delight,
And all is lovely to the sight.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: The newt and toad wonder how He disappeared, as they now inherit His abode. The otter remains undisturbed in her damp crevice, and even though the scene is picturesque and peaceful, Fancy must be restrained from imagining anything unpleasant. The creatures that inhabit this area avoid the scrutiny of the sun, while the region is abundant with beautiful flowers and serene surroundings.

text:
Spring finds not here a melancholy breast,
When she applies her annual test
To dead and living; when her breath
Quickens, as now, the withered heath;--
Nor flaunting Summer--when he throws
His soul into the briar-rose;
Or calls the lily from her sleep
Prolonged beneath the bordering deep;
Nor Autumn, when the viewless wren
Is warbling near the BROWNIE'S Den.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: The changing seasons do not bring sadness to this place. In spring, when new life emerges and the heath begins to bloom, there is no melancholy. Summer's vibrant energy, as he brings forth the beautiful briar-rose and lily from the deep, does not stir sadness. Even in autumn, when the wren sings near the BROWNIE'S Den, there is no melancholy.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland 1814  I. Suggested By A Beautiful Ruin Upon One Of The Islands Of Loch Lomond,
explanation: This passage describes the beauty of a wild and untouched place, similar to the idyllic grotto in Nysa's isle where young Bacchus was hidden from his stepmother Rhea. The location is described as full of vibrant colors, with blooming flowers and fruit surrounding the infant god. The passage highlights the contrast between the liveliness of the environment and the celestial beauty of Bacchus himself.

text:
THAT way look, my Infant, lo!
What a pretty baby-show!
See the kitten on the wall,
Sporting with the leaves that fall,
Withered leaves---one---two---and three---
From the lofty elder-tree!
Through the calm and frosty air
Of this morning bright and fair,
Eddying round and round they sink
Softly, slowly: one might think,
From the motions that are made,
Every little leaf conveyed
Sylph or Faery hither tending,---
To this lower world descending,
Each invisible and mute,
In his wavering parachute.
explanation: Look at that, my baby, see the charming display! A kitten is playing with the fallen leaves from the elder-tree on the wall. The leaves are gently swirling down in the serene and frosty air of this beautiful morning. The way they move makes it appear as if each leaf is being carried by a sylph or faery, silently floating down with their wavering parachute.

text:
---But the Kitten, how she starts,
Crouches, stretches, paws, and darts!
First at one, and then its fellow
Just as light and just as yellow;
explanation: The poem describes the actions of a playful kitten. It crouches, stretches, paws, and darts. It plays with objects that are light and yellow, one after the other.

text:
There are many now---now one---
Now they stop and there are none
What intenseness of desire
In her upward eye of fire!
With a tiger-leap half way
Now she meets the coming prey,
Lets it go as fast, and then
Has it in her power again:
Now she works with three or four,
Like an Indian conjurer;
explanation: The speaker observes a woman who seems to possess an intense desire and fierce determination in her eyes. She leaps like a tiger towards her prey, then releases it before catching it again with ease. She works with three or four others, seemingly like an Indian conjurer. The sudden shift from many to none suggests the woman's ability to control her environment and her prey.

text:
Quick as he in feats of art,
Far beyond in joy of heart.
Were her antics played in the eye
Of a thousand standers-by,
Clapping hands with shout and stare,
What would little Tabby care
For the plaudits of the crowd?
Over happy to be proud,
Over wealthy in the treasure
Of her own exceeding pleasure!
'Tis a pretty baby-treat;
explanation: If a thousand people were watching and applauding her, little Tabby wouldn't care about their approval. She is happy enough to enjoy her own fun and doesn't need the validation of others. Her joy is enough treasure for her.

text:
Nor, I deem, for me unmeet;
Here, for neither Babe nor me,
Other play-mate can I see.
Of the countless living things,
That with stir of feet and wings
(In the sun or under shade,
Upon bough or grassy blade)
And with busy revellings,
Chirp and song, and murmurings,
Made this orchard's narrow space,
And this vale so blithe a place;
explanation: I cannot find a suitable companion for myself or my child in this location. The orchard and valley are filled with numerous creatures, such as birds and insects, that fill the area with sound and movement. However, none of them seem to be a good match for us to play with.

text:
Multitudes are swept away
Never more to breathe the day:
Some are sleeping; some in bands
Travelled into distant lands;
explanation: Many have been taken away, never to see the light of day again. Some are peacefully resting in their eternal slumber, while others have been forced to journey to far-off lands in groups.

text:
Others slunk to moor and wood,
Far from human neighborhood;
And, among the Kinds that keep
With us closer fellowship,
With us openly abide,
All have laid their mirth aside.
explanation: Some creatures have retreated to the moors and woods, far from human civilization. Those who still keep close to humans have abandoned their usual merriment and have become more reserved.

text:
Where is he that giddy Sprite,
Blue-cap, with his colors bright,
Who was blest as bird could be,
Feeding in the apple-tree;
explanation: Where can one find the playful and lively sprite, known as Blue-cap, with his vibrant colors? He was once as happy as a bird, contentedly feeding in the apple tree.

He caused destruction and chaos, recklessly damaging and scattering blossoms in his path. He hung upside down with his head towards the ground, flapping and resting in a circular motion. He then leapt and released himself, repeating the process with no regard for the consequences.

text:
Lithest, gaudiest Harlequin!
Prettiest Tumbler ever seen!
Light of heart and light of limb;
What is now become of Him?
Lambs, that through the mountains went
Frisking, bleating merriment,
When the year was in its prime,
They are sobered by this time.
explanation: This passage describes a Harlequin, a type of clown, who is extremely agile and brightly dressed. The narrator also mentions a talented acrobat who is very attractive. However, the poem ends on a somber note, pondering the fate of these lively performers. The metaphor of lambs who used to frolic happily in the mountains, but are now more subdued, suggests that the same might be true for these performers. The passage leaves the reader to wonder what might have happened to them and whether they are still performing or have moved on to something else.

text:
If you look to vale or hill,
If you listen, all is still,
Save a little neighboring rill,
That from out the rocky ground
Strikes a solitary sound.
explanation: If you observe the valley or hill, there is no noise except for a nearby stream that produces a distinct sound as it flows from the rocky surface.
Hills and plains sparkle but without purpose, while the still air is meaningless. The Morning's serene and pure sky is also without effect.

text:
Creature none can she decoy
Into open sign of joy:
Is it that they have a fear
Of the dreary season near?
Or that other pleasures be
Sweeter even than gaiety ?
Yet, whate'er enjoyments dwell
In the impenetrable cell
Of the silent heart which Nature
Furnishes to every creature;
explanation: The speaker is observing a creature that is unable to express joy openly. They wonder if it's because the creature is afraid of the upcoming dreary season or if there are other pleasures that are more enjoyable than being happy. Regardless, the speaker acknowledges that every creature has their own secret joys that are kept hidden in their hearts, provided by nature.

text:
Whatsoe'er we feel and know
Too sedate for outward show,
Such a light of gladness breaks,
Pretty Kitten! from thy freaks,---
Spreads with such a living grace
O'er my little Dora's face;
explanation: The speaker is expressing how sometimes they feel too calm to show their emotions outwardly. However, they observe their kitten's playful behavior and notice how it brings a light of joy and happiness to their daughter's face. The speaker marvels at how the kitten's actions spread a sense of liveliness and beauty.

text:
Yes, the sight so stirs and charms
Thee, Baby, laughing in my arms,
That almost I could repine
That your transports are not mine,
That I do not wholly fare
Even as ye do, thoughtless pair!
And I will have my careless season
Spite of melancholy reason,
Will walk through life in such a way
That, when time brings on decay,
Now and then I may possess
Hours of perfect gladsomeness.
explanation: The sight of you, my baby, laughing in my arms is so delightful that I almost feel envious of your carefree nature. Sometimes, I wish I could be as carefree as you and not be burdened by the weight of the world. Despite this, I have decided to enjoy life and have my moments of happiness, even if it means ignoring my worries and concerns. This way, when old age arrives, I can look back on my life and remember moments of pure joy.
One can find happiness in simple things like a random toy, the playful energy of a kitten or the innocent laughter of a child. Sharing in these moments of joy can also bring one a sense of ecstasy.

text:
I would fare like that or this,
Find my wisdom in my bliss;
Keep the sprightly soul awake,
And have faculties to take,
Even from things by sorrow wrought,
Matter for a jocund thought,
Spite of care, and spite of grief,
To gambol with Life's falling Leaf.
explanation: I will strive to maintain a positive outlook on life, finding happiness in both good and bad situations. I will keep my mind alert and open to new experiences, even when faced with difficult circumstances. I will find joy in unexpected places and refuse to let sorrow or stress bring me down. Instead, I will playfully dance through the ups and downs of life.

text:
'REST, rest, perturbed Earth!
O rest, thou doleful Mother of Mankind!'
A Spirit sang in tones more plaintive than the wind:
'From regions where no evil thing has birth
I come--thy stains to wash away,
Thy cherished fetters to unbind,
And open thy sad eyes upon a milder day.
The Heavens are thronged with martyrs that have risen
From out thy noisome prison;
The penal caverns groan
With tens of thousands rent from off the tree
Of hopeful life,--by battle's whirlwind blown
Into the deserts of Eternity.
Unpitied havoc! Victims unlamented!
But not on high, where madness is resented,
And murder causes some sad tears to flow,
Though, from the widely-sweeping blow,
The choirs of Angels spread, triumphantly augmented.
explanation: A spirit sings a mournful song to the Earth, urging it to rest and find peace. The spirit comes from a place where evil does not exist and wants to cleanse the Earth of its stains and free it from the chains that bind it. The spirit promises a better future and reveals that the heavens are filled with martyrs who have risen from the Earth's prison. The Earth is filled with victims of war who have been cast into the deserts of eternity without pity or lamentation. The murders and destruction caused by humanity do not go unnoticed by the heavens, but the angels continue to spread triumphantly despite the devastation.

text:
'False Parent of Mankind!
Obdurate, proud, and blind,
I sprinkle thee with soft celestial dews,
Thy lost, maternal heart to re-infuse!
Scattering this far-fetched moisture from my wings,
Upon the act a blessing I implore,
Of which the rivers in their secret springs,
The rivers stained so oft with human gore,
Are conscious;--may the like return no more!
May Discord--for a Seraph's care
Shall be attended with a bolder prayer--
May she, who once disturbed the seats of bliss
These mortal spheres above,
Be chained for ever to the black abyss.
And thou, O rescued Earth, by peace and love,
And merciful desires, thy sanctity approve!'
The Spirit ended his mysterious rite,
And the pure vision closed in darkness infinite.
explanation: The speaker addresses a false parent of mankind, accusing them of being obstinate, proud, and blind. The speaker then sprinkles them with celestial dews in an attempt to re-infuse their lost maternal heart. The speaker hopes that the blessing they implore will prevent the rivers from being stained with human gore ever again. They pray that Discord, who once disturbed the seats of bliss above mortal spheres, will be chained forever to the black abyss. The speaker calls for peace, love, and merciful desires to sanctify the rescued Earth. The spirit ends their mysterious rite, and the pure vision closes in infinite darkness.

text:
A MONTH, sweet Little-ones, is past
Since your dear Mother went away,---
And she tomorrow will return;
Tomorrow is the happy day.
explanation: It has been a month since the mother of the children left, but tomorrow she will return and bring happiness to them.

text:
O blessed tidings! thought of joy!
The eldest heard with steady glee;
Silent he stood; then laughed amain,---
And shouted, ' Mother, come to me!'
explanation: The news received was a source of great happiness, as evidenced by the eldest's reaction. He heard it calmly and then burst into laughter and shouted for his mother to come to him.

text:
Louder and louder did he shout,
With witless hope to bring her near;
'Nay, patience! patience, little boy!
Your tender mother cannot hear.'
explanation: The boy shouted louder and louder, with a foolish belief that it would make his mother come closer. However, she could not hear him and he was advised to be patient.

text:
I told of hills, and far-off town,
And long, long vale to travel through;---
He listens, puzzled, sore perplexed,
But he submits; what can he do ?
explanation: I described to him the hills, a distant town, and a lengthy valley to journey through. He appeared confused and troubled, yet accepted the situation with resignation. There was nothing else he could do to change the circumstances.

His sister is not troubled by any conflict; she does not struggle with the unknown elements of time, distance, and the differences between day and night. She is not affected by the ties that bind us as human beings.

text:
Her joy is like an instinct, joy
Of kitten, bird, or summer fly;
She dances, runs without an aim,
She chatters in her ecstasy.
explanation: She exudes joy naturally and instinctively, much like a kitten, bird or fly in the summertime. Her happiness is evident in her carefree movements, as she dances and runs without any particular destination in mind. She also expresses her elation through her constant chatter and excitement.

text:
Her brother now takes up the note,
And echoes back his sister's glee;
They hug the infant in my arms,
As if to force his sympathy.
explanation: The sister passes the note to her brother who also expresses excitement by mimicking his sister's joy. They both embrace the baby in my arms, trying to make him share their happiness.

text:
Then, settling into fond discourse,
We rested in the garden bower;
While sweetly shone the evening sun
In his departing hour.
explanation: We sat down and had a lovely conversation while relaxing in the garden. The sun was shining beautifully as it began to set.

text:
We told o'er all that we had done,---
Our rambles by the swift brook's side
Far as the willow-skirted pool,
Where two fair swans together glide.
explanation: We recounted everything we had experienced during our travels, including our walks along the fast-moving stream, all the way to the pool bordered by willows, where we observed two graceful swans swimming together.

text:
We talked of change, of winter gone,
Of green leaves on the hawthorn spray,
Of birds that build their nests and sing
And all 'since Mother went away!'
explanation: We discussed the changes in nature, including the end of winter and the appearance of green leaves on the hawthorn branch. We also talked about the birds that build their nests and sing, all since the speaker's mother had passed away.

text:
To her these tales they will repeat,
To her our new-born tribes will show,
The goslings green, the ass's colt,
The lambs that in the meadow go.
explanation: She will hear these stories again and again, and our young communities will proudly display the young geese with their green feathers, the young donkeys, and the lambs grazing in the fields.
The evening star is now visible and it's time for the children to go to bed. They feel a brief moment of sadness in their hearts as they prepare to depart.

text:
'Tis gone---and in a merry fit
They run up stairs in gamesome race;
I, too, infected by their mood,
I could have joined the wanton chase.
explanation: The moment has passed and the people around are in a playful mood, running up the stairs in a race. Their joy is infectious and I feel inclined to join in the playful chase.

text:
Five minutes past---and, O the change!
Asleep upon their beds they lie;
Their buy limbs in perfect rest,
And closed the sparkling eye.
explanation: After five minutes have passed, there is a noticeable difference. The individuals are now asleep in their beds, with their bodies relaxed and their eyes closed, devoid of any sparkle.

text:
YET, yet, Biscayans! we must meet our Foes
With firmer soul, yet labour to regain
Our ancient freedom; else 'twere worse than vain
To gather round the bier these festal shows.
poem_title: Feelings Of A Noble Biscayan At One Of Those Funerals
explanation: Despite the challenges we face, we must remain strong and determined as Biscayans. We must work tirelessly to reclaim our long-standing freedom, or else all the pomp and ceremony surrounding our mourning will be for nothing.

text:
A garland fashioned of the pure white rose
Becomes not one whose father is a slave:
Oh, bear the infant covered to his grave!
These venerable mountains now enclose
A people sunk in apathy and fear.
poem_title: Feelings Of A Noble Biscayan At One Of Those Funerals
explanation: The purity of a garland made from white roses is not enough to erase the fact that the person wearing it may still be of slave descent. The speaker begs for the infant to be buried with dignity, despite their circumstances. The mountains surrounding the area are home to a community that has become complacent and fearful.

text:
If this endure, farewell, for us, all good!
The awful light of heavenly innocence
Will fail to illuminate the infant's bier;
And guilt and shame, from which is no defence,
Descend on all that issues from our blood.
poem_title: Feelings Of A Noble Biscayan At One Of Those Funerals
explanation: If this continues, then it's goodbye to all that is good for us! The bright light of pure innocence from heaven will not shine on the child's coffin, and the weight of guilt and shame, for which there is no protection, will be passed down through our lineage.

text:
ENOUGH of rose-bud lips, and eyes
Like harebells bathed in dew,
Of cheek that with carnation vies,
And veins of violet hue;
Earth wants not beauty that may scorn
A likening to frail flowers;
Yea, to the stars, if they were born
For seasons and for hours.
explanation: Stop focusing on physical attributes such as lips and eyes that resemble rosebuds and harebells. Cheeks that compete with the color of carnations and veins that resemble violets are also not worth fixating on. There is plenty of beauty in the world that cannot be compared to delicate flowers, even the stars themselves would surpass such comparisons if they had been created for only a short period of time.

text:
Through Moscow's gates, with gold unbarred,
Stepped One at dead of night,
Whom such high beauty could not guard
From meditated blight;
By stealth she passed, and fled as fast
As doth the hunted fawn,
Nor stopped, till in the dappling east
Appeared unwelcome dawn.
explanation: A person, who was of great beauty, left Moscow in the middle of the night despite the gates being open and made their escape quickly, like a hunted animal. However, their beauty could not protect them from some impending danger. They ran until the dawn appeared in the sky.

text:
Seven days she lurked in brake and field,
Seven nights her course renewed,
Sustained by what her scrip might yield,
Or berries of the wood;
At length, in darkness travelling on,
When lowly doors were shut,
The haven of her hope she won,
Her foster-mother's hut.
explanation: For a week, she hid in thickets and open fields, and every night she continued her journey, surviving on whatever she had in her bag or wild berries. Finally, when doors were being shut for the night, she made it to her foster mother's cottage, having travelled in darkness.

text:
'To put your love to dangerous proof
I come,' said she, 'from far;
For I have left my Father's roof,
In terror of the czar.'
No answer did the Matron give,
No second look she cast,
But hung upon the fugitive,
Embracing and embraced.
explanation: She declared that she had come from far to test the depth of their love and had left her father's house out of fear of the czar. The matron did not respond with words but instead embraced the runaway and was also embraced in return.

text:
She led the Lady to a seat
Beside the glimmering fire,
Bathed duteously her wayworn feet,
Prevented each desire:---
The cricket chirped, the house-dog dozed,
And on that simple bed,
Where she in childhood had reposed,
Now rests her weary head.
explanation: She guided the Lady to a chair by the shining fire and carefully washed her tired feet, fulfilling her every need. The cricket made its sound and the household dog slept while she lay on the modest bed where she had slept as a child, now exhausted.

text:
When she, whose couch had been the sod,
Whose curtain, pine or thorn,
Had breathed a sigh of thanks to God,
Who comforts the forlorn;
While over her the Matron bent
Sleep sealed her eyes, and stole
Feeling from limbs with travel spent,
And trouble from the soul.
explanation: As the woman lay on the ground, with only the earth beneath her and trees serving as her shelter, she let out a grateful sigh to the divine being who comforts those who are lost and alone. The Matron watched over her as she slept, and the woman's exhaustion and worries seemed to fade away as she rested peacefully.

text:
Refreshed, the Wanderer rose at morn,
And soon again was dight
In those unworthy vestments worn
Through long and perilous flight;
And 'O beloved Nurse,' she said,
'My thanks with silent tears
Have unto Heaven and You been paid:
Now listen to my fears !
explanation: The Wanderer woke up feeling rejuvenated and put on her old clothes that she wore during her dangerous journey. She expressed her gratitude to her nurse and silently thanked Heaven. However, she also shared her worries with her nurse.

text:
'Have you forgot'---and here she smiled---
'The babbling flatteries
You lavished on me when a child
Disporting round your knees?
I was your lambkin, and your bird,
Your star, your gem, your flower;
Light words, that were more lightly heard
In many a cloudless hour!
explanation: The speaker reminds someone of the sweet words they used to say to her when she was a child playing at their feet. She was their beloved lamb, bird, star, gem, and flower, and they used to speak these flattering words to her often in carefree times. However, she now questions if they have forgotten these words, as they seem to have become distant and indifferent. The speaker's smile hints at a playful teasing, but also a longing for the affectionate words of the past.

The admired and beloved blossom has turned into bitter fruit, as a powerful figure has set his sights on me and I have rejected his advances. To avoid his anger, I must be concealed and led away by my beloved foster father on a new journey, as I cannot remain in my current location.

text:
'I cannot bring to utter woe
Your proved fidelity.'---
'Dear Child, sweet Mistress, say not so!
For you we both would die.'
'Nay, nay, I come with semblance feigned
And cheek embrowned by art;
Yet, being inwardly unstained,
With courage will depart.'
explanation: The speaker expresses gratitude to someone for their faithfulness, saying that they cannot bring them sadness or sorrow. However, the other person insists that they would be willing to die for the speaker if necessary. The speaker then admits that their outward appearance may not accurately reflect their true emotions, but they have the strength to endure difficult situations.

text:
'But whither would you, could you, flee?
A poor Man's counsel take;
The Holy Virgin gives to me
A thought for your dear sake;
Rest, shielded by our Lady's grace,
And soon shall you be led
Forth to a safe abiding-place,
Where never foot doth tread.'
explanation: The speaker advises the listener to seek counsel from a poor man and take the advice of the Holy Virgin for their safety. The speaker believes that the listener can find rest and protection through the grace of the Lady, who will guide them to a secure place where no one will find them.

text:
THE dwelling of this faithful pair
In a straggling village stood,
For One who breathed unquiet air
A dangerous neighbourhood;
But wide around lay forest ground
With thickets rough and blind;
And pine-trees made a heavy shade
Impervious to the wind.
explanation: This loyal couple lived in a dispersed community that was situated in a hazardous area for someone who sought peace. The region was surrounded by dense forests with rough and impenetrable thickets, and the shade of the pine-trees was so dense that it could not be penetrated by the wind.

text:
And there, sequestered from the eight,
Was spread a treacherous swamp,
On which the noonday sun shed light
As from a lonely lamp;
And midway in the unsafe morass,
A single Island rose
Of firm dry ground, with healthful grass
Adorned, and shady boughs.
explanation: In a secluded location away from the crowd, there lay a dangerous marsh illuminated by the sun like a solitary lamp. In the midst of the perilous swamp was a solitary island covered in healthy grass and shady trees, providing a secure and welcoming haven.

text:
The Woodman knew, for such the craft
This Russian vassal plied,
That never fowler's gun, nor shaft
Of archer, there was tried;
A sanctuary seemed the spot
From all intrusion free;
And there he planned an artful Cot
For perfect secrecy.
explanation: The Woodman was aware that the Russian servant who practised his craft there had never used a hunter's gun or an archer's arrow in that area. The place seemed like a sanctuary that was free from all interference. The Woodman then devised a clever plan to build a hidden cottage for complete secrecy.

text:
With earnest pains unchecked by dread
Of Power's far-stretching hand,
The bold good Man his labor sped
At nature's pure command;
Heart-soothed, and busy as a wren,
While, in a hollow nook,
She moulds her sight-eluding den
Above a murmuring brook.
explanation: The brave and virtuous man works diligently without fear of the powerful hand of authority, following the natural order of things. He is content and industrious, like a wren building its nest in a quiet spot above a babbling stream.

text:
His task accomplished to his mind,
The twain ere break of day
Creep forth, and through the forest wind
Their solitary way;
Few words they speak, nor dare to slack
Their pace from mile to mile,
Till they have crossed the quaking marsh,
And reached the lonely Isle.
