explanation: After finishing their task, the two individuals venture out before sunrise and make their way through the forest in silence. They keep a steady pace and do not stop until they have crossed the unstable marsh and arrived at the isolated island.

Ina was searching for her hiding spot among the pine-trees, and the sun was shining brightly in the sky. However, she could not find her abode, which had been promised to her. The Woodman smiled, but there was no sign of a threshold, roof or window. Everything appeared to be wild and untouched, as it always had been.

text:
Advancing, you might guess an hour,
The front with such nice care
Is masked, 'if house it be or bower,'
But in they entered are;
As shaggy as were wall and roof
With branches intertwined,
So smooth was all within, air-proof,
And delicately lined:
explanation: As they proceeded forward, it was estimated that an hour had passed. The front of the structure was so well hidden that it was unclear if it was a house or a bower. However, they still entered the structure. The walls and roof were covered in tangled branches, but the interior was flawlessly smooth and sealed against the outside air. It was also lined with delicate materials.

text:
And hearth was there, and maple dish,
And cups in seemly rows,
And couch---all ready to a wish
For nurture or repose;
And Heaven doth to her virtue grant
That here she may abide
In solitude, with every want
By cautious love supplied.
explanation: The room was equipped with everything one could need for comfort and relaxation, including a fireplace, a maple dish, and neatly arranged cups. The couch was also inviting, ready to provide comfort and rest. It was clear that every detail had been taken care of with careful consideration and love. The speaker expresses that the person who inhabits this space is deserving of such luxury, and wishes for them to find solace and contentment in their solitude.

text:
No queen, before a shouting crowd,
Led on in bridal state,
E'er struggled with a heart so proud,
Entering her palace gate:
Rejoiced to bid the world farewell,
No saintly anchoress
E'er took possession of her cell
With deeper thankfulness.
explanation: Never before has a queen, amidst cheers from the crowd, felt such pride in her heart as she entered her palace gates on her wedding day. She was overjoyed to leave the world behind and start her new life as a queen. Similarly, no devout nun has ever been as grateful as she takes possession of her cell.

text:
'Father of all, upon thy care
And mercy am I thrown;
Be thou my safeguard!'---such her prayer
When she was left alone,
Kneeling amid the wilderness
When joy had passed away,
And smiles, fond efforts of distress
To hide what they betray!
explanation: In a moment of solitude and despair, the speaker calls out to the universal father for protection and guidance. Alone in the wilderness, she kneels and prays for mercy, acknowledging her dependence on a higher power. She reflects on the fleeting nature of joy and the ways in which people often use smiles to conceal their true feelings. The speaker's prayer is a plea for strength and support in a difficult and uncertain world.

text:
The prayer is heard, the Saints have seen,
Diffused through form and face,
Resolves devotedly serene;
That monumental grace
Of Faith, which doth all passions tame
That Reason should control;
And shows in the untrembling frame
A statue of the soul.
explanation: The Saints have heard and seen the prayer, which has instilled a devoted and serene resolve within them. This grace of Faith is a monument that tames all passions, allowing Reason to take control. It is through this unwavering composure that the soul is like a statue.

text:
'TIS sung in ancient minstrelsy
That Phoebus wont to wear
The leaves of any pleasant tree
Around his golden hair;
Till Daphne, desperate with pursuit
Of his imperious love,
At her own prayer transformed, took root,
A laurel in the grove.
explanation: In ancient songs, it is told that Phoebus, the Greek god of music and poetry, used to adorn his golden hair with leaves from various trees. However, his relentless pursuit of Daphne, a beautiful nymph, led her to plead with the gods to transform her into a laurel tree. This tragic event resulted in Phoebus wearing laurel leaves in honor of his lost love.

text:
Then did the Penitent adorn
His brow with laurel green;
And 'mid his bright locks never shorn
No meaner leaf was seen;
And poets sage, through every age,
About their temples wound
The bay; and conquerors thanked the Gods,
With laurel chaplets crowned,
explanation: The Penitent decorated his head with a wreath of green laurel, and it was the most distinguished leaf among his shiny locks. Throughout history, wise poets have placed laurel wreaths around their temples, while conquerors have expressed gratitude to the Gods by crowning their heads with laurel chaplets.

text:
Into the mists of fabling Time
So far runs back the praise
Of Beauty, that disdains to climb
Along forbidden ways;
That scorns temptation; power defies
Where mutual love is not;
And to the tomb for rescue flies
When life would be a blot.
explanation: The admiration for Beauty has been present since ancient times, as it remains true today. Beauty is not willing to use dishonest tactics or compromise its morality to achieve success. It refuses to succumb to authority or temptation if it means sacrificing the purity of mutual love. Beauty will seek refuge in death if necessary to avoid living a life that is impure.

text:
To this fair Votaress, a fate
More mild doth Heaven ordain
Upon her Island desolate;
And word, not breathed in vain,
Might tell what intercourse she found,
Her silence to endear;
What birds she tamed, what flowers the ground
Sent forth her peace to cheer.
explanation: Heaven has ordained a kinder fate for the beautiful Votaress on her desolate island. There are untold stories of the interactions she has had, which have endeared her to the island's inhabitants. She has tamed birds and brought peace to the land through the flowers that grow around her.

text:
To one mute Presence, above all,
Her soothed affections clung,
A picture on the cabin wall
By Russian usage hung---
The Mother-maid, whose countenance bright
With love abridged the day;
And, communed with by taper light,
Chased spectral fears away.
explanation: Above all else, there was a picture on the wall of the cabin that brought comfort to the speaker. It was a depiction of a mother and child, a common image in Russian culture. The mother's loving expression had a calming effect and helped to dispel any fears that arose during the night.

text:
And oft as either Guardian came,
The joy in that retreat
Might any common friendship shame,
So high their heart would beat;
And to the lone Recluse, whate'er
They brought, each visiting
Was like the crowding of the year
With a new burst of spring.
explanation: Whenever either of the Guardians came to the retreat, the happiness they brought was so great that it outshone any regular friendship. Their visits were like a new and exhilarating burst of spring for the solitary Recluse, no matter what they brought with them. The joy they brought was immeasurable and their presence was greatly appreciated.

text:
But, when she of her Parents thought,
The pang was hard to bear;
And, if with all things not enwrought,
That trouble still is near.
Before her flight she had not dared
Their constancy to prove,
Too much the heroic Daughter feared
The weakness of their love.
explanation: The protagonist is experiencing a difficult time when she thinks about her parents. The pain is intense, and it remains despite her efforts to distract herself. She is hesitant to leave them because she is afraid that they will not be able to handle it. The protagonist is afraid to test her parents' loyalty and love for her.

text:
Dark is the past to them, and dark
The future still must be,
Till pitying Saints conduct her bark
Into a safer sea---
Or gentle Nature close her eyes,
And set her Spirit free
From the altar of this sacrifice,
In vestal purity.
explanation: The past is a dark time for them and they fear the future will remain the same until they are guided by compassionate saints to a safer place or until nature takes them away from this sacrifice and frees their spirit in purity.

text:
Yet, when above the forest-glooms
The white swans southward passed,
High as the pitch of their swift plume
Her fancy rode the blast;
And bore her toward the fields of France
Her Father's native land,
To mingle in the rustic dance,
The happiest of the band!
explanation: As the white swans flew over the dark forest, the speaker's imagination took flight with them. She imagined herself traveling to her father's homeland of France and dancing joyfully with the locals. The swans' graceful flight and the imagined freedom it brought served as a momentary escape from the speaker's current reality.

text:
Of those beloved fields she oft
Had heard her Father tell
In phrase that now with echoes soft
Haunted her lonely cell;
She saw the hereditary bowers,
She heard the ancestral stream;
The Kremlin and its haughty towers
Forgotten like a dream !
explanation: She often heard her father speak fondly of the fields that were dear to him, and now those memories echoed in her lonely cell. She could vividly imagine the family lands and the flowing river that had been passed down through generations. Even the grand Kremlin, once so imposing, now seemed like a distant dream.

text:
THE ever-changing Moon had traced
Twelve times her monthly round,
When through the unfrequented Waste
Was heard a startling sound;
A shout thrice sent from one who chased
At speed a wounded deer,
Bounding through branches interlaced,
And where the wood was clear.
explanation: After twelve lunar cycles, the Moon witnessed a commotion in a desolate area as a hunter pursued a wounded deer. The chase was fast-paced, with the deer leaping through tangled branches and clearing the woods. The sound of the hunter's shout echoed three times, alarming anyone within earshot.

text:
The fainting creature took the marsh,
And toward the Island fled,
While plovers screamed with tumult harsh
Above his antlered head;
This, Ina saw; and, pale with fear,
Shrunk to her citadel;
The desperate deer rushed on, and near
The tangled covert fell.
explanation: A weakened animal stumbled towards the marsh and ran towards an island while birds screeched loudly above its head. Ina witnessed this and became scared, hiding in her fortress. The distressed deer continued to run and eventually collapsed close to the tangled bushes.

text:
Across the marsh, the game in view,
The Hunter followed fast,
Nor paused, till o'er the stag he blew
A death-proclaiming blast;
Then, resting on her upright mind,
Came forth the Maid---'In me
Behold,' she said, ' a stricken Hind
Pursued by destiny!
explanation: The Hunter chased after the game in the distance and did not stop until he blew a fatal signal over the stag. The Maid, with a clear conscience, then appeared and declared that she was like the hunted Hind, pursued by fate.

text:
'From your deportment, Sir! I deem
That you have worn a sword,
And will not hold in light esteem
A suffering woman's word;
There is my covert, there perchance
I might have lain concealed,
My fortunes hid, my countenance
Not even to you revealed.
explanation: Sir, based on how you carry yourself, I believe that you have military experience and would not disregard the words of a woman in distress. I could have hidden in that area over there and kept my identity and situation a secret from you.

text:
'Tears might be shed, and I might pray,
Crouching and terrified,
That what has been unveiled to day,
You would in mystery hide;
But I will not defile with dust
The knee that bend to adore
The God in heaven;---attend, be just;
This ask I, and no more!
explanation: Although tears may be shed and fear may overcome me, I pray that You hide the unveiled truth in mystery. I refuse to dirty my knees by bowing to worship anything other than the God in heaven. I simply ask that You listen and be fair, nothing more.

text:
'I speak not of the winter's cold,
For summer's heat exchanged,
While I have lodged in this rough hold,
From social life estranged;
Nor yet of trouble and alarms:
High Heaven is my defence;
And every season has soft arms
For injured Innocence.
explanation: I am not talking about the harsh cold of winter, but rather the scorching heat of summer that I have experienced while living in this rugged dwelling, isolated from society. I am also not referring to any difficulties or fears I may have faced, as I am protected by God above. Every season has its comforting aspects, even for those who have been wronged and are innocent.

text:
'From Moscow to the Wilderness
It was my choice to come,
Lest virtue should be harborless,
And honor want a home;
And happy were I, if the Czar
Retain his lawless will,
To end life here like this poor deer,
Or a lamb on a green hill.'
explanation: I decided to leave Moscow and venture into the wilderness in order to uphold virtue and honor. I am content with living my life in solitude, much like a deer or lamb on a hill, as long as the Czar continues with his tyrannical ways.

text:
'Are you the Maid,' the Stranger cried,
'From Gallic parents sprung,
Whose vanishing was rumored wide,
Sad theme for every tongue;
Who foiled an Emperor's eager quest?
You, Lady, forced to wear
These rude habiliments, and rest
Your head in this dark lair!'
explanation: The Stranger asked the Lady if she was the Maid who disappeared and was rumored widely. She had foiled an Emperor's quest and was forced to wear rough clothes and stay in a dark place.

text:
But wonder, pity, soon were quelled;
And in her face and mien
The soul's pure brightness she beheld
Without a veil between:
He loved, he hoped,---a holy flame
Kindled 'mid rapturous tears;
The passion of a moment came
As on the wings of years.
explanation: The initial feelings of amazement and sympathy were quickly subdued, and instead the speaker saw the pure and unfiltered essence of the subject's soul in her expression and demeanor. This led to the speaker experiencing a profound love and hope, which were ignited in a moment that felt as though it had been building for years.

text:
'Such bounty is no gift of chance,'
Exclaimed he; 'righteous Heaven,
Preparing your deliverance,
To me the charge hath given.
The Czar full oft in words, and deeds
Is stormy and self-willed;
But, when the Lady Catherine pleads,
His violence is stilled.
explanation: He exclaimed that the abundance they received was not by chance but rather a result of the divine intervention of a righteous Heaven, which had given him the responsibility of delivering it to them. He noted that although the Czar was often known for his stormy and self-willed behavior, he was easily calmed down whenever Lady Catherine spoke in his defense.

text:
'Leave open to my wish the course,
And I to her will go;
From that humane and heavenly source,
Good, only good, can flow.''
Faint sanction given, the Cavalier
Was eager to depart,
Though question followed question, dear
To the Maiden's filial heart.
explanation: The speaker asks for the freedom to choose their own path, and promises to only pursue good things. The Cavalier is eager to leave, despite the Maiden's many questions that are important to her.

text:
Light was his step,---his hopes, more light,
Kept pace with his desires;
And the fifth morning gave him sight
Of Moscow's glittering spires.
He sued:---heart-smitten by the wrong,
To the lorn Fugitive
The Emperor sent a pledge as strong
As sovereign power could give.
explanation: He walked with a spring in his step, his aspirations soaring and matching his buoyant spirit. On the fifth morning of his journey, he finally saw the gleaming spires of Moscow. He pleaded his case, deeply affected by the injustice he had suffered. The Emperor, moved by the plight of this desperate exile, offered him a powerful assurance of protection, one that only a ruler could provide.

text:
O more than mighty change! If e'er
Amazement rose to pain,
And joy's excess produced a fear
Of something void and vain;
'Twas when the Parents, who had mourned
So long the lost as dead,
Beheld their only Child returned,
The household floor to tread.
explanation: The return of the only child after being presumed dead for a long time was a great and overwhelming change. The parents were amazed and overwhelmed with joy, but at the same time, they were fearful of the possibility that it could all be a void and meaningless illusion. This change was so powerful that it caused the parents to experience pain and fear, despite the joy of having their child back in their lives.

The Maiden's initial feeling of gratitude transformed into love, as the Deliverer and herself were united in marriage. The bride, Catherine, received her own reward and the Czar granted her a dowry. The entire city of Moscow rejoiced in the triumph of the wedding.

The ground was covered with flowers as the expensive and luxurious wedding celebration took place. Among the many distinguished guests, the foster parent sat, feeling encouraged by the presence of the emperor. They did not hide in the shadows but basked in the glory of the high honor bestowed upon them by both society and nature.

text:
FROM Stirling castle we had seen
The mazy Forth unravelled;
Had trod the banks of Clyde, and Tay,
And with the Tweed had travelled;
And when we came to Clovenford,
Then said my 'winsome Marrow,'
'Whate'er betide, we'll turn aside,
And see the Braes of Yarrow.'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: From Stirling Castle, we had an aerial view of the winding Forth river. We explored the banks of the Clyde, Tay, and Tweed rivers. When we arrived at Clovenford, my charming companion suggested we take a detour to visit the hills of Yarrow, no matter what obstacles we may face.

text:
'Let Yarrow folk, 'frae' Selkirk town,
Who have been buying, selling,
Go back to Yarrow, 'tis their own;
Each maiden to her dwelling!
On Yarrow's banks let herons feed,
Hares couch, and rabbits burrow!
But we will downward with the Tweed,
Nor turn aside to Yarrow.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: The speaker urges the people from Yarrow who have been buying and selling in Selkirk town to return home. He suggests that each maiden should go to her own dwelling. The speaker wants the herons, hares, and rabbits to remain on the banks of Yarrow, but he himself plans to travel downwards with the Tweed and avoid going to Yarrow.

text:
'There's Galla Water, Leader Haughs,
Both lying right before us;
And Dryborough, where with chiming Tweed
The lintwhites sing in chorus;
There's pleasant Tiviot-dale, a land
Made blithe with plough and harrow:
Why throw away a needful day
To go in search of Yarrow?
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: The speaker points out the beauty of Galla Water, Leader Haughs, Dryborough, and Tiviot-dale, all of which are in close proximity. They question the need to waste time searching for Yarrow when there is already so much beauty around them. The lintwhites singing in chorus with the chiming Tweed in Dryborough and the pleasant land of Tiviot-dale, made lively by plough and harrow, are particularly delightful. The speaker suggests that it would be better to appreciate the beauty that is already present rather than searching for something that may not be as appealing.

text:
'What's Yarrow but a river bare,
That glides the dark hills under?
There are a thousand such elsewhere
As worthy of your wonder.'
--Strange words they seemed of slight and scorn
My True-love sighed for sorrow;
And looked me in the face, to think
I thus could speak of Yarrow!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: The speaker questions the significance of the Yarrow River, suggesting that there are many other rivers as deserving of admiration. The speaker's true love finds these words to be insulting and sighs in sorrow at the speaker's lack of appreciation for the beauty of Yarrow.

text:
'Oh! green,' said I, 'are Yarrow's holms,
And sweet is Yarrow flowing!
Fair hangs the apple frae the rock,
But we will leave it growing.
O'er hilly path, and open Strath,
We'll wander Scotland thorough;
But, though so near, we will not turn
Into the dale of Yarrow.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: I exclaimed how beautiful the green fields of Yarrow are and how pleasant it is to see the river flowing. Despite the tempting sight of an apple hanging from a rock, we will not pluck it and leave it to grow. We will explore Scotland through its hills and valleys but we will resist the temptation to turn towards Yarrow's valley, even though it is so close.

text:
'Let beeves and home-bred kine partake
The sweets of Burn-mill meadow;
The swan on still St. Mary's Lake
Float double, swan and shadow!
We will not see them; will not go,
To-day, nor yet to-morrow,
Enough if in our hearts we know
There's such a place as Yarrow.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: We should let the cows graze in the meadow at Burn-mill and enjoy the stillness of St. Mary's Lake where swans swim with their reflections. Even though we may not physically visit these places today or tomorrow, it is enough to know that Yarrow exists and hold it in our hearts.

text:
'Be Yarrow stream unseen, unknown!
It must, or we shall rue it:
We have a vision of our own;
Ah! why should we undo it?
The treasured dreams of times long past,
We'll keep them, winsome Marrow!
For when we're there, although 'tis fair,
'Twill be another Yarrow!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: Let the Yarrow stream remain hidden and undiscovered, or else we will regret it. We have a unique vision that we must not abandon. We will hold onto our cherished memories of the past, dear Marrow, for even if we return to a place that appears the same, it will never be the same Yarrow as before.

text:
'If Care with freezing years should come,
And wandering seem but folly,--
Should we be loth to stir from home,
And yet be melancholy;
Should life be dull, and spirits low,
'Twill soothe us in our sorrow,
That earth has something yet to show,
The bonny holms of Yarrow!'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Yarrow Unvisited
explanation: If old age and aimlessness should make us hesitant to leave our homes and cause us to feel sad, we can take comfort in knowing that there are still beautiful places to discover on Earth, such as the lovely meadows of Yarrow.

poem_title: On The Final Submission Of The Tyrolese
explanation: The shepherds fought for a moral cause, otherwise they would not have been able to maintain their focus and sense of purpose when powerful rulers were defeated. The pursuit of this moral good was not in vain.

text:
For in their magnanimity and fame
Powers have they left, an impulse, and a claim
Which neither can be overturned nor bought.
Sleep, Warriors, sleep! among your hills repose!
We know that ye, beneath the stern control
Of awful prudence, keep the unvanquished soul:
And when, impatient of her guilt and woes,
Europe breaks forth; then, Shepherds! shall ye rise
For perfect triumph o'er your Enemies.
poem_title: On The Final Submission Of The Tyrolese
explanation: The powers, impulses, and claims left by the magnanimous and famous Warriors cannot be overturned or bought. They should rest among their hills while their unvanquished soul is kept under control by their awful prudence. When Europe breaks forth with guilt and woes, the Shepherds will rise for perfect triumph over their enemies.

text:
O'ER the wide earth, on mountain and on plain,
Dwells in the affections and the soul of man
A Godhead, like the universal PAN;
But more exalted, with a brighter train:
And shall his bounty be dispensed in vain,
Showered equally on city and on field,
And neither hope nor steadfast promise yield
In these usurping times of fear and pain?
Such doom awaits us. Nay, forbid it Heaven!
We know the arduous strife, the eternal laws
To which the triumph of all good is given,
High sacrifice, and labour without pause,
Even to the death:--else wherefore should the eye
Of man converse with immortality?
poem_title: O’er The Wide Earth, On Mountain And On Plain
explanation: There exists a Godhead in the hearts and souls of all people, residing on mountains and plains across the vast earth. This divine being is like the universal Pan, but more elevated and radiant. However, in these times of fear and suffering, will this deity's generosity be in vain? Will it be distributed equally in both cities and fields without any hope or promise? Unfortunately, this seems to be our fate. But we must not let this happen. We are aware of the challenges we face, the constant struggle and sacrifice required for the triumph of good over evil. We must be prepared to work tirelessly, even to the point of death, if we hope to attain a conversation with immortality.

text:
A FAMOUS man is Robin Hood,
The English ballad-singer's joy!
And Scotland has a thief as good,
An outlaw of as daring mood;
She has her brave ROB ROY!
Then clear the weeds from off his Grave,
And let us chant a passing stave,
In honour of that Hero brave!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Robin Hood is a renowned figure in English ballads, while Scotland has its own equally daring outlaw in Rob Roy. We should pay homage to Rob Roy by clearing the weeds from his grave and singing a tribute to this brave hero.

text:
Heaven gave Rob Roy a dauntless heart
And wondrous length and strength of arm:
Nor craved he more to quell his foes,
Or keep his friends from harm.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Rob Roy was blessed by heaven with a fearless attitude and extraordinary physical abilities, including long and powerful arms. He didn't desire anything else to defeat his enemies or protect his loved ones from danger.

text:
Yet was Rob Roy as wise as brave;
Forgive me if the phrase be strong;--
A Poet worthy of Rob Roy
Must scorn a timid song.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Rob Roy was not only courageous but also intelligent. The poet who writes about him must not shy away from using strong words, as he deserves nothing less than a bold and powerful tribute.

text:
Say, then, that he was 'wise' as brave;
As wise in thought as bold in deed:
For in the principles of things
'He' sought his moral creed.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: The person in question was both courageous and intelligent. Their bravery was matched by their wisdom, as they sought to understand the fundamental principles of life in order to form their moral beliefs.

text:
Said generous Rob, 'What need of books?
Burn all the statutes and their shelves:
They stir us up against our kind;
And worse, against ourselves.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Rob, who is a generous person, believes that books are unnecessary and should be burned. He thinks that the laws and regulations contained in these books only create division and conflict within society. Furthermore, they encourage people to turn against each other and even against themselves.

text:
'We have a passion--make a law,
Too false to guide us or control!
And for the law itself we fight
In bitterness of soul.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: We possess an intense desire to enact a law that we know is flawed and incapable of providing proper guidance or regulation. Despite this, we proceed to fight vehemently for the implementation of the law, causing internal turmoil and animosity towards one another.

text:
'And, puzzled, blinded thus, we lose
Distinctions that are plain and few:
These find I graven on my heart:
'That' tells me what to do.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: We become confused and unable to distinguish clearly when we are perplexed and blinded. However, there are some simple distinctions that are engraved in our hearts, and the word "that" helps us to know what action to take.

text:
'The creatures see of flood and field,
And those that travel on the wind!
With them no strife can last; they live
In peace, and peace of mind.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: The animals that inhabit both the water and the land, as well as those that soar through the air, possess a unique ability to live in harmony with one another. Conflict and discord are not part of their existence; instead, they enjoy a peaceful coexistence and a sense of tranquility within themselves.

text:
'For why?--because the good old rule
Sufficeth them, the simple plan,
That they should take, who have the power,
And they should keep who can.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: This is because those in power abide by a simple, ancient principle: they take what they want and keep it for themselves. There is no need for complexity or justification; the strong simply exert their dominance over the weak. This approach has endured over time and remains the guiding principle for those in positions of authority.

text:
'A lesson that is quickly learned,
A signal this which all can see!
Thus nothing here provokes the strong
To wanton cruelty.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: This is a lesson that can be quickly understood by all. It is a clear signal that nothing should provoke the strong to act with cruel intentions.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: The poem suggests that any form of abnormal behavior or thinking is discouraged and those who foolishly try to pursue it are tamed. However, everyone has the freedom to shape their desires according to their own capabilities. It emphasizes the importance of staying within the boundaries of societal norms and not attempting to deviate from them. The poem implies that one should not aim for things that are beyond their reach, and instead, focus on what is achievable within their limitations.

text:
'All kinds, and creatures, stand and fall
By strength of prowess or of wit:
'Tis God's appointment who must sway,
And who is to submit.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: God decides who will succeed or fail based on their strength and intelligence. All creatures must abide by God's decisions and accept their place in the world.

text:
'Since, then, the rule of right is plain,
And longest life is but a day;
To have my ends, maintain my rights,
I'll take the shortest way.'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: The speaker asserts that the path to achieving their goals and preserving their rights is straightforward, as the rule of right is easily understood. They also emphasize the fleeting nature of life, likening it to a single day. Thus, they conclude that they will take the most efficient and direct route to achieve their objectives.

text:
And thus among these rocks he lived,
Through summer heat and winter snow:
The Eagle, he was lord above,
And Rob was lord below.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Rob lived among the rocks throughout the year, enduring both the scorching summer heat and the freezing winter snow. While the eagle ruled the skies, Rob was the master of the land below.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: It could have been possible, or at least it seemed that way, but unfortunate circumstances prevented it from happening. The political situation at the time was not favorable, as the power of the government was too strong. It was a matter of timing, and unfortunately, he arrived too late.

text:
Or shall we say an age too soon?
For, were the bold Man living 'now',
How might he flourish in his pride,
With buds on every bough!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Maybe it's too early for this time, or that is to say, it may be too soon for the bold man to exist in this era. If he were alive now, he would be in his prime, with buds blooming on every tree and branch.

text:
Then rents and factors, rights of chase,
Sheriffs, and lairds and their domains,
Would all have seemed but paltry things,
Not worth a moment's pains.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: The subjects of rents, factors, rights of chase, sheriffs, and lairds with their domains would have appeared insignificant and not worth considering.

text:
Rob Roy had never lingered here,
To these few meagre Vales confined;
But thought how wide the world, the times
How fairly to his mind!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Rob Roy had never stayed in these small valleys because he believed the world was vast and there were better times ahead that suited him well.

text:
And to his Sword he would have said,
Do Thou my sovereign will enact
From land to land through half the earth!
Judge thou of law and fact!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: He would have instructed his sword to carry out his orders and travel across half the world to enforce his will. The sword would act as both judge and executioner, deciding what is right and wrong and punishing those who do not comply with his wishes.

text:
''Tis fit that we should do our part,
Becoming, that mankind should learn
That we are not to be surpassed
In fatherly concern.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: It is appropriate for us to take action and demonstrate to humanity that we are capable of showing fatherly care and concern that cannot be surpassed by anyone else.

text:
'Of old things all are over old,
Of good things none are good enough:--
We'll show that we can help to frame
A world of other stuff.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Everything from the past is outdated and everything that is good isn't good enough. We will prove ourselves by contributing to the creation of something new and different.

text:
'I, too, will have my kings that take
From me the sign of life and death:
Kingdoms shall shift about, like clouds,
Obedient to my breath.'
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: I will also have rulers who hold power over life and death, and kingdoms will constantly change, like clouds, following my every command.

text:
And, if the word had been fulfilled,
As 'might' have been, then, thought of joy!
France would have had her present Boast,
And we our own Rob Roy!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: If only the promise had been kept, imagine the happiness that would have been felt. France would have had reason to boast and we would have celebrated our own hero, Rob Roy.

text:
Oh! say not so; compare them not;
I would not wrong thee, Champion brave!
Would wrong thee nowhere; least of all
Here standing by thy grave.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Please don't compare them, I don't want to offend you, my brave Champion. I wouldn't want to hurt you anywhere, especially not here at your final resting place.

text:
For Thou, although with some wild thoughts,
Wild Chieftain of a savage Clan!
Hadst this to boast of; thou didst love
The 'liberty' of man.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: You, as a wild leader of a savage clan, had some untamed ideas. However, you had one thing to be proud of - your love for the freedom of humanity.

text:
And, had it been thy lot to live
With us who now behold the light,
Thou would'st have nobly stirred thyself,
And battled for the Right.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: If you had lived among us and experienced the same circumstances that we do, you would have bravely fought for what is just and right.

text:
For thou wert still the poor man's stay,
The poor man's heart, the poor man's hand;
And all the oppressed, who wanted strength,
Had thine at their command.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: You were the support, love, and helping hand of the poor. They could rely on you whenever they needed strength to fight against oppression.

text:
Bear witness many a pensive sigh
Of thoughtful Herdsman when he strays
Alone upon Loch Veol's heights,
And by Loch Lomond's braes!
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Many a thoughtful herdsman can be seen sighing pensively as he wanders alone on the heights of Loch Veol and by the braes of Loch Lomond.

text:
And, far and near, through vale and hill,
Are faces that attest the same;
The proud heart flashing through the eyes,
At sound of ROB ROY'S name.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  X. Rob Roy’s Grave                                                        .
explanation: Faces from all over, whether in the valleys or on the hills, bear witness to the same thing: the proud heart that shines through their eyes at the mere mention of Rob Roy's name.

text:
DEGENERATE Douglas! oh, the unworthy Lord!
Whom mere despite of heart could so far please,
And love of havoc, (for with such disease
Fame taxes him,) that he could send forth word
To level with the dust a noble horde,
A brotherhood of venerable Trees,
Leaving an ancient dome, and towers like these,
Beggared and outraged!--Many hearts deplored
The fate of those old Trees; and oft with pain
The traveller, at this day, will stop and gaze
On wrongs, which Nature scarcely seems to heed:
For sheltered places, bosoms, nooks, and bays,
And the pure mountains, and the gentle Tweed,
And the green silent pastures, yet remain.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xii. Sonnet Composed At ---- Castle
explanation: The poem "Degenerate Douglas" laments the destruction of a group of noble trees by Lord Douglas. The speaker expresses their disgust for Lord Douglas, who seems to have a love for destruction and chaos. The trees were part of a venerable brotherhood and their destruction left an ancient building and towers in ruins. Many mourned the loss of these old trees and even today, travelers stop to observe the injustice. Despite this, nature continues to thrive in sheltered places, mountains, pastures, and the gentle Tweed.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour Of Scotland, 1803  Vi. Glen-Almain, Or, The Narrow Glen
explanation: Ossian, a poet who wrote about battles and death, rests in a quiet and secluded narrow gorge. The only sound heard is a gentle stream flowing nearby.

text:
And should, methinks, when all was past,
Have rightfully been laid at last
Where rocks were rudely heaped, and rent
As by a spirit turbulent;
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour Of Scotland, 1803  Vi. Glen-Almain, Or, The Narrow Glen
explanation: It seems appropriate that when everything is said and done, the remains should be placed where the rocks are piled up and broken as if by a restless spirit.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour Of Scotland, 1803  Vi. Glen-Almain, Or, The Narrow Glen
explanation: In a place where the scenery was harsh and the noise was unruly, and where everything seemed incompatible; within a gloomy and mournful hideaway, fear and sadness intersect.

text:
But this is calm; there cannot be
A more entire tranquillity.
Does then the Bard sleep here indeed?
Or is it but a groundless creed?
What matters it?--I blame them not
Whose Fancy in this lonely Spot
Was moved; and in such way expressed
Their notion of its perfect rest.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour Of Scotland, 1803  Vi. Glen-Almain, Or, The Narrow Glen
explanation: The speaker observes the calmness of the place and wonders if the bard is really buried here or if it's just a belief. Regardless, the speaker doesn't judge those who were inspired by the peacefulness of the spot and expressed their thoughts about it.

text:
A convent, even a hermit's cell,
Would break the silence of this Dell:
It is not quiet, is not ease;
But something deeper far than these:
The separation that is here
Is of the grave; and of austere
Yet happy feelings of the dead:
And, therefore, was it rightly said
That Ossian, last of all his race!
Lies buried in this lonely place.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour Of Scotland, 1803  Vi. Glen-Almain, Or, The Narrow Glen
explanation: This valley is so quiet and peaceful that even a convent or a hermit's cell would disturb the silence. However, it's not just a lack of noise or ease that makes it special, but a deeper sense of separation that comes with death. It's an austere yet happy feeling that belongs to the dead. That's why it's fitting that Ossian, the last of his people, is buried in this lonely place.

text:
WHAT crowd is this? what have we here! we must not pass it by;
A Telescope upon its frame, and pointed to the sky:
Long is it as a barber's pole, or mast of little boat,
Some little pleasure-skiff, that doth on Thames's waters float.
explanation: Who is in this gathering? What is happening here? We cannot ignore it. There is a telescope mounted on a stand and directed towards the sky. It is as long as a barber's pole or a small boat's mast. Perhaps it belongs to a small pleasure boat floating on the Thames.

The Showman is wise in his choice of location, opting for Leicester's bustling square. The night is pleasant, with clear skies and a calm but eager crowd who eagerly await their turn to pay and witness what the Showman has to offer. Those who are not currently viewing are envious of those who are, acknowledging that the experience must be truly unique and insightful.

text:
Yet, Showman, where can lie the cause? Shall thy Implement have blame,
A boaster, that when he is tried, fails, and is put to shame?
Or is it good as others are, and be their eyes in fault?
Their eyes, or minds? or, finally, is yon resplendent vault?
explanation: The speaker wonders why the Showman's tool is failing. Is it because it is a boastful tool that fails when put to the test? Or is it just like any other tool but the fault lies with the people who are using it- perhaps their eyes or minds are to blame? Or maybe the fault lies with the resplendent sky above them.

text:
Is nothing of that radiant pomp so good as we have here?
Or gives a thing but small delight that never can be dear?
The silver moon with all her vales, and hills of mightiest fame,
Doth she betray us when they're seen? or are they but a name?
explanation: Is anything as good as what we have here? Or is anything that doesn't hold value truly enjoyable? The moon with its stunning valleys and famous hills, do they deceive us or are they just a label?

text:
Or is it rather that Conceit rapacious is and strong,
And bounty never yields so much but it seems to do her wrong?
Or is it, that when human Souls a journey long have had
And are returned into themselves, they cannot but be sad?
explanation: Is it possible that the feeling of superiority is powerful and greedy, while acts of kindness and generosity are never enough and can even be seen as offensive? Alternatively, could it be that after a long period of growth and self-discovery, individuals are unable to avoid feeling melancholic upon returning to their former selves?

text:
Or must we be constrained to think that these Spectators rude,
Poor in estate, of manners base, men of the multitude,
Have souls which never yet have risen, and therefore prostrate lie?
No, no, this cannot be;--men thirst for power and majesty!
explanation: Is it fair to assume that the spectators who lack refinement and wealth are incapable of having elevated souls? Are we to believe that they are content with being subservient? Absolutely not. Everyone wants to feel powerful and important.

text:
Does, then, a deep and earnest thought the blissful mind employ
Of him who gazes, or has gazed? a grave and steady joy,
That doth reject all show of pride, admits no outward sign,
Because not of this noisy world, but silent and divine!
explanation: Does a profound and sincere contemplation occupy the contented mind of someone who gazes or has gazed? This brings a solemn and unwavering delight, which refuses any display of arrogance and welcomes no external indication. It does not belong to this clamorous world, but rather to a quiet and heavenly realm.

text:
Whatever be the cause, 'tis sure that they who pry and pore
Seem to meet with little gain, seem less happy than before:
One after One they take their turn, nor have I one espied
That doth not slackly go away, as if dissatisfied.
explanation: No matter the reason, those who search and study intensely seem to gain little and become less content than before. Each one takes their turn, but I have not seen a single one who does not leave lazily and dissatisfied.

text:
------Brook and road
Were fellow-travellers in this gloomy Pass,
And with them did we journey several hours
At a slow step. The immeasurable height
Of woods decaying, never to be decayed,
The stationary blasts of waterfalls,
And in the narrow rent, at every turn,
Winds thwarting winds bewildered and forlorn,
The torrents shooting from the clear blue sky,
The rocks that muttered close upon our ears,
Black drizzling crags that spake by the wayside
As if a voice were in them, the sick sight
And giddy prospect of the raving stream,
The unfettered clouds and region of the heavens,
Tumult and peace, the darkness and the light--
Were all like workings of one mind, the features
Of the same face, blossoms upon one tree,
Characters of the great Apocalypse,
The types and symbols of Eternity,
Of first, and last, and midst, and without end.
explanation: The speaker describes a journey through a dark and ominous pass with a brook and road as companions. The decaying woods and constant waterfalls create an overwhelming sense of height and power. The winds are chaotic and the narrow path is full of treacherous rocks and cliffs. The clouds and sky are limitless and the scenery is both beautiful and terrifying, representing the workings of one mind and the symbols of eternity. The journey is a metaphor for life, with its tumultuous and peaceful moments, darkness and light, and the sense of the infinite.

text:
MARK the concentred hazels that enclose
Yon old grey Stone, protected from the ray
Of noontide suns:--and even the beams that play
And glance, while wantonly the rough wind blows,
Are seldom free to touch the moss that grows
Upon that roof, amid embowering gloom,
The very image framing of a Tomb,
In which some ancient Chieftain finds repose
Among the lonely mountains.--Live, ye trees!
And thou, grey Stone, the pensive likeness keep
Of a dark chamber where the Mighty sleep:
For more than Fancy to the influence bends
When solitary Nature condescends
To mimic Time's forlorn humanities.
poem_title: Mark The Concentrated Hazels That Enclose
explanation: The speaker directs the reader's attention to a group of hazel trees that surround an old grey stone, which is shielded from the sun's rays. Even the wind does not touch the moss growing on the stone's roof. The stone resembles a tomb where an ancient chieftain rests among the lonely mountains. The speaker urges the trees to live on, and the stone to keep its pensive likeness of a dark chamber where the mighty sleep. Solitary nature mimics Time's forlorn humanities, and the speaker suggests that even more than imagination, reality is influenced by this phenomenon.

text:
OFT have I caught, upon a fitful breeze,
Fragments of far-off melodies,
With ear not coveting the whole,
A part so charmed the pensive soul.
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: I have often heard bits of distant tunes on a restless wind that did not make me long for the complete melody, as one part alone could enchant my pensive spirit.

text:
While a dark storm before my sight
Was yielding, on a mountain height
Loose vapours have I watched, that won
Prismatic colours from the sun;
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: As a storm faded from my view, I observed loose vapors on a mountain peak that reflected the colors of the sun, creating a prismatic display.

text:
Nor felt a wish that heaven would show
The image of its perfect bow.
What need, then, of these finished Strains?
Away with counterfeit Remains!
An abbey in its lone recess,
A temple of the wilderness,
Wrecks though they be, announce with feeling
The majesty of honest dealing.
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: The speaker has never wished to see a perfect rainbow in the sky, therefore, they see no need for these polished poems. They believe that fake artifacts should be done away with and instead, the ruins of an isolated abbey or temple show the true beauty of authenticity. These remains, even in their destroyed state, display the importance of honesty.

text:
Spirit of Ossian! if imbound
In language thou may'st yet be found,
If aught (intrusted to the pen
Or floating on the tongues of men,
Albeit shattered and impaired)
Subsist thy dignity to guard,
In concert with memorial claim
Of old grey stone, and high-born name
That cleaves to rock or pillared cave
Where moans the blast, or beats the wave,
Let Truth, stern arbitress of all,
Interpret that Original,
And for presumptuous wrongs atone;--
Authentic words be given, or none!
Time is not blind;--yet He, who spares
Pyramid pointing to the stars,
Hath preyed with ruthless appetite
On all that marked the primal flight
Of the poetic ecstasy
Into the land of mystery.
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: The speaker addresses the spirit of Ossian, an ancient Scottish bard, asking if his essence can still be found in language, even if it has been damaged over time. The speaker suggests that the spirit of Ossian should be preserved through written works and oral tradition, alongside physical landmarks such as stones and caves that bear his name. The speaker urges that only authentic words should be used to interpret Ossian's original work and those who have wronged his legacy should make amends. The speaker acknowledges that Time has destroyed much of Ossian's work, but laments that even physical monuments have not been spared from the ravages of Time.

text:
No tongue is able to rehearse
One measure, Orpheus! of thy verse;
Musaeus, stationed with his lyre
Supreme among the Elysian quire,
Is, for the dwellers upon earth,
Mute as a lark ere morning's birth.
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: Orpheus' poetry is so remarkable that even Musaeus, who is considered the best among the Elysian choir, cannot fully replicate it. No one on earth can truly appreciate the beauty of Orpheus' verse, as it is beyond human comprehension.

text:
Why grieve for these, though past away
The music, and extinct the lay?
When thousands, by severer doom,
Full early to the silent tomb
Have sunk, at Nature's call; or strayed
From hope and promise, self-betrayed;
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: There is no need to mourn the loss of music and songs from the past when there are many others who have died prematurely or have fallen from grace due to their own actions.

poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: The poets in question have lost their former glory and are now burdened with regret over their past actions. They are desperate for redemption and are without any companionship due to their own mistakes. The author then turns to more successful poets who have remained true to their craft and have not strayed from their path, urging them to continue their work.

text:
Whose lofty genius could survive
Privation, under sorrow thrive;
In whom the fiery Muse revered
The symbol of a snow-white beard,
Bedewed with meditative tears
Dropped from the lenient cloud of years.
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: This passage describes a person whose great intellect can endure hardship and find success in the midst of sorrow. The author also notes that this person is revered by the Muse, symbolized by their snowy white beard that is dampened by tears shed during deep contemplation. The tears are compared to a gentle cloud, further emphasizing the person's wisdom and experience gained over time.

text:
Brothers in soul! though distant times
Produced you nursed in various climes,
Ye, when the orb of life had waned,
A plenitude of love retained:
Hence, while in you each sad regret
By corresponding hope was met,
Ye lingered among human kind,
Sweet voices for the passing wind,
Departing sunbeams, loth to stop,
Though smiling on the last hill top!
Such to the tender-hearted maid
Even ere her joys begin to fade;
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: This passage is about the connection between people who may have grown up in different places and times, but still share a strong bond. The author refers to them as "brothers in soul" who have a lot of love for each other, even as they approach the end of their lives. They are compared to sweet voices and departing sunbeams that are reluctant to disappear, and bring comfort to those around them. The passage suggests that this bond is especially important for young women, who may need the support of these kind-hearted individuals as they face challenges in life.

text:
Such, haply, to the rugged chief
By fortune crushed, or tamed by grief;
Appears, on Morven's lonely shore,
Dim-gleaming through imperfect lore,
The Son of Fingal; such was blind
Maeonides of ampler mind;
Such Milton, to the fountain head
Of glory by Urania led!
poem_title: Written In A Blank Leaf Of Macpherson's Ossian
explanation: On Morven's desolate coast, there resides a figure who resembles the likes of the great epic poets: Fingal's son, who is cloaked in a veil of mystery, appears to those who are crushed by fate or subdued by sorrow. He is reminiscent of the likes of Maeonides and Milton, who were both blessed with a greater understanding of the world and led by Urania to the pinnacle of glory. The Son of Fingal is shrouded in the same aura of greatness, illuminated dimly through limited knowledge.

text:
Sweet was the walk along the narrow lane
At noon, the bank and hedge-rows all the way
Shagged with wild pale green tufts of fragrant hay,
Caught by the hawthorns from the loaded wain,
Which Age with many a slow stoop strove to gain;
explanation: The walk along the narrow lane was pleasant at noon, with the banks and hedges covered in wild, pale green tufts of fragrant hay. The hay was caught by the hawthorns from a loaded wagon, and even though Age struggled to gather it with many slow stoops, the scenery remained sweet.

text:
And childhood, seeming still most busy, took
His little rake; with cunning side-long look,
Sauntering to pluck the strawberries wild, unseen.
Now, too, on melancholy's idle dreams
Musing, the lone spot with my soul agrees,
Quiet and dark; for through the thick wove trees
Scarce peeps the curious star till solemn gleams
The clouded moon, and calls me forth to stray
Thro' tall, green, silent woods and ruins gray.
explanation: As a child, the speaker was busy playing and exploring, using a small rake to collect wild strawberries while trying to remain unnoticed. Now, the speaker finds solace in quiet and dark places, often lost in melancholic thoughts. The thick trees and clouds obscure the stars, but the moon occasionally shines through and beckons the speaker to wander through the silent woods and ruins.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xiv. Fly, Some Kind Haringer, To Grasmere-Dale
explanation: Someone, a kind messenger, please fly to Grasmere-dale and inform the people there that we are coming today. Travel swiftly over the fields and hills, but make sure to tell one particular cottage the news.

text:
There let a mystery of joy prevail,
The kitten frolic, like a gamesome sprite,
And Rover whine, as at a second sight
Of near-approaching good that shall not fail:
And from that Infant's face let joy appear;
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xiv. Fly, Some Kind Haringer, To Grasmere-Dale
explanation: Let there be an aura of happiness, a sense of inexplicable joy. The kitten plays around, full of energy like a mischievous fairy, while Rover whines in anticipation of something good that's about to happen. Let the baby's face reflect the happiness and the joy that surrounds them.

text:
Yea, let our Mary's one companion child--
That hath her six weeks' solitude beguiled
With intimations manifold and dear,
While we have wandered over wood and wild--
Smile on his Mother now with bolder cheer.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  Xiv. Fly, Some Kind Haringer, To Grasmere-Dale
explanation: Let Mary's only child, who has kept her company for six weeks with affectionate gestures, bring a smile to her face as we return from our journey through the woods and wilderness.

text:
COME ye--who, if (which Heaven avert!) the Land
Were with herself at strife, would take your stand,
Like gallant Falkland, by the Monarch's side,
And, like Montrose, make Loyalty your pride--
Come ye--who, not less zealous, might display
Banners at enmity with regal sway,
And, like the Pyms and Miltons of that day,
Think that a State would live in sounder health
If Kingship bowed its head to Commonwealth--
Ye too--whom no discreditable fear
Would keep, perhaps with many a fruitless tear,
Uncertain what to choose and how to steer--
And ye--who might mistake for sober sense
And wise reserve the plea of indolence--
Come ye--whate'er your creed--O waken all,
Whate'er your temper, at your Country's call;
explanation: This passage is a call to action to all individuals, regardless of their political beliefs, to unite and stand with their country in times of strife. The author references historical figures such as Falkland and Montrose, who stood by the monarchy, as well as Pyms and Miltons, who opposed regal rule and supported Commonwealth. The passage invites those who may be uncertain or hesitant in their beliefs to join in with the cause of their country, without allowing fear or indolence to deter them. Regardless of one's creed or temperament, the message is clear: it is time to awaken and answer the call of one's country.

text:
Resolving (this a free-born Nation can)
To have one Soul, and perish to a man,
Or save this honoured Land from every Lord
But British reason and the British sword.
explanation: The people of this Nation have come to a decision to unite as one and fight to the death, rather than allow any other rulers to take control. They will only submit to British authority and the power of their military might in order to protect their beloved Land.

text:
THE gentlest Shade that walked Elysian plains
Might sometimes covet dissoluble chains;
Even for the tenants of the zone that lies
Beyond the stars, celestial Paradise,
Methinks 'twould heighten joy, to overleap
At will the crystal battlements, and peep
Into some other region, though less fair,
To see how things are made and managed there.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: Even the most peaceful spirits in the afterlife may sometimes desire to experience more than their own surroundings, such as the paradise beyond the stars. It would bring them great pleasure to be able to break free from the confines of their own realm and observe other worlds, even if they are not as beautiful. They long to witness the creation and management of these other places.

text:
Change for the worse might please, incursion bold
Into the tracts of darkness and of cold;
O'er Limbo lake with aery flight to steer,
And on the verge of Chaos hang in fear.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: Sometimes people may find pleasure in negative change, embracing a bold invasion into the depths of darkness and coldness. They may even navigate through the Limbo lake with ease, fearlessly hovering on the edge of Chaos.

text:
Such animation often do I find,
Power in my breast, wings growing in my mind,
Then, when some rock or hill is overpast,
Perhance without one look behind me cast.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: I often feel inspired and energized, as if I have wings in my mind, when I encounter challenges that I must overcome. However, once I have succeeded and moved on from these obstacles, I may not even take a moment to reflect on my progress before continuing forward.

text:
Some barrier with which Nature, from the birth
Of things, has fenced this fairest spot on earth.
O pleasant transit, Grasmere! to resign
Such happy fields, abodes so calm as thine;
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: Nature has created a barrier around Grasmere, the most beautiful place on earth, since the beginning of time. It is a pleasant journey to leave such peaceful and happy fields behind, as Grasmere is a tranquil abode.

poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: This passage describes a person who is not isolated and struggling with themselves, but rather chooses to live freely and in harmony with nature. They are not bound by the pressures of work, time or materialism, but find joy in simple pleasures even in the most remote and challenging environments. Their freedom comes from within, and they are able to extract happiness and luxury from even the harshest conditions.

text:
With prompt embrace all beauty to enfold,
And having rights in all that we behold.
--Then why these lingering steps?--A bright adieu,
For a brief absence, proves that love is true;
Ne'er can the way be irksome or forlorn
That winds into itself for sweet return.
poem_title: Memorials Of A Tour In Scotland, 1803  I. Departure From The Vale Of Grasmere, August 1803
explanation: Embrace beauty and cherish all that we see, for we have the right to do so. Why hesitate? A quick goodbye proves that love is genuine. The journey may not always be easy, but it will lead us back to the sweet return.

text:
SEVEN Daughter had Lord Archibald,
All children of one mother:
You could not say in one short day
What love they bore each other.
A garland, of seven lilies, wrought!
Seven sisters that together dwell;
But he, bold Knight as ever fought,
Their Father, took of them no thought,
He loved the wars so well.
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: Lord Archibald had seven daughters who all had the same mother, and they loved each other deeply, but their father was more interested in fighting wars than caring for his family. The seven sisters lived together and were symbolized by a garland of seven lilies. However, their father did not pay much attention to them, leading to a sense of loneliness in their home of Binnorie. The poem calls for a mournful song to express the sadness of their solitude.

text:
Fresh blows the wind, a western wind,
And from the shores of Erin,
Across the wave, a Rover brave
To Binnorie is steering:
Right onward to the Scottish strand
The gallant ship is borne;
The warriors leap upon the land,
And hark! the Leader of the band
Hath blown his bugle horn.
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: The wind is blowing fresh from the west, and a brave Rover is sailing from Erin to Binnorie. The ship is headed straight for the Scottish shore, and as it arrives, the warriors jump off and the Leader blows his horn. The song calls for a mournful tune as it speaks of the solitude of Binnorie.

text:
Beside a grotto of their own,
With boughs above them closing,
The Seven are laid, and in the shade
They lie like fawns reposing.
But now, upstarting with affright
At noise of man and steed,
Away they fly to left, to rightÑ
Of your fair household, Father-knight,
Methinks you take small heed!
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: Seven individuals are resting in a grotto under the shelter of branches. They seem peaceful like fawns until the sound of humans and horses frightens them and they scatter in different directions. The speaker, who addresses a Father-knight, observes that he seems indifferent to the disturbance caused by his household. The speaker then invites the readers to sing a mournful song about the loneliness of Binnorie.

text:
Away the even fair Campbells fly,
And, over hill and hollow,
With menace proud, and insult loud,
The youthful Rovers follow.
Cried they, 'Your Father loves to roam:
Enough for him to find
The empty house when he comes home;
For us your yellow ringlets comb,
For us be fair and kind!'
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: The Campbells flee while the young Rovers chase after them with arrogance and insults. They mockingly suggest that the Campbells' father prefers to wander and leave an empty house, while they demand the attention of the fair-haired Campbell girls. The poem ends with a mournful song about the desolate state of Binnorie.

text:
Some close behind, some side to side,
Like clouds in stormy weather;
They run, and cry, 'Nay, let us die,
And let us die together.'
A lake was near; the shore was steep;
There never foot had been;
They ran, and with a deperate leap
Together plunged into the deep,
Nor ever more were seen.
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: A group of people were running closely together, like clouds in a storm. They cried out that they wanted to die together and soon came across a steep lakeshore where no one had ever been. Without hesitation, they made a desperate leap into the water and were never seen again. The poem ends with a mournful call to sing about the solitude of Binnorie.

text:
The stream that flows out of the lake,
As through the glen it rambles,
Repeats a moan o'er moss and stone,
For those seven lovely Campbells.
Seven little Islands, green and bare,
Have risen from out the deep:
The fishers say, those sisters fair,
By faeries all are buried there,
And there together sleep.
Sing, mournfully, oh! mournfully,
The solitude of Binnorie!
explanation: The flowing stream that meanders through the glen from the lake echoes a mournful tune over moss and stones, lamenting the fate of the seven beautiful Campbell sisters. The seven green and barren islands that have emerged from the deep are said to be the final resting place of the sisters, buried by faeries and sleeping together. The solitude of Binnorie is mournfully sung, as the tragic tale of the Campbell sisters is retold.

text:
Let us quit the leafy arbor,
And the torrent murmuring by;
For the sun is in his harbor,
Weary of the open sky.
explanation: We should leave the shady trees and the babbling stream because the sun is setting and is tired of being out in the open.

text:
Evening now unbinds the fetters
Fashioned by the glowing light;
All that breathe are thankful debtors
To the harbinger of night.
explanation: As the evening approaches, the bonds created by the bright light of the day are released. All living beings are grateful to the arrival of the night.

text:
Yet by some grave thoughts attended
Eve renews her calm career;
For the day that now is ended,
Is the longest of the year.
explanation: Despite being weighed down by serious thoughts, Eve continues on her peaceful journey. The day that has just passed happens to be the longest one of the year.

text:
Dora! sport, as now thou sportest,
On this platform, light and free;
Take thy bliss, while longest, shortest,
Are indifferent to thee!
explanation: Dora, enjoy yourself as you play on this platform with a carefree attitude. The length of time you spend playing does not matter as long as you are happy in the moment.

text:
Who would check the happy feeling
That inspires the linnet's song?
Who would stop the swallow, wheeling
On her pinions swift and strong?
explanation: Who would dare to ruin the joyous emotions that bring about the melodious song of the linnet? Who would be audacious enough to halt the swift and robust wings of the wheeling swallow?

text:
Yet at this impressive season,
Words which tenderness can speak
From the truths of homely reason,
Might exalt the loveliest cheek;
explanation: During this beautiful time of year, simple and sincere words spoken from the heart can enhance the beauty of even the most attractive face through the power of truth and common sense.

text:
And, while shades to shades succeeding
Steal the landscape from the sight,
I would urge this moral pleading,
Last forerunner of "Good night!"
explanation: As the shades of night take over the landscape, I implore you to consider my final plea before bidding farewell.

text:
Summer ebbs; -- each day that follows
Is a reflux from on high,
Tending to the darksome hollows
Where the frosts of winter lie.
explanation: As summer fades away, each passing day becomes a retreat back towards the colder months. The days grow shorter and the weather cools, leading towards the winter season.

text:
He who governs the creation,
In his providence, assigned
Such a gradual declination
To the life of human kind.
explanation: The creator, in his wisdom, has decreed a slow decline in the lifespan of humanity.

text:
Yet we mark it not; -- fruits redden,
Fresh flowers blow, as flowers have blown,
And the heart is loth to deaden
Hopes that she so long hath known.
explanation: We do not acknowledge the passing of time, despite the ripening of fruits and the blooming of fresh flowers. Our hearts are reluctant to let go of the hopes that we have held onto for so long.

text:
Be thou wiser, youthful Maiden!
And when thy decline shall come,
Let not dowers, or boughs fruit-laden,
Hide the knowledge of thy doom.
explanation: Young woman, strive to gain wisdom and understanding. And when you reach old age, do not let material possessions or distractions hide the truth of your impending mortality.

text:
Now, even now, ere wrapped in slumber,
Fix thine eyes upon the sea
That absorbs time, space, and number;
Look thou to Eternity!
explanation: Before you fall asleep, look out at the sea which has the ability to take in time, space, and number. Focus on eternity and its vastness.

text:
Follow thou the flowing river
On whose breast are thither borne
All deceived, and each deceiver,
Through the gates of night and morn;
explanation: Follow the path of the river, where both the deceived and the deceivers are carried through the gates of night and day.

text:
Through the year's successive portals;
Through the bounds which many a star
Marks, not mindless of frail mortals,
When his light returns from far.
explanation: Over the years, passing from one season to the next; crossing the boundaries that separate the stars, which remind us of our fleeting existence. These celestial markers shine their light upon us from great distances, each time they return.

text:
Thus when thou with Time hast travelled
Toward the mighty gulf of things,
And the mazy stream unravelled
With thy best imaginings;
explanation: As you journey through time towards the vast expanse of existence and untangle the complex web of your thoughts and dreams, remember to cherish every moment and experience life to the fullest.

text:
Think, if thou on beauty leanest,
Think how pitiful that stay,
Did not virtue give the meanest
Charms superior to decay.
explanation: Consider that relying solely on physical beauty is a futile pursuit as it will inevitably fade with time. Only through the possession of virtuous qualities can one attain a lasting charm that surpasses the effects of aging.

text:
Duty, like a strict preceptor,
Sometimes frowns, or seems to frown;
Choose her thistle for thy sceptre,
While youth's roses are thy crown.
explanation: Duty can be harsh and unyielding, much like a stern teacher. However, it is important to embrace it and prioritize it over the fleeting pleasures of youth. Rather than holding onto the metaphorical roses of youth, it is better to take up the thistle of duty as a symbol of authority and responsibility.

text:
Grasp it, -- if thou shrink and tremble,
Fairest damsel of the green,
Thou wilt lack the only symbol
That proclaims a genuine queen;
explanation: Take hold of it, dear lady of the forest, even if it frightens you. Without it, you will not possess the emblem that signifies true royalty.

text:
And ensures those palms of honor
Which selected spirits wear,
Bending low before the Donor,
Lord of heaven's unchanging year!
explanation: This verse speaks of the recognition given to exceptional individuals who are chosen for honor. They are humbled before the giver of this recognition, the Lord of the eternal heavens.

text:
'TIS not for the unfeeling, the falsely refined,
The squeamish in taste, and the narrow of mind,
And the small critic wielding his delicate pen,
That I sing of old Adam, the pride of old men.
explanation: I am not writing for those who lack emotions, those who pretend to be sophisticated, those with narrow-mindedness, and those who criticize with a delicate pen. My topic is about old Adam, a source of pride for elderly men.

The man resides in the heart of London, his walking stick a symbol of his authority and his aging hair a sign of his wisdom. His eyes shine brightly, especially when contrasted with the remaining flush of youth on his cheek.

text:
'Mid the dews, in the sunshine of morn,--'mid the joy
Of the fields, he collected that bloom, when a boy,
That countenance there fashioned, which, spite of a stain
That his life hath received, to the last will remain.
explanation: During the morning, amidst the dew and fields, a boy collected a bloom that he used to create a countenance. Despite the stain on his life, the countenance will endure until the end.

text:
A Farmer he was; and his house far and near
Was the boast of the country for excellent cheer:
How oft have I heard in sweet Tilsbury Vale
Of the silver-rimmed horn whence he dealt his mild ale!
explanation: The subject of the passage is a farmer who is known for his excellent hospitality. His house is renowned for its delicious food and drink, with the silver-rimmed horn being a symbol of his famous mild ale. The speaker has heard many stories about this farmer and his home in the Tilsbury Vale.

text:
Yet Adam was far as the farthest from ruin,
His fields seemed to know what their Master was doing:
And turnips, and corn-land, and meadow, and lea,
All caught the infection--as generous as he.
explanation: Adam's farm was thriving and far from destruction. His crops, including turnips, corn, meadow, and lea, seemed to be flourishing in sync with their master's guidance. They all appeared to be thriving due to Adam's generosity and care.

text:
Yet Adam prized little the feast and the bowl,--
The fields better suited the ease of his soul:
He strayed through the fields like an indolent wight,
The quiet of nature was Adam's delight.
explanation: Adam found more comfort and contentment in wandering through the fields than in partaking in feasts and drinking from bowls. He was a laid-back individual who enjoyed the peacefulness of nature. His soul felt more at ease when he was surrounded by the tranquility of the natural world.

text:
For Adam was simple in thought; and the poor,
Familiar with him, made an inn of his door:
He gave them the best that he had; or, to say
What less may mislead you, they took it away.
explanation: Adam was a man of uncomplicated thinking, and the destitute individuals who knew him felt comfortable enough to make his home their temporary lodging. Adam willingly offered them the best of what he had, or to put it more accurately, they helped themselves without any hesitation.

text:
Thus thirty smooth years did he thrive on his farm:
The Genius of plenty preserved him from harm:
At length, what to most is a season of sorrow,
His means are run out,--he must beg, or must borrow.
explanation: For thirty years, he prospered on his farm, thanks to the abundance brought about by his hard work. But eventually, he found himself in a difficult situation that many experience. His resources had been depleted, leaving him with the options of begging or borrowing to survive.

text:
To the neighbours he went,--all were free with their money;
For his hive had so long been replenished with honey,
That they dreamt not of dearth;--He continued his rounds,
Knocked here--and knocked there, pounds still adding to pounds.
explanation: He went to his neighbours and they were generous with their money because he had been successful in his business and they didn't realize that he was experiencing financial difficulties. He went from house to house, collecting more and more money.

text:
He paid what he could with his ill-gotten pelf,
And something, it might be, reserved for himself:
Then (what is too true) without hinting a word,
Turned his back on the country--and off like a bird.
explanation: He used his illegally obtained money to pay off some of his debts, while keeping some for himself. He then left the country without saying anything and disappeared quickly.

text:
