You lift up your eyes!--but I guess that you frame
A judgment too harsh of the sin and the shame;
In him it was scarcely a business of art,
For this he did all in the 'ease' of his heart.
explanation: When you look up and judge someone for their sins and shame, you may be too harsh. The person in question didn't commit their actions with the intention of being an artist; rather, it came naturally to them. Their actions were done with ease and without much thought.

text:
To London--a sad emigration I ween--
With his grey hairs he went from the brook and the green;
And there, with small wealth but his legs and his hands,
As lonely he stood as a crow on the sands.
explanation: He left his home in the countryside, full of sadness, to move to London. Despite having little money, he relied on his own physical abilities to make a living in the big city. He felt isolated and alone, like a solitary crow on a deserted beach.

text:
All trades, as need was, did old Adam assume,--
Served as stable-boy, errand-boy, porter, and groom;
But nature is gracious, necessity kind,
And, in spite of the shame that may lurk in his mind,
explanation: Adam took on various jobs as he needed them, from being a stable boy to a porter and groom. Despite any potential embarrassment he may have felt, nature and necessity were on his side and allowed him to make a living in these various roles.

He appears to be much younger, has a green complexion, and is well-built. His blood seems to be flowing twice as fast as before, and his beard hairs seem to be moving. He is very active and busy, with his fingers moving like bees in a hive.

text:
For he's not like an Old Man that leisurely goes
About work that he knows, in a track that he knows;
But often his mind is compelled to demur,
And you guess that the more then his body must stir.
explanation: He is not like an elderly man who works at his own pace and in a familiar routine. His mind often pauses and hesitates, causing his body to move more in response.

text:
In the throng of the town like a stranger is he,
Like one whose own country's far over the sea;
And Nature, while through the great city he hies,
Full ten times a day takes his heart by surprise.
explanation: The speaker feels like a foreigner in the city, as if their true home is far away. Despite being surrounded by urban life, the beauty of nature still manages to catch their attention multiple times a day.

text:
This gives him the fancy of one that is young,
More of soul in his face than of words on his tongue;
Like a maiden of twenty he trembles and sighs,
And tears of fifteen will come into his eyes.
explanation: He appears youthful in spirit, with a face that expresses more emotion than words can convey. His demeanor is reminiscent of a twenty-year-old woman, as he quivers and exhales in a manner that suggests vulnerability. Even tears of a fifteen-year-old can be observed streaming down his face.

text:
What's a tempest to him, or the dry parching heats?
Yet he watches the clouds that pass over the streets;
With a look of such earnestness often will stand,
You might think he'd twelve reapers at work in the Strand.
explanation: He doesn't care about storms or heat waves, but he does watch the clouds pass over the streets with great interest. He stands with such intensity that it seems as if he has a dozen workers in the busy Strand.

text:
Where proud Covent-garden, in desolate hours
Of snow and hoar-frost, spreads her fruits and her flowers,
Old Adam will smile at the pains that have made
Poor winter look fine in such strange masquerade.
explanation: During the winter season when snow and frost cover Covent Garden, a traditionally vibrant area of London known for its fruits and flowers, the character Old Adam finds amusement in the efforts made to maintain the appearance of beauty in such harsh weather conditions. Despite the desolation, Old Adam takes pleasure in the strange masquerade of winter.

text:
'Mid coaches and chariots, a waggon of straw,
Like a magnet, the heart of old Adam can draw;
With a thousand soft pictures his memory will teem,
And his hearing is touched with the sounds of a dream.
explanation: Amidst the hustle and bustle of coaches and chariots, a simple wagon made of straw has the power to draw in the attention of old Adam. The memories it evokes are plentiful, filling his mind with images of his past, and the sounds he hears transport him to a dreamlike state.

text:
Up the Haymarket hill he oft whistles his way,
Thrusts his hands in a waggon, and smells at the hay;
He thinks of the fields he so often hath mown,
And is happy as if the rich freight were his own.
explanation: He walks up the Haymarket hill while whistling, and puts his hands in a wagon to smell the hay. He remembers the fields he has mowed before and feels joyful as if he owns the hay in the wagon.

text:
But chiefly to Smithfield he loves to repair,--
If you pass by at morning, you'll meet with him there.
The breath of the cows you may see him inhale,
And his heart all the while is in Tilsbury Vale.
explanation: He enjoys spending time in Smithfield, but he particularly loves going there. If you happen to pass by in the morning, you will likely run into him. He can be seen inhaling the breath of cows, and his heart is always in Tilsbury Vale.

text:
Now farewell, old Adam! when low thou art laid,
May one blade of grass spring up over thy head;
And I hope that thy grave, wheresoever it be,
Will hear the wind sigh through the leaves of a tree.
explanation: Goodbye, old Adam. When you are laid to rest, may a single blade of grass grow over your head. It is my wish that your final resting place, wherever it may be, will be accompanied by the gentle sound of the wind rustling through the leaves of a tree.

text:
WHO fancied what a pretty sight
This Rock would be if edged around
With living snow-drops? circlet bright!
How glorious to this orchard-ground!
Who loved the little Rock, and set
Upon its head this coronet?
poem_title: Who Fancied What A Pretty Sight
explanation: Someone had the idea to adorn the Rock with snowdrops, creating a beautiful circular decoration. They admired how it would add to the beauty of the orchard. The person who loved the Rock placed the crown on top of it.

text:
Was it the humour of a child?
Or rather of some gentle maid,
Whose brows, the day that she was styled
The shepherd-queen, were thus arrayed?
Of man mature, or matron sage?
Or old man toying with his age!
poem_title: Who Fancied What A Pretty Sight
explanation: The source of the humor expressed in the poem is uncertain. It could be the humor of a child, a gentle maiden, a mature man, a wise matron, or an old man enjoying their age. The poem questions who the source of the humor could be and leaves it open to interpretation.

text:
I asked--'twas whispered; The device
To each and all might well belong:
It is the Spirit of Paradise
That prompts such work, a Spirit strong,
That gives to all the self-same bent
Where life is wise and innocent.
poem_title: Who Fancied What A Pretty Sight
explanation: I inquired, and it was suggested to me that anyone can possess the tool for such work. The driving force behind such endeavors is the Spirit of Paradise, which is powerful and instills the same inclination in everyone who lives with wisdom and purity.

text:
IT is not to be thought of that the Flood
Of British freedom, which, to the open sea
Of the world's praise, from dark antiquity
Hath flowed, 'with pomp of waters, unwithstood,'
Roused though it be full often to a mood
Which spurns the check of salutary bands,
That this most famous Stream in bogs and sands
Should perish; and to evil and to good
Be lost for ever. In our halls is hung
Armoury of the invincible Knights of old:
We must be free or die, who speak the tongue
That Shakespeare spake; the faith and morals hold
Which Milton held.--In everything we are sprung
Of Earth's first blood, have titles manifold
explanation: The poet expresses that the idea of the British freedom being lost forever due to obstacles and challenges it may face, is not to be entertained. The freedom that has flowed since ancient times should not be lost, as it is too valuable for both good and evil. The poet suggests that the invincible knights of old hang in halls as a reminder of the freedom they fought for, and that those who speak Shakespeare's language must remain free or face death. He also reminds readers that their beliefs and values should align with those of Milton, and that the British people have a long-standing history that they should be proud of.

text:
ONE morning (raw it was and wet---
A foggy day in winter time)
A Woman on the road I met,
Not old, though something past her prime:
Majestic in her person, tall and straight;
And like a Roman matron's was her mien and gait.
explanation: On a cold and misty winter morning, while walking on the road, I came across a woman who was not very old but had already crossed her prime. She had a regal appearance, standing tall and straight, and her demeanor and walk were reminiscent of a Roman matron.

The speaker believes that the spirit of the past is still present and alive. They feel proud that their country has produced such a powerful and dignified spirit. However, when they see this spirit begging for charity like a poor person, their pride is not diminished.

text:
When from these lofty thoughts I woke,
'What is it,' said I, 'that you bear,
Beneath the covert of your Cloak,
Protected from this cold damp air? '
She anwered, soon as she the question heard,
'A simple burthen, Sir, a little Singing-bird.'
explanation: I woke up from my deep thoughts and noticed someone carrying something under their cloak to protect it from the cold and damp air. When I asked what it was, the person replied that it was just a small singing bird, nothing more.

text:
And, thus continuing, she said,
'I had a Son, who many a day
Sailed on the seas, but he is dead;
In Denmark he was cast away:
And I have travelled weary miles to see
If aught which he had owned might still remain for me.
explanation: She spoke again, stating that her son had spent numerous days sailing on the seas, but unfortunately, he had perished in Denmark. She had traveled a great distance in hopes of finding anything that belonged to him that may have survived.

The bird and the cage belonged to the speaker's son, who took good care of it on their many voyages together. However, on the son's last voyage, he left the bird behind, possibly due to premonitions he had.

text:
He to a fellow-lodger's care
Had left it, to be watched and fed,
And pipe its song in safety;---there
I found it when my Son was dead;
And now, God help me for my little wit!
I bear it with me, Sir;---he took so much delight in it.'
explanation: The speaker entrusted his pet bird to a roommate's care to ensure it was properly looked after and could continue to sing without danger. When the speaker's son passed away, he retrieved the bird and now carries it with him as a reminder of his son's joy and love for the bird. The speaker acknowledges his limited understanding but expresses his deep sorrow and attachment to the bird.

text:
O'ERWEENING Statesmen have full long relied
On fleets and armies, and external wealth:
But from 'within' proceeds a Nation's health;
Which shall not fail, though poor men cleave with pride
To the paternal floor; or turn aside,
In the thronged city, from the walks of gain,
As being all unworthy to detain
A Soul by contemplation sanctified.
poem_title: O’erweening Statesmen Have Full Long Relied
explanation: For a long time, arrogant politicians have placed their trust in military and economic power, but the true well-being of a nation comes from within. Even if poor individuals remain attached to their ancestral land or reject the pursuit of material gain in urban areas, the nation's prosperity will not falter. Such people are simply choosing to prioritize the sanctity of their spiritual contemplation over material possessions.

text:
There are who cannot languish in this strife,
Spaniards of every rank, by whom the good
Of such high course was felt and understood;
Who to their Country's cause have bound a life
Erewhile, by solemn consecration, given
To labour and to prayer, to nature, and to heaven.
poem_title: O’erweening Statesmen Have Full Long Relied
explanation: There are Spaniards who cannot endure the conflict and have dedicated their lives to their country's cause through hard work, prayer, and a connection to nature and heaven. They come from all walks of life and understand the value of this noble pursuit.

text:
SHADE of Caractacus, if spirits love
The cause they fought for in their earthly home
To see the Eagle ruffled by the Dove
May soothe thy memory of the chains of Rome.
explanation: Oh Caractacus, if the spirits of those who fought for a cause in their earthly life truly love that cause, then the sight of the mighty Eagle being challenged by the peaceful Dove may bring some peace to your memories of the oppressive Roman rule.

text:
These children claim thee for their sire; the breath
Of thy renown, from Cambrian mountains, fans
A flame within them that despises death
And glorifies the truant youth of Vannes.
explanation: The children see you as their father and are inspired by your reputation which spreads from the mountains in Wales. This inspiration ignites a passion within them that makes them fearless of death and celebrates their rebellious youth in Vannes.

text:
With thy own scorn of tyrants they advance,
But truth divine has sanctified their rage,
A silver cross enchased with flowers of France
Their badge, attests the holy fight they wage.
explanation: They march forward with a deep disdain for oppressive rulers, but their anger is imbued with the righteousness of divine truth. The emblem of their cause is a silver cross adorned with the blooms of France, bearing witness to the sacred battle they are waging.

text:
The shrill defiance of the young crusade
Their veteran foes mock as an idle noise;
But unto Faith and Loyalty comes aid
From Heaven, gigantic force to beardless boys.
explanation: Although the older opponents ridicule the passionate and loud rebellion of the youth, the power of faith and loyalty is bestowed upon them by a divine force, granting immense strength to these inexperienced individuals.

text:
BY their floating mill,
That lies dead and still,
Behold yon Prisoners three,
The Miller with two Dames, on the breast of the Thames!
The platform is small, but gives room for them all;
And they're dancing merrily.
explanation: Three prisoners, a miller and two women, are seen dancing joyfully on a small platform located on the breast of the Thames river, near their floating mill which is now lifeless and still. The scene is an unusual sight as it is uncommon to find prisoners dancing merrily.

text:
From the shore come the notes
To their mill where it floats,
To their house and their mill tethered fast:
To the small wooden isle where, their work to beguile,
They from morning to even take whatever is given;--
And many a blithe day they have past.
explanation: The sound of music drifts from the shore to where the workers are stationed at their mill, which is securely attached to their house. They also have a small wooden island nearby where they spend their days working and enjoying whatever comes their way. They have spent many joyful days in this place.

text:
In sight of the spires,
All alive with the fires
Of the sun going down to his rest,
In the broad open eye of the solitary sky,
They dance,--there are three, as jocund as free,
While they dance on the calm river's breast.
explanation: Three people dance joyfully on the calm river as the sun sets behind the spires, creating a beautiful sight. The open sky watches over them as they twirl and move in unison, enjoying their freedom and the tranquility of the water.

A group of men and women dance in a circle, creating their own music and enjoying the moment without a care. The music is not meant for them specifically, but they take it as their own and let it free them from any worries they may have. They dance without a set time limit, shouting "Long as ye please!" as they revel in the joy of the moment.

text:
They dance not for me,
Yet mine is their glee!
Thus pleasure is spread through the earth
In stray gifts to be claimed by whoever shall find;
Thus a rich loving-kindness, redundantly kind,
Moves all nature to gladness and mirth.
explanation: Although the dance is not meant for the speaker, they still experience joy from watching others dance. The pleasure of dancing is shared among all beings, and whoever finds it can claim it as their own. Nature is abundant with loving kindness and this kindness spreads happiness and joy throughout the world.

During the spring season, when the showers come, the birds become lively and sing their songs. The wind also adds to their joy by causing the leaves to touch each other and the waves to move in unison. All of these aspects of nature are happy because it is their natural right to be so.

text:
DEAR Child of Nature, let them rail!
--There is a nest in a green dale,
A harbour and a hold;
Where thou, a Wife and Friend, shalt see
Thy own heart-stirring days, and be
A light to young and old.
poem_title: To A Young Lady Who Had Been Reproached For Taking Long Walks In The Country
explanation: Child of Nature, ignore those who criticize you. There is a safe and secure place for you in a green valley, where you can be a spouse and companion and experience fulfilling moments. You will also become a beacon of hope and inspiration for people of all ages.

text:
There, healthy as a shepherd boy,
And treading among flowers of joy
Which at no season fade,
Thou, while thy babes around thee cling,
Shalt show us how divine a thing
A Woman may be made.
poem_title: To A Young Lady Who Had Been Reproached For Taking Long Walks In The Country
explanation: The speaker is addressing a woman who is healthy and joyful, like a shepherd boy among flowers. The speaker believes that this woman is an embodiment of divinity and can demonstrate to others the divine qualities a woman can possess. The speaker is praising the woman for her physical and spiritual attributes.

text:
Thy thoughts and feelings shall not die,
Nor leave thee, when grey hairs are nigh,
A melancholy slave;
But an old age serene and bright,
And lovely as a Lapland night,
Shall lead thee to thy grave.
poem_title: To A Young Lady Who Had Been Reproached For Taking Long Walks In The Country
explanation: Your thoughts and emotions won't fade away even as you grow old, nor will they leave you feeling sorrowful and trapped. Instead, you will enjoy a peaceful and joyful old age, as beautiful as a night in Lapland, that will guide you towards your final resting place.

text:
IN youth from rock to rock I went
From hill to hill in discontent
Of pleasure high and turbulent,
Most pleased when most uneasy;
But now my own delights I make,---
Thirst at every rill can slake,
And gladly Nature's love partake,
Of Thee, sweet Daisy!
explanation: When I was young, I roamed restlessly from rock to rock and hill to hill in search of excitement and thrill. I was happiest when I felt uneasy, but now I find joy in simpler pleasures. I enjoy quenching my thirst at every stream and embracing nature's beauty, particularly in the form of a sweet daisy.

During the changing seasons, nature adorns itself for you. In winter, it wears a garland with few gray hairs, and in spring, it uses soft airs to part the clouds so that the sun can shine on you. During summer, the fields belong to you, and in autumn, even the melancholy season finds delight in your crimson head, especially when it rains.

text:
In shoals and bands, a morrice train,
Thou greet'st the traveller in the lane;
Pleased at his greeting thee again;
Yet nothing daunted,
Nor grieved if thou be set at nought:
And oft alone in nooks remote
We meet thee, like a pleasant thought,
When such are wanted.
explanation: You can often see this creature, traveling in groups or alone, as you walk along the lane. It greets you happily and isn't bothered if you ignore it. Sometimes it appears in secluded areas, providing comfort when needed.

text:
Be violets in their secret mews
The flowers the wanton Zephyrs choose;
Proud be the rose, with rains and dew
Her head impearling,
Thou liv'st with less ambitious aim,
Yet hast not gone without thy fame;
Thou art indeed by many a claim
The Poet's darling.
explanation: Be like violets hidden away in secret places, the flowers that the playful Zephyrs seek out. Let the rose be proud, with rain and dew adorning her head. You may live with less ambition, but you have still gained fame through many qualities. You are truly beloved by poets.

text:
If to a rock from rain he fly,
Or, some bright day of April sky,
Imprisoned by hot sunshine lie
Near the green holly,
And wearily at length should fare;
He need but look about, and there
Thou art!---a friend at hand, to care
His melancholy.
explanation: If he takes shelter under a rock during a rainstorm or lounges in the sun on a bright April day beside a holly bush, and eventually feels weary, all he has to do is look around and he will see a friend nearby to help ease his sadness.

I have found myself drawn to your influence on countless occasions, whether it be surrounded by nature or man-made structures. Even in the short span of an hour, I have experienced a range of emotions and memories that have been sparked by your sweetness and charm. Sometimes it is a feeling of unwavering love, other times it is a fleeting moment of happiness or a recollection of a forgotten memory. Regardless, your impact on my imagination and creativity is undeniable.

text:
If stately passions in me burn,
And one chance look to Thee should turn,
I drink out of an humbler urn
A lowlier pleasure;
The homely sympathy that heeds
The common life, our nature breeds;
A wisdom fitted to the needs
Of hearts at leisure.
explanation: If I feel strong emotions and happen to look at you, I will find joy in simple things. The understanding and compassion for everyday life that we share is more satisfying to me than grandiose passions. This wisdom is better suited for people who have the time to appreciate it.

text:
Fresh-smitten by the morning ray,
When thou art up, alert and gay,
Then, cheerful Flower! my spirits play
With kindred gladness:
And when, at dusk, by dews opprest
Thou sink'st, the image of thy rest
Hath often eased my pensive breast
Of careful sadness.
explanation: When the morning sun shines on you, you make me happy and I feel the same energy as you. And when you close up at night, I feel comforted by your peacefulness and it helps me forget my troubles.

text:
And all day long I number yet,
All seasons through, another debt,
Which I, wherever thou art met,
To thee am owing;
An instinct call it, a blind sense;
A happy, genial influence,
Coming one knows not how, nor whence,
Nor whither going.
explanation: Throughout each day and every season, I am constantly aware of a debt that I owe to you whenever we cross paths. It is an innate feeling, an indescribable force that brings me happiness and positivity without explanation of its origin or destination.

text:
Child of the Year! that round dost run
Thy pleasant course,---when day's begun
As ready to salute the sun
As lark or leveret,
Thy long-lost praise thou shalt regain;
Nor be less dear to future men
Than in old time;---thou not in vain
Art Nature's favourite.
explanation: Oh Child of the Year! You run your pleasant course, always ready to greet the rising sun just like a lark or leveret. Your long-lost praise will be restored and you will continue to be loved by future generations just as you were in the past. You are Nature's favorite for good reason.

text:
THERE is a bondage worse, far worse, to bear
Than his who breathes, by roof, and floor, and wall,
Pent in, a Tyrant's solitary Thrall:
'Tis his who walks about in the open air,
One of a Nation who, henceforth, must wear
Their fetters in their souls. For who could be,
Who, even the best, in such condition, free
From self-reproach, reproach that he must share
With Human-nature? Never be it ours
To see the sun how brightly it will shine,
And know that noble feelings, manly powers,
Instead of gathering strength, must droop and pine;
And earth with all her pleasant fruits and flowers
Fade, and participate in man's decline.
And earth with all her pleasant fruits and flowers
Fade, and participate in man's decline.
And earth with all her pleasant fruits and flowers
Fade, and participate in man's decline.
poem_title: There Is A Bondage Worse, Far Worse, To Bear
explanation: There is a worse form of bondage than being a solitary prisoner confined by walls and a roof, and that is being part of a nation that is forced to wear their chains internally. Even the best among them cannot be truly free from self-reproach as they share the burden of their human nature. It is a sad fate to have to witness the beauty of the sun and nature while knowing that their noble feelings and abilities are suppressed. As a result, the Earth and its abundance of life slowly wither away alongside the decline of humanity.

text:
ONCE in a lonely hamlet I sojourned
In which a Lady driven from France did dwell;
The big and lesser griefs with which she mourned,
In friendship she to me would often tell.
This Lady, dwelling upon British ground,
Where she was childless, daily would repair
To a poor neighbouring cottage; as I found,
For sake of a young Child whose home was there.
explanation: I once stayed in a remote village where a woman who had been forced to leave France lived. She confided in me about her sorrows big and small. This lady, who had no children of her own, visited a nearby poor cottage regularly to spend time with a young child who lived there.

text:
Once having seen her clasp with fond embrace
This Child, I chanted to myself a lay,
Endeavouring, in our English tongue, to trace
Such things as she unto the Babe might say:
And thus, from what I heard and knew, or guessed,
My song the workings of her heart expressed.
explanation: After witnessing a mother embrace her child, I attempted to capture her words to the baby in a song written in English. Drawing from what I heard, knew, and assumed, my lyrics sought to convey the emotions and thoughts that were evident in the mother's heart.

text:
'Dear Babe, thou daughter of another,
One moment let me be thy mother!
An infant's face and looks are thine,
And sure a mother's heart is mine:
Thy own dear mother's far away,
At labour in the harvest field:
Thy little sister is at play;--
What warmth, what comfort would it yield
To my poor heart, if thou wouldst be
One little hour a child to me!
explanation: The speaker addresses a young girl, calling her "Babe" and expressing a desire to act as her mother for a brief time. The girl resembles an infant and the speaker believes her maternal instinct would kick in. The girl's mother is not present and her sister is playing. The speaker longs for the comfort of motherhood and asks the girl to spend an hour with her as her child.

text:
'Across the waters I am come,
And I have left a babe at home:
A long, long way of land and sea!
Come to me--I'm no enemy:
I am the same who at thy side
Sate yesterday, and made a nest
For thee, sweet Baby!--thou hast tried,
Thou know'st the pillow of my breast;
Good, good art thou:--alas! to me
Far more than I can be to thee.
explanation: I have traveled far across the waters, leaving my baby behind. The journey was long, over both land and sea. I want to assure you that I am not your enemy. Yesterday, I sat by your side and created a comfortable place for you, sweet baby. You have already experienced the comfort of resting on my chest. You are such a good baby, but unfortunately, I need you more than you need me.

The speaker addresses their infant, expressing their maternal love and claiming ownership of the child. Despite shedding tears, the speaker asserts their possession of the baby. The nurse advises against crying on a baby's face, but the speaker disagrees with this superstition.

text:
'My own dear Little-one will sigh,
Sweet Babe! and they will let him die.
'He pines,' they'll say, 'it is his doom,
And you may see his hour is come.'
Oh! had he but thy cheerful smiles,
Limbs stout as thine, and lips as gay,
Thy looks, thy cunning, and thy wiles,
And countenance like a summer's day,
They would have hopes of him;--and then
I should behold his face again!
explanation: The speaker laments the fate of their beloved child, who is ill and likely to die soon. They express their sadness that the child's condition is seen as inevitable, and that they will not receive the care and attention they deserve. The speaker imagines how different things would be if the child had the health and vitality of another child they know, and wishes that they could see their child's face again if they were given a chance of recovery.

The speaker reflects on the fleeting nature of time and memories, likening them to forgotten dreams. They recall a few smiles that were precious to them, particularly those of a beloved baby. However, the speaker realizes they must let go of the baby, as their presence stirs up conflicting emotions and memories. They lament the loss of the baby's sweetest smile, which they cannot seem to recall.

text:
'Oh! how I love thee!--we will stay
Together here this one half day.
My sister's child, who bears my name,
From France to sheltering England came;
She with her mother crossed the sea;
The babe and mother near me dwell:
Yet does my yearning heart to thee
Turn rather, though I love her well:
Rest, little Stranger, rest thee here!
Never was any child more dear!
explanation: I love you so much and we will spend half of the day together. My niece, who has my name, came from France with her mother to seek refuge in England. They live close to me, but my heart yearns for you even though I love her too. So rest here, little stranger, because you are the most precious child I have ever known.

text:
'--I cannot help it; ill intent
I've none, my pretty Innocent!
I weep--I know they do thee wrong,
These tears---and my poor idle tongue.
Oh, what a kiss was that! my cheek
How cold it is! but thou art good;
Thine eyes are on me--they would speak,
I think, to help me if they could.
Blessings upon that soft, warm face,
My heart again is in its place!
explanation: The speaker insists that they have no malicious intentions towards the innocent person they are addressing. They express remorse for the harm that has been done to the person and express their emotions through tears and speech. The speaker comments on the kindness of the innocent person's gaze and receives comfort from their presence. The speaker blesses the person's face and feels their heart has been restored.

As long as the speaker has the little love, they cannot feel sad in the grove. They find contentment, hope, and motherly joy in the child. The speaker sees similarities between the child and their own family, and plans to call the child by their own child's name. They even promise to tell their child stories about the little love when they return home.

poem_title: The Fairest, Brightest, Hues Of Ether Fade
explanation: The beauty of the sky slowly diminishes, and even the most pleasant sounds eventually come to an end. However, my dear friend, the music you have played on your flute has created a peaceful and melodic atmosphere that echoes through the rocky valley.

text:
Such strains of rapture as the Genius played
In his still haunt on Bagdad's summit high;
He who stood visible to Mirza's eye,
Never before to human sight betrayed.
poem_title: The Fairest, Brightest, Hues Of Ether Fade
explanation: The Genius played such beautiful music that it brought a sense of joy and ecstasy to those who heard it. He stood on top of a mountain in Bagdad, and was visible to Mirza, who had never seen anything like it before.

text:
Lo, in the vale, the mists of evening spread!
The visionary Arches are not there,
Nor the green Islands, nor the shining Seas:
Yet sacred is to me this Mountain's head,
Whence I have risen, uplifted, on the breeze
Of harmony, above all earthly care.
poem_title: The Fairest, Brightest, Hues Of Ether Fade
explanation: The evening mists are spreading in the valley, and there are no visionary arches or beautiful landscapes to be seen. However, the mountain holds a special place in the speaker's heart. The mountain's peak has lifted them up on the wings of music and freed them from all worldly worries.

poem_title: The Stars Are Mansions Built By Nature's Hand
explanation: Nature has created the stars as heavenly abodes where the blessed spirits reside, shining in their immortal glory. Similarly, the vast ocean provides a wonderfully designed habitat for life to flourish, filled with love and peace.

text:
All that we see--is dome, or vault, or nest,
Or fortress, reared at Nature's sage command.
Glad thought for every season! but the Spring
Gave it while cares were weighing on my heart,
'Mid song of birds, and insects murmuring;
And while the youthful year's prolific art--
Of bud, leaf, blade, and flower--was fashioning
Abodes where self-disturbance hath no part.
poem_title: The Stars Are Mansions Built By Nature's Hand
explanation: Everything we observe in nature, whether it's a dome, vault, nest or fortress, has been constructed by the command of Nature's wisdom. It's a comforting thought for every season, especially during Spring when my heart is heavy with worries. Amidst the chorus of birds and the hum of insects, the abundance of growth in the form of buds, leaves, blades and flowers is shaping homes where there is no room for inner turmoil.

text:
THEY seek, are sought; to daily battle led,
Shrink not, though far outnumbered by their Foes,
For they have learnt to open and to close
The ridges of grim war; and at their head
Are captains such as erst their country bred
Or fostered, self-supported chiefs,--like those
Whom hardy Rome was fearful to oppose;
explanation: They are both the seekers and the sought, constantly engaged in battle and unafraid, even when outnumbered by their enemies. They have mastered the art of warfare and are led by capable leaders who were either born or raised by their country. These self-sufficient chiefs resemble the ones who even mighty Rome was hesitant to confront.

text:
Whose desperate shock the Carthaginian fled.
In One who lived unknown a shepherd's life
Redoubted Viriatus breathes again;
And Mina, nourished in the studious shade,
With that great Leader vies, who, sick of strife
And bloodshed, longed in quiet to be laid
In some green island of the western main.
explanation: The Carthaginian was frightened by the shock of an unknown person. This person was a shepherd named Viriatus who had a reputation for being fearless. Another person named Mina, who was educated and preferred peace over violence, was compared to Viriatus as a great leader. Both wished to find peace in a peaceful place in the western part of the world.

text:
SCORN not the Sonnet; Critic, you have frown'd,
Mindless of its just honours; with this key
Shakespeare unlock'd his heart; the melody
Of this small lute gave ease to Petrarch's wound;
explanation: Don't dismiss the Sonnet, critic, for you have not recognized its true value. Shakespeare used it to reveal his innermost thoughts and feelings, while Petrarch found solace in its musicality during times of heartache.

text:
A thousand times this pipe did Tasso sound;
With it Camöens sooth'd an exile's grief;
The Sonnet glitter'd a gay myrtle leaf
Amid the cypress with which Dante crown'd
His visionary brow: a glow-worm lamp,
It cheer'd mild Spenser, call'd from Faery-land
To struggle through dark ways; and when a damp
Fell round the path of Milton, in his hand
The Thing became a trumpet; whence he blew
Soul-animating strains--alas, too few!
explanation: This poem highlights the significance of poetry and how it has been a source of comfort and inspiration for many great poets throughout history. The pipe of Tasso has been played thousands of times, and Camöens used it to ease his pain of being exiled. The Sonnet, like a glittering myrtle leaf, provided solace for Dante amidst the cypress trees. For Spenser, it was like a glow-worm lamp, guiding him through dark times. And when Milton was faced with difficulties, poetry became a trumpet in his hand, and he used it to create soul-stirring poetry that unfortunately, there were too few of. This poem is a celebration of poetry and its ability to uplift and inspire.

text:
She wept.--Life's purple tide began to flow
In languid streams through every thrilling vein;
Dim were my swimming eyes--my pulse beat slow,
And my full heart was swell'd to dear delicious pain.
poem_title: Sonnet: On Seeing Miss Helen Maria Williams Weep At A Tale Of Distress
explanation: She cried and as she did, she started to feel life's intensity spread through her body. Her eyes became hazy and her pulse slowed down as her heart swelled with a sweet and pleasurable pain.

poem_title: Sonnet: On Seeing Miss Helen Maria Williams Weep At A Tale Of Distress
explanation: As my heart became empty and my eyes began to close, I let out a sigh that brought back a wanderer to my embrace. The moment of stillness in my life was precious, and the sigh that signaled the wanderer's return was even more precious, bringing them back to their final resting place.

text:
That tear proclaims--in thee each virtue dwells,
And bright will shine in misery's midnight hour;
As the soft star of dewy evening tells
What radiant fires were drown'd by day's malignant pow'r,
That only wait the darkness of the night
To cheer the wand'ring wretch with hospitable light.
poem_title: Sonnet: On Seeing Miss Helen Maria Williams Weep At A Tale Of Distress
explanation: Your tear signifies that all virtues reside within you and will shine even in the darkest of times. Just like the evening star that shines brightly after being hidden by the sun's light during the day, your virtues will provide a guiding light to those who are lost and suffering.

text:
THOUGH many suns have risen and set
Since thou, blithe May, wert born,
And Bards, who hailed thee, may forget
Thy gift, thy beauty scorn;
There are who to a birthday strain
Confine not harp and voice,
But evermore throughout thy reign
Are grateful and rejoice!
explanation: Although many years have passed since the birth of May, some poets may have forgotten her beauty and no longer celebrate it. However, there are still those who continue to sing praises to May and express their gratitude for her reign. They do not limit their celebrations to just her birthday but continue to appreciate her throughout her season.

text:
Delicious odor! music sweet,
Too sweet to pass away!
Oh for a deathless song to meet
The soul's desire---a lay
That, when a thousand year are told,
Should praise thee, genial Power!
Through summer heat, autumnal cold,
And winter's dreariest hour.
explanation: The fragrance is delightful and the music is so sweet, it's impossible to ignore. The speaker longs for a timeless song that can fulfill the soul's desires and praise the kind and generous power for a thousand years. The song should be able to endure through all seasons - the heat of summer, the chill of autumn, and the dreariness of winter.

text:
Earth, sea, thy presence feel---nor less,
If yon ethereal blue
With its soft smile the truth express,
The heavens have felt it too.
The inmost heart of man if glad
Partakes a livelier cheer;
And eye that cannot but be sad
Let fall a brightened tear.
explanation: The presence of nature, both on land and in the sea, is palpable and cannot be ignored. Even the skies above, with their gentle expression, bear witness to this truth. When a person's heart is filled with joy, their spirits are lifted and their emotions are heightened. On the other hand, even those who cannot help but feel sad may find themselves shedding tears that are somehow brighter than usual when surrounded by the beauty of the natural world.

text:
Since thy return, through days and weeks
Of hope that grew by stealth,
How many wan and faded cheeks
Have kindled into health!
The Old, by thee revived, have said,
'Another year is ours;'
And wayworn Wanderers, poorly fed,
Have smiled upon thy flowers.
explanation: Since you came back, there have been many people who have regained their health after weeks of hoping for it. Even the elderly have said they have another year to live, and those who have been traveling without proper food have smiled at the sight of your flowers. Your presence has brought new life and hope to those who have been struggling.

text:
Who tripping lisps a merry song
Amid his playful peers?
The tender Infant who was long
A prisoner of fond fears;
But now, when every sharp-edged blast
Is quiet in its sheath,
His Mother leaves him free to taste
Earth's sweetness in thy breath.
explanation: Who is singing happily among his friends, despite previously being imprisoned by fear? It is a young child who can now enjoy the sweetness of the world around him thanks to the protection of his mother from the harsh elements.

text:
Thy help is with the weed that creeps
Along the humblest ground;
No cliff so bare but on its steeps
Thy favors may be found;
But most on some peculiar nook
That our own hands have drest,
Thou and thy train are proud to look,
And seem to love it best.
explanation: Your assistance can be found in the humblest of places, even in the weeds that creep along the ground. No cliff is too barren for your favors to be bestowed upon it. However, you seem to take the most pride in the places that we have personally cultivated and tended to. In those particular nooks, you and your companions appear to take a special liking to and show your affection towards.

text:
And yet how pleased we wander forth
When May is whispering, 'Come!
'Choose from the bowers of virgin earth
The happiest for your home;
HeavenÕs bounteous love through me is spread
From sunshine, clouds, winds, waves,
Drops on the mouldering turret's head,
And on your turf-clad graves!'
explanation: In the month of May, we feel delighted as we venture out to explore nature's offerings. The gentle whispers of the season encourage us to choose the most blissful place to reside in. The generosity of heaven is evident through the warmth of the sun, the playfulness of the clouds, the power of the winds, and the rhythm of the waves. Even the ruins of ancient castles receive the same love as our grass-covered graves.

text:
Such greeting heard, away with sighs
For lilies that must fade,
Or ' the rathe primrose as it dies
Forsaken' in the shade!
Vernal fruitions and desires
Are linked in endless chase;
While, as one kindly growth retires,
Another takes its place.
explanation: Don't be sad about the fleeting beauty of flowers like lilies and primroses that wither and die. Instead, embrace the cyclical nature of life and the constant renewal of new growth and desires that come with each passing season. Just as one type of plant fades away, another takes its place, creating an endless cycle of growth and change.

Even the beautiful month of May can experience misfortune through pests and disease that can ruin budding hopes. Love and happiness may also be fleeting and easily lost, especially for the young who may feel trapped by unforeseen circumstances. This is a harsh reality that affects everyone, regardless of how seemingly perfect their life may appear.

text:
Lo! Streams that April could not check
Are patient of thy rule;
Gurgling in foamy water-break,
Loitering in glassy pool:
By thee, thee only, could be sent
Such gentle mists as glide,
Curling with unconfirmed intent,
On that green mountain's side.
explanation: The streams that were too strong for the month of April to control now obey your authority. They gurgle and loiter under your command, whether in foamy water-breaks or glassy pools. Only you have the power to send the delicate mists that gracefully curl around the green mountain's side, with an uncertain purpose.

text:
How delicate the leafy veil
Through which yon house of God
Gleams 'mid the peace of this deep dale
By few but shepherds trod!
And lowly huts, near beaten ways,
No sooner stand attired
In thy fresh wreaths, than they for praise
Peep forth, and are admired.
explanation: The leafy veil through which the church is visible in the peaceful valley is delicate and only traversed by a few shepherds. The nearby huts, situated along well-trodden paths, also become adorned with fresh wreaths and are admired for their beauty.

text:
Season of fancy and of hope,
Permit not for one hour,
A blossom from thy crown to drop,
Nor add to it a flower!
Keep, lovely May, as if by touch
Of self restraining art,
This modest charm of not too much,
Part seen, imagined part!
explanation: May is a time of beauty and optimism. The author implores the season to preserve its delicate allure and not add too much to it. May is urged to maintain a balance between what can be seen and what is left to the imagination, using a self-restraining touch. The author wishes for May to keep its charm and not lose any of its blossoms or add too many flowers to its crown.

text:
Bright Flower! whose home is everywhere,
Bold in maternal Nature's care,
And all the long year through the heir
Of joy or sorrow;
Methinks that there abides in thee
Some concord with humanity,
Given to no other flower I see
The forest thorough!
explanation: The bright flower is a universal symbol of maternal care that thrives in all seasons, regardless of joy or sorrow. It seems to share a connection with humanity that no other flower possesses, as it flourishes throughout the forest.

text:
Is it that Man is soon deprest?
A thoughtless Thing! who, once unblest,
Does little on his memory rest,
Or on his reason,
And Thou would'st teach him how to find
A shelter under every wind,
A hope for times that are unkind
And every season?
explanation: The speaker questions if people are easily depressed and thoughtless, forgetting past struggles and not using reason to find solutions. The speaker addresses a person who wants to teach Man how to find hope and shelter in difficult times.

text:
Thou wander'st the wide world about,
Uncheck'd by pride or scrupulous doubt,
With friend to greet thee, or without,
Yet pleased and willing;
Meek, yielding to the occasion's call,
And all things suffering from all,
Thy function apostolical
In peace fulfilling.
explanation: You travel the world without any arrogance or hesitation, whether you have someone to accompany you or not. You are content and eager to adapt to any circumstance, humbly enduring whatever comes your way. Your purpose is to spread peace, and you fulfill it with a gentle and accommodating manner.

text:
Sweet Flower! belike one day to have
A place upon thy Poet's grave,
I welcome thee once more:
But He, who was on land, at sea,
My Brother, too, in loving thee,
Although he loved more silently,
Sleeps by his native shore.
explanation: The speaker greets a sweet flower that may one day be placed on his grave. He welcomes it back but notes that his brother, who also loved the flower, but more quietly, is buried near his birthplace.

text:
Ah! hopeful, hopeful was the day
When to that Ship he bent his way,
To govern and to guide:
His wish was gained: a little time
Would bring him back in manhood's prime
And free for life, these hills to climb;
With all his wants supplied.
explanation: The speaker expresses their hope and excitement for the day when someone boarded a ship to govern and guide, achieving their desired wish. They anticipate that in a short amount of time, this person will return at the peak of their adulthood and be free to climb the hills with all their needs met.

text:
And full of hope day followed day
While that stout Ship at anchor lay
Beside the shores of Wight;
The May had then made all things green;
And, floating there, in pomp serene,
That Ship was goodly to be seen,
His pride and his delight!
explanation: Each day was filled with optimism as the sturdy ship remained anchored by the shores of Wight. The month of May had transformed the landscape into a vibrant green, and the ship, with its grand appearance, floated majestically. The vessel was a source of pride and joy for its owner.

text:
Yet then, when called ashore, he sought
The tender peace of rural thought:
In more than happy mood
To your abodes, bright daisy Flowers!
He then would steal at leisure hours,
And loved you glittering in your bowers
A starry multitude.
explanation: When he was summoned back to land, he desired the calmness and simplicity of rural life. He was filled with joy as he visited the homes of daisy flowers and appreciated their beauty as they sparkled in their gardens. He would often spend his free time enjoying the sight of the vast number of flowers that resembled stars in the night sky.

text:
But hark the word!--the ship is gone;--
Returns from her long course:--anon
Sets sail:--in season due,
Once more on English earth they stand:
But, when a third time from the land
They parted, sorrow was at hand
For Him and for his crew.
explanation: Listen closely, the ship has departed on its long journey and will soon return, setting sail again at the right time. The crew will return to English soil again, but when they leave for a third time, there will be sorrow for both the captain and the crew.

text:
Ill-fated Vessel!--ghastly shock!
--At length delivered from the rock,
The deep she hath regained;
And through the stormy night they steer;
Labouring for life, in hope and fear,
To reach a safer shore--how near,
Yet not to be attained!
explanation: The ship that was doomed to fail has finally been freed from the rock it was stuck on. The crew navigates through a stormy night, desperately trying to reach a safer shore. Although they are close, there is no guarantee they will make it. They continue to work hard, hoping to survive the treacherous journey.

text:
"Silence!" the brave Commander cried:
To that calm word a shriek replied,
It was the last death-shriek.
--A few (my soul oft sees that sight)
Survive upon the tall mast's height;
But one dear remnant of the night--
For Him in vain I seek.
explanation: The Commander ordered silence, but instead of quiet, a scream was heard, which turned out to be the final death cry. A few survivors were left on the tall mast, but the narrator cannot find one particular person, whom they hold dear. The narrator reflects on this traumatic experience frequently.

text:
Six weeks beneath the moving sea
He lay in slumber quietly;
Unforced by wind or wave
To quit the Ship for which he died,
(All claims of duty satisfied;)
And there they found him at her side;
And bore him to the grave.
explanation: For six weeks, he slept peacefully under the sea's motion, without any force from the wind or waves to leave the ship that he died for, having fulfilled his duty. Eventually, they discovered him lying next to the ship, and they carried him to his final resting place.

text:
Vain service! yet not vainly done
For this, if other end were none,
That He, who had been cast
Upon a way of life unmeet
For such a gentle Soul and sweet,
Should find an undisturbed retreat
Near what he loved, at last--
explanation: Although the service may seem pointless, it was not done in vain. Even if there were no other purpose, it was worth it for the fact that the gentle and kind-hearted person who had been forced onto a path that did not suit them would be able to find a peaceful refuge near what they loved in the end.

text:
That neighbourhood of grove and field
To Him a resting-place should yield,
A meek man and a brave!
The birds shall sing and ocean make
A mournful murmur for 'his' sake;
And Thou, sweet Flower, shalt sleep and wake
Upon his senseless grave.
explanation: This poem describes a peaceful neighbourhood of groves and fields that would be a perfect resting place for a humble and courageous man. The birds would sing and the ocean would mourn for him, while a sweet flower would grow on his grave.

text:
ABRUPTLY paused the strife;--the field throughout
Resting upon his arms each warrior stood,
Checked in the very act and deed of blood,
With breath suspended, like a listening scout.
poem_title: The Germans On The Heighs Of Hochheim
explanation: The battle suddenly came to a halt, with every soldier freezing in place and holding their weapons. They were stopped in the middle of fighting, their breaths held in anticipation, as if they were scouts listening for the slightest sound.

text:
O Silence! thou wert mother of a shout
That through the texture of yon azure dome
Cleaves its glad way, a cry of harvest home
Uttered to Heaven in ecstasy devout!
The barrier Rhine hath flashed, through battle-smoke,
On men who gaze heart-smitten by the view,
As if all Germany had felt the shock!
--Fly, wretched Gauls! ere they the charge renew
Who have seen--themselves now casting off the yoke--
The unconquerable Stream his course pursue.
poem_title: The Germans On The Heighs Of Hochheim
explanation: Silence, you were the source of a shout that pierced through the sky, a cry of joy and gratitude to Heaven. The soldiers gazed in awe at the Rhine, which had broken through the smoke of battle, as if all of Germany had felt the impact. The defeated Gauls were urged to flee before the Germans, who had been inspired by the sight of the unconquerable river and were now free from oppression.

text:
BRIGHT Flower! whose home is everywhere,
Bold in maternal Nature's care,
And all the long year through the heir
Of joy or sorrow;
Methinks that there abides in thee
Some concord with humanity,
Given to no other flower I see
The forest thorough!
explanation: This poem is about a bright flower that can be found everywhere and is taken care of by nature. It experiences both joy and sorrow throughout the year. The speaker believes that there is a connection between the flower and humanity that is not present in any other flower in the forest.

text:
Is it that Man is soon deprest?
A thoughtless Thing! who, once unblest,
Does little on his memory rest,
Or on his reason,
And Thou would'st teach him how to find
A shelter under every wind,
A hope for times that are unkind
And every season?
explanation: The speaker questions whether mankind is easily discouraged and forgetful, lacking in both memory and reason. The speaker then addresses someone who wants to teach Man how to find comfort and hope, regardless of the circumstances. The implication is that Man needs guidance in order to face challenges and adversity.

text:
Thou wander'st the wide world about,
Uncheck'd by pride or scrupulous doubt,
With friend to greet thee, or without,
Yet pleased and willing;
Meek, yielding to the occasion's call,
And all things suffering from all,
Thy function apostolical
In peace fulfilling.
explanation: You roam freely throughout the vast world, without arrogance or hesitation, whether accompanied by a friend or alone, content and eager. You are humble, adaptable to any situation, and willing to endure all hardships as you fulfill your peaceful mission.
Oh, you whose imagination is inspired from distant places, who uses language as a playful disguise, and who can give form to indescribable feelings through a light and effortless movement and melody.

text:
Thou faery voyager! that dost float
In such clear water, that thy boat
May rather seem
To brood on air than on an earthly stream;
explanation: Oh, fairy traveler! You glide through crystal clear water in a way that makes your boat appear as though it is suspended in air rather than floating on a river.

text:
Suspended in a stream as clear as sky,
Where earth and heaven do make one imagery;
O blessed vision! happy child!
Thou art so exquisitely wild,
I think of thee with many fears
For what may be thy lot in future years.
explanation: The speaker admires a child who is suspended in a clear stream, creating a beautiful image of the connection between heaven and earth. Despite the beauty of the moment, the speaker is fearful for the child's future and what may become of them.

text:
I thought of times when Pain might be thy guest,
Lord of thy house and hospitality;
And Grief, uneasy lover! never rest
But when she sate within the touch of thee.
explanation: The speaker reflects on instances where pain and grief may be present in one's life, with pain being welcomed as a host in their home and grief finding solace only in their presence. The use of personification adds depth to the emotions being conveyed, with pain being given the title of "Lord" and grief being described as an "uneasy lover". The overall tone is contemplative, suggesting that the speaker has experienced such moments themselves and is reflecting on the role these emotions have played in their life.

text:
O too industrious folly!
O vain and causeless melancholy!
Nature will either end thee quite;
Or, lengthening out thy season of delight,
Preserve for thee, by individual right,
A young lamb's heart among the full-grown flocks.
explanation: This passage is a warning against excessive work and unnecessary sadness. It suggests that if one works too hard or becomes too melancholic without reason, nature will either cause their demise or allow them to enjoy life like a young lamb among adult sheep. The message is to find balance in life and not let hard work or negative emotions consume you.

text:
What hast thou to do with sorrow,
Or the injuries of to-morrow?
Thou art a dew-drop, which the morn brings forth,
Ill fitted to sustain unkindly shocks,
Or to be trailed along the soiling earth;
explanation: Why concern yourself with sadness or potential harm in the future? You are like a delicate dew-drop that appears with the morning, and is not meant to withstand harshness or be dragged through dirt.

text:
A gem that glitters while it lives,
And no forewarning gives;
But, at the touch of wrong, without a strife
Slips in a moment out of life.
explanation: This passage describes the fleeting nature of life and how easily it can be taken away. The gem is a metaphor for life, which can appear beautiful and precious, but also delicate and vulnerable. There are no warnings or guarantees – life can be snatched away suddenly and unexpectedly, especially when faced with adversity or danger. The passage is a reminder to cherish every moment and appreciate the fragility of life.

text:
FOND words have oft been spoken to thee, Sleep!
And thou hast had thy store of tenderest names;
The very sweetest, Fancy culls or frames,
When thankfulness of heart is strong and deep!
Dear Bosom-child we call thee, that dost steep
In rich reward all suffering; Balm that tames
All anguish; Saint that evil thoughts and aims
Takest away, and into souls dost creep,
Like to a breeze from heaven. Shall I alone,
I surely not a man ungently made,
Call thee worst Tyrant by which Flesh is crost?
Perverse, self-willed to own and to disown,
Mere slave of them who never for thee prayed,
Still last to come where thou art wanted most!
explanation: Sleep has been praised with many endearing names, reflecting the gratitude and appreciation felt towards it. It is often referred to as a cherished child, capable of soothing all suffering and eradicating negative thoughts. It is seen as a divine breeze that brings peace and calm to the soul. However, the speaker questions whether he alone is the only one who sees sleep as a cruel tyrant. Sleep, he argues, is stubbornly unpredictable and often fails to show up when needed most, making it seem like a slave to those who don't value it. Despite the conflicting opinions, it is clear that sleep holds a significant place in our lives, both as a source of comfort and frustration.

text:
YE brood of conscience--Spectres! that frequent
The bad Man's restless walk, and haunt his bed--
Fiends in your aspect, yet beneficent
In act, as hovering Angels when they spread
Their wings to guard the unconscious Innocent--
Slow be the Statutes of the land to share
A laxity that could not but impair
'Your' power to punish crime, and so prevent.
explanation: The speaker addresses the conscience of wrongdoers, calling them "spectres" and "fiends" that haunt them day and night. However, he also recognizes their importance in preventing crime by acting as a moral compass. He warns against laws that would weaken their power to punish, as this would only lead to more wrongdoing.

text:
And ye, Beliefs! coiled serpent-like about
The adage on all tongues, 'Murder will out,'
How shall your ancient warnings work for good
In the full might they hitherto have shown,
If for deliberate shedder of man's blood
Survive not Judgment that requires his own?
explanation: Beliefs, personified as a coiled serpent, are often associated with the adage "Murder will out". However, if those who intentionally take the life of another person are not held accountable and punished, how can this warning be effective in deterring such heinous acts? The poem suggests that the power of beliefs lies in their ability to promote justice and accountability, but this can only be achieved if those who commit murder face the consequences of their actions.

text:
WHEN, to the attractions of the busy world,
Preferring studious leisure, I had chosen
A habitation in this peaceful Vale,
Sharp season followed of continual storm
In deepest winter; and, from week to week,
Pathway, and lane, and public road, were clogged
With frequent showers of snow. Upon a hill
At a short distance from my cottage, stands
A stately Fir-grove, whither I was wont
To hasten, for I found, beneath the roof
Of that perennial shade, a cloistral place
Of refuge, with an unincumbered floor.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: When I decided to live in the tranquil valley, prioritizing solitary learning over the bustle of city life, I encountered a harsh winter of unrelenting storms. Snow frequently obstructed pathways, lanes, and roads, making travel difficult. Fortunately, close to my cottage, there was a majestic grove of fir trees on a hilltop that I often visited. Under the cover of its evergreen canopy, I found a quiet sanctuary with plenty of space to move around.

text:
Here, in safe covert, on the shallow snow,
And, sometimes, on a speck of visible earth,
The redbreast near me hopped; nor was I loth
To sympathise with vulgar coppice birds
That, for protection from the nipping blast,
Hither repaired.--A single beech-tree grew
Within this grove of firs! and, on the fork
Of that one beech, appeared a thrush's nest;
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: I found myself in a secure hiding spot amidst the shallow snow and occasionally on a small patch of land where a robin would come close to me. I didn't mind showing empathy with the common birds who sought shelter from the bitter wind in this area. Only one beech tree grew amongst the fir trees, and on the branch of that tree was a nest belonging to a thrush.

text:
A last year's nest, conspicuously built
At such small elevation from the ground
As gave sure sign that they, who in that house
Of nature and of love had made their home
Amid the fir-trees, all the summer long
Dwelt in a tranquil spot. And oftentimes,
A few sheep, stragglers from some mountain-flock,
Would watch my motions with suspicious stare,
From the remotest outskirts of the grove,--
Some nook where they had made their final stand,
Huddling together from two fears--the fear
Of me and of the storm. Full many an hour
Here did I lose. But in this grove the trees
Had been so thickly planted, and had thriven
In such perplexed and intricate array;
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: Last year's nest was built in a conspicuous location, not far from the ground, indicating that the birds living there had found a peaceful home among the fir trees throughout the summer. Occasionally, a few stray sheep from a mountain flock would observe my movements with suspicion from the distant edges of the forest, huddled together in fear of me and the storm. Despite the distractions, I spent many hours in this grove, where the trees were planted in a dense and complex arrangement.

text:
That vainly did I seek, beneath their stems
A length of open space, where to and fro
My feet might move without concern or care;
And, baffled thus, though earth from day to day
Was fettered, and the air by storm disturbed,
I ceased the shelter to frequent,--and prized,
Less than I wished to prize, that calm recess.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: I searched in vain for an open space between the stems of the trees where I could walk freely without worry. However, despite my efforts, the earth was bound and the air was disturbed with storms, preventing me from finding the calm shelter I desired. As a result, I stopped visiting the shelter as frequently and did not value it as much as I had hoped to.

text:
The snows dissolved, and genial Spring returned
To clothe the fields with verdure. Other haunts
Meanwhile were mine; till, one bright April day,
By chance retiring from the glare of noon
To this forsaken covert, there I found
A hoary pathway traced between the trees,
And winding on with such an easy line
Along a natural opening, that I stood
Much wondering how I could have sought in vain
For what was now so obvious. To abide,
For an allotted interval of ease,
Under my cottage-roof, had gladly come
From the wild sea a cherished Visitant;
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: As the snow melted away and Spring arrived to bring greenery to the fields, the speaker sought out new places to explore. One day in April, they stumbled upon a neglected path in a secluded area and were amazed by how easily visible it was. The speaker had previously searched in vain for this path, but now it seemed obvious. They had been spending time in their cottage, enjoying the company of a beloved guest who had come from the sea.

text:
And with the sight of this same path--begun,
Begun and ended, in the shady grove,
Pleasant conviction flashed upon my mind
That, to this opportune recess allured,
He had surveyed it with a finer eye,
A heart more wakeful; and had worn the track
By pacing here, unwearied and alone,
In that habitual restlessness of foot
That haunts the Sailor measuring o'er and o'er
His short domain upon the vessel's deck,
While she pursues her course through the dreary sea.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: As I looked upon the familiar path that led to the quiet grove, I had a sudden realization that the person I was thinking of had likely walked this same path many times before. They had probably come here often, with a keen eye and a restless heart, pacing back and forth in the same way a sailor walks the deck of a ship on a long voyage. This thought brought a pleasant conviction to my mind, and I felt a sense of comfort in knowing that this special place had held a special meaning for someone else as well.

text:
When thou hadst quitted Esthwaite's pleasant shore,
And taken thy first leave of those green hills
And rocks that were the play-ground of thy youth,
Year followed year, my Brother! and we two,
Conversing not, knew little in what mould
Each other's mind was fashioned; and at length,
When once again we met in Grasmere Vale,
Between us there was little other bond
Than common feelings of fraternal love.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: After leaving the enjoyable shore of Esthwaite and saying goodbye to the green hills and rocks that were once his playground, the narrator and his brother went years without conversing and knowing little of each other's mind. Eventually, they reunited in Grasmere Vale, where their only connection was their mutual love and affection for each other as brothers.

text:
But thou, a Schoolboy, to the sea hadst carried
Undying recollections! Nature there
Was with thee; she, who loved us both, she still
Was with thee; and even so didst thou become
A 'silent' Poet; from the solitude
Of the vast sea didst bring a watchful heart
Still couchant, an inevitable ear,
And an eye practised like a blind man's touch.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: As a schoolboy, you carried memories of the sea that would never fade away. Nature was with you during that time, and she still loved both of us. You became a poet, though a silent one, as you spent time in the solitude of the vast sea. Your heart was alert, always listening, and your eyes were trained like a blind person's touch, thanks to your time spent in the company of the sea.

text:
--Back to the joyless Ocean thou art gone;
Nor from this vestige of thy musing hours
Could I withhold thy honoured name,--and now
I love the fir-grove with a perfect love.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: You have returned to the unexciting ocean and I cannot help but mention how much time you spent here. I hold you in high regard and because of our time together, I now have a deep affection for the fir-grove.

text:
Thither do I withdraw when cloudless suns
Shine hot, or wind blows troublesome and strong;
And there I sit at evening, when the steep
Of Silver-how, and Grasmere's peaceful lake,
And one green island, gleam between the stems
Of the dark firs, a visionary scene!
And, while I gaze upon the spectacle
Of clouded splendour, on this dream-like sight
Of solemn loveliness, I think on thee,
My Brother, and on all which thou hast lost.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: I go there when it's sunny or when the wind is strong and annoying. I sit there in the evening, looking at the beautiful view of Silver-how, Grasmere's peaceful lake, and a green island shining through the dark firs. It's like a dream, and I think of my lost brother while admiring the beauty.

text:
Nor seldom, if I rightly guess, while Thou,
Muttering the verses which I muttered first
Among the mountains, through the midnight watch
Art pacing thoughtfully the vessel's deck
In some far region, here, while o'er my head,
At every impulse of the moving breeze,
The fir-grove murmurs with a sea-like sound,
Alone I tread this path;--for aught I know,
Timing my steps to thine; and, with a store
Of undistinguishable sympathies,
Mingling most earnest wishes for the day
When we, and others whom we love, shall meet
A second time, in Grasmere's happy Vale.
poem_title: When To The Attractions Of The Busy World
explanation: Sometimes I imagine that while you are reciting the verses we first spoke together during our mountain walks, pacing thoughtfully on the deck of a ship in a faraway place during the midnight watch, I am alone here walking along this path. I may be walking in time with you, and with a multitude of indistinguishable sympathies, I am hoping earnestly for the day when we and our loved ones will meet again in the happy valley of Grasmere.

text:
WHERE lies the Land to which yon Ship must go?
Fresh as a lark mounting at break of day,
Festively she puts forth in trim array;
Is she for tropic suns, or polar snow?
What boots the inquiry?--Neither friend nor foe
She cares for; let her travel where she may,
She finds familiar names, a beaten way
Ever before her, and a wind to blow.
poem_title: Where Lies The Land To Which Yon Ship Must Go?
explanation: The poem "Where Lies the Land" by Arthur Hugh Clough poses the question of where a ship is headed. The ship sets sail in the morning and seems to be well-prepared for the journey ahead. However, it is unclear whether the ship is headed for tropical or polar regions. Ultimately, it doesn't matter as the ship seems to be indifferent to its destination and will find its way regardless. The poem suggests that the journey and the familiarity of the path ahead are more important than the destination itself.

text:
Yet still I ask, what haven is her mark?
And, almost as it was when ships were rare,
(From time to time, like Pilgrims, here and there
Crossing the waters) doubt, and something dark,
Of the old Sea some reverential fear,
Is with me at thy farewell, joyous Bark!
poem_title: Where Lies The Land To Which Yon Ship Must Go?
explanation: The speaker is questioning where the destination of the ship is and the uncertainty and fear associated with the sea. The ship is compared to a pilgrim traveling across the waters, which adds to the reverence and respect for the sea. The speaker bids farewell to the ship with a mix of joy and sadness, acknowledging the dangers that come with sailing on the open sea.

text:
A Rock there is whose homely front
The passing traveller slights;
Yet there the glow-worms hang their lamps,
Like stars, at various heights;
And one coy Primrose to that Rock
The vernal breeze invites.
What hideous warfare hath been waged,
What kingdoms overthrown,
Since first I spied that Primrose-tuft
And marked it for my own;
A lasting link in Nature's chain
From highest heaven let down!
explanation: The poem describes a rock that appears unremarkable to most travelers, but is home to a variety of glow worms that hang like stars at different heights. The rock also attracts a solitary primrose that is enticed by the spring breeze. The speaker reflects on the history and conflicts that have occurred since they first noticed the primrose, and sees it as a small but significant part of the natural world that connects everything together.

The flowers remain loyal to their stems and come together once again. The stems, in turn, remain dedicated to the roots that work behind the scenes. The roots cling steadfastly to the rock, with every fiber of their being.

text:
Close clings to earth the living rock,
Though threatening still to fall:
The earth is constant to her sphere;
And God upholds them all:
So blooms this lonely Plant, nor dreads
Her annual funeral.
explanation: This plant grows close to the earth, clinging tightly to the living rock, despite the danger of falling. The earth remains steadfast in its orbit, and God supports everything. The plant continues to bloom every year without fear of its eventual demise.
The meditative strain ended as the day's air was soft and pleasant. The hoary mountain peaks were uplifted, and the sunny valley appeared lively. I then sang a song to the Primrose of the Rock.

text:
I sang-Let myriads of bright flowers,
Like Thee, in field and grove
Revive unenvied;-mightier far,
Than tremblings that reprove
Our vernal tendencies to hope,
Is God's redeeming love;
explanation: I sing of a desire to see many beautiful flowers sprout in fields and groves without any envy. This desire is stronger than the fear that arises from the fragility of our hopes in spring. However, God's redeeming love is even more powerful than this desire.

text:
That love which changed-for wan disease,
For sorrow that had bent
O'er hopeless dust, for withered age-
Their moral element,
And turned the thistles of a curse
To types beneficent.
explanation: Love has the power to transform negative aspects of life such as illness, grief, and aging into positive ones. It changes the moral nature of these difficult experiences and turns them into symbols of kindness and generosity. Love is capable of turning curses into blessings.

text:
Sin-blighted though we are, we too,
The reasoning Sons of Men,
From one oblivious winter called
Shall rise, and breathe again;
And in eternal summer lose
Our threescore years and ten.
explanation: Despite our sinful nature, as human beings we will also experience a rebirth after a cold and forgetful winter. We will rise again and continue living in an eternal summer, where we will no longer be bound by the limitations of living only seventy years.

text:
To humbleness of heart descends
This prescience from on high,
The faith that elevates the just,
Before and when they die;
And makes each soul a separate heaven
A court for Deity.
explanation: Humility allows for divine knowledge to be obtained, granting the righteous faith that elevates them both in life and in death, creating an individual heaven and a dwelling place for God within each soul.

text:
WHEN, far and wide, swift as the beams of morn
The tidings past of servitude repealed,
And of that joy which shook the Isthmian Field,
The rough Aetolians smiled with bitter scorn.
explanation: The news of freedom and the joyful celebration at the Isthmian Field spread rapidly throughout the land. However, the Aetolians responded with disdainful laughter, mocking the occasion.

text:
''Tis known,' cried they, 'that he, who would adorn
His envied temples with the Isthmian crown,
Must either win, through effort of his own,
The prize, or be content to see it worn
By more deserving brows.--Yet so ye prop,
Sons of the brave who fought at Marathon,
Your feeble spirits! Greece her head hath bowed,
As if the wreath of liberty thereon
Would fix itself as smoothly as a cloud,
Which, at Jove's will, descends on Pelion's top.'
explanation: They exclaimed that it is well-known that anyone who wishes to be crowned with the Isthmian crown must either put in the effort to win it themselves or accept that it will be worn by someone more deserving. However, they criticized the weak spirits of the sons of the brave who fought at Marathon, as they seemed to believe that Greece would easily regain its freedom without putting in the necessary effort. The group believed that Greece was being too complacent and assuming that freedom would just come to them, much like a cloud descending upon Pelion's top at the will of Jove.

poem_title: Upon The Sight Of A Beautiful Picture Painted By Sir G. H. Beaumont, Bart
explanation: The art that is capable of capturing the beauty of nature and preserving it in a magnificent form is truly admirable. It is a testament to the power of the human mind to be able to hold back the fleeting smoke and the fleeting sunbeams from the day. The ability to capture and preserve the beauty of nature is something that should be praised and celebrated.

text:
Which stopped that band of travellers on their way,
Ere they were lost within the shady wood;
And showed the Bark upon the glassy flood
For ever anchored in her sheltering bay.
poem_title: Upon The Sight Of A Beautiful Picture Painted By Sir G. H. Beaumont, Bart
explanation: The sight of a tree halted a group of travelers before they got lost in the forest. They also saw a ship docked in a calm bay.

text:
Soul-soothing Art! whom Morning, Noontide, Even,
Do serve with all their changeful pageantry;
Thou, with ambition modest yet sublime,
Here, for the sight of mortal man, hast given
To one brief moment caught from fleeting time
The appropriate calm of blest eternity.
poem_title: Upon The Sight Of A Beautiful Picture Painted By Sir G. H. Beaumont, Bart
explanation: Art is a source of solace for the soul, which is served by the changing beauty of morning, noon, and evening. It is modest yet sublime in its ambition, and grants mortal man a glimpse of the peaceful eternity that is often elusive in our fleeting lives.

text:
Our walk was far among the ancient trees:
There was no road, nor any woodman's path;
But a thick umbrage--checking the wild growth
Of weed and sapling, along soft green turf
Beneath the branches--of itself had made
A track, that brought us to a slip of lawn,
And a small bed of water in the woods.
explanation: We walked a great distance through the old trees without a road or path made by woodcutters.
