The thick foliage prevented the growth of weeds and small trees on the soft grass under the tree branches, creating a natural trail that led us to a small patch of grass and a small body of water in the forest.

text:
All round this pool both flocks and herds might drink
On its firm margin, even as from a well,
Or some stone-basin which the herdsman's hand
Had shaped for their refreshment; nor did sun,
Or wind from any quarter, ever come,
But as a blessing to this calm recess,
This glade of water and this one green field.
explanation: The pool was a source of refreshment for both flocks and herds, who could drink from its firm edge like they would from a well or stone basin. The area was blessed with calmness, as the sun and wind never disturbed this peaceful glade of water and green field. It was a tranquil haven for animals seeking relief from the hot sun or thirst.

text:
The spot was made by Nature for herself;
The travellers know it not, and 'twill remain
Unknown to them; but it is beautiful;
And if a man should plant his cottage near,
Should sleep beneath the shelter of its trees,
And blend its waters with his daily meal,
He would so love it, that in his death-hour
Its image would survive among his thoughts:
And therefore, my sweet MARY, this still Nook,
With all its beeches, we have named from You!
explanation: Nature has created a beautiful spot that is unknown to travellers, but if someone were to build a cottage there, sleep under the trees and use its waters for sustenance, they would come to love it so much that it would remain in their thoughts even in their final moments. Therefore, the spot has been named after Mary, as it is a place of love and tranquillity.

The valley is filled with happiness as echoes from the hills create a continuous song to celebrate the arrival of May. Birds, such as magpies and mountain ravens, add to the cheerful atmosphere with their chattering and the young ravens have left their nests to explore and find food. They playfully dart through the clouds, enjoying their newfound freedom.

text:
Beneath a rock, upon the grass,
Two boys are sitting in the sun;
Their work, if any work they have,
Is out of mind---or done.
On pipes of sycamore they play
The fragments of a Christmas hymn;
Or with that plant which in our dale
We call stag-horn, or fox's tail,
Their rusty hats they trim:
And thus, as happy as the day,
Those Shepherds wear the time away.
explanation: Two boys are sitting on the grass under a rock, enjoying the sun and not thinking about any work they may have. They play Christmas hymns on pipes made of sycamore and decorate their hats with stag-horn or fox's tail plants found in the dale. They are content and pass the time happily like shepherds.

text:
Along the river's stony marge
The sand-lark chants a joyous song;
The thrush is busy in the wood,
And carols loud and strong.
A thousand lambs are on the rocks,
All newly born! both earth and sky
Keep jubilee, and more than all,
Those boys with their green coronal;
They never hear the cry,
That plaintive cry! which up the hill
Comes from the depth of Dungeon-Ghyll.
explanation: The sand-lark sings a happy tune by the rocky edge of the river, while the thrush loudly sings in the nearby woods. The earth and sky are filled with celebration, with a thousand newborn lambs on the rocks and boys wearing green crowns. However, they are oblivious to the sorrowful cry that echoes from the depths of Dungeon-Ghyll, up the hill.

text:
Said Walter, leaping from the ground,
'Down to the stump of yon old yew
We'll for our whistles run a race.'
Away the shepherds flew;
They leapt---they ran---and when they came
Right opposite to Dungeon-Ghyll,
Seeing that he should lose the prize,
'Stop! ' to his comrade Walter cries---
James stopped with no good will:
Said Walter then, exulting; 'Here
You'll find a task for half a year.
explanation: Walter suggested a race to the shepherds, proposing that they run down to the old yew stump to see who would win. The shepherds eagerly took up the challenge and began to run and leap, with James and Walter neck and neck as they approached Dungeon-Ghyll. Realizing that he was losing, James came to a stop, much to Walter's annoyance. Walter then boasted that James had a task that would take him six months to complete.

text:
Cross, if you dare, where I shall cross---
Come on, and tread where I shall tread.'
The other took him at his word,
And followed as he led.
It was a spot which you may see
If ever you to Langdale go;
Into a chasm a mighty block
Hath fallen, and made a bridge of rock:
The gulf is deep below;
And, in a basin black and small,
Receives a lofty waterfall.
explanation: The speaker challenges someone to follow him across a rock bridge in a chasm in Langdale. The other person accepts and follows him across the bridge, which was formed by a large block falling into the chasm. The chasm has a deep gorge below and a small basin that receives a waterfall.

text:
With staff in hand across the cleft
The challenger pursued his march;
And now, all eyes and feet, hath gained
The middle of the arch.
When list! he hears a piteous moan---
Again !---his heart within him dies---
His pulse is stopped, his breath is lost,
He totters, pallid as a ghost,
And, looking down, espies
A lamb, that in the pool is pent
Within that black and frightful rent.
explanation: The challenger continued his journey across the arch with his staff in hand. He reached the middle of the arch, but suddenly heard a moan that made him stop in his tracks. His heart sank as he heard the sound again, causing him to lose his breath and balance. He looked down and saw a lamb trapped in the pool below the arch. The sight of the helpless animal made him pale as a ghost. The pool was within a dark and terrifying gap.

text:
The lamb had slipped into the stream,
And safe without a bruise or wound
The cataract had borne him down
Into the gulf profound.
His dam had seen him when he fell,
She saw him down the torrent borne;
And, while with all a mother's love
She from the lofty rocks above
Sent forth a cry forlorn,
The lamb, still swimming round and round,
Made answer to that plaintive sound.
explanation: A lamb fell into a stream and was carried away by a cataract into a deep gulf. Despite this, the lamb was unharmed. The mother of the lamb saw him fall and heard his cries as he was carried away by the current. She cried out in distress, but the lamb continued to swim in circles, responding to its mother's calls.

text:
When he had learnt what thing it was,
That sent this rueful cry; I ween
The Boy recovered heart, and told
The sight which he had seen.
Both gladly now deferred their task;
Nor was there wanting other aid---
A Poet, one who loves the brooks
Far better than the sages' books,
By chance had thither strayed;
And there the helpless lamb he found
By those huge rocks encompassed round.
explanation: After discovering the source of the distressed cry, the boy gained courage and revealed what he had witnessed. As a result, both he and the poet who happened upon the scene postponed their duties to provide assistance to the helpless lamb trapped by large rocks. The poet, who preferred the company of streams over scholars, used his expertise to free the animal.

text:
He drew it from the troubled pool,
And brought it forth into the light:
The Shepherds met him with his charge,
An unexpected sight!
Into their arms the lamb they took,
Whose life and limbs the flood had spared;
Then up the steep ascent they hied,
And placed him at his mother's side;
And gently did the Bard
Those idle Shepherd-Boys upbraid,
And bade them better mind their trade.
explanation: The poet rescued a lamb from a troubled pool and was met by some surprised shepherds. The lamb was unharmed by the water and was returned to its mother. The poet scolded the shepherd boys who had let the lamb wander into danger and reminded them to focus on their responsibilities as shepherds.

text:
ERE the Brothers through the gateway
Issued forth with old and young,
To the Horn Sir Eustace pointed
Which for ages there had hung.
Horn it was which none could sound,
No one upon living ground,
Save He who came as rightful Heir
To Egremont's Domains and Castle fair.
explanation: Before the Brothers left their home with both the elderly and the young ones, Sir Eustace directed their attention to an old horn that had been hanging there for many years. It was a horn that nobody had been able to blow except for the rightful heir to the Egremont's properties and castle.

text:
Heirs from times of earliest record
Had the House of Lucie born,
Who of right had held the Lordship
Claimed by proof upon the Horn:
Each at the appointed hour
Tried the Horn,--it owned his power;
He was acknowledged: and the blast,
Which good Sir Eustace sounded, was the last.
explanation: The House of Lucie, descendants from ancient times, held the Lordship that was proven by their ability to blow a horn. Each heir would blow the horn at the designated time, and if the horn acknowledged their power, they were recognized as the rightful Lord. Sir Eustace was the last to successfully sound the horn.

text:
With his lance Sir Eustace pointed,
And to Hubert thus said he,
'What I speak this Horn shall witness
For thy better memory.
Hear, then, and neglect me not!
At this time, and on this spot,
The words are uttered from my heart,
As my last earnest prayer ere we depart.
explanation: Sir Eustace pointed his lance towards Hubert and spoke to him, informing him that the horn would serve as a witness to his words. He requested that Hubert listen carefully, stating that what he was about to say should not be ignored. He spoke earnestly, making it clear that his words came from the heart and were his final prayer before they departed.

text:
'On good service we are going
Life to risk by sea and land,
In which course if Christ our Saviour
Do my sinful soul demand,
Hither come thou back straightway,
Hubert, if alive that day;
Return, and sound the Horn, that we
May have a living House still left in thee!'
explanation: We will risk our lives on land and sea to provide good service. If, in doing so, Christ calls for my sinful soul, Hubert should return immediately and sound the Horn. This way, we will still have a living House in him.

text:
'Fear not,' quickly answered Hubert;
'As I am thy Father's son,
What thou askest, noble Brother,
With God's favour shall be done.'
So were both right well content:
Forth they from the Castle went,
And at the head of their Array
To Palestine the Brothers took their way.
explanation: Hubert reassured his brother not to worry and told him that as the son of their father, he will ensure that his request is fulfilled with God's favor. The brothers were both satisfied and left the castle with their army to go to Palestine.

text:
Side by side they fought (the Lucies
Were a line for valour famed),
And where'er their strokes alighted,
There the Saracens were tamed.
Whence, then, could it come--the thought--
By what evil spirit brought?
Oh! can a brave Man wish to take
His Brother's life, for Lands' and Castle's sake?
explanation: The Lucies fought bravely alongside each other, known for their courageousness in battle. Their strikes were precise and effective, causing the Saracens to submit. However, a disturbing thought arose - why would a brave man want to kill his own brother for the sake of land and property? What evil spirit could influence such a desire?

text:
'Sir!' the Ruffians said to Hubert,
'Deep he lies in Jordan flood.'
Stricken by this ill assurance,
Pale and trembling Hubert stood.
'Take your earnings.'--Oh! that I
Could have 'seen' my Brother die!
It was a pang that vexed him then;
And oft returned, again, and yet again.
explanation: Hubert was informed by the ruffians that his brother had drowned in the Jordan river. This news left Hubert pale and trembling. He wished he could have been there to witness his brother's death. The thought of his brother dying without him was a painful one that haunted him repeatedly. The ruffians paid Hubert for the message and left him to grieve.

text:
Months passed on, and no Sir Eustace!
Nor of him were tidings heard;
Wherefore, bold as day, the Murderer
Back again to England steered.
To his Castle Hubert sped;
Nothing has he now to dread.
But silent and by stealth he came,
And at an hour which nobody could name.
explanation: Sir Eustace was still missing and there were no news of him after months. The murderer, feeling confident, decided to return to England and head to his castle. Hubert, the murderer, arrived at his castle secretly and at an unknown time to avoid suspicion. He felt safe and had nothing to fear.

It was impossible to determine the time of day or night, whether it was evening or morning, as no one had seen him arrive and no one had heard the Horn. However, Hubert lived happily, surrounded by abundance and shared his bed with a beautiful lady. Time passed pleasantly for him.

text:
Likewise he had sons and daughters;
And, as good men do, he sate
At his board by these surrounded,
Flourishing in fair estate.
And while thus in open day
Once he sate, as old books say,
A blast was uttered from the Horn,
Where by the Castle-gate it hung forlorn.
explanation: He also had both sons and daughters and, being a good man, he often sat at his table surrounded by them, enjoying his prosperous state. One day, as he sat in the open, a loud blast emanated from the Horn, which had been hanging neglected by the Castle gate. This event is recorded in old books.

text:
'Tis the breath of good Sir Eustace!
He is come to claim his right:
Ancient castle, woods, and mountains
Hear the challenge with delight.
Hubert! though the blast be blown
He is helpless and alone:
Thou hast a dungeon, speak the word!
And there he may be lodged, and thou be Lord.
explanation: Sir Eustace has returned and is claiming his rightful ownership of the castle, woods, and mountains. The surroundings anticipate the challenge with pleasure. Hubert is powerless and without support, and Sir Eustace suggests he could be imprisoned in a dungeon and Hubert could become the new Lord.

text:
Speak!--astounded Hubert cannot;
And, if power to speak he had,
All are daunted, all the household
Smitten to the heart, and sad.
'Tis Sir Eustace; if it be
Living man, it must be he!
Thus Hubert thought in his dismay,
And by a postern-gate he slunk away.
explanation: Hubert is so shocked that he cannot speak, and even if he could, everyone in the house is too scared and sad to listen. He is convinced that the person he sees is Sir Eustace, and he is very distressed. He quietly leaves through a side gate.

text:
Long, and long was he unheard of:
To his Brother then he came,
Made confession, asked forgiveness,
Asked it by a brother's name,
And by all the saints in heaven;
And of Eustace was forgiven:
Then in a convent went to hide
His melancholy head, and there he died.
explanation: He was unknown for a long time until he finally revealed himself to his brother and asked for forgiveness, invoking the names of the saints. His brother forgave him, and he then sought refuge in a convent where he lived out the rest of his days in sadness until he passed away.

text:
But Sir Eustace, whom good angels
Had preserved from murderers' hands,
And from Pagan chains had rescued,
Lived with honour on his lands.
Sons he had, saw sons of theirs:
And through ages, heirs of heirs,
A long posterity renowned,
Sounded the Horn which they alone could sound.
explanation: Sir Eustace, who was saved by angels from murderers and Pagan captivity, lived a respected life on his estate. He had sons and saw his sons have sons, creating a long line of descendants who were known for their ability to sound a unique horn. This family legacy continued for generations.

text:
'What is good for a bootless bene?'
With these dark words begins my Tale;
And their meaning is, whence can comfort spring
When Prayer is of no avail?
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: My tale begins with the question of what can bring comfort to someone who is helpless and without resources. The words "bootless bene" suggest a sense of desperation and hopelessness. The speaker wonders how one can find solace when even prayer seems ineffective. This opening sets a somber and introspective tone for the rest of the story.

text:
'What is good for a bootless bene?'
The Falconer to the Lady said;
And she made answer 'ENDLESS SORROW!'
For she knew that her Son was dead.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The Falconer asked the Lady what could be done for someone who has no boots. The Lady replied with the phrase "endless sorrow" because she knew that her son had died.

text:
She knew it by the Falconer's words,
And from the look of the Falconer's eye;
And from the love which was in her soul
For her youthful Romilly.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: She was aware of Romilly's death from the Falconer's words and the expression in his eyes. Her heart was filled with love for Romilly, who was once her youthful companion.

text:
--Young Romilly through Barden woods
Is ranging high and low;
And holds a greyhound in a leash,
To let slip upon buck or doe.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: A young boy named Romilly is wandering through the Barden woods, searching both high and low. He is accompanied by a greyhound whom he has on a leash, ready to release at the sight of a deer or a buck.

text:
The pair have reached that fearful chasm,
How tempting to bestride!
For lordly Wharf is there pent in
With rocks on either side.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The two individuals have arrived at a frightening gap, and it is tempting to cross over it. The Wharf river is enclosed by massive boulders on both sides, creating a feeling of being trapped.

text:
This striding-place is called THE STRID,
A name which it took of yore:
A thousand years hath it borne that name,
And shall a thousand more.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The name of this place where one takes long strides is called THE STRID. It has been called this for a thousand years and will continue to be called so for another thousand years.

text:
And hither is young Romilly come,
And what may now forbid
That he, perhaps for the hundredth time,
Shall bound across THE STRID?
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: Young Romilly has arrived at the location known as THE STRID, and one wonders if anything will prevent him from leaping across it once again, possibly for the hundredth time.

text:
He sprang in glee,--for what cared he
That the river was strong, and the rocks were steep?--
But the greyhound in the leash hung back,
And checked him in his leap.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The person in the story jumped with joy, not caring about the strong river or steep rocks. However, the greyhound on a leash held back and stopped him from leaping.

text:
The Boy is in the arms of Wharf,
And strangled by a merciless force;
For never more was young Romilly seen
Till he rose a lifeless corse.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The boy, Romilly, is being held by someone or something at the wharf and is being strangled with great cruelty. He has not been seen alive since this event and was later found dead.

text:
Now there is stillness in the vale,
And long, unspeaking, sorrow:
Wharf shall be to pitying hearts
A name more sad than Yarrow.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The valley is now quiet and filled with sorrowful silence, causing Wharf to be known as a place of greater sadness than Yarrow, evoking pity from those who hear of it.

text:
If for a lover the Lady wept,
A solace she might borrow
From death, and from the passion of death;--
Old Wharf might heal her sorrow.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The Lady could find comfort in death and the intensity of the emotions it brings if she wept for a lover. Old Wharf could help ease her grief.

text:
She weeps not for the wedding-day
Which was to be to-morrow:
Her hope was a further-looking hope,
And hers is a mother's sorrow.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The woman is not crying over the fact that her wedding day is supposed to be tomorrow. Her hope was for a future beyond the wedding day, and she is now experiencing the sadness of a mother.

text:
He was a tree that stood alone,
And proudly did its branches wave;
And the root of this delightful tree
Was in her husband's grave!
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The speaker describes a tree that stands alone with waving branches. The root of the tree is located in her husband's grave. The tree is depicted as delightful.

text:
Long, long in darkness did she sit,
And her first words were, 'Let there be
In Bolton, on the field of Wharf,
A stately Priory!'
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: She sat in darkness for a long time before speaking her first words: "Let there be a stately Priory on the field of Wharf in Bolton."

text:
The stately Priory was reared;
And Wharf, as he moved along,
To matins joined a mournful voice,
Nor failed at evensong.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The impressive Priory was built and as Wharf walked by, he sang a sad tune during the morning and evening prayers.

text:
And the Lady prayed in heaviness
That looked not for relief!
But slowly did her succour come,
And a patience to her grief.
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: The Lady prayed with a heavy heart and did not expect any relief. However, her relief came slowly, and she gained the patience to endure her grief.

text:
Oh! there is never sorrow of heart
That shall lack a timely end,
If but to God we turn, and ask
Of Him to be our friend!
poem_title: The Force Of Prayer, Or, The Founding Of Bolton, A Tradition
explanation: There is no heartache that won't come to an end if we turn to God and ask for His friendship.

text:
THOSE words were uttered as in pensive mood
We turned, departing from that solemn sight:
A contrast and reproach to gross delight,
And life's unspiritual pleasures daily wooed!
But now upon this thought I cannot brood;
poem_title: Those Words Were Uttered As In Pensive Mood
explanation: We spoke those words with a reflective tone, as we left behind a solemn scene that stood in stark contrast and rebuke to the mundane pleasures of life that we are constantly tempted by. However, I cannot dwell on this thought any longer.

text:
It is unstable as a dream of night;
Nor will I praise a cloud, however bright,
Disparaging Man's gifts, and proper food.
Grove, isle, with every shape of sky-built dome,
Though clad in colours beautiful and pure,
Find in the heart of man no natural home:
The immortal Mind craves objects that endure:
These cleave to it; from these it cannot roam,
Nor they from it: their fellowship is secure.
poem_title: Those Words Were Uttered As In Pensive Mood
explanation: The speaker deems fleeting dreams and beautiful clouds unworthy of praise, as they detract from the value of human accomplishments and sustenance. Natural landscapes and structures, no matter how picturesque, fail to resonate with the human heart, which seeks permanence. The mind desires lasting objects that will remain connected to it, and it will not stray from them, nor will they separate from the mind.

text:
TWO Voices are there; one is of the sea,
One of the mountains; each a mighty Voice:
In both from age to age thou didst rejoice,
They were thy chosen music, Liberty!
There came a Tyrant, and with holy glee
Thou fought'st against him; but hast vainly striven:
Thou from thy Alpine holds at length art driven,
Where not a torrent murmurs heard by thee.
poem_title: Thought Of A Briton On The Subjugation Of Switzerland
explanation: There are two powerful voices in the world - that of the sea and that of the mountains. Throughout history, people have found joy in both of these natural wonders, as they represent freedom and liberation. However, when a tyrant appeared, people fought against him with enthusiasm and zeal, but their efforts were in vain. Eventually, they were forced to retreat to the mountains, where they no longer had the freedom to hear the soothing sounds of the sea.

text:
Of one deep bliss thine ear hath been bereft:
Then cleave, O cleave to that which still is left;
For, high-souled Maid, what sorrow would it be
That Mountain floods should thunder as before,
And Ocean bellow from his rocky shore,
And neither awful Voice be heard by thee!
poem_title: Thought Of A Briton On The Subjugation Of Switzerland
explanation: You have lost the experience of one great joy, but hold on tightly to what remains. It would be a great sorrow if you were unable to hear the thunderous roar of mountain floods or the bellowing of the ocean from its rocky shore. As a high-spirited woman, don't let that happen.

text:
LADY! the songs of Spring were in the grove
While I was shaping beds for winter flowers;
While I was planting green unfading bowers,
And shrubs--to hang upon the warm alcove,
And sheltering wall; and still, as Fancy wove
The dream, to time and nature's blended powers
I gave this paradise for winter hours,
A labyrinth, Lady! which your feet shall rove.
explanation: The speaker addresses a lady, informing her that while the songs of Spring were present in the grove, they were occupied with preparing beds for winter flowers and planting green, evergreen bowers and shrubs to hang upon the warm alcove and sheltering wall. As they wove the dream of this paradise, they blended time and nature's powers to create a labyrinth which the lady would be able to explore.

text:
Yes! when the sun of life more feebly shines,
Becoming thoughts, I trust, of solemn gloom
Or of high gladness you shall hither bring;
And these perennial bowers and murmuring pines
Be gracious as the music and the bloom
And all the mighty ravishment of spring.
explanation: When my life starts to fade, I hope that my thoughts will be filled with both somber reflections and joyous memories, and that they will bring me back to this place. These beautiful surroundings of everlasting gardens and whispering pine trees will be just as lovely as the music and flowers of spring.

text:
HUMANITY, delighting to behold
A fond reflection of her own decay,
Hath painted Winter like a traveller old,
Propped on a staff, and, through the sullen day,
In hooded mantle, limping o'er the plain,
As though his weakness were disturbed by pain:
Or, if a juster fancy should allow
An undisputed symbol of command,
The chosen sceptre is a withered bough,
Infirmly grasped within a palsied hand.
These emblems suit the helpless and forlorn;
But mighty Winter the device shall scorn.
explanation: Winter is often portrayed by humans as an elderly traveler, using a staff to support his frail body as he limps through the day in a hooded cloak. Some may even use a withered branch to symbolize his authority, held shakily in his hand. However, these depictions only serve to show our own fear of aging and weakness. In truth, Winter is a powerful force that cannot be tamed by such feeble symbols.

text:
For he it was--dread Winter! who beset,
Flinging round van and rear his ghastly net,
That host, when from the regions of the Pole
They shrunk, insane ambition's barren goal--
That host, as huge and strong as e'er defied
Their God, and placed their trust in human pride!
As fathers persecute rebellious sons,
He smote the blossoms of their warrior youth;
He called on Frost's inexorable tooth
Life to consume in Manhood's firmest hold;
Nor spared the reverend blood that feebly runs;
For why--unless for liberty enrolled
And sacred home--ah! why should hoary Age be bold?
explanation: Winter, the dreadful season, surrounded and trapped the army with his icy grip as they retreated from their futile attempt at conquering the Pole. This mighty army, who believed in their own strength over the power of God, suffered the consequences of their foolishness. Winter attacked them like a father punishing rebellious sons, destroying their youthful warriors and even taking the lives of the elderly. Winter's wrath spared no one, except for those fighting for their freedom and homes. For what reason should the elderly risk their lives, if not for a noble cause?

text:
Fleet the Tartar's reinless steed,
But fleeter far the pinions of the Wind,
Which from Siberian caves the Monarch freed,
And sent him forth, with squadrons of his kind,
And bade the Snow their ample backs bestride,
And to the battle ride.
No pitying voice commands a halt,
No courage can repel the dire assault;
Distracted spiritless, benumbed, and blind,
Whole legions sink--and, in one instant, find
Burial and death: look for them--and descry,
When morn returns, beneath the clear blue sky,
A soundless waste, a trackless vacancy!
explanation: The Tartar's horse may be fast, but the wind is even faster as it was unleashed by the Monarch from the caves of Siberia, along with his squadrons. These creatures rode on the snow and charged into battle without any mercy or hesitation, leaving no chance for their enemies to stop them. Their opponents were left spiritless, confused, and helpless as they were overcome by the sheer force of the attack. The result was a devastating loss of life that left a vast, empty landscape in its wake, devoid of any sound or sign of life.

text:
NEXT morning Troilus began to clear
His eyes from sleep, at the first break of day,
And unto Pandarus, his own Brother dear,
For love of God, full piteously did say,
We must the Palace see of Cresida;
For since we yet may have no other feast,
Let us behold her Palace at the least!
explanation: The next morning, Troilus woke up and immediately asked his dear brother Pandarus to go with him to see Cresida's palace. He begged his brother to come with him out of love and said that since they couldn't have any other celebration, they should at least see the palace.

text:
And therewithal to cover his intent
A cause he found into the Town to go,
And they right forth to Cresid's Palace went;
But, Lord, this simple Troilus was woe,
Him thought his sorrowful heart would break in two;
For when he saw her doors fast bolted all,
Well nigh for sorrow down he 'gan to fall.
explanation: Troilus found a reason to go to the town to cover up his true intentions and went straight to Cressida's palace. However, he was filled with immense sorrow and felt like his heart was breaking into two when he saw that her doors were tightly locked. This caused him great distress and almost caused him to collapse in sorrow.

text:
Therewith when this true Lover 'gan behold,
How shut was every window of the place,
Like frost he thought his heart was icy cold;
For which, with changed, pale, and deadly face,
Without word uttered, forth he 'gan to pace;
And on his purpose bent so fast to ride,
That no wight his continuance espied.
explanation: The true lover became distressed upon seeing that all the windows of the location were shut. He felt as though his heart had turned cold as ice. He began to pace back and forth with a pale and deadly appearance, without uttering any words. He quickly made up his mind to leave the place and ride away without anyone noticing.

text:
Then said he thus,--O Palace desolate!
O house of houses, once so richly dight!
O Palace empty and disconsolate!
Thou lamp of which extinguished is the light;
O Palace whilom day that now art night,
Thou ought'st to fall and I to die; since she
Is gone who held us both in sovereignty.
explanation: The speaker expresses his sorrow over the desolate and empty palace, which was once richly decorated and illuminated. The palace, which used to be a symbol of power and authority, is now a gloomy and dark place. The speaker suggests that the palace should fall and he should die, as the person who held sovereignty over them both is no longer present.

text:
O, of all houses once the crowned boast!
Palace illumined with the sun of bliss;
O ring of which the ruby now is lost,
O cause of woe, that cause has been of bliss:
Yet, since I may no better, would I kiss
Thy cold doors; but I dare not for this rout;
Farewell, thou shrine of which the Saint is out.
explanation: This poem laments the loss of a once great and glorious palace, now filled with sadness and despair. The speaker longs to pay homage to the now-empty palace, but is afraid to do so in the midst of the current chaos. The poem ends with a farewell to the "shrine" that once held great significance, but is now devoid of its former glory.

text:
Therewith he cast on Pandarus an eye,
With changed face, and piteous to behold;
And when he might his time aright espy,
Aye as he rode, to Pandarus he told
Both his new sorrow and his joys of old,
So piteously, and with so dead a hue,
That every wight might on his sorrow rue.
explanation: He looked at Pandarus with a sorrowful expression and shared his new and old joys with him while riding. He did this so pitifully and with such a pale face that anyone who saw him would feel sorry for his sorrow.

text:
Forth from the spot he rideth up and down,
And everything to his rememberance
Came as he rode by places of the town
Where he had felt such perfect pleasure once.
Lo, yonder saw I mine own Lady dance,
And in that Temple she with her bright eyes,
My Lady dear, first bound me captive-wise.
explanation: He rode around the town, recalling past memories of places where he had experienced great pleasure. He saw his beloved Lady dancing in a temple with her bright eyes, the same place where she first captivated him.

text:
And yonder with joy-smitten heart have I
Heard my own Cresid's laugh; and once at play
I yonder saw her eke full blissfully;
And yonder once she unto me 'gan say--
Now, my sweet Troilus, love me well, I pray!
And there so graciously did me behold,
That hers unto the death my heart I hold.
explanation: With a heart full of joy, I have heard my beloved Cresid's laughter from a distance. I have even seen her playing happily there before. Once she spoke to me, saying "Love me well, my sweet Troilus." Her gracious gaze held my heart so tightly that I will love her until the day I die.

text:
And at the corner of that self-same house
Heard I my most beloved Lady dear,
So womanly, with voice melodious
Singing so well, so goodly, and so clear,
That in my soul methinks I yet do hear
The blissful sound; and in that very place
My Lady first me took unto her grace.
explanation: I heard my beloved Lady singing beautifully at the corner of the same house where she first showed me kindness. Her voice was so melodious and clear that I still remember it in my soul.

text:
O blissful God of Love! then thus he cried,
When I the process have in memory,
How thou hast wearied me on every side,
Men thence a book might make, a history;
What need to seek a conquest over me,
Since I am wholly at thy will? what joy
Hast thou thy own liege subjects to destroy?
explanation: The speaker addresses the God of Love and expresses their weariness from being constantly manipulated by love. They suggest that their experiences could be turned into a book or a history due to the extent of their suffering. The speaker questions why the God of Love would need to conquer them when they are already completely at their mercy. The speaker also questions the joy that the God of Love derives from destroying their loyal subjects.

text:
Dread Lord! so fearful when provoked, thine ire
Well hast thou wreaked on me by pain and grief.
Now mercy, Lord! thou know'st well I desire
Thy grace above all pleasures first and chief;
And live and die I will in thy belief;
For which I ask for guerdon but one boon,
That Cresida again thou send me soon.
explanation: Oh fearful Lord, my suffering at your wrath has been immense. I plead for your mercy, as my desire for your grace outweighs any other pleasure. I will live and die in my faith in you, and ask for only one thing in return - that you send Cresida back to me soon.

text:
Constrain her heart as quickly to return,
As thou dost mine with longing her to see,
Then know I well that she would not sojourn.
Now, blissful Lord, so cruel do not be
Unto the blood of Troy, I pray of thee,
As Juno was unto the Theban blood,
From whence to Thebes came griefs in multitude.
explanation: Please, dear Lord, do not be cruel to me and my love by keeping her away for too long. If you make her heart ache to see me as much as mine does for her, then she will not stay away. I beg of you not to be as cruel as Juno was to the Theban people, who suffered greatly because of her actions.

text:
And after this he to the gate did go,
Whence Cresid rode, as if in haste she was;
And up and down there went, and to and fro,
And to himself full oft he said, alas!
From hence my hope, and solace forth did pass.
O would the blissful God now for his joy,
I might her see again coming to Troy!
explanation: He went to the gate where he saw Cresid riding away hurriedly. He paced back and forth, lamenting the loss of his hope and comfort. He wished that he could see her again as she returned to Troy, praying to God for this joy.

I guided her to a hill and sadly said goodbye as she rode off to her father. My heart aches with grief and I returned home alone as an outcast without any joy. Unless I see her soon in Troy, I will continue to feel this way.

text:
And of himself did he imagine oft,
That he was blighted, pale, and waxen less
Than he was wont; and that in whispers soft
Men said, what may it be, can no one guess
Why Troilus hath all this heaviness?
All which he of himself conceited wholly
Out of his weakness and his melancholy.
explanation: Troilus often imagined that he looked sickly, pale, and thinner than usual, and he believed that people whispered about him and wondered why he was so sad. However, these thoughts were a result of his own insecurities and melancholy mood.

text:
Another time he took into his head,
That every wight, who in the way passed by,
Had of him ruth, and fancied that they said,
I am right sorry Troilus will die:
And thus a day or two drove wearily;
As ye have heard; such life 'gan he to lead
As one that standeth betwixt hope and dread.
explanation: At one point, Troilus believed that everyone who passed him on the street felt sorry for him and thought he was going to die. This made him feel anxious and he lived for a day or two in a state of uncertainty, not knowing whether to hope for the best or fear the worst.

text:
For which it pleased him in his songs to show
The occasion of his woe, as best he might;
And made a fitting song, of words but few,
Somewhat his woeful heart to make more light;
And when he was removed from all men's sight,
With a soft night voice, he of his Lady dear,
That absent was, 'gan sing as ye may hear.
explanation: He found solace in expressing his sorrow through his songs and used them to narrate the cause of his pain as best as he could. Despite using minimal words, he was able to compose a suitable song that helped ease the burden on his heavy heart. When he was isolated from everyone, he sang softly in the night, dedicating his songs to his beloved Lady who was far away from him.

text:
O star, of which I lost have all the light,
With a sore heart well ought I to bewail,
That ever dark in torment, night by night,
Toward my death with wind I steer and sail;
For which upon the tenth night if thou fail
With thy bright beams to guide me but one hour,
My ship and me Charybdis will devour.
explanation: I am lamenting the loss of a guiding star that used to light my way. Without it, I am navigating towards my own demise through dark and painful nights. If the star fails to guide me even for an hour on the tenth night, I fear I will be consumed by the treacherous Charybdis.

text:
As soon as he this song had thus sung through,
He fell again into his sorrows old;
And every night, as was his wont to do,
Troilus stood the bright moon to behold;
And all his trouble to the moon he told,
And said; I wis, when thou art horn'd anew,
I shall be glad if all the world be true.
explanation: After singing a sad song, Troilus resumed his usual habit of looking at the moon every night and pouring out his troubles to it. He expressed his hope that when the moon waxes again, his problems will be resolved and the world will be a better place.

On that day when my beloved Lady departed, her horns were as old as they are now. Her absence causes me great pain and sorrow. I implore the moon to move swiftly in its orbit, so that its horns may once again begin to grow. For when they do, I believe my Lady will return, bringing with her happiness and joy.

text:
The day is more, and longer every night
Than they were wont to be---for he thought so;
And that the sun did take his course not right,
By longer way than he was wont to go;
And said, I am in constant dread I trow,
That Phaeton his son is yet alive,
His too fond father's car amiss to drive.
explanation: The speaker observes that the day seems longer and the night shorter than usual, and attributes this to the sun taking a longer path than it used to. The speaker expresses concern that Phaeton, the son of the god Helios who disastrously tried to drive his father's chariot, may still be alive and causing the sun's erratic movements.

He walked quickly along the walls, hoping to catch a glimpse of the Greek army. As he walked, he talked to himself, imagining that he could see his beloved Lady or the enemy's tents. The sweet air that surrounded him filled him with happiness and pleasure.

text:
And certainly this wind, that more and more
By moments thus increaseth in my face,
Is of my Lady's sighs heavy and sore;
I prove it thus; for in no other space
Of all this town, save only in this place,
Feel I a wind, that soundeth so like pain;
It saith, Alas, why severed are we twain?
explanation: The wind that is blowing against me is getting stronger and stronger, and I believe it is my Lady's heavy and mournful sighs that are causing it. This is the only place in the town where I feel such a painful wind, and it seems to be saying, "Alas, why are we separated?"

text:
A weary while in pain he tosseth thus,
Till fully past and gone was the ninth night;
And ever at his side stood Pandarus,
Who busily made use of all his might
To comfort him, and make his heart more light;
Giving him always hope, that she the morrow
Of the tenth day will come, and end his sorrow.
explanation: For nine nights, a tired and pained man tossed and turned, with Pandarus by his side, doing everything he could to lift the man's spirits and offer comfort. Pandarus gave the man hope that his sorrow would come to an end on the tenth day when the woman he longed for would finally arrive.

text:
Oh, for a kindling touch from that pure flame
Which ministered, erewhile, to a sacrifice
Of gratitude, beneath Italian skies,
In words like these: 'Up, Voice of song! proclaim
'Thy saintly rapture with celestial aim:
'For lo! the Imperial City stands released
'From bondage threatened by the embattled East,
'And Christendom respires; from guilt and shame
'Redeemed, from miserable fear set free
'By one day's feat, one mighty victory.                     10
'--Chant the Deliverer's praise in every tongue!
'The cross shall spread, the crescent hath waxed dim;
'He conquering, as in joyful Heaven is sung,
'HE CONQUERING THROUGH GOD, AND GOD BY HIM.'
poem_title: Siege Of Vienna Raised By John Sobieski
explanation: The speaker yearns for the passion and inspiration of a previous moment when they witnessed a sacrifice of gratitude under the Italian sky. They call for a voice of song to proclaim the joy and relief felt as the Imperial City was freed from threatened bondage by the East, allowing Christendom to breathe freely. The speaker urges the voice to chant the praises of the Deliverer in every language, as the victory has redeemed them from guilt and fear. The cross shall spread, while the crescent fades, and they celebrate the triumph of God through the conquering Deliverer.

poem_title: Though Narrow Be That Old Man’s Cares                                                  .
explanation: The old man may have limited concerns and be close-minded, but he possesses a greater significance than what meets the eye. He holds a vast realm of senses, expanding as far as the imagination can reach. His travels are filled with a mystical joy, making his experiences rich and otherworldly.

text:
The region of his inner spirit teems
With vital sounds and monitory gleams
Of high astonishment and pleasing fear.
He the seven birds hath seen, that never part,
Seen the SEVEN WHISTLERS in their nightly rounds,
And counted them: and oftentimes will start--
For overhead are sweeping GABRIEL'S HOUNDS
Doomed, with their impious Lord, the flying Hart
To chase for ever, on aerial grounds!
poem_title: Though Narrow Be That Old Man’s Cares                                                  .
explanation: The speaker's inner self is full of life and wonder, as well as a sense of both fear and pleasure. He has witnessed the seven birds that never separate, known as the Seven Whistlers, on their nightly journey and has counted them. He often feels startled by the sound of Gabriel's Hounds who fly overhead, chasing a flying Hart with their unrighteous leader for all eternity in the sky.

text:
MARK how the feathered tenants of the flood,
With grace of motion that might scarcely seem
Inferior to angelical, prolong
Their curious pastime! shaping in mid air
(And sometimes with ambitious wing that soars
High as the level of the mountain-tops)
A circuit ampler than the lake beneath--
Their own domain; but ever, while intent
On tracing and retracing that large round,
Their jubilant activity evolves
Hundreds of curves and circlets, to and fro,
Upward and downward, progress intricate
Yet unperplexed, as if one spirit swayed
Their indefatigable flight. 'Tis done--
Ten times, or more, I fancied it had ceased;
poem_title: Water-Fowl Observed Frequently Over The Lakes Of Rydal And Grasmere
explanation: Observe how the birds on the water move with such graceful motion, almost comparable to that of angels. They playfully fly in mid-air, sometimes soaring as high as the mountain-tops, creating a circuit larger than the lake below. Their movements are intricate, yet seamless, as if they are controlled by a single spirit. They continue their activity, tracing and retracing their path in hundreds of curves and circles, without any confusion. Watching them, it seems as though their flight will never end.

text:
But lo! the vanished company again
Ascending; they approach--I hear their wings,
Faint, faint at first; and then an eager sound,
Past in a moment--and as faint again!
They tempt the sun to sport amid their plumes;
poem_title: Water-Fowl Observed Frequently Over The Lakes Of Rydal And Grasmere
explanation: Suddenly, the company that had disappeared reappears, and I can hear the sound of their wings. It is faint at first, but then it becomes more eager before quickly passing by and becoming faint once again. Their feathers seem to entice the sun to play with them.

text:
They tempt the water, or the gleaming ice,
To show them a fair image; 'tis themselves,
Their own fair forms, upon the glimmering plain,
Painted more soft and fair as they descend
Almost to touch;--then up again aloft,
Up with a sally and a flash of speed,
As if they scorned both resting-place and rest!
poem_title: Water-Fowl Observed Frequently Over The Lakes Of Rydal And Grasmere
explanation: People entice the water or ice to reflect their own beautiful image, making it appear softer and more beautiful as they come closer to it. Then they quickly ascend back up with a burst of speed, seemingly rejecting any desire for rest or relaxation.

text:
The Shepherd, looking eastward, softly said,
"Bright is thy veil, O Moon, as thou art bright!"
Forthwith, that little cloud, in ether spread
And penetrated all with tender light,
She cast away, and showed her fulgent head
Uncovered; dazzling the Beholder's sight
As if to vindicate her beauty's right
Her beauty thoughtlessly disparaged.
poem_title: The Shepherd, Looking Eastward, Softly Said
explanation: The Shepherd gazed towards the east and commented on how bright the Moon's veil was. The small cloud covering the Moon dissipated, revealing its radiant and shining form. The Moon's beauty was on full display, as if it was proving its worthiness to those who had doubted its splendor.

poem_title: The Shepherd, Looking Eastward, Softly Said
explanation: As the veil that was covering her was removed or discarded, it floated away and gradually became darker. A large object approached her, seemingly with the intention of burying or hiding her. Despite this, she humbly accepted the obscurity and remained content, proud in her modesty.
The weather is chilly and the nights are prolonged, with the north-wind producing a sad melody. Only my beloved remains lively on my chest while all other joyful things are dormant.

text:
The kitten sleeps upon the hearth,
The crickets long have ceased their mirth;
There's nothing stirring in the house
Save one 'wee', hungry, nibbling mouse,
Then why so busy thou?
explanation: The kitten is peacefully sleeping by the fireplace while the crickets have stopped chirping a long time ago. There is no movement in the house except for a small mouse that is hungrily nibbling on something. This begs the question: why are you so busy when everything else is so calm and still?

text:
Nay! start not at that sparkling light;
'Tis but the moon that shines so bright
On the window pane bedropped with rain:
Then, little Darling! sleep again,
And wake when it is day.
explanation: Don't be afraid of the shining light, it's just the moon reflecting on the window that has raindrops on it. So go back to sleep, my dear child, and wake up when it's morning.

text:
HIGH is our calling, Friend!--Creative Art
(Whether the instrument of words she use,
Or pencil pregnant with ethereal hues,)
Demands the service of a mind and heart,
Though sensitive, yet, in their weakest part,
Heroically fashioned--to infuse
Faith in the whispers of the lonely Muse,
While the whole world seems adverse to desert.
explanation: Our calling, my friend, is to elevate ourselves to a higher level through the use of creative art. Whether we express ourselves through words or visuals, it requires a mind and heart that are both sensitive and strong enough to imbue faith in the voice of the Muse, even when the world seems to be against us. It takes courage to pursue this path, but it is a noble one that can bring us closer to our true selves.

text:
And, oh! when Nature sinks, as oft she may,
Through long-lived pressure of obscure distress,
Still to be strenuous for the bright reward,
And in the soul admit of no decay,
Brook no continuance of weak-mindedness--
Great is the glory, for the strife is hard!
explanation: When nature is weighed down by persistent and concealed suffering, it is crucial to continue striving for the eventual reward and maintain an unwavering spirit that cannot be weakened by despair. This is a great accomplishment, as the fight against adversity is difficult and requires immense strength.

text:
SOON did he Almighty Giver of all rest
Take those dear young Ones to a fearless nest;
And in Death's arms has long reposed the Friend
For whom this simple Register was penned.
poem_title: Upon Perusing The Forgoing Epistle Thirty Years After Its Composition
explanation: The Almighty Giver of all soon brought the young ones to a place without fear. The friend for whom this record was created has been resting in Death's embrace for a long time.

text:
Thanks to the moth that spared it for our eyes;
And Strangers even the slighted Scroll may prize,
Moved by the touch of kindred sympathies.
For--save the calm, repentance sheds o'er strife
Raised by remembrances of misused life,
The light from past endeavours purely willed
And by Heaven's favour happily fulfilled;
poem_title: Upon Perusing The Forgoing Epistle Thirty Years After Its Composition
explanation: The moth that spared a scroll has allowed even strangers to appreciate it, as they can relate to the emotions it evokes. The scroll may bring about a sense of calm and repentance in those who reflect on their past mistakes. However, it also highlights the light that comes from past endeavors that were purely intended and successfully realized with the help of divine intervention.

text:
Save hope that we, yet bound to Earth, may share
The joys of the Departed--what so fair
As blameless pleasure, not without some tears,
Reviewed through Love's transparent veil of years?
poem_title: Upon Perusing The Forgoing Epistle Thirty Years After Its Composition
explanation: We should keep faith that despite being on Earth, we can still experience the happiness of those who have passed on. There is nothing more beautiful than innocent joy, even if it brings some sadness, when viewed through the lens of love and the passage of time.

text:
THE Voice of song from distant lands shall call
To that great King; shall hail the crowned Youth
Who, taking counsel of unbending Truth,
By one example hath set forth to all
How they with dignity may stand; or fall,
If fall they must. Now, whither doth it tend?
And what to him and his shall be the end?
That thought is one which neither can appal
Nor cheer him; for the illustrious Swede hath done
The thing which ought to be; is raised 'above'
All consequences: work he hath begun
Of fortitude, and piety, and love,
Which all his glorious ancestors approve:
The heroes bless him, him their rightful son.
explanation: The voice of song from distant lands will call out to the great King, hailing the crowned Youth who has demonstrated the power of unbending truth and set an example for others to follow with dignity, even in the face of failure. The illustrious Swede has undertaken a noble task that he knows will have consequences, but he is not afraid. His work embodies fortitude, piety, and love, earning him the approval of his glorious ancestors and the blessings of the heroes who came before him.

text:
By Derwent's side my Father's cottage stood,
(The Woman thus her artless story told)
One field, a flock, and what the neighboring flood
Supplied, to him were more than mines of gold.
Light was my sleep; my days in transport roll'd:
With thoughtless joy I stretch'd along the shore
My father's nets, or watched, when from the fold
High o'er the cliffs I led my fleecy store,
A dizzy depth below! his boat and twinkling oar.
explanation: The Woman tells the narrator that her father's cottage was situated by Derwent's side and that he had only one field, a flock of sheep, and what the nearby flood could provide, but he considered it more valuable than gold mines. She recalls how she used to sleep lightly and spend her days in blissful happiness. She would either lay out her father's fishing nets along the shore or lead her flock of sheep over the cliffs, which was a dizzying experience due to the depth below.

text:
My father was a good and pious man,
An honest man, by honest parents bred,
And I believe that, soon as I began
To lisp, he made me kneel beside my bed,
And in his hearing there my prayers I said:
And afterwards, by my good father taught,
I read, and loved the books in which I read;
For books in every neighboring house I sought,
And nothing to my mind a sweeter pleasure brought.
explanation: The speaker's father was a good and religious man, raised by honest parents. From a young age, the speaker was taught to pray by their father and continued to read and love books as they grew older. They sought out books in neighboring houses and found nothing more pleasurable than reading.

Do I have the capacity to erase from my memory the beautiful things that used to grace my garden? The peas, mint, thyme, roses, and lilies that I would pick for the Sabbath morning? The ringing of the Sabbath bells and the enchanting chime? The playful antics during shearing time and my hen's hidden nest in the long grass? The gathering of cowslips in the dewy prime of May? The swans that would swim towards me from afar, showing off their snowy elegance?

I have vivid memories of the staff that supported my father's body as he moved around, the comfortable seat he had under a sycamore tree, accompanied by the humming of bees, or by the winter fire, dressed in his finest clothes on market mornings, and my loyal dog, whom I often had to calm down when strangers walked by. I also remember the red-breasted bird that would peck at my window for years.

text:
The suns of twenty summers danced along, -
Ah! little marked, how fast they rolled away:
Then rose a mansion proud our woods among,
And cottage after cottage owned its sway,
No joy to see a neighboring house, or stray
Through pastures not his own, the master took;
My Father dared his greedy wish gainsay;
He loved his old hereditary nook,
And ill could I the thought of such sad parting brook.
explanation: Twenty summers went by quickly as the sun shone down, and a grand house was built among the trees, followed by cottages that also belonged to the owner. However, the owner did not take pleasure in seeing other houses or wandering through fields that did not belong to him. The narrator's father refused to give in to the owner's desire to expand and loved their ancestral home. The narrator, too, could not bear the thought of leaving and parting with their beloved home.

text:
But, when he had refused the proffered gold,
To cruel injuries he became a prey,
Sore traversed in whate'er he bought and sold:
His troubles grew upon him day by day,
Till all his substance fell into decay.
His little range of water was denied;
All but the bed where his old body lay,
All, all was seized, and weeping, side by side,
We sought a home where we uninjured might abide.
explanation: When the protagonist declined the offer of gold, he was subjected to cruel mistreatment and suffered losses in his trade. His problems only worsened with time, resulting in the depletion of his wealth. His access to water was restricted and all his possessions were seized, except for his bed. He and his companions were forced to leave in search of a safe haven where they could live without fear of harm.

text:
Can I forget that miserable hour,
When from the last hill-top, my sire surveyed,
Peering above the trees, the steeple tower,
That on his marriage-day sweet music made?
Till then he hoped his bones might there be laid,
Close by my mother in their native bowers:
Bidding me trust in God, he stood and prayed, — I could not pray: — through tears that fell in showers,
Glimmer'd our dear-loved home, alas! no longer ours!
explanation: The speaker recalls a painful memory of their father standing atop a hill, looking at the steeple tower where he had married the speaker's mother. The father had hoped to be buried there alongside the mother, but their home was no longer theirs. The father had urged the speaker to trust in God, but the speaker couldn't bring themselves to pray and tears fell as they looked at their lost home.

text:
There was a youth whom I had loved so long,
That when I loved him not I cannot say.
‘Mid the green mountains many and many a song
We two had sung, like little birds in May.
When we began to tire of childish play
We seemed still more and more to prize each other:
We talked of marriage and our marriage day;
And I in truth did love him like a brother,
For never could I hope to meet with such another.
explanation: I had loved a young man for so long that I cannot recall when I stopped loving him. We sang many songs together like little birds in May amid the green mountains. As we grew older, we talked about marriage and how much we treasured each other's company. I loved him like a brother and knew I could never find someone like him again.

text:
His father said, that to a distant town
He must repair, to ply the artist's trade.
What tears of bitter grief till then unknown!
What tender vows our last sad kiss delayed!
To him we turned: — we had no other aid.
Like one revived, upon his neck I wept,
And her whom he had loved in joy, he said
He well could love in grief: his faith he kept;
And in a quiet home once more my father slept
explanation: The speaker's father informed him that he needed to go to a different town to pursue his career as an artist. This news resulted in tears of sorrow and delayed goodbyes between the speaker and his loved ones. The speaker and his family relied on the father's support as they bid farewell. The father offered comfort and promised to remain faithful to his lover even in difficult times. Eventually, the father found a peaceful home to rest in.

text:
IN trellised shed with clustering roses gay,
And, MARY! oft beside our blazing fire,
When yeas of wedded life were as a day
Whose current answers to the heart's desire,
Did we together read in Spenser's Lay
How Una, sad of soul--in sad attire,
The gentle Una, of celestial birth,
To seek her Knight went wandering o'er the earth.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: In a shed covered in trellises of roses, my beloved Mary and I often sat by the warm fire during the early years of our marriage. Time flew by so quickly and our days together felt like a dream come true. During these moments, we read together from Spenser's Lay, a tale about a celestial being named Una who was in distress and searching for her knight.

text:
Ah, then, Beloved! pleasing was the smart,
And the tear precious in compassion shed
For Her, who, pierced by sorrow's thrilling dart,
Did meekly bear the pang unmerited;
Meek as that emblem of her lowly heart
The milk-white Lamb which in a line she led,--
And faithful, loyal in her innocence,
Like the brave Lion slain in her defence.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: My dear one, the pain I felt was sweet, and my tears were worth it as I sympathized with the woman who was hit by the sharp arrow of sorrow. She accepted the undeserved pain with humility, just like the pure-hearted lamb she led on a string. She was also loyal and faithful in her purity, like the brave lion who died protecting her.

text:
Notes could we hear as of a faery shell
Attuned to words with sacred wisdom fraught;
Free Fancy prized each specious miracle,
And all its finer inspiration caught;
Till in the bosom of our rustic Cell,
We by a lamentable change were taught
That 'bliss with mortal Man may not abide:'
How nearly joy and sorrow are allied!
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: We were once able to hear the notes of a mystical shell that were in tune with words filled with divine knowledge. Our imagination cherished every beautiful wonder and captured all of its exquisite inspiration until a sorrowful event occurred in our simple abode. This event taught us that happiness cannot coexist with humanity and how closely related joy and sorrow truly are.

text:
For us the stream of fiction ceased to flow,
For us the voice of melody was mute.
--But, as soft gales dissolve the dreary snow,
And give the timid herbage leave to shoot,
Heaven's breathing influence failed not to bestow
A timely promise of unlooked-for fruit,
Fair fruit of pleasure and serene content
From blossoms wild of fancies innocent.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: We no longer had access to fiction and music, but like a gentle wind melting snow and allowing plants to grow, a heavenly influence gave us hope for unexpected and enjoyable experiences. This hope came from innocent and wild imaginations that promised us peaceful contentment.

text:
It soothed us--it beguiled us--then, to hear
Once more of troubles wrought by magic spell;
And griefs whose aery motion comes not near
The pangs that tempt the Spirit to rebel:
Then, with mild Una in her sober cheer,
High over hill and low adown the dell
Again we wandered, willing to partake
All that she suffered for her dear Lord's sake.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: Listening to tales of magical spells and distant griefs that do not compare to the deep emotional turmoil that can cause rebellion within us, brought us comfort and captivated us. Then, we followed Una, who was calm and serious, through the hills and valleys, eager to share in the suffering she endured for the sake of her beloved Lord.

text:
Then, too, this Song 'of mine' once more could please,
Where anguish, strange as dreams of restless sleep,
Is tempered and allayed by sympathies
Aloft ascending, and descending deep,
Even to the inferior Kinds; whom forest-trees
Protect from beating sunbeams, and the sweep
Of the sharp winds;--fair Creatures!--to whom Heaven
A calm and sinless life, with love, hath given.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: The poet expresses his hope that his song will be well-received once again. He describes his song as one that can soothe the pain and suffering of those who are restless and troubled. He suggests that his song can bring comfort to all creatures, even those that are lower in the hierarchy of life. He praises the forest-trees for their ability to protect the animals from harsh weather conditions. He admires the beauty and innocence of these creatures, who have been blessed with a peaceful and loving existence by Heaven.

text:
This tragic Story cheered us; for it speaks
Of female patience winning firm repose;
And, of the recompense that conscience seeks,
A bright, encouraging, example shows;
Needful when o'er wide realms the tempest breaks,
Needful amid life's ordinary woes;--
Hence, not for them unfitted who would bless
A happy hour with holier happiness.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: The story is a tragedy but it brings us some comfort as it tells us of a woman who patiently endures her troubles and finds peace. It also shows us that doing what is right and having a clear conscience can bring rewards. This is an inspiring example for us all to follow, especially during difficult times. It is a lesson that can be applied not only during major upheavals but also in our everyday struggles. This example is relevant to those who seek to add more happiness and meaning to their lives.

text:
He serves the Muses erringly and ill,
Whose aim is pleasure light and fugitive:
Oh, that my mind were equal to fulfil
The comprehensive mandate which they give--
Vain aspiration of an earnest will!
Yet in this moral Strain a power may live,
Beloved Wife! such solace to impart
As it hath yielded to thy tender heart.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: The author laments his inability to fully serve the Muses, as his pursuit of fleeting pleasure is often misguided. He expresses a desire for his mind to be capable of fulfilling their vast and complex demands, but acknowledges that this may be an unattainable goal. Nevertheless, he believes that his moral musings may offer comfort to his beloved wife, as they have previously done for her.

text:
RYDAL MOUNT, WESTMORELAND,
April , 1815.
_____________
'Action is transitory--a step, a blow,
The motion of a muscle--this way or that--
'Tis done; and in the after-vacancy
We wonder at ourselves like men betrayed:
Suffering is permanent, obscure and dark,
And has the nature of infinity.
Yet through that darkness (infinite though it seem
And irremoveable) gracious openings lie,
By which the soul--with patient steps of thought
Now toiling, waked now on wings of prayer--
May pass in hope, and, though from mortal bonds
Yet undelivered, rise with sure ascent
Even to the fountain-head of peace divine.'
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Dedication
explanation: In this letter from Rydal Mount, Westmoreland in April 1815, the author reflects on the transitory nature of action, which is fleeting and quickly forgotten, and the permanent and obscure nature of suffering, which seems infinite. However, the author notes that even in the darkness of suffering, there are opportunities for the soul to pass through gracious openings with patient thought and prayer. Though mortal bonds may still hold the soul, with hope it can rise to the fountain-head of peace divine.

text:
LIE here, without a record of thy worth,
Beneath a covering of the common earth!
It is not from unwillingness to praise,
Or want of love, that here no Stone we raise;
poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: Rest peacefully here, without any monument to showcase your value, buried under the ordinary ground. We do not fail to honor or cherish you because of any reluctance or absence of affection; it is simply that we choose not to erect a stone in your memory.

text:
More thou deserv'st; but 'this' man gives to man,
Brother to brother, 'this' is all we can.
Yet they to whom thy virtues made thee dear
Shall find thee through all changes of the year:
This Oak points out thy grave; the silent tree
Will gladly stand a monument of thee.
poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: Although you deserve more recognition, all we can offer is brotherly love and support. Those who cherished your virtues will always remember you, even as time passes. Your final resting place is marked by an oak tree that will serve as a lasting tribute to your memory.

poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: We mourned for you and hoped for your end to come, and finally, we have laid you to rest. Your life had endured until all that brought joy had succumbed to the burden of old age.

text:
Extreme old age had wasted thee away,
And left thee but a glimmering of the day;
Thy ears were deaf, and feeble were thy knees,--
I saw thee stagger in the summer breeze,
Too weak to stand against its sportive breath,
And ready for the gentlest stroke of death.
poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: You were extremely old and frail, barely able to see, hear, or stand. Even the slightest breeze caused you to sway and stumble, and death seemed to be knocking at your door.

poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: We were happy when it arrived but saddened when you passed away. Men and women alike shed tears for the many memories we shared with you, both big and small, that were intertwined with our daily lives.

text:
But for some precious boons vouchsafed to thee,
Found scarcely anywhere in like degree!
For love, that comes wherever life and sense
Are given by God, in thee was most intense;
poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: You have been granted some rare gifts that are hard to find elsewhere. The love within you is incredibly strong, as it is a natural part of life given by God.

text:
A chain of heart, a feeling of the mind,
A tender sympathy, which did thee bind
Not only to us Men, but to thy Kind:
Yea, for thy fellow-brutes in thee we saw
A soul of love, love's intellectual law:--
Hence, if we wept, it was not done in shame;
Our tears from passion and from reason came,
And, therefore, shalt thou be an honoured name!
poem_title: Tribute To The Memory Of The Same Dog
explanation: Your compassion connected us not only to humanity but also to all creatures, displaying a love that transcends intellect. We shed tears not out of embarrassment but out of overwhelming emotion and logic. Because of this, you will forever hold a place of honor in our hearts.

text:
Let other bards of angels sing,
Bright suns without a spot;
But thou art no such perfect thing:
Rejoice that thou art not!
explanation: Some poets may write about flawless angels and pristine suns, but that is not what this poem is about. The speaker is addressing someone or something that is not perfect and encouraging them to find joy in their imperfections. The tone is almost playful, as if the speaker is teasing the subject. Overall, the message is that it's okay to be imperfect and that there is beauty in imperfection.

text:
Heed not tho' none should call thee fair;
So, Mary, let it be
If nought in loveliness compare
With what thou art to me.
explanation: Don't worry if no one else thinks you are beautiful, Mary. To me, nothing compares to your loveliness.

text:
True beauty dwells in deep retreats,
Whose veil is unremoved
Till heart with heart in concord beats,
And the lover is beloved.
explanation: The essence of true beauty is hidden in secluded places, and its true form is only revealed when two hearts beat as one and the lover is loved in return.

text:
'Tis night: in silence looking down,
The Moon, from cloudless ether, sees
A Camp, and a beleaguered Town,
And Castle, like a stately crown
On the steep rocks of winding Tees;--
And southward far, with moor between,
Hill-top, and flood, and forest green,
The bright Moon sees that valley small
Where Rylstone's old sequestered Hall
A venerable image yields
Of quiet to the neighbouring fields;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: At night, the Moon peers down from the clear sky and observes a Camp, a besieged Town, and a Castle perched on the high rocks of the twisting Tees River. Further south, separated by moors, hills, rivers, and forests, the Moon gazes upon a small valley where Rylstone's ancient and secluded Hall stands as a peaceful symbol for the surrounding fields.

text:
While from one pillared chimney breathes
The smoke, and mounts in silver wreaths.
--The courts are hushed;--for timely sleep
The greyhounds to their kennel creep;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The smoke rises from a chimney with one pillar and forms silver wreaths as the courts fall silent. The greyhounds retire to their kennels for a well-deserved rest.

text:
The peacock in the broad ash tree
Aloft is roosted for the night,
He who in proud prosperity
Of colours manifold and bright
Walked round, affronting the daylight;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The peacock has settled for the night on a broad ash tree. This bird is known for its bright and colorful feathers, and it strutted around confidently during the day.

text:
And higher still, above the bower
Where he is perched, from yon lone Tower
The hall-clock in the clear moonshine
With glittering finger points at nine.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: In the poem, the speaker describes a bird perched on a bower. The bird is situated so high up that it is possible to see the clock on a distant tower. In the moonlight, the clock's hand points to the number nine and glitters in the night sky.

text:
Ah! who could think that sadness here
Hath any sway? or pain, or fear?
A soft and lulling sound is heard
Of streams inaudible by day;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: It is difficult to believe that sadness, pain, or fear could exist in this place. The soothing sound of the streams that cannot be heard during the day creates a peaceful atmosphere.

text:
The garden pool's dark surface, stirred
By the night insects in their play,
Breaks into dimples small and bright;
A thousand, thousand rings of light
That shape themselves and disappear
Almost as soon as seen:--and lo!
Not distant far, the milk-white Doe--
The same who quietly was feeding
On the green herb, and nothing heeding,
When Francis, uttering to the Maid
His last words in the yew-tree shade,
Involved whate'er by love was brought
Out of his heart, or crossed his thought,
Or chance presented to his eye,
In one sad sweep of destiny--
The same fair Creature, who hath found
Her way into forbidden ground;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The garden pool, disturbed by playful night insects, creates small and bright dimples on its dark surface. These fleeting dimples form a thousand rings of light that quickly disappear. Nearby, a milk-white Doe, who was previously feeding on greenery, has entered forbidden ground. This same Doe was present when Francis shared his deepest thoughts and emotions with the Maid in the yew-tree shade, encapsulating all of his love and fate into one moment.

text:
Where now--within this spacious plot
For pleasure made, a goodly spot,
With lawns and beds of flowers, and shades
Of trellis-work in long arcades,
And cirque and crescent framed by wall
Of close-clipt foliage green and tall,
Converging walks, and fountains gay,
And terraces in trim array--
Beneath yon cypress spiring high,
With pine and cedar spreading wide
Their darksome boughs on either side,
In open moonlight doth she lie;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: She is lying in a spacious and well-designed garden that was made for pleasure. The garden has lawns, flower beds, trellis-work, and long arcades with converging walks, fountains, and terraces that are all beautifully maintained. It is framed by a wall of green and tall foliage, and there are cirques and crescents that add to its charm. She is lying beneath a towering cypress tree, surrounded by dark pine and cedar trees. It is all illuminated by the bright light of the moon.

text:
Happy as others of her kind,
That, far from human neighbourhood,
Range unrestricted as the wind,
Through park, or chase, or savage wood.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: She is content like her fellow animals who live far away from humans and are free to roam wherever they please, whether it be in a park, a hunting ground, or a wild forest.

text:
But see the consecrated Maid
Emerging from a cedar shade
To open moonshine, where the Doe
Beneath the cypress-spire is laid;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: A holy maiden appears from a grove of cedar trees and steps into the light of the moon, where a deer rests under a cypress tree.

text:
Like a patch of April snow--
Upon a bed of herbage green,
Lingering in a woody glade
Or behind a rocky screen--
Lonely relic! which, if seen
By the shepherd, is passed by
With an inattentive eye.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: This stanza describes a patch of snow in April that remains in a green field or hidden behind rocks in a forest. It is a lonely and forgotten sight that goes unnoticed by the shepherd as he passes by.

text:
Nor more regard doth She bestow
Upon the uncomplaining Doe
Now couched at ease, though oft this day
Not unperplexed nor free from pain,
When she had tried, and tried in vain,
Approaching in her gentle way,
To win some look of love, or gain
Encouragement to sport or play
