Attempts which still the heart-sick Maid
Rejected, or with slight repaid.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The female deer, referred to as "She," is shown to have little regard for a fellow doe who is resting nearby. The resting doe has had a difficult day and has experienced pain and confusion. Despite trying to connect with the other doe and gain some affection or encouragement to play, she has been rejected or given only minimal attention.

text:
Yet Emily is soothed;--the breeze
Came fraught with kindly sympathies.
As she approached yon rustic Shed
Hung with late-flowering woodbine, spread
Along the walls and overhead,
The fragrance of the breathing flowers
Revived a memory of those hours
When here, in this remote alcove,
(While from the pendent woodbine came
Like odours, sweet as if the same)
A fondly-anxious Mother strove
To teach her salutary fears
And mysteries above her years.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: Emily finds comfort in the gentle breeze that carries with it a sense of empathy. She walks towards a simple shed adorned with blooming woodbine, the sweet scent of which brings back memories of her childhood. In this secluded spot, her mother worked to instill important values and knowledge beyond her years. The fragrant flowers serve as a reminder of the love and guidance that Emily received from her mother in this special place.

text:
Yes, she is soothed: an Image faint,
And yet not faint--a presence bright
Returns to her--that blessed Saint
Who with mild looks and language mild
Instructed here her darling Child,
While yet a prattler on the knee,
To worship in simplicity
The invisible God, and take for guide
The faith reformed and purified.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: She feels comforted as a vague but distinct image of a bright and peaceful presence appears before her. This presence reminds her of a holy Saint who had taught her child, when they were young and innocent, to worship the invisible God with a simple faith and to follow a reformed and purified path. The memory of this saintly figure brings solace to her troubled heart.

text:
'Tis flown--the Vision, and the sense
Of that beguiling influence,
'But oh! thou Angel from above,
Mute Spirit of maternal love,
That stood'st before my eyes, more clear
Than ghosts are fabled to appear
Sent upon embassies of fear;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The vision has disappeared, along with the captivating feeling it brought. However, a silent angel of maternal love still lingers, having appeared more vividly than any ghost sent to frighten.

text:
As thou thy presence hast to me
Vouchsafed, in radiant ministry
Descend on Francis; nor forbear
To greet him with a voice, and say;--
'If hope be a rejected stay,
'Do thou, my christian Son, beware
'Of that most lamentable snare,
'The self-reliance of despair!''
Then from within the embowered retreat
Where she had found a grateful seat
Perturbed she issues. She will go!
Herself will follow to the war,
And clasp her Father's knees;--ah, no!
She meets the insuperable bar,
The injunction by her Brother laid;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The speaker is asking for divine intervention for someone named Francis, warning him to be cautious of the dangerous trap of relying solely on oneself when hope is lost. The speaker requests that the divine presence descend upon Francis and urge him to avoid this pitfall. The speaker is interrupted by a woman who had been sitting nearby, who is overcome with emotion and declares that she will follow her father to war and plead with him for mercy. However, she is stopped by a command from her brother.

text:
His parting charge--but ill obeyed--
That interdicted all debate,
All prayer for this cause or for that;
All efforts that would turn aside
The headstrong current of their fate:
'Her duty is to stand and wait;'
In resignation to abide
The shock, AND FINALLY SECURE
O'ER PAIN AND GRIEF A TRIUMPH PURE.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: He gave them a final order, but it was not followed well. The order prohibited any discussion or prayer for any cause, and also any attempt to divert their fate. He told them that their duty was to wait patiently and accept what was to come, and in doing so, they would ultimately triumph over pain and grief.

text:
--She feels it, and her pangs are checked.
But now, as silently she paced
The turf, and thought by thought was chased,
Came One who, with sedate respect,
Approached, and, greeting her, thus spake;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: As she walked on the grass, her pain subsided. However, she was lost in thought when someone approached her with respect and greeted her.

text:
'An old man's privilege I take:
Dark is the time--a woeful day!
Dear daughter of affliction, say
How can I serve you? point the way.'
'Rights have you, and may well be bold;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: As an elderly man, I have the privilege to offer my assistance. It is a dark and sorrowful time, and as the daughter of affliction, please tell me how I can be of service. You have rights and the ability to ask for help without hesitation.'

text:
You with my Father have grown old
In friendship--strive--for his sake go--
Turn from us all the coming woe:
This would I beg; but on my mind
A passive stillness is enjoined.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: As my father and you have aged together, I implore you to strive for his sake and distance yourself from the impending troubles that may come our way. However, I am unable to actively participate in this request as I am required to maintain a passive stillness in my mind.

text:
On you, if room for mortal aid
Be left, is no restriction laid;
You not forbidden to recline
With hope upon the Will divine.'
'Hope,' said the old Man, 'must abide
With all of us, whate'er betide.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The old man stated that there are no limitations on seeking mortal assistance if it is available, and that it is not forbidden to have hope in the divine will. He believes that hope is necessary for everyone, regardless of their circumstances.

text:
In Craven's Wilds is many a den,
To shelter persecuted men:
Far under ground is many a cave,
Where they might lie as in the grave,
Until this storm hath ceased to rave:
Or let them cross the River Tweed,
And be at once from peril freed!'
'Ah tempt me not!' she faintly sighed;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: In Craven's Wilds, there are numerous dens where persecuted individuals can seek refuge. There are also underground caves where they can hide until the storm of persecution subsides. Alternatively, they can cross the River Tweed and escape the danger altogether. Despite the tempting offer, the woman weakly declined.

text:
'I will not counsel nor exhort,
With my condition satisfied;
But you, at least, may make report
Of what befalls;--be this your task--
This may be done;--'tis all I ask!'
She spake--and from the Lady's sight
The Sire, unconscious of his age,
Departed promptly as a Page
Bound on some errand of delight.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The Lady said she wouldn't advise or encourage anyone, as she was content with her own situation. However, she asked the person she was speaking to to at least report back to her about what happens next. This was the only thing she asked for. After speaking, the elderly man left quickly like a young messenger running an errand.

text:
--The noble Francis--wise as brave,
Thought he, may want not skill to save.
With hopes in tenderness concealed,
Unarmed he followed to the field;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: Francis, who was both wise and brave, believed that he possessed the necessary skills to save someone in need. He concealed his hope and tenderness as he followed the person to the field, without any weapons or protection.

text:
Him will I seek: the insurgent Powers
Are now besieging Barnard's Towers,--
'Grant that the Moon which shines this night
May guide them in a prudent flight!'
But quick the turns of chance and change,
And knowledge has a narrow range;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: I will search for him amidst the rebel forces that are currently attacking Barnard's Towers. I hope that the moonlight tonight will guide them to safety. However, life is unpredictable and knowledge can be limited.

text:
Whence idle fears, and needless pain,
And wishes blind, and efforts vain.--
The Moon may shine, but cannot be
Their guide in flight--already she
Hath witnessed their captivity.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: Unnecessary worry, unfounded fears, and pointless efforts are all for naught. The moon may be shining, but it cannot guide them to freedom as it has already seen them being held captive.

text:
She saw the desperate assault
Upon that hostile castle made;--
But dark and dismal is the vault
Where Norton and his sons are laid!
Disastrous issue!--he had said
'This night yon faithless Towers must yield,
Or we for ever quit the field.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: She witnessed the intense attack on the enemy castle, but knew that the burial vault of Norton and his sons was a gloomy and terrifying place. Norton had previously declared that the outcome of the battle would be disastrous unless the towers were conquered that night.

text:
--Neville is utterly dismayed,
For promise fails of Howard's aid;
And Dacre to our call replies
That 'he' is unprepared to rise.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: Neville is feeling extremely disappointed because Howard has not kept his promise to help, and Dacre has responded to their request for assistance by stating that he is not ready to take action.

text:
My heart is sick;--this weary pause
Must needs be fatal to our cause.
The breach is open--on the wall,
This night, the Banner shall be planted!'
--'Twas done: his Sons were with him--all;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The speaker's heart is heavy, as he believes that the current situation will lead to the downfall of their cause. The breach is open and the enemy will soon be upon them. However, the speaker is determined to plant their banner on the wall that night. He is accompanied by his sons, who are also devoted to their cause.

text:
They belt him round with hearts undaunted
And others follow;--Sire and Son
Leap down into the court;--''Tis won'--
They shout aloud--but Heaven decreed
That with their joyful shout should close
The triumph of a desperate deed
Which struck with terror friends and foes!
The friend shrinks back--the foe recoils
From Norton and his filial band;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: Norton and his followers bravely face their enemies, the friend and foes alike are struck with terror as they witness the triumph of their desperate deed. The group's joyous shouts signifying their victory are cut short by the realization that their actions have caused fear among both friends and foes. Norton and his son jump down into the court, with hearts undaunted, and are joined by others. However, their triumph is short-lived as Heaven has decreed that their moment of jubilation should end with the aftermath of their daring feat. The sight of Norton and his filial band causes the friend to shrink back, and the foe to recoil in fear.

text:
But they, now caught within the toils,
Against a thousand cannot stand;--
The foe from numbers courage drew,
And overpowered that gallant few.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The group is now trapped and unable to resist the enemy's attack, as they are vastly outnumbered. The enemy was emboldened by their superior numbers and was able to defeat the brave few.

text:
'A rescue for the Standard!' cried
The Father from within the walls;
But, see, the sacred Standard falls!--
Confusion through the Camp spread wide:
Some fled; and some their fears detained:
But ere the Moon had sunk to rest
In her pale chambers of the west,
Of that rash levy nought remained.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fourth
explanation: The Father, from within the walls, called out for a rescue of the Standard, but unfortunately, it fell. This caused confusion among the Camp and some people ran away while others were too afraid to move. However, by the time the moon had set, there was nothing left of the hasty group that had formed.

text:
VANGUARD of Liberty, ye men of Kent,
Ye children of a Soil that doth advance
Her haughty brow against the coast of France,
Now is the time to prove your hardiment!
To France be words of invitation sent!
They from their fields can see the countenance
Of your fierce war, may ken the glittering lance
And hear you shouting forth your brave intent.
explanation: Men of Kent, defenders of freedom, your land stands proudly against the French coast. Now is the moment to show your courage and invite the French to face your mighty army. They can see your fierce determination from their own fields, witness the glint of your lances, and hear your resolute battle cries. It is time to prove your worth and defend your homeland with all your might.

In the past, the people of Kent successfully negotiated with the Normans and gained a strong reputation. They also secured their own rights and privileges. However, now is not the time for negotiations. The people of Britain are united and standing with Kent. The message to the people of Kent is clear, it is time to fight for victory or die trying.

text:
HIGH on a point of rugged ground
Among the wastes of Rylstone Fell
Above the loftiest ridge or mound
Where foresters or shepherds dwell,
An edifice of warlike frame
Stands single--Norton Tower its name--
It fronts all quarters, and looks round
O'er path and road, and plain and dell,
Dark moor, and gleam of pool and stream,
Upon a prospect without bound.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: Norton Tower, a military structure, stands tall on a rugged point of land in the desolate Rylstone Fell. It overlooks the highest ridges and peaks where only foresters and shepherds abide. The tower is uniquely positioned to survey all directions, offering views of paths, roads, plains, valleys, dark moors, and streams, providing a boundless perspective.

text:
The summit of this bold ascent--
Though bleak and bare, and seldom free
As Pendle-hill or Pennygent
From wind, or frost, or vapours wet--
Had often heard the sound of glee
When there the youthful Nortons met,
To practise games and archery:
How proud and happy they! the crowd
Of Lookers-on how pleased and proud!
And from the scorching noon-tide sun,
From showers, or when the prize was won,
They to the Tower withdrew, and there
Would mirth run round, with generous fare;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The top of this daring climb, despite being barren and frequently battered by harsh weather conditions, was a popular meeting place for the youth of Nortons. It was here that they would engage in games and archery, often drawing a crowd of onlookers who were proud of their accomplishments. When the heat became too much or the rain began to fall, they would retreat to the Tower where they would continue to revel in each other's company, sharing food and laughter.

text:
And the stern old Lord of Rylstone-hall
Was happiest, proudest, of them all!
But now, his Child, with anguish pale,
Upon the height walks to and fro;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The Lord of Rylstone-hall used to be the happiest and most proud of his family, but now his child walks back and forth on a hill with a look of pain and sadness.

text:
'Tis well that she hath heard the tale,
Received the bitterness of woe:
For she 'had' hoped, had hoped and feared,
Such rights did feeble nature claim;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: It's a good thing that she has heard the story and understands the pain involved. She had hoped for a different outcome but also feared the worst. It's natural to feel this way in difficult situations.

text:
And oft her steps had hither steered,
Though not unconscious of self-blame;
For she her brother's charge revered,
His farewell words; and by the same,
Yea by her brother's very name,
Had, in her solitude, been cheered.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: She had walked to this place many times before, but always with a sense of guilt. She deeply respected her brother's instructions and his parting words, and it was his name that brought her comfort during her lonely moments.

text:
Beside the lonely watch-tower stood
That grey-haired Man of gentle blood,
Who with her Father had grown old
In friendship; rival hunters they,
And fellow warriors in their day;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The grey-haired man of gentle birth stood next to the solitary watchtower. He had grown old with the girl's father, with whom he shared a friendship that had been established through their shared passion for hunting and fighting. They were once both skilled hunters and warriors, but now only memories of their past remained.

text:
To Rylstone he the tidings brought;
Then on this height the Maid had sought,
And, gently as he could, had told
The end of that dire Tragedy,
Which it had been his lot to see.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: He went to Rylstone and shared the news, then found the Maid on a hilltop and informed her of the tragic events he had witnessed as delicately as possible.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The Lady asked if Francis was truly alive, to which the response was that her brother had been spared and his life was not taken. He has been praised for his efforts and the belief is that he did not lead a futile existence. The speaker implies that Francis' course was a solitary one, but it was not without merit.

text:
Not vainly struggled in the might
Of duty, seeing with clear sight;
He was their comfort to the last,
Their joy till every pang was past.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: He fulfilled his duty without any self-centered motives and was able to see things clearly. He provided comfort to those around him until their very end, and brought them joy even in their darkest moments.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: I saw when they arrived in York. Even if their feet were tied up, they still might be criticized by respectable people. However, they seemed to embrace their disgrace and shame as a source of glory and victory.

text:
Nor wanted 'mid the pressing crowd
Deep feeling, that found utterance loud,
'Lo, Francis comes,' there were who cried,
'A Prisoner once, but now set free!
'Tis well, for he the worst defied
Through force of natural piety;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: As Francis made his way through the bustling crowd, some were heard shouting out in excitement upon seeing him, recalling his past as a prisoner but now a free man. It was evident that his deep emotions were not suppressed, as he expressed them with great fervor. His natural piety had enabled him to overcome the worst of his experiences, which was commendable.

text:
He rose not in this quarrel; he,
For concord's sake and England's good,
Suit to his Brothers often made
With tears, and of his Father prayed--
And when he had in vain withstood
Their purpose--then did he divide,
He parted from them; but at their side
Now walks in unanimity.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: In this dispute, he did not take sides, but instead tried to reconcile his brothers for the sake of peace and the benefit of England. He pleaded with them and even appealed to their father to no avail. Eventually, he separated from them, but has since reunited with them and now stands united.

text:
Then peace to cruelty and scorn,
While to the prison they are borne,
Peace, peace to all indignity!'
And so in Prison were they laid--
Oh hear me, hear me, gentle Maid,
For I am come with power to bless,
By scattering gleams, through your distress,
Of a redeeming happiness.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The speaker wishes for peace to prevail over cruelty and scorn as the prisoners are taken to the prison. They plead for peace and an end to all forms of indignity. The prisoners are eventually taken to their cells, but the speaker, who has the power to bless, implores the gentle Maid to listen to their plea. They promise to bring some relief to her distress by providing glimpses of redeeming happiness.

text:
Me did a reverent pity move
And privilege of ancient love;
And, in your service, making bold,
Entrance I gained to that stronghold.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: I showed respect and empathy, as well as the honor of long-standing affection. With courage, I gained access to the fortress in order to serve you.

text:
Your Father gave me cordial greeting;
But to his purposes, that burned
Within him, instantly returned:
He was commanding and entreating,
And said--'We need not stop, my Son!
Thoughts press, and time is hurrying on'--
And so to Francis he renewed
His words, more calmly thus pursued.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The speaker was greeted warmly by Francis' father, but the father's urgent intentions caused him to quickly resume his previous demeanor. He was commanding and insistent, stating that time was of the essence and they needed to keep moving. Francis' father then calmly reiterated his words to Francis.

text:
'Might this our enterprise have sped,
Change wide and deep the Land had seen,
A renovation from the dead,
A spring-tide of immortal green:
The darksome altars would have blazed
Like stars when clouds are rolled away;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: If our project had succeeded, it would have brought about significant and profound changes to the land, akin to a rebirth and an everlasting rejuvenation. The old, gloomy altars would have come to life, illuminated like stars emerging from behind clouds.

text:
Salvation to all eyes that gazed,
Once more the Rood had been upraised
To spread its arms, and stand for aye.
Then, then--had I survived to see
New life in Bolton Priory;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The Rood, a religious symbol, had been raised again giving salvation to all who gazed upon it. The speaker expresses a desire to have lived to see new life in Bolton Priory.

text:
The voice restored, the eye of Truth
Re-opened that inspired my youth;
To see her in her pomp arrayed--
This Banner (for such vow I made)
Should on the consecrated breast
Of that same Temple have found rest:
I would myself have hung it high,
Fit offering of glad victory!
A shadow of such thought remains
To cheer this sad and pensive time;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: My voice has returned, and with it the clarity of Truth that once inspired me in my youth. It fills me with joy to see her in her full glory, and I had pledged to hang this Banner on the sacred walls of the Temple as a symbol of my devotion. I had hoped to hang it high as a tribute to our triumph. Though circumstances have changed and we are now in a somber time, the memory of my vow remains as a glimmer of hope to sustain me.

text:
A solemn fancy yet sustains
One feeble Being--bids me climb
Even to the last--one effort more
To attest my Faith, if not restore.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The idea of persevering through hardship is still present in my mind and encourages me to keep going, even if it's just one more step, to prove my belief or perhaps regain it.

text:
Hear then,' said he, 'while I impart,
My Son, the last wish of my heart.
The Banner strive thou to regain;
And, if the endeavour prove not vain,
Bear it--to whom if not to thee
Shall I this lonely thought consign?--
Bear it to Bolton Priory,
And lay it on Saint Mary's shrine;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The speaker tells his son to listen closely to his final request. He wants his son to try and retrieve the Banner, and if successful, to carry it to Bolton Priory and place it on Saint Mary's shrine. The speaker feels that his son is the best person to carry out this task and entrusts him with this responsibility.

text:
To wither in the sun and breeze
'Mid those decaying sanctities.
There let at least the gift be laid,
The testimony there displayed;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: Let the gift be left and the testimony displayed amidst the decaying sanctities, as they wither in the sun and breeze.

text:
Bold proof that with no selfish aim,
But for lost Faith and Christ's dear name,
I helmeted a brow though white,
And took a place in all men's sight;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: This passage describes a person who acts selflessly for the sake of faith and Christ's name. They wear a helmet and stand boldly in front of others, despite their own fears or doubts. This person is willing to be seen and take action in the name of their beliefs.

text:
Yea offered up this noble Brood,
This fair unrivalled Brotherhood,
And turned away from thee, my Son!
And left--but be the rest unsaid,
The name untouched, the tear unshed;--
My wish is known, and I have done:
Now promise, grant this one request,
This dying prayer, and be thou blest!'
Then Francis answered--'Trust thy Son,
For, with God's will, it shall be done!'--
The pledge obtained, the solemn word
Thus scarcely given, a noise was heard,
And Officers appeared in state
To lead the prisoners to their fate.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: Yea presented his brave and unmatched group of brothers to his son, but then turned away, unable to say more. He made it clear that he had a wish, and asked his son to grant his dying prayer, promising that he would be blessed if he did. Francis assured his father that he could trust him, and that he would do as he asked with God's will. As soon as Francis made this promise, officers arrived to take the prisoners away to their execution.

text:
They rose, oh! wherefore should I fear
To tell, or, Lady, you to hear?
They rose--embraces none were given--
They stood like trees when earth and heaven
Are calm; they knew each other's worth,
And reverently the Band went forth.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The group stood up, and there is no reason for me to be afraid to tell you about it, my Lady. They stood up without embracing each other, like trees in a peaceful world. They understood each other's value and respectfully left as a group.

text:
They met, when they had reached the door,
One with profane and harsh intent
Placed there--that he might go before
And, with that rueful Banner borne
Aloft in sign of taunting scorn,
Conduct them to their punishment:
So cruel Sussex, unrestrained
By human feeling, had ordained.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: They encountered each other as they arrived at the door, one with a vulgar and cruel purpose to lead the way with a flag of mockery, signifying their impending punishment. This was the plan of the heartless Sussex, who had no regard for their emotions.

text:
The unhappy Banner Francis saw,
And, with a look of calm command
Inspiring universal awe,
He took it from the soldier's hand;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: Banner Francis appeared distressed upon seeing the unhappy banner. Nevertheless, he managed to maintain his composure and instill a sense of fear in those around him. He grabbed the banner from the soldier's hand, demonstrating his authority and control over the situation.

text:
And all the people that stood round
Confirmed the deed in peace profound.
--High transport did the Father shed
Upon his Son--and they were led,
Led on, and yielded up their breath;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The people present at the scene verified the peaceful confirmation of the act. The Father was overwhelmed with emotion as he witnessed his Son's sacrifice. They were guided to their final moments as they peacefully surrendered their lives.

text:
Together died, a happy death!--
But Francis, soon as he had braved
That insult, and the Banner saved,
Athwart the unresisting tide
Of the spectators occupied
In admiration or dismay,
Bore instantly his Charge away.'
These things, which thus had in the sight
And hearing passed of Him who stood
With Emily, on the Watch-tower height,
In Rylstone's woeful neighbourhood,
He told; and oftentimes with voice
Of power to comfort or rejoice;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: Francis bravely saved the Banner and passed away happily with his Charge. The spectators were either in admiration or dismay as he did this. This was witnessed by the person who was with Emily on the Watch-tower height in Rylstone's woeful neighbourhood. He shared these events and often spoke with a voice that had the power to either comfort or bring joy.

text:
For deepest sorrows that aspire,
Go high, no transport ever higher.
'Yes--God is rich in mercy,' said
The old Man to the silent Maid,
'Yet, Lady! shines, through this black night,
One star of aspect heavenly bright;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The old man consoled the silent maid by saying that even in the midst of the deepest sorrows, one can find solace by seeking the divine. He added that God is abundant in his mercy and there is a star that shines bright in the darkest of nights, offering hope and comfort to those who seek it.

text:
Your Brother lives--he lives--is come
Perhaps already to his home;
Then let us leave this dreary place.'
She yielded, and with gentle pace,
Though without one uplifted look,
To Rylstone-hall her way she took.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Fifth
explanation: The speaker informs someone that their brother is alive and may have already returned home, suggesting they leave this dismal location. The person agrees and they both begin to make their way to Rylstone-hall, with the individual walking calmly and without making eye contact.

text:
'TIS spent--this burning day of June!
Soft darkness o'er its latest gleams is stealing;
The buzzing dor-hawk, round and round, is wheeling,--
That solitary bird
Is all that can be heard
In silence deeper far than that of deepest noon!
Confiding Glow-worms, 'tis a night
Propitious to your earth-born light!
But, where the scattered stars are seen
In hazy straits the clouds between,
Each, in his station twinkling not,
Seems changed into a pallid spot.
explanation: The day of June is coming to a close, as darkness gradually takes over the remaining traces of light. The only sound that breaks the deep silence is the buzzing of a solitary dor-hawk, circling around in the sky. The darkness is so profound that it even surpasses the stillness of noon. The evening is perfect for glow-worms to reveal their light, as the stars in the sky are barely visible through the hazy clouds. They seem to have lost their usual brightness and turned into faint, pale spots in the sky.

text:
The mountains against heaven's grave weight
Rise up, and grow to wondrous height.
The air, as in a lion's den,
Is close and hot;--and now and then
Comes a tired and sultry breeze
With a haunting and a panting,
Like the stifling of disease;
explanation: The mountains stand tall and mighty, seemingly bearing the weight of heaven itself. They continue to grow to incredible heights. The air in this place is thick and stifling, much like the inside of a lion's den. Occasionally, a weary breeze blows through, but it provides little relief and instead feels like the oppressive breath of a disease.

text:
But the dews allay the heat,
And the silence makes it sweet.
Hush, there is some one on the stir!
'Tis Benjamin the Waggoner;
explanation: The cooling moisture of the dew helps to ease the warmth, while the quietness of the surroundings adds to the pleasantness. Suddenly, there is movement, and it turns out to be Benjamin the Waggoner.

text:
Who long hath trod this toilsome way,
Companion of the night and day.
That far-off tinkling's drowsy cheer,
Mixed with a faint yet grating sound
In a moment lost and found,
The Wain announces--by whose side
Along the banks of Rydal Mere
He paces on, a trusty Guide,--
Listen! you can scarcely hear!
Hither he his course is bending;--
Now he leaves the lower ground,
And up the craggy hill ascending
Many a stop and stay he makes,
Many a breathing-fit he takes;--
Steep the way and wearisome,
Yet all the while his whip is dumb!
The Horses have worked with right good-will,
And so have gained the top of the hill;
explanation: The speaker reflects on the journey taken by a trusted guide, who has been a faithful companion during both day and night. The sound of distant bells signals the arrival of the guide's wagon, which slowly makes its way along the banks of Rydal Mere. Despite the steep and arduous path, the horses have persevered and made it to the top of the hill. The speaker marvels at the guide's ability to navigate the difficult terrain without needing to use his whip.

text:
He was patient, they were strong,
And now they smoothly glide along,
Recovering breath, and pleased to win
The praises of mild Benjamin.
explanation: Benjamin's admiration was earned by their strong endurance and his patient approach as they now glide effortlessly, breathing comfortably again.

text:
Heaven shield him from mishap and snare!
But why so early with this prayer?--
Is it for threatenings in the sky?
Or for some other danger nigh?
No; none is near him yet, though he
Be one of much infirmity;
explanation: May heaven protect him from harm and danger! But why is this prayer being said so soon? Is there a looming threat in the sky or some other impending danger? No, there is no immediate danger, but the person being prayed for is frail and vulnerable.

text:
For at the bottom of the brow,
Where once the DOVE and OLIVE-BOUGH
Offered a greeting of good ale
To all who entered Grasmere Vale;
explanation: At the foot of the hill where the DOVE and OLIVE-BOUGH used to welcome visitors with good ale in Grasmere Vale, lies a place of significance.

The speaker encourages someone who is leaving to do so with a cheerful attitude. The place they are leaving behind is now inhabited by a poet, who is described as unassuming and not prone to excessive drinking. The location is identified as the spot where a dove and olive branch were once present, likely referencing the story of Noah's Ark in the Bible.

Even though our hero is weak and prone to making mistakes, he still needs to be careful and watchful. He may walk confidently, but when he reflects on the past, everything appears bleak and uncertain.

text:
He shrugs his shoulders, shakes his head,
And, for the honest folk within,
It is a doubt with Benjamin
Whether they be alive or dead!
'Here' is no danger,--none at all!
Beyond his wish he walks secure;
explanation: Benjamin is uncertain if the honest people around him are alive or dead, as he shrugs and shakes his head. However, he feels safe from any danger and walks confidently beyond his desires.

If he can resist the temptation that lies beyond the mile marker, he will have proven his ability to deny himself and his pride. The door beyond that marker will call out to him with a tempting voice, but he must resist it to demonstrate his strength of character.

text:
If he resist those casement panes,
And that bright gleam which thence will fall
Upon his Leaders' bells and manes,
Inviting him with cheerful lure:
For still, though all be dark elsewhere,
Some shining notice will be 'there',
Of open house and ready fare.
explanation: If he ignores the window frames and the light shining from them, which illuminates the bells and manes of his Leaders, he will miss out on the invitation to join them. Even though everything else may seem dark, there will always be a noticeable glimmer of open hospitality and welcoming provisions.

text:
The place to Benjamin right well
Is known, and by as strong a spell
As used to be that sign of love
And hope--the OLIVE-BOUGH and DOVE;
explanation: Benjamin's location is widely recognized and has a powerful association with love and hope, much like the traditional symbols of an olive branch and dove.

text:
He knows it to his cost, good Man!
Who does not know the famous SWAN?
Object uncouth! and yet our boast,
For it was painted by the Host;
explanation: The man who is unfamiliar with the famous SWAN will come to regret it. Although it may appear odd, we take pride in it because it was painted by the Host.

text:
His own conceit the figure planned,
'Twas coloured all by his own hand;
And that frail Child of thirsty clay,
Of whom I sing this rustic lay,
Could tell with self-dissatisfaction
Quaint stories of the bird's attraction!
Well! that is past--and in despite
Of open door and shining light.
explanation: The figure was planned by the person's own arrogance and painted by themselves. The poem is about a fragile child made of clay who could tell stories of how the bird was attracted to the figure but was dissatisfied with itself. However, that is all in the past, and despite the open door and shining light, the figure remains unchanged.
The conqueror is attempting to ascend Dunmail-raise and is doing so with the same gentleness as when he ascended from Rydal Mere.
They are not afraid of his whip, but they listen to his voice with joy. They decide whether to stand or go, and they measure their efforts and time with a sense of pride.

text:
And, while they strain, and while they rest,
He thus pursues his thoughts at leisure.
Now am I fairly safe to-night--
And with proud cause my heart is light:
I trespassed lately worse than ever--
But Heaven has blest a good endeavour;
explanation: As they work and take breaks, he leisurely ponders his thoughts. He feels safe for the night and takes pride in his good deeds, despite recently committing a worse offense. However, he believes that his efforts have been blessed by Heaven.

text:
And, to my soul's content, I find
The evil One is left behind.
Yes, let my master fume and fret,
Here am I--with my horses yet!
My jolly team, he finds that ye
Will work for nobody but me!
Full proof of this the Country gained;
explanation: I am pleased to say that I have left the Devil behind, and my horses are still loyal to me despite my master's anger. The whole country has witnessed the fact that my horses will only work for me and no one else.

text:
It knows how ye were vexed and strained,
And forced unworthy stripes to bear,
When trusted to another's care.
Here was it--on this rugged slope,
Which now ye climb with heart and hope,
I saw you, between rage and fear,
Plunge, and fling back a spiteful ear,
And ever more and more confused,
As ye were more and more abused:
As chance would have it, passing by
I saw you in that jeopardy:
A word from me was like a charm;
explanation: The speaker witnessed the speaker's distress and mistreatment at the hands of another, causing the speaker to bear unworthy stripes. The speaker remembers seeing the speaker on a rugged slope, struggling with rage and fear, and being more and more confused as they were abused. By chance, the speaker passed by and was able to calm the situation with a single word.

text:
Ye pulled together with one mind;
And your huge burthen, safe from harm,
Moved like a vessel in the wind!
--Yes, without me, up hills so high
'Tis vain to strive for mastery.
explanation: You worked together with a single purpose, and your large load remained unharmed, moving smoothly like a ship in the wind. It is useless to try to conquer steep hills without me.

text:
Then grieve not, jolly team! though tough
The road we travel, steep, and rough;
Though Rydal-heights and Dunmail-raise,
And all their fellow banks and braes,
Full often make you stretch and strain,
And halt for breath and halt again,
Yet to their sturdiness 'tis owing
That side by side we still are going!
While Benjamin in earnest mood
His meditations thus pursued,
A storm, which had been smothered long,
Was growing inwardly more strong;
explanation: Do not despair, my cheerful companions, even though the path we take is challenging, steep, and rugged. The hills of Rydal and Dunmail, along with their surrounding slopes, may require much effort and frequent stops to catch our breaths, but it is thanks to their toughness that we are able to continue on side by side. Meanwhile, Benjamin is lost in deep thought, and an internal tempest that has been brewing within him for some time is gathering strength.

text:
And, in its struggles to get free,
Was busily employed as he.
The thunder had begun to growl--
He heard not, too intent of soul;
explanation: As the struggle to break free intensified, he was completely occupied. The sound of thunder began to rumble, but he was so focused that he didn't notice it.

text:
The air was now without a breath--
He marked not that 'twas still as death.
But soon large rain-drops on his head
Fell with the weight of drops of lead;--
He starts--and takes, at the admonition,
A sage survey of his condition.
explanation: The atmosphere was completely still, and he didn't even notice. Suddenly, heavy raindrops began to fall on his head. The weight of the drops felt like lead. This startled him, and he took a moment to assess his situation.

The road appears dark to him, with a slight glimmer where it lies. The sky and hills are blacker than the road, with every hill appearing darker as it reaches the sky. The surroundings are one gloomy room, with the sky, hills, and valley being hung over with darkness.

text:
Save that above a single height
Is to be seen a lurid light,
Above Helm-crag--a streak half dead,
A burning of portentous red;
explanation: A glowing, ominous red streak can be observed above Helm-crag, rising to an impressive height. The light is eerie and half-dead, indicating something troubling may be on the horizon.

text:
And near that lurid light, full well
The ASTROLOGER, sage Sidrophel,
Where at his desk and book he sits,
Puzzling aloft his curious wits;
explanation: The wise astrologer, Sidrophel, sits at his desk and studies his book under the eerie glow of the light. He concentrates intently, trying to solve the intricate puzzles that challenge his brilliant mind.

text:
He whose domain is held in common
With no one but the ANCIENT WOMAN,
Cowering beside her rifted cell,
As if intent on magic spell;--
Dread pair, that, spite of wind and weather,
Still sit upon Helm-crag together!
The ASTROLOGER was not unseen
By solitary Benjamin;
explanation: A mysterious figure, known only to the ancient woman with whom he shares his domain, sits atop Helm-crag, seemingly casting a spell. This pair, undeterred by any weather, remains together. The astrologer, another enigmatic character, was noticed by Benjamin, who was the only other person present.

text:
But total darkness came anon,
And he and everything was gone:
And suddenly a ruffling breeze,
(That would have rocked the sounding trees
Had aught of sylvan growth been there)
Swept through the Hollow long and bare:
The rain rushed down--the road was battered,
As with the force of billows shattered;
explanation: Suddenly, darkness enveloped everything and the man disappeared. A gust of wind blew through the empty space, causing a rustling sound that would have swayed the trees if there were any around. The rain poured down heavily, pummeling the road as if it were being hit by waves.

text:
The horses are dismayed, nor know
Whether they should stand or go;
And Benjamin is groping near them
Sees nothing, and can scarcely hear them.
explanation: The horses are confused and unsure whether to move or stay still, causing them to feel dismayed. Benjamin is near them, but he is struggling to see and hear anything clearly.

text:
He is astounded,--wonder not,--
With such a charge in such a spot;
Astounded in the mountain gap
With thunder-peals, clap after clap,
Close-treading on the silent flashes--
And somewhere, as he thinks, by crashes
Among the rocks; with weight of rain,
And sullen motions long and slow,
That to a dreary distance go--
Till, breaking in upon the dying strain,
A rending o'er his head begins the fray again.
explanation: He is amazed by the intense storm happening in the mountain pass, which includes thunder, lightning, heavy rain, and echoing crashes. The sound of rocks crashing is mixed in with the thunderous noise, and the rain is slow and gloomy. The storm seems to be dissipating, but suddenly a loud tearing noise starts up again.

text:
Meanwhile, uncertain what to do,
And oftentimes compelled to halt,
The horses cautiously pursue
Their way, without mishap or fault;
explanation: The horses move forward hesitantly, unsure of what to do next, often stopping in their tracks. They proceed with caution, yet manage to avoid any mishaps or mistakes along the way.

The pile of stones marking the burial site of King Dunmail has been reached, who was the last monarch to rule over Cumberland. He once held supreme authority in the region and was a brave ruler, as indicated by the large heap of stones placed over his remains.

text:
His bones, and those of all his Power
Slain here in a disastrous hour!
When, passing through this narrow strait,
Stony, and dark, and desolate,
Benjamin can faintly hear
A voice that comes from some one near,
A female voice--Whoe'er you be,
Stop,' it exclaimed, 'and pity me!'
And, less in pity than in wonder,
Amid the darkness and the thunder,
The Waggoner, with prompt command,
Summons his horses to a stand.
explanation: The speaker laments the loss of those who lost their lives in a tragic event, along with the bones of the powerful figures. As Benjamin travels through a narrow and bleak path, he hears a woman's voice, urging him to stop and show her mercy. Although he is more surprised than sympathetic, he stops his wagon and horses amidst the stormy darkness.

text:
While, with increasing agitation,
The Woman urged her supplication,
In rueful words, with sobs between--
The voice of tears that fell unseen;
explanation: The woman pleaded with growing distress, her words filled with regret and tears that flowed silently.

text:
There came a flash--a startling glare,
And all Seat-Sandal was laid bare!
'Tis not a time for nice suggestion,
And Benjamin, without a question,
Taking her for some way-worn rover,
Said, 'Mount, and get you under cover!'
Another voice, in tone as hoarse
As a swoln brook with rugged course,
Cried out, 'Good brother, why so fast?
I've had a glimpse of you--'avast!'
Or, since it suits you to be civil,
Take her at once--for good and evil!'
'It is my Husband,' softly said
The Woman, as if half afraid:
By this time she was snug within,
Through help of honest Benjamin;
explanation: In this passage, there was a sudden flash of light which exposed everything in Seat-Sandal. Benjamin, assuming that a woman he saw was a weary traveler, offered her shelter. However, another voice interrupted and suggested that Benjamin take the woman immediately, whether it be for better or for worse. The woman, timidly identifying the speaker as her husband, sought refuge inside with the assistance of Benjamin.

text:
She and her Babe, which to her breast
With thankfulness the Mother pressed;
And now the same strong voice more near
Said cordially, 'My Friend, what cheer?
Rough doings these! as God's my judge,
The sky owes somebody a grudge!
We've had in half an hour or less
A twelvemonth's terror and distress!'
Then Benjamin entreats the Man
Would mount, too, quickly as he can:
The Sailor--Sailor now no more,
But such he had been heretofore--
To courteous Benjamin replied,
'Go you your way, and mind not me;
explanation: The woman held her baby close to her chest, grateful for their safety. A voice, belonging to a man who had experienced the same terror, spoke kindly to her, asking how she was doing. He remarked on the roughness of the situation, indicating that he believed the sky was angry with someone. The man, who had been a sailor in the past, declined the woman's husband's invitation to join them and told him to leave him be.

text:
For I must have, whate'er betide,
My Ass and fifty things beside,--
Go, and I'll follow speedily!'
The Waggon moves--and with its load
Descends along the sloping road;
explanation: The speaker in this passage is insistent on having their donkey and other items, despite any obstacles. They urge the wagon to move on, promising to follow quickly. The wagon begins its descent down a sloping road while carrying a heavy load.

text:
And the rough Sailor instantly
Turns to a little tent hard by:
For when, at closing-in of day,
The family had come that way,
Green pasture and the soft warm air
Tempted them to settle there.--
Green is the grass for beast to graze,
Around the stones of Dunmail-raise!
The Sailor gathers up his bed,
Takes down the canvas overhead;
explanation: The rough Sailor quickly heads towards a nearby small tent as the day draws to a close and a family passes by, enticed by the lush pasture and the warm, pleasant weather. The grass is green and perfect for grazing animals around the Dunmail-raise stones. The Sailor proceeds to pack up his bedding and remove the canvas covering.

text:
And, after farewell to the place,
A parting word--though not of grace,
Pursues, with Ass and all his store,
The way the Waggon went before.
explanation: As they bid farewell to the location, a final statement, though not particularly polite, follows along with Ass and his belongings as they travel the same path as the wagon before them.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The Harp humbly followed our lead and we started our song with the description of a forest and a lone woman. We commenced with her and her companion in the woods, knowing that the song would culminate with the same.

text:
The Friend who stood before her sight,
Her only unextinguished light;
Her last companion in a dearth
Of love, upon a hopeless earth.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The Friend was the only source of light in the protagonist's life and the last remaining companion in a loveless world.

text:
For She it was--this Maid, who wrought
Meekly, with foreboding thought,
In vermeil colours and in gold
An unblest work; which, standing by,
Her Father did with joy behold,--
Exulting in its imagery;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The Maid created a work of art in red and gold, but with a sense of apprehension. It was not blessed and her father, who admired the imagery, rejoiced at its creation.

text:
A Banner, fashioned to fulfil
Too perfectly his headstrong will:
For on this Banner had her hand
Embroidered (such her Sire's command)
The sacred Cross; and figured there
The five dear wounds our Lord did bear;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The banner was created in accordance with the strong will of the person it was made for. It had the sacred Cross embroidered on it, as ordered by the person's father, along with a depiction of the five wounds that Jesus bore.

text:
Full soon to be uplifted high,
And float in rueful company!
It was the time when England's Queen
Twelve years had reigned, a Sovereign dread;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Soon they will be lifted high and will mourn together. This was during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I of England, who had been ruling for 12 years and was a feared monarch.

text:
Nor yet the restless crown had been
Disturbed upon her virgin head;
But now the inly-working North
Was ripe to send its thousands forth,
A potent vassalage, to fight
In Percy's and in Neville's right,
Two Earls fast leagued in discontent,
Who gave their wishes open vent;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: At this point in time, the young queen's reign had not yet faced any challenges. However, the North was becoming restless and ready to send its armies to fight on behalf of two discontented Earls, Percy and Neville, who had formed an alliance. Their grievances were openly expressed, and they were prepared to use their significant influence as vassals to assert their rights.

text:
And boldly urged a general plea,
The rites of ancient piety
To be triumphantly restored,
By the stern justice of the sword!
And that same Banner, on whose breast
The blameless Lady had exprest
Memorials chosen to give life
And sunshine to a dangerous strife;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He confidently advocated for the restoration of the ancient religious traditions through military force. He also spoke of the significance of the banner, which the Lady had adorned with symbols to inspire and invigorate the soldiers in the dangerous conflict.

text:
That Banner, waiting for the Call,
Stood quietly in Rylstone-hall.
It came; and Francis Norton said,
'O Father! rise not in this fray--
The hairs are white upon your head;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: At Rylstone-hall, a banner was patiently waiting for its call to action. When the call finally came, Francis Norton urged his father not to join in the fight, reminding him of his old age and the white hairs on his head.

text:
Dear Father, hear me when I say
It is for you too late a day!
Bethink you of your own good name:
A just and gracious Queen have we,
A pure religion, and the claim
Of peace on our humanity.--
'Tis meet that I endure your scorn;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Father, it is too late for you to change your ways. Please consider your reputation, as we have a fair and kind queen, a pure religion, and strive for peace. I am willing to endure your disdain for my beliefs.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: As your eldest son, I do not seek power or wealth, Father. Instead, I humbly implore you to spare the use of the Banner and dissolve this army. Let us live peacefully at home, without any blame or conflict.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The speaker declares that they are doing what they are doing for the sake of their brethren and especially for someone named Emily. The hall is filled with loud noises and the Father can barely hear the name of his beloved daughter being mentioned with a dying tone. The Father looks at the banner with pride and his eyes are filled with tears of joy.

text:
Then did he seize the staff, and say:
'Thou, Richard, bear'st thy father's name,
Keep thou this ensign till the day
When I of thee require the same:
Thy place be on my better hand;--
And seven as true as thou, I see,
Will cleave to this good cause and me.'
He spake, and eight brave sons straightway
All followed him, a gallant band!
Thus, with his sons, when forth he came
The sight was hailed with loud acclaim
And din of arms and minstrelsy,
From all his warlike tenantry,
All horsed and harnessed with him to ride,--
A voice to which the hills replied!
But Francis, in the vacant hall,
Stood silent under dreary weight,--
A phantasm, in which roof and wall
Shook, tottered, swam before his sight;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The speaker took hold of a staff and addressed Richard, telling him to keep the staff until he asks for it back. He instructed Richard to stand on his right side, and predicted that seven other loyal men would join him in his cause. Immediately, eight of his sons followed him and his appearance was celebrated with cheers and music from his soldiers. However, Francis, who was not a part of this celebration, stood alone in the hall, feeling overwhelmed and disoriented.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He was overcome by a vision that seemed like a dream of the night, leaving him feeling lonely and forsaken. He eventually stumbled upon a small gate and, upon waking, realized he was staring up at the peaceful and still sky.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He stood on the grass with fresh air around him and heard a distant but audible military cheer, which echoed through the sheltered spot where he stood.

text:
He heard, and it disturbed him not.
There stood he, leaning on a lance
Which he had grasped unknowingly,
Had blindly grasped in that strong trance,
That dimness of heart-agony;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He listened, but the sound did not upset him. He remained in place, propping himself up with a spear that he had unconsciously taken hold of during a moment of intense emotional pain. Despite not being aware of his actions, he held onto the weapon tightly.

text:
There stood he, cleansed from the despair
And sorrow of his fruitless prayer.
The past he calmly hath reviewed:
But where will be the fortitude
Of this brave man, when he shall see
That Form beneath the spreading tree,
And know that it is Emily?
He saw her where in open view
She sate beneath the spreading yew--
Her head upon her lap, concealing
In solitude her bitter feeling:
'Might ever son 'command' a sire,
The act were justified to-day.'
This to himself--and to the Maid,
Whom now he had approached, he said--
'Gone are they,--they have their desire;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The man, once burdened with despair and sadness due to his unfulfilled prayers, now stood cleansed. He calmly reflected on his past, but wondered if he would have the strength to face Emily when he sees her under the tree. As he approached her, he saw her sitting alone, hiding her pain. He contemplated whether a son could ever command his father, justifying his actions. He then spoke to Emily, telling her that those who had caused them pain were gone and had achieved what they wanted.

text:
And I with thee one hour will stay,
To give thee comfort if I may.'
She heard, but looked not up, nor spake;
And sorrow moved him to partake
Her silence; then his thoughts turned round,
And fervent words a passage found.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The speaker offers to stay with the person for an hour to provide comfort, but the person does not respond or acknowledge the offer. The speaker is moved by the person's silence and begins to share their thoughts and feelings with fervent words.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The sons have departed, although they were misled, with their father leading the way. The sons submit to their natural leader and the father had promised allegiance to noble Percy. However, an even stronger force compels him to follow through with his actions.

text:
This said, our tears to-day may fall
As at an innocent funeral.
In deep and awful channel runs
This sympathy of Sire and Sons;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Although we may shed tears like we would at a funeral for an innocent person, there is a profound connection between fathers and sons that runs deep and powerfully.

text:
Untried our Brothers have been loved
With heart by simple nature moved;
And now their faithfulness is proved:
For faithful we must call them, bearing
That soul of conscientious daring.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Our Brothers, who were previously untested, have been loved with a genuine and natural affection. They have now demonstrated their faithfulness, and we must acknowledge them as being faithful due to their courageous and righteous nature.

text:
--There were they all in circle--there
Stood Richard, Ambrose, Christopher,
John with a sword that will not fail,
And Marmaduke in fearless mail,
And those bright Twins were side by side;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: A group of individuals, including Richard, Ambrose, Christopher, John with a reliable sword, Marmaduke in sturdy armor, and the Twins standing next to each other, were gathered in a circle.

text:
And there, by fresh hopes beautified,
Stood He, whose arm yet lacks the power
Of man, our youngest, fairest flower!
I, by the right of eldest born,
And in a second father's place,
Presumed to grapple with their scorn,
And meet their pity face to face;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He stood there, adorned with renewed hope, but lacking the strength of a full-grown man. He was our youngest and most beautiful creation. As the eldest, I took on the role of a second father and dared to confront their contempt and engage them with my own vulnerability.

text:
Yea, trusting in God's holy aid,
I to my Father knelt and prayed;
And one, the pensive Marmaduke,
Methought, was yielding inwardly,
And would have laid his purpose by,
But for a glance of his Father's eye,
Which I myself could scarcely brook.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: I prayed to God for help and trusted in Him. Marmaduke seemed to be having second thoughts and was close to giving up, but a look from his father convinced him otherwise. The look was so powerful that it even affected me.

text:
Then be we, each and all, forgiven!
Thou, chiefly thou, my Sister dear,
Whose pangs are registered in heaven--
The stifled sigh, the hidden tear,
And smiles, that dared to take their place,
Meek filial smiles, upon thy face,
As that unhallowed Banner grew
Beneath a loving old Man's view.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: May we all be forgiven, especially my dear Sister whose pain is known to heaven - the suppressed sighs, the secret tears, and the gentle smiles that covered your face as that cursed banner was raised before our loving elder.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Your difficult role has been fulfilled, so now you can be content. I have a different and less challenging responsibility to undertake than yours, but it still needs to be done.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: I cannot join forces with them as our goals and intentions do not align. However, I will physically be present with them.

text:
Unarmed and naked will I go,
Be at their side, come weal or woe:
On kind occasions I may wait,
See, hear, obstruct, or mitigate.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: I will approach the situation without any weapons or clothes and stand by their side through good or bad times. Depending on the circumstances, I may observe, listen, hinder, or ease the situation.

text:
Bare breast I take and an empty hand.'--
Therewith he threw away the lance,
Which he had grasped in that strong trance,
Spurned it, like something that would stand
Between him and the pure intent
Of love on which his soul was bent.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He discarded his lance and took off his armor, symbolizing his willingness to abandon his former way of life in pursuit of love. He was so focused on his desire for love that he rejected anything that stood in the way of it, including his weapons and armor. His soul was set on the pure intention of love, and he was willing to do whatever it took to attain it.

text:
'For thee, for thee, is left the sense
Of trial past without offence
To God or man; such innocence,
Such consolation, and the excess
Of an unmerited distress;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: You are the one who has emerged from the trials with a clear conscience before both God and man. You possess an innocence that brings comfort, despite the undeserved pain you have endured.

text:
In that thy very strength must lie.
--O Sister, I could prophesy!
The time is come that rings the knell
Of all we loved, and loved so well:
Hope nothing, if I thus may speak
To thee, a woman, and thence weak:
Hope nothing, I repeat; for we
Are doomed to perish utterly:
'Tis meet that thou with me divide
The thought while I am by thy side,
Acknowledging a grace in this,
A comfort in the dark abyss.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The speaker is telling their sister that their strength must come from within, and they feel like they can predict the future. They believe that everything they once loved is coming to an end and advises their sister not to hope for anything. They think that both of them are doomed to fail and that they should acknowledge the comfort of being together in the dark times.

text:
But look not for me when I am gone,
And be no farther wrought upon:
Farewell all wishes, all debate,
All prayers for this cause, or for that!
Weep, if that aid thee; but depend
Upon no help of outward friend;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Do not search for me once I have left, and do not be troubled any further. Goodbye to all desires, arguments, and prayers, whether for this or that! Cry if it helps you, but do not rely on any assistance from external sources.

text:
Espouse thy doom at once, and cleave
To fortitude without reprieve.
For we must fall, both we and ours--
This Mansion and these pleasant bowers,
Walks, pools, and arbours, homestead, hall--
Our fate is theirs, will reach them all;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Accept your fate and hold onto your courage firmly without hesitation. We are destined to fail, and everything we own, including this house, gardens, pools, and fields, will meet the same fate. Our destiny is intertwined, and it will reach all aspects of our lives, including our homes, halls, and farms.

text:
The young horse must forsake his manger,
And learn to glory in a Stranger;
The hawk forget his perch; the hound
Be parted from his ancient ground:
The blast will sweep us all away--
One desolation, one decay!
And even this Creature!' which words saying,
He pointed to a lovely Doe,
A few steps distant, feeding, straying;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: The speaker is saying that all creatures, including a young horse, hawk, and hound, must leave their familiar homes and learn to adapt to new environments. Ultimately, all living things will face the same fate of destruction and decay. The speaker then points to a beautiful doe, emphasizing that even this creature is not exempt from this cycle of life and death.

text:
Fair creature, and more white than snow!
'Even she will to her peaceful woods
Return, and to her murmuring floods,
And be in heart and soul the same
She was before she hither came;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Oh beautiful creature, so pure and snow-white! She will soon return to her peaceful woods and the gentle flow of her streams. Her heart and soul will remain unchanged, just as they were before she arrived here.

text:
Ere she had learned to love us all,
Herself beloved in Rylstone-hall.
--But thou, my Sister, doomed to be
The last leaf on a blasted tree;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: Before she could develop affection for everyone, she was already adored in the Rylstone-hall. However, my dear sister, you are fated to be the final leaf on a withered tree.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: We have not lived in vain if we shared a common belief and walked together in faith. It brings happiness to know that we have been partners in spreading this faith and that you have often been the leader in this journey.

poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: If we have shared a common thought and understood it in the same way, and if our personal lives have been affected by our passion for a cause, then we have learned to value patience and putting others before ourselves.

text:
If we like combatants have fared,
And for this issue been prepared;
If thou art beautiful, and youth
And thought endue thee with all truth--
Be strong;--be worthy of the grace
Of God, and fill thy destined place:
A Soul, by force of sorrows high,
Uplifted to the purest sky
Of undisturbed humanity!'
He ended,--or she heard no more;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: If we have prepared ourselves for combat and faced our challenges, and if you possess beauty, youth, and wisdom, then be strong and deserving of God's grace. Fulfill your destiny as a soul that has been elevated by the trials and tribulations of life to reach the highest level of pure humanity. The speaker concludes their thought or the listener stops hearing.

text:
He led her from the yew-tree shade,
And at the mansion's silent door,
He kissed the consecrated Maid;
And down the valley then pursued,
Alone, the armed Multitude.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Second
explanation: He took the woman away from the shade of the yew tree and brought her to the silent door of the mansion, where he kissed her. Afterwards, he went down the valley by himself, following the armed group of people.

text:
WHY comes not Francis?--From the doleful City
He fled,--and, in his flight, could hear
The death-sounds of the Minster-bell:
That sullen stroke pronounced farewell
To Marmaduke, cut off from pity!
To Ambrose that! and then a knell
For him, the sweet half-opened Flower!
For all--all dying in one hour!
--Why comes not Francis? Thoughts of love
Should bear him to his Sister dear
With the fleet motion of a dove;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker wonders why Francis has not arrived yet. Francis fled from the city and could hear the death toll of the Minster-bell which announced the death of Marmaduke and Ambrose, as well as a knell for a sweet, half-opened flower, and all dying in one hour. Despite his thoughts of love for his sister, Francis has not yet arrived.

text:
Yea, like a heavenly messenger
Of speediest wing, should he appear.
Why comes he not?--for westward fast
Along the plain of York he past;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: It is said that a messenger with the swiftest wings of heaven should have arrived by now, but he has not appeared yet. He was last seen heading westward along the plain of York.

text:
Reckless of what impels or leads,
Unchecked he hurries on;--nor heeds
The sorrow, through the Villages,
Spread by triumphant cruelties
Of vengeful military force,
And punishment without remorse.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He moves forward recklessly, without consideration for what drives him or the consequences of his actions. He pays no attention to the suffering caused by the merciless military force and their brutal punishments that spread sorrow throughout the villages.

text:
He marked not, heard not, as he fled
All but the suffering heart was dead
For him abandoned to blank awe,
To vacancy, and horror strong:
And the first object which he saw,
With conscious sight, as he swept along--
It was the Banner in his hand!
He felt--and made a sudden stand.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He didn't notice or hear anything as he ran away. He was consumed by his suffering heart and felt empty and terrified. As he ran, the first thing he saw was the Banner in his hand, and this sudden realization made him stop in his tracks.

text:
He looked about like one betrayed:
What hath he done? what promise made?
Oh weak, weak moment! to what end
Can such a vain oblation tend,
And he the Bearer?--Can he go
Carrying this instrument of woe,
And find, find anywhere, a right
To excuse him in his Country's sight?
No; will not all men deem the change
A downward course, perverse and strange?
Here is it;--but how? when? must she,
The unoffending Emily,
Again this piteous object see?
Such conflict long did he maintain,
Nor liberty nor rest could gain:
His own life into danger brought
By this sad burden--even that thought,
Exciting self-suspicion strong
Swayed the brave man to his wrong.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The person being described looks around feeling betrayed and guilty, wondering what promise he made. He regrets his past actions and questions the purpose of his sacrifice. Carrying a burden of grief and guilt, he fears being judged by his country for his mistakes. He wonders if anyone will understand or accept his reasons for his actions. He struggles with his conscience, unable to find peace or freedom. The thought of the danger he has put himself in by carrying this burden only adds to his self-doubt and suspicion. Despite his bravery, he cannot escape the inner turmoil caused by his own actions.

text:
And how--unless it were the sense
Of all-disposing Providence,
Its will unquestionably shown--
How has the Banner clung so fast
To a palsied, and unconscious hand;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker ponders how the Banner has remained firmly attached to a hand that is paralyzed and unaware. They question whether this could be attributed to the will of a higher power, as it seems impossible otherwise.

text:
Clung to the hand to which it passed
Without impediment? And why,
But that Heaven's purpose might be known,
Doth now no hindrance meet his eye,
No intervention, to withstand
Fulfilment of a Father's prayer
Breathed to a Son forgiven, and blest
When all resentments were at rest,
And life in death laid the heart bare?--
Then, like a spectre sweeping by,
Rushed through his mind the prophecy
Of utter desolation made
To Emily in the yew-tree shade:
He sighed, submitting will and power
To the stern embrace of that grasping hour.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: The speaker wonders why there are no obstacles to the fulfillment of Heaven's purpose, as if it were clinging to a hand that passed without impediment. The lack of hindrance allows the Father's prayer for the Son, who was forgiven and blessed when all resentments were at rest and life was laid bare in death. The speaker's mind is then rushed by the prophecy of Emily's utter desolation in the yew-tree shade. He sighs, submitting his will and power to the embrace of that grasping hour.

text:
'No choice is left, the deed is mine--
Dead are they, dead!--and I will go,
And, for their sakes, come weal or woe,
Will lay the Relic on the shrine.'
So forward with a steady will
He went, and traversed plain and hill;
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: With no other option left, the protagonist takes responsibility for their actions and decides to carry out their plan. They acknowledge that those who were affected by their actions are now deceased and are determined to complete their mission, regardless of the outcomes. With a resolute mind, they move forward, crossing various terrains to reach their destination.

text:
And up the vale of Wharf his way
Pursued;--and, at the dawn of day,
Attained a summit whence his eyes
Could see the Tower of Bolton rise.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: He traveled through the valley of Wharf and reached a high point at dawn where he could see the Tower of Bolton.

text:
There Francis for a moment's space
Made halt--but hark! a noise behind
Of horsemen at an eager pace!
He heard, and with misgiving mind.
poem_title: The White Doe Of Rylstone, Or, The Fate Of The Nortons  -  Canto Sixth
explanation: Francis paused for a moment, but then heard the sound of horsemen approaching at a rapid pace from behind. He became anxious and worried about the source of the noise.

text:
--'Tis Sir George Bowes who leads the Band:
They come, by cruel Sussex sent;
Who, when the Nortons from the hand
Of death had drunk their punishment,
Bethought him, angry and ashamed,
How Francis, with the Banner claimed
As his own charge, had disappeared,
