The 'Alma Redemptoris' did he hear;
And as he durst he drew him near and near,
And hearkened to the words and to the note,
Till the first verse he learned it all by rote.
explanation: While sitting in school, a young child eagerly studied his primer while the other students recited the 'Alma Redemptoris' anthem. The child approached and listened closely, learning the entire first verse by heart.

text:
'This Latin knew he nothing what it said,
For he too tender was of age to know;
But to his comrade he repaired, and prayed
That he the meaning of this song would show,
And unto him declare why men sing so;
This oftentimes that he might be at ease,
This child did him beseech on his bare knees.
explanation: The Latin boy did not understand the meaning of the song because he was too young. He asked his friend to explain it to him, and begged him to reveal why people sing. The boy often asked his friend for clarity, hoping it would bring him comfort.

text:
'His Schoolfellow, who elder was than he,
Answered him thus:--'This song, I have heard say,
Was fashioned for our blissful Lady free;
Her to salute, and also her to pray
To be our help upon our dying day:
If there is more in this, I know it not;
Song do I learn,--small grammar I have got.'
explanation: The speaker's older schoolmate responds to his question about the meaning of a song by explaining that it was created to pay homage to the Virgin Mary and ask for her assistance in the afterlife. The schoolmate admits that he does not know any additional information about the song beyond this purpose, as his focus is on learning the song rather than studying grammar.

text:
''And is this song fashioned in reverence
Of Jesu's Mother?' said this Innocent;
'Now, certes, I will use my diligence
To con it all ere Christmas-tide be spent;
Although I for my Primer shall be shent,
And shall be beaten three times in an hour,
Our Lady I will praise with all my power.'
explanation: The Innocent asks if the song is meant to honor Jesus' mother and pledges to learn it before Christmas, even if it means getting punished for neglecting his lessons. Despite the potential consequences, he is determined to praise the Virgin Mary with all his might.

text:
'His Schoolfellow, whom he had so besought,
As they went homeward taught him privily
And then he sang it well and fearlessly,
From word to word according to the note:
Twice in a day it passed through his throat;
Homeward and schoolward whensoe'er he went,
On Jesu's Mother fixed was his intent.
explanation: His classmate had taught him the song he had been begging to learn, and he sang it confidently and accurately, following the melody. He sang it twice a day, on his way to and from school, with his mind fixed on the Virgin Mary.

text:
'Through all the Jewry (this before said I)
This little Child, as he came to and fro,
Full merrily then would he sing and cry,
O 'Alma Redemptoris!' high and low:
The sweetness of Christ's Mother pierced so
His heart, that her to praise, to her to pray,
He cannot stop his singing by the way.
explanation: The speaker observes that a young child in the Jewish community frequently sings the hymn "Alma Redemptoris" with great joy and enthusiasm. The child's love and devotion for the Virgin Mary is evident in his singing, as she holds a special place in his heart. Even as he goes about his daily activities, he cannot help but sing her praises and offer up prayers to her. The speaker is struck by the child's pure and unwavering faith, despite being raised in a different religious tradition.

text:
'The Serpent, Satan, our first foe, that hath
His wasp's nest in Jew's heart, upswelled--'O woe,
O Hebrew people!' said he in his wrath,
'Is it an honest thing? Shall this be so?
That such a Boy where'er he lists shall go
In your despite, and sing his hymns and saws,
Which is against the reverence of our laws!'
explanation: In this passage, the speaker describes Satan as the serpent and the first enemy of humanity. Satan is upset that a certain boy is able to go wherever he wants and sing his songs and hymns, which goes against the laws and traditions of the Hebrew people. The speaker suggests that Satan has a nest in the hearts of the Jews and expresses his dismay at the situation, lamenting that such behavior is not honest or respectful to their laws.

text:
'From that day forward have the Jews conspired
Out of the world this Innocent to chase;
And to this end a Homicide they hired,
That in an alley had a privy place,
And, as the Child 'gan to the school to pace,
This cruel Jew him seized, and held him fast
And cut his throat, and in a pit him cast.
explanation: The Jews, according to the speaker, conspired to kill an innocent child, hiring a murderer who waited in an alleyway. The murderer seized the child as he walked to school, cutting his throat and dumping him in a pit. The speaker's words suggest that the Jews were responsible for this heinous act.

text:
'I say that him into a pit they threw,
A loathsome pit, whence noisome scents exhale;
O cursed folk! away, ye Herods new!
What may your ill intentions you avail?
Murder will out; certes it will not fail;
Know, that the honour of high God may spread,
The blood cries out on your accursed deed.
explanation: They threw him into a disgusting pit that emits foul odors. These people are cursed and should be called "Herods new." Their evil intentions will not benefit them in any way. The truth about the murder will eventually come out and justice will prevail. It is important to remember that the honor of God will be upheld and the blood of the victim cries out against the perpetrators' wicked deed.

text:
'O Martyr 'stablished in virginity!
Now may'st thou sing for aye before the throne,
Following the Lamb celestial,' quoth she,
'Of which the great Evangelist, Saint John,
In Patmos wrote, who saith of them that go
Before the Lamb singing continually,
That never fleshly woman they did know.
explanation: The speaker addresses a martyr who has maintained her virginity, praising her for now being able to sing before the throne of God and follow the Lamb, as described by Saint John in his writings. The speaker emphasizes that those who go before the Lamb are those who have never known a fleshly woman.

text:
'Now this poor widow waiteth all that night
After her little Child, and he came not;
For which, by earliest glimpse of morning light,
With face all pale with dread and busy thought,
She at the School and elsewhere him hath sought
Until thus far she learned, that he had been
In the Jews' street, and there he last was seen.
explanation: The widow waited anxiously throughout the night for her child, but he did not return. She searched for him at the school and other places until she discovered that he had been seen in the Jews' street. She was worried and frightened, and her face showed her concern as she tried to find her child.

text:
'With Mother's pity in her breast enclosed
She goeth, as she were half out of her mind,
To every place wherein she hath supposed
By likelihood her little Son to find;
And ever on Christ's Mother meek and kind
She cried, till to the Jewry she was brought,
And him among the accursed Jews she sought.
explanation: The speaker describes a mother who is consumed with grief and despair as she searches for her lost son. She wanders aimlessly, driven by her desperate hope of finding him, and calls out to the Virgin Mary for help. Eventually, she ends up in the Jewish quarter, where she continues to search for her child despite the hostility of the people around her. Her love for her son and her determination to find him are palpable, and the reader is left with a sense of the intensity of maternal love and the power of human resilience in the face of tragedy.

text:
'She asketh, and she piteously doth pray
To every Jew that dwelleth in that place
To tell her if her child had passed that way;
They all said--Nay; but Jesu of his grace
Gave to her thought, that in a little space
She for her Son in that same spot did cry
Where he was cast into a pit hard by.
explanation: The woman begs and pleads with every Jewish person in the area, asking if they have seen her lost child. Unfortunately, all of them respond that they have not. However, through divine intervention, the woman suddenly feels compelled to cry out for her child in a specific location, where he was found in a nearby pit.

text:
'O thou great God that dost perform thy laud
By mouths of Innocents, lo! here thy might;
This gem of chastity, this emerald,
And eke of martyrdom this ruby bright,
There, where with mangled throat he lay upright,
The 'Alma Redemptoris' 'gan to sing,
So loud, that with his voice the place did ring.
explanation: God, who is praised by innocent voices, demonstrates his power through this pure and chaste individual, who is also a martyr. The individual lies with a slit throat, while the hymn 'Alma Redemptoris' is sung so loudly that the entire place resonates with the sound.

text:
'The Christian folk that through the Jewry went
Come to the spot in wonder at the thing;
And hastily they for the Provost sent;
Immediately he came, not tarrying,
And praiseth Christ that is our heavenly King,
And eke his Mother, honour of Mankind:
Which done he bade that they the Jews should bind.
explanation: A group of Christian people passed through the Jewish area and were amazed by something they saw. They quickly called for the Provost, who arrived promptly and praised Jesus and Mary. He then ordered for the Jews to be arrested.

text:
'This Child with piteous lamentation then
Was taken up, singing his song alway;
And with procession great and pomp of men
To the next Abbey him they bare away;
His Mother swooning by the body lay:
And scarcely could the people that were near
Remove this second Rachel from the bier.
explanation: The child was picked up with a sad cry and his singing continued as he was ceremoniously carried to the nearby Abbey with a large procession of people. His mother fainted and lay by his lifeless body, and it was difficult for those nearby to remove her from the funeral bier, evoking the image of Rachel mourning for her children in the Bible.

text:
'Torment and shameful death to every one
This Provost doth for those bad Jews prepare
That of this murder wist, and that anon:
Such wickedness his judgments cannot spare;
Who will do evil, evil shall he bear;
Them therefore with wild horses did he draw,
And after that he hung them by the law.
explanation: The Provost has prepared a punishment of torment and shameful death for any bad Jews who were involved in a murder. His judgments do not spare those who commit wickedness, and he believes that those who do evil will bear the consequences of their actions. He chose to draw them with wild horses and then hang them according to the law.

text:
'Upon his bier this Innocent doth lie
Before the altar while the Mass doth last:
The Abbot with his convent's company
Then sped themselves to bury him full fast;
And, when they holy water on him cast,
Yet spake this Child when sprinkled was the water,
And sang, 'O Alma Redemptoris Mater!'
explanation: This innocent child is laid on his bier in front of the altar while the Mass is being conducted. The Abbot and his group of monks quickly arranged for his burial. Even when they sprinkled holy water on him, the child continued to speak and sing the hymn 'O Alma Redemptoris Mater.'

text:
'This Abbot, for he was a holy man,
As all Monks are, or surely ought to be,
In supplication to the Child began
Thus saying, 'O dear Child! I summon thee
In virtue of the holy Trinity
Tell me the cause why thou dost sing this hymn
Since that thy throat is cut, as it doth seem.'
explanation: The Abbot, who was a pious man like all monks should be, prayed to the Child and asked why it was singing a hymn despite having its throat slit. He invoked the holy Trinity and sought an explanation for this strange phenomenon.

text:
''My throat is cut unto the bone, I trow,'
Said this young Child, 'and by the law of kind
I should have died, yea many hours ago;
But Jesus Christ, as in the books ye find,
Will that his glory last, and be in mind;
And, for the worship of his Mother dear,
Yet may I sing 'O Alma!' loud and clear.
explanation: The young child declares that his throat has been cut down to the bone, and according to natural law, he should have died many hours ago. However, he believes that Jesus Christ, as written in books, wants his glory to last and be remembered. He also believes that he can still sing the praises of Mary, the mother of Jesus, by singing 'O Alma!' loudly and clearly.

text:
''This well of mercy, Jesu's Mother sweet,
After my knowledge I have loved alway;
And in the hour when I my death did meet
To me she came, and thus to me did say,
'Thou in thy dying sing this holy lay,'
As ye have heard; and soon as I had sung
Methought she laid a grain upon my tongue.
explanation: I have always loved this well of mercy, which is Jesu's sweet mother, as long as I can remember. When I was dying, she appeared to me and told me to sing this holy song, which I did. After I finished singing, she seemed to place a grain on my tongue.

text:
''Wherefore I sing, nor can from song refrain,
In honour of that blissful Maiden free,
Till from my tongue off-taken is the grain;
And after that thus said she unto me;
'My little Child, then will I come for thee
Soon as the grain from off thy tongue they take:
Be not dismayed, I will not thee forsake!'
explanation: I sing in praise of the joyful Virgin and cannot stop, until the grain is removed from my tongue. The Virgin then spoke to me, promising to come for me once the grain is removed and not to worry, as she will not abandon me.

The Abbot, who was a holy Monk, removed the grain from the dying man's tongue, causing him to pass away peacefully. Witnessing this miracle, the Abbot wept tears of sorrow that fell like rain, and he fell to the ground, lying still as if he were bound.

text:
'Eke the whole Convent on the pavement lay,
Weeping and praising Jesu's Mother dear;
And after that they rose, and took their way,
And lifted up this Martyr from the bier,
And in a tomb of precious marble clear
Enclosed his uncorrupted body sweet.--
Where'er he be, God grant us him to meet!
explanation: The entire convent was on the pavement crying and praising the mother of Jesus. They then got up and proceeded to lift the martyr's body from the bier and placed it in an expensive marble tomb. They hoped to one day meet him wherever he may be.

text:
'Young Hew of Lincoln! in like sort laid low
By cursed Jews--thing well and widely known,
For it was done a little while ago--
Pray also thou for us, while here we tarry
Weak sinful folk, that God, with pitying eye,
In mercy would his mercy multiply
On us, for reverence of his Mother Mary!'
explanation: The poet is asking Young Hew of Lincoln, who was also a victim of the Jews, to intercede for them as they are weak and sinful. The poet hopes that God will have mercy on them because of the reverence they have for Mary, the mother of Jesus. This event of the Jews harming Young Hew is well-known and recent.

text:
OAK of Guernica! Tree of holier power
Than that which in Dodona did enshrine
(So faith too fondly deemed) a voice divine
Heard from the depths of its aerial bower--
How canst thou flourish at this blighting hour?
What hope, what joy can sunshine bring to thee,
Or the soft breezes from the Atlantic sea,
The dews of morn, or April's tender shower?
Stroke merciful and welcome would that be
Which should extend thy branches on the ground,
If never more within their shady round
Those lofty-minded Lawgivers shall meet,
Peasant and lord, in their appointed seat,
Guardians of Biscay's ancient liberty.
poem_title: The Oak Of Guernica Supposed Address To The Same
explanation: The Oak of Guernica is a powerful tree that surpasses the holy power of the one in Dodona, which was believed to contain the voice of a divine being. However, at this moment of blight, it is difficult to understand how it can continue to thrive. The sunshine, soft breezes, Atlantic sea, morning dew, and April rain cannot bring hope or joy to it. Instead, it would be merciful and welcome if a stroke would bring its branches to the ground. It is unfortunate that the lofty-minded Lawgivers, who were guardians of Biscay's ancient liberty, may never again meet under the shade of its branches.

text:
Tho' searching damps and many an envious flaw
Have marred this Work, the calm ethereal grace,
The love deep-seated in the Saviour's face,
The mercy, goodness, have not failed to awe
The Elements; as they do melt and thaw
The heart of the Beholder- and erase
(At least for one rapt moment) every trace
Of disobedience to the primal law.
poem_title: The Last Supper, by Leonardo da Vinci, in the Refectory of the Convent of Maria della Grazia—Milan
explanation: Despite the obstacles and imperfections that have affected this piece of work, the serene and divine beauty, the affection embodied in the face of the Savior, and His mercy and goodness have not failed to impress the Elements. The Elements melt and thaw the heart of the observer and, for a moment, erase any sign of disobedience to the original law.

text:
The annunciation of the dreadful truth
Made to the Twelve, survives: lips, forehead, cheek,
And hand reposing on the board in ruth
Of what it utters, while the unguilty seek
Unquestionable meanings, still bespeak
A labour worthy of eternal youth!
poem_title: The Last Supper, by Leonardo da Vinci, in the Refectory of the Convent of Maria della Grazia—Milan
explanation: The news of the terrible truth that was shared with the Twelve still lingers, as evidenced by their expressions and gestures. Even the innocent among them are trying to decipher the full meaning of what was revealed, a task that seems eternal in its difficulty and significance.
